text: PERSON PERSON was the headliner in the three-prospect package the ORGANIZATION received from the ORGANIZATION for PERSON last July, but PERSON quickly asserted himself as one of the best starting pitchers in his new system. PERSON signed him for a well over-slot $600,000 as an 11th-rounder in 2016, one month after he infamously threw a 164-pitch complete game at ORGANIZATION (PERSON, Pa.). He impressed the ORGANIZATION so much in his first spring training that they sent him to low Class A at age 18, and he struck out 113 in 94 1/3 innings between the two organizations.PERSON added strength during his first full year in pro ball, boosting his high-spin-rate fastball consistently into the low 90s, and his 6-foot-4 frame still has room to add more muscle. His curveball already had good depth and added power as well, becoming a consistent plus pitch. His changeup isn't as consistent as his other offerings but has the makings of an average pitch.Because PERSON didn't become a full-time pitcher until his junior year in high school, he's just scratching the surface of his potential. There's still some effort in his delivery but he's athletic and toned it down in his first full season, so the ORGANIZATION think he'll throw more strikes. His curveball and competitiveness will serve him well if he eventually moves into the bullpen.

PERSON made headlines for all the wrong reasons when he threw a nine-inning, 164-pitch complete game at ORGANIZATION (PERSON, Pa.) in May 2016. A month later, the ORGANIZATION selected him in the 11th round and gave him $600,000 to pass up a commitment to GPE. He made such a good impression in his first Spring Training that he earned an assignment to low Class A at age 18, and he continued to stand out before the ORGANIZATION acquired him in the Yu Darvish trade in July.PERSON's best present weapon is his curveball, which has depth and could become a true plus offering once it adds more power. He usually works at 88-93 mph with his fastball and should add more velocity once he fills out his projectable 6-foot-4 frame. His changeup is more of a work in progress, but has some potential.He didn't become a full-time pitcher until he was a junior in high school, so PERSON still has room for lots of growth. He has a quick arm and his pitches should continue to improve as he gets stronger and refines his delivery. ORGANIZATION officials praise his competitive nature.

PERSON PERSON pitched at FACILITY (ORGANIZATION, GPE.) and GPE (GPE.) JC before embarking on a 14-year big league career. His nephew PERSON, meanwhile, is already following the same path. After turning down the ORGANIZATION as a 25th-round Draft pick, he returned to the ORGANIZATION and emerged as one of the top junior college pitching prospects, leading all Division I ORGANIZATION pitchers in strikeouts (156) and strikeout rate (18.8 per nine innings). The ORGANIZATION made PERSON their fourth-round pick in June, signed him for slightly above slot value and then watched him carve up hitters while reaching PERSON, where he posted double-digit strikeouts in two of his seven starts.PERSON's curveball is nasty, a true plus pitch that he can also manipulate to have harder, slider-like action. He opened his sophomore season throwing in the upper 80s but now sits 91-94 mph and can touch 96. His changeup has come along quickly in his first full season and gives PERSON a third big league-caliber pitch that he uses to neutralize right-handed hitters. PERSON works from the third-base side of the mound and has an athletic but funky delivery that masks everything he throws with deception.PERSON's delivery also can hamper his ability to throw strikes at times, and the ORGANIZATION hope to smoothen it out without costing him any of his natural deception. He might not have the cleanest profile and does come with some risk, but PERSON's bat-missing ability is undeniable and could help him rise through the ranks relatively quickly en route to a back-of-the-rotation role, perhaps even more.

PERSON PERSON pitched at FACILITY (ORGANIZATION, GPE.) and GPE (GPE.) JC before embarking on a 14-year big league career. His nephew PERSON, meanwhile, is already following the same path. After turning down the ORGANIZATION as a 25th-rounder last summer, he returned to the ORGANIZATION and emerged as one of the top junior college pitching prospects, leading all Division I ORGANIZATION pitchers in strikeouts (156) and strikeout rate (18.8 per nine innings). The ORGANIZATION made PERSON their fourth-round pick in June, signed him for slightly above slot value ($520,000) and assigned him to Rookie-level Helena.PERSON's money pitch is a plus curveball that he can manipulate into a harder, shorter slider at times. He opened his sophomore season throwing in the upper 80s but ended the year working at 91-94 mph while reaching double-digit strikeouts in his last five starts, including 17 in his final outing. He also has a changeup that he doesn't use very often. PERSON is athletic but has a funky delivery that hampers his ability to throw strikes. It does, however, give him plenty of deception, leading to lots of swings and misses. Some scouts worry that most of his whiffs come out of the zone, either on curveballs down or fastballs up, and wonder how his stuff will play against more advanced hitters. If it all clicks for PERSON, he could rise through the ranks relatively quickly en route to a back-of-the-rotation role, and perhaps even more.

The GPE continued their recent trend of collecting international players with advanced bats when they signed PERSON out of GPE for $1.5 million, the largest bonus in their 2017 class. He would have come to the GPE for his debut at age 17 last summer, but he fractured his right arm in May and missed the entire Rookie-level PERSON season. He's thriving while seeing his first pro action this summer in the AZL.A switch-hitter, PERSON has a quick, compact swing and exhibits precocious feel for the barrel from both sides of the plate. He makes repeated hard contact, already drives balls to the gaps and should have 20-homer power once he matures physically. Presently an above-average runner, he figures to slow down a bit as he gets stronger. Though PERSON would have broken into pro ball as a shortstop in 2018, most international scouts thought he was destined for second base and the GPE have deployed him there this summer. While his actions and average arm are substandard at short, his fast hands should be an asset when it comes to turning double plays at second. He could become a solid defender at second base if he can quicken his footwork.

Ranked No. 22 on ORGANIZATION's list of the Top 30 international prospects for 2017-18, GPE endeared himself to evaluators as a ORGANIZATION amateur with his projectable frame and overall potential as a switch-hitting shortstop. The Indians were among the teams intrigued by GPE's upside, so much so that they signed him with a $1.5 million bonus, the largest of all their July 2 signees.Scouts like GPE's balanced hitting approach at the plate, quick hands and short swing. He makes hard contact and has also shown the ability to hit for power, driving the ball with authority into the gaps from both sides of the plate. That will only improve as he adds strength to his projectable frame, leading many to project GPE as at least an average hitter with similar power. On the other side of the ball, GPE shows solid infield actions and a decent glove. There's still room for improvement with his footwork on defense, but there's no questioning his arm strength and accuracy. Because of his skill set, GPE projects to be an average fielder and is likely best suited for second base.

GPE is a strong and athletic middle infielder with the potential to be a special hitter. The Indians certainly agreed with that assessment, as they secured the rights to the ORGANIZATION switch-hitter's future with a $1.5 million bonus, the largest of all their July 2 signees.Scouts like GPE's balanced hitting approach at the plate, quick hands and short swing. The switch-hitting infielder has shown the ability to drive the ball into the gaps from both sides of the plate. He makes hard contact and has also shown the ability to hit for power.On the other side of the ball, GPE shows solid infield actions and a decent glove. There's still room for improvement with his footwork on defense, but there's no questioning his arm strength and accuracy. Because of his skill set, GPE projects to be an average fielder and is likely best suited for second base.

Prior to the 2018 Draft, the earliest a player from PERSON A&M-Corpus PERSON had been drafted was the ninth round. PERSON's path to easily beating that hasn't necessarily been straight. He was academically ineligible as a sophomore, but then came out and showed very good stuff early in the spring. While he wasn't as dominant all year, it was still enough for the ORGANIZATION to take him in the third round and he went straight to the Class A Advanced California League for his full-season debut.PERSON was up to 98 mph at times during his junior season, sitting more in the 92-95 mph range, throwing the pitch with good sink and showing he could maintain his velocity through starts. He has good feel for his secondary stuff and can throw a distinct curve and slider, though they sometimes blur together into a power slurve. He can really spin it and his breaking stuff does flash plus and he has solid tumbling changeup.Though he has swing-and-miss stuff, PERSON didn't dominate in college as much as one would think, as he has trouble commanding his pitches both within and outside the strike zone. With a funky delivery, he might best be suited for the bullpen, but he was given a chance to start at the start of his pro career.

One of the best two-way players in college baseball, PERSON doubled as a third baseman and closer for a resurgent GPE program the last two years. Though he ranked among the ORGANIZATION Division I saves leaders thanks to an 88-92 mph fastball and an effective slider, pro teams were looking at his value solely as a position player in the GPE. A strong junior season catapulted him into the second round, where the ORGANIZATION gave him just over $1.1 million, full pick value, to sign, then sent him to the short-season LOCATION for his pro debut.PERSON makes consistent line-drive contact from the right side of the plate and improved offensively in each of his three seasons with the ORGANIZATION. He has the strength and bat speed to hit for more power -- he shows at least solid raw pop in batting practice and more than tripled his career home run total as a junior -- but he'll probably top out at 12-15 homers per year unless he adds more loft to his swing. He puts the bat on the ball so easily that he rarely walks, another adjustment he'll have to make as he progresses in his pro career.PERSON has fringy speed out of the batter's box but a quicker first step that helps make him at least a solid defender at third base. He also has soft hands and a strong arm, though he needs to improve his defensive consistency. If everything comes together, he could be a .270 hitter with 20 homers who's an asset at the hot corner.

Finding college pitchers with both track record and unreached potential is a rarity. But that's exactly what the ORGANIZATION think they might have found in PERSON, their fourth-round pick in the 2018 Draft. A converted shortstop who didn't pitch much until later in his amateur career, PERSON spent most of his first two years at ORGANIZATION pitching out of the bullpen. He made a successful move to the rotation as a junior and has kept on looking like a future starter in his year-plus with the ORGANIZATION.PERSON stands out because of his athleticism, his live and fresh arm and his upside. He commands his low-90s fastball well, allowing it to play up, and he complements it well with his solid changeup, his best secondary offering. He also mixes in a breaking ball that's still developing, but has the chance to give him three usable pitches.Thanks to his ability to repeat his delivery, PERSON has been a strike-throwing machine. There could be more to unlock here, which would allow him to reach a ceiling as a back-end starter.

Ranked No. 25 on MLBPipeline.com's Top 30 international prospects for the 2016-17 signing period, the ORGANIZATION thought highly enough of his skills behind and at the plate to give the ORGANIZATION catcher $3.53 million to sign him in July 2016. He made a solid, albeit unspectacular pro debut in the ORGANIZATION in 2017, then was one of the prospects declared a free agent as a penalty for PERSON's international rules violations. The ORGANIZATION signed PERSON for $550,000 once the prospects were eligible to sign with a new organization.PERSON is a defense-first backstop, one who can really catch and throw. The teenager threw out 38 percent of would-be basestealers in the ORGANIZATION in 2017. In addition to his strong arm and quick release, he's a very good receiver with soft hands and knows how to control the game well. His offensive skillset remains a work in progress. He does have potential at the plate, relying on a line-drive approach. He has some strength, with some gap power that could develop. His strike zone discipline has improved and will have to continue to do so as he moves up the ladder.PERSON takes his job behind the plate seriously and will have to maintain his 6-foot-2 frame to keep shining back there. At the very least, he looks like a sure-handed backup. If his bat starts to come, he could be a lot more than that.

GPE has produced a fair share of GPE talent over the years, with PERSON and PERSON the most recent examples to get taken in the first round (both in 2015). There hasn't been much in the way of middle infielders to come from north of the border, but the ORGANIZATION are hopeful that PERSON, who signed for $1.3 million as a second-round pick, will be the first to reverse that trend. PERSON made his pro debut in the Rookie-level Gulf Coast League, where he tallied six hits in nine at-bats before an oblique injury prematurely ended his season. PERSON might be a bit unpolished, but he has considerable tools and upside. He has a decent approach at the plate for his age and experience level, with a natural feel to hit and good bat speed. There should be some gap power in the future as well, and he should compile plenty of doubles and triples thanks to his plus speed and sharp baserunning. PERSON is capable of making the spectacular play defensively, and while his arm might grade out as average, he can reach back for more when needed and he's usually very accurate. He will struggle at times with the backhand play, but most feel he can stick at short. If not, his tools also would fit nicely at the keystone. PERSON needs to add strength to his athletic frame, but that should come as he matures physically. Having turned 18 not long before the GPE, he'll have plenty of time to fulfill his fairly high ceiling.

GPE has produced a fair share of GPE talent over the years, with PERSON and PERSON the most recent examples to get taken in the first round (both in 2015). There hasn't been much in the way of middle infielders to come from north of the border, but the ORGANIZATION are hopeful that GPE, who signed for $1.3 million as a second-round pick, will be the first to reverse that trend.GPE might be a bit unpolished, but he has considerable tools and upside. He has a decent approach at the plate for his age and experience level, with a natural feel to hit and good bat speed. There should be some power in the future as well, albeit mostly to the gaps, and he should compile plenty of doubles and triples thanks to his plus speed and sharp baserunning. GPE is capable of making the spectacular play defensively, and while his arm might grade out as average, he can reach back for more when needed and he's usually very accurate. He will struggle at times with the backhand play, but most feel he can stick at short. If not, he'd make an outstanding second baseman and has enough arm for third.GPE needs to add strength to his athletic frame, but that should come as he matures physically. Having turned 18 not long before the GPE, he'll have plenty of time to fulfill his fairly high ceiling.

After strong performances with the GPE junior national team had pushed him up ORGANIZATION boards in 2017, ORGANIZATION landed an above-slot $1.3 million signing bonus from the Orioles after they took him the second round. An oblique injury limited him to just two games that summer, and ORGANIZATION struggled at the outset of 2018, hitting .212 with a .524 OPS during his first month in the ORGANIZATION York-Penn League. He broke out in the second half, raking at a .358 clip (.913 OPS) over his final 36 contests, and authored a 19-game hit streak along the way. ORGANIZATION has natural feel to hit, demonstrating good bat speed and the ability to hit to all fields from the right side of the plate, albeit with below-average power. He does have some pop to the gaps, however, and should be a consistent source of doubles and triples as he adds strength to his athletic frame. Plus speed might be ORGANIZATION's best tool, and club officials rave about his baserunning instincts. ORGANIZATION's defense and arm have improved considerably in the professional ranks to the point where scouts now view him as an above-average defender who can stick at shortstop. With his slow start and torrid finish, ORGANIZATION arguably was PERSON's most improved prospect in 2018. ORGANIZATION officials are quick to praise infield coordinator PERSON and hitting coordinator PERSON for their role in his development, as they each spent a lot of time working with ORGANIZATION and made him a more confident player overall. He doesn't have a very high ceiling, but the tools and skills are all there for ORGANIZATION to develop into an everyday player.

As a GPE junior in 2018, PERSON flirted with no-hitters in back-to-back early-season starts against PERSON and PERSON, striking out 14 in each outing. The performances sent his ORGANIZATION stock soaring, though he wasn't nearly as dominant the rest of the way and missed time in March with shoulder tendinitis. After the ORGANIZATION made him their fourth-round pick in June, PERSON averaged 15.3 strikeouts-per-nine during his pro debut in the Class A Short PERSON York-Penn League. PERSON was dealt to the ORGANIZATION in the ORGANIZATION trade in January 2019.PERSON's best pitch is his fastball, which sits around 91-93 mph and peaks at 95. He uses his 6-foot-6 frame to create good plane and extension, and has some crossfire in his delivery that imparts running life on his heater. His changeup has been more reliable than his slider this spring, with each showing signs of becoming a solid offering when at their best.PERSON is more physical than athletic, and he sometimes struggles to keep his delivery together and locate his pitches where he wants. If he can do a better job of maintaining his velocity into the later innings, improving the consistency of his secondary offerings and commanding his stuff, he could be a No. 3 starter. If not, he might be more of a sixth- or seventh-inning reliever because he lacks an overpowering fastball or a dynamic second pitch.

GPE (GPE) featured the best hitting prospect/pitching prospect duo in high school baseball. That was confirmed during the first two days of the 2018 Draft, as the ORGANIZATION selected shortstop ORGANIZATION with their first-round pick and then signed him for below slot so as to save money for PERSON, who signed for $2.45 million -- well above his slot's recommended value of $652,900 -- after being taken in the third round. PERSON can work in the low 90s with heavy sink on his two-seam fastball and hit 96 mph with his four-seamer. He has advanced feel for a breaking ball, showing the ability to morph his sharp slider into a bigger-breaking curveball or a harder cutter. He also has a deceptive changeup with tumble that lacks consistency but also can be his best pitch at times.At 6-foot-5 and 220 pounds, PERSON has a frame built for durability and also the room to add some more strength. He's athletic and repeats his delivery well, allowing him to throw strikes, and scouts have long praised his competitive demeanor on the mound.

Many believe that GPE (GPE) PERSON featured the best hitting prospect/pitching prospect duo in high school baseball in GPE Groshans and PERSON. That was confirmed during the first two days of the 2018 Draft, as the ORGANIZATION selected Groshans with their first-round pick and then signed him for below slot to save money for the TCU-committed PERSON, who signed for $2.45 million -- well above his slot's recommended value of $652,900 -- after being taken in the third round. He made his pro debut alongside Groshans in the ORGANIZATION. PERSON can work in the low 90s with heavy sink on his two-seam fastball and reach back for 96 mph with his four-seamer. He has advanced feel for a breaking ball, showing the ability to morph his sharp slider, which flashes above-average potential, into a bigger-breaking curveball or a harder cutter. He also has a deceptive changeup with tumble that lacks consistency but could be another above-average offering for him once developed. An imposing presence on the mound at 6-foot-5 and 240-plus pounds, PERSON has a frame built for durability and also the room to add some more strength. He's athletic and repeats his delivery well, allowing him to throw strikes, and scouts have long praised his competitive demeanor on the mound.

A standout in the ORGANIZATION, PERSON impressed scouts with his physicality and power potential while performing well in games. It earned him a ranking as ORGANIZATION's No. 23 international prospect for the 2018-19 international period as well as a $1.45 million bonus from the ORGANIZATION, who signed the GPE infielder on July 2. He made his professional debut in the ORGANIZATION in 2019. PERSON advanced for his age, the 6-foot-1, 195-pound PERSON has grown in the past year and his overall game has improved, too. He has a good approach and already shows feel for finding the barrel, with plus bat speed and some natural leverage to his swing that could make him at least an average hitter. He can already drive the ball out of the ballpark, and he's expected to show more power as he refines his swing mechanics and adds strength to his projectable frame. While he runs well, PERSON is likely to lose a step with physical maturation.On defense, PERSON shows good hands and a good arm as a shortstop, though there's a chance he will end up at third base because of his skill set and his body type. To go along with his physical attributes, PERSON is a competitor who has been praised for his intensity on the field and how he really enjoys playing the game.

Sometimes a player who enters his ORGANIZATION season as the best player in the class struggles with the pressure and the spotlight. Then there are players like PERSON, who somehow managed to surpass expectations during his junior season at FACILITY after helping the ORGANIZATION win the ORGANIZATION World Series and earning ORGANIZATION Most Outstanding Player honors in the process. He capped things off by being a member of ORGANIZATION's ORGANIZATION over the summer and kept on rolling on both sides of the ball during the spring, batting .411 with a 1.326 ORGANIZATION and 17 home runs. The performance netted him the prestigious ORGANIZATION and PERSON, and the ORGANIZATION made him the ORGANIZATION. 1 overall pick in the ORGANIZATION before signing him with a record $8.1 million bonus. The switch-hitting backstop is the complete package at and behind the plate. He has an advanced approach at the plate, walking more than he struck out at FACILITY, with the ability to make consistent, hard contact and drive the ball from both sides of the plate. More of a gap-to-gap doubles hitter early in his college career, his over-the-fence power started to show up more during his junior season and should continue to emerge in the pro ranks. PERSON is also outstanding behind the plate, with excellent hands, agility and a very strong throwing arm, and he's even a better runner than some give him credit for. With his all-around skills at a premium position, PERSON has one of the highest ceilings among all prospects and could move quickly through the ORGANIZATION as a result. The last time the ORGANIZATION took a switch-hitting college backstop with their first pick, PERSON, it worked out pretty well.

Since signing in 2014, GPE has moved methodically through the lower levels of the ORGANIZATION system, one rung at a time. His first taste of full-season ball in 2017 saw him take a huge leap forward, and he finished fourth in the LOCATION League in strikeouts and ninth in GPE has always had a good feel for pitching, and in 2017 everything took a step forward, stuff-wise. While he featured a 90-95 mph fastball previously, he sat more 92-94 mph and touched 95-96 more consistently in 2017. He commands his heater well and throws it with a lot of life, leading to a steady ground-ball rate. His secondary stuff improved as well, with a sharper breaking ball, now a slider. His changeup flashes above-average, with more consistent feel for it. He throws all three for strikes, and the increased sharpness led to a much better strikeout rate.The full season of innings in 2017 allowed GPE to work on his full repertoire and when to use it. With his feel for pitching and improving stuff, GPE certainly has an up arrow next to his name.

Ever since signing with the Phillies in May 2014, all GPE has done is pitch well. It started with his debut that summer in the ORGANIZATION and continued with his GPE debut in 2015. The next step up to the ORGANIZATION York-Penn PERSON wasn't too much of a challenge, as GPE finished with a sub-3.00 ORGANIZATION and landed among the league leaders in ORGANIZATION. The athletic, albeit a bit undersized, right-hander has the chance to have a solid three-pitch mix. He'll throw his fastball anywhere in the 90-95 mph range and he throws it with a lot of life, inducing ground-ball outs at a very high rate. He'll show an average breaking ball, but it's inconsistent, something he'll have to tighten up as he moves up the ladder. He has a feel for a changeup, which could also be a Major PERSON average offering for him. He tends to be a strike-thrower but does not miss a ton of bats, something that sharper secondary stuff will help.More than anything, GPE needs to get out and pitch and log PERSON innings so he can work on his full repertoire. A full season in a rotation has certainly helped him move in the right direction.

When PERSON, who signed back in May 2014, finished among the LOCATION League top 10 in strikeouts and ORGANIZATION during his full-season debut in 2017, there was a lot of anticipation over what the right-hander might do for an encore. While he was a little more uneven in some aspects of his performance, his pure stuff excited the ORGANIZATION enough for him to be added to the 40-man roster this past offseason.Pure stuff-wise, PERSON's is as electric as perhaps any prospect's in baseball and when he's locked in, he can be virtually unhittable. He uses his three-pitch mix to miss a lot of bats, striking out 10 per nine innings in his first two years of full-season ball. His fastball now comfortably sits in the 92-94 mph range and he can easily touch 95-96 mph, commanding the pitch well. PERSON also throws it with a ton of movement, getting ground-ball outs at a consistent clip. Both his sharp slider and his changeup flash plus at ORGANIZATION throws a lot of strikes, but he's still learning to harness his premium stuff within the zone, and it was inconsistencies with that which sometimes led to him getting hit in the ORGANIZATION State League. He just needs more development time to iron that out and the ORGANIZATION feel he has the athleticism, aptitude and competitiveness to reach his ceiling as a frontline starter.

After signing in May 2014 out of the ORGANIZATION, GPE spent a summer in the ORGANIZATION before making his GPE debut in 2015. He threw very well in the ORGANIZATION, leaving the ORGANIZATION very excited to see what the future has in store for the young right-hander.Not the biggest guy in the world at 6-foot-1, he reminds some of fellow ORGANIZATION prospect PERSON, though he's a bit more physical. GPE has the chance to have a solid three-pitch mix, highlighted by a fastball that took a nice jump forward in the ORGANIZATION and now touches 94-95 mph with regularity. While his breaking ball and changeup are behind the fastball, his curve does show flashes of being above average, and he has a good feel for his sinking change. While his command will have to improve, he already has a good feel for the strike zone.Even with his lack of size, GPE's arsenal and feel for pitching have the ORGANIZATION thinking they have a starting pitcher on their hands. It may take some time, but the wait should be worth it.

There are some exciting things brewing on the mound for the ORGANIZATION at the bottom of the organizational chain. PERSON has electric stuff that screams future frontline starter. Perhaps a half-step behind him is PERSON, whose very strong GPE debut in the ORGANIZATION and follow-up in the ORGANIZATION York-Penn League in 2016 has the ORGANIZATION excited to see what comes next.PERSON stands out already for his advanced feel for pitching that belies his age to go along with very encouraging steps forward stuff-wise. His fastball has jumped velocity wise, and he'll now throw it in the 90-95 mph range. He throws it with sink to get groundball outs and it's possible there's more in the tank to come. He spins a good breaking ball already and has feel for a changeup, both of which are inconsistent but have the chance to be at least PERSON average. PERSON throws strikes, but can refine his overall command to make his stuff play up even more.While the ORGANIZATION might be cautious with this teenager for the time being, his ability to execute on the mound could allow him to move a bit more quickly as he matures, with a future as a No. 3 type starter a possibility.

The ORGANIZATION were aggressive in this summer's international amateur market, signing shortstop PERSON and PERSON, an outfielder ranked 18th on MLBPipeline.com's Top 30 International prospects list. PERSON's speed and power combination netted him a $1.5 million bonus.PERSON has drawn comparisons to former big league outfielder PERSON, an excellent athlete with a strong, well-proportioned frame who plays with high energy at all times. He's an aggressive hitter with outstanding bat speed and raw power, one who uses a toe tap for timing. That pop shows up more on the pull side right now, but he does have the ability to drive the ball to all fields.His plus speed is an asset on both sides of the ball. He projects as a center fielder now, but could end up fitting the profile of an athletic right fielder when all is said and done.

When the ORGANIZATION went shopping in the international amateur market last summer, they aggressively went after, and signed, a pair of exciting GPE position players. One was shortstop PERSON; the other was PERSON, the toolsy outfielder who ranked 18th on ORGANIZATION's Top 30 international prospects list and signed for $1.5 million.Compared to former big league outfielder PERSON, PERSON has a power-speed combination that could be special one day. He is a premium athlete with a strong frame who has a high-energy style on the field. An aggressive hitter, PERSON has terrific bat speed and outstanding raw power. That pop shows up more on the pull side, but he can drive the ball to all fields and should tap into it more consistently as he refines his approach at the plate. PERSON's plus speed should continue to help him on both sides of the ball as he begins his pro career in earnest.PERSON is a center fielder for the time being, but there's the chance he could grow and develop more into the prototypical athletic right-fielder mold down the road. He has a long way to go, taking his first official steps in 2018.

Targeting projectable, tooled-up prospects at premium positions, the ORGANIZATION handed out a pair of seven-figure bonuses to GPE amateurs in 2017, signing both shortstop PERSON and PERSON, a center fielder, on July 2. While PERSON was widely viewed as the better prospect and therefore received a higher bonus, PERSON signed for $1.5 million after he ranked 19th on ORGANIZATION's Top 30 international prospects list.PERSON is a premium athlete with a strong frame who has a high-energy style on the field. An aggressive hitter, he has terrific bat speed and outstanding raw power from the right side of the plate. That pop shows up more on the pull side, but he can drive the ball to all fields and should tap into it more consistently as he refines his approach at the plate. PERSON's plus speed should continue to help him on both sides of the ball.PERSON is a center fielder for the time being, but there's the chance he could grow and develop more into the prototypical athletic right-fielder mold down the road. PERSON's power-speed combination has earned him comparisons to Jose PERSON from some scouts, and the ORGANIZATION would be thrilled if he become that caliber of player.

The ORGANIZATION were willing to blow past their bonus pool and incur a heavy tax to sign PERSON, who some scouts considered the top player in the 2014 international signing class, for $2.95 million on his 16th birthday in July. Signed for $690,000 out of GPE at the start of the 2013 signing period, PERSON has become one of the top catching prospects in the ORGANIZATION' system. The ORGANIZATION gave PERSON $690,000 to sign out of GPE in July 2013 hoping he would develop into a solid all-around, if a bit defensive-minded, catcher. Typically young catchers, especially teenagers signed at age 16, are either offensively or defensively-minded early in their career. The ORGANIZATION were encouraged with how PERSON, who signed in July 2013 for $690,000 out of GPE, began his pro career, playing well in both his 2014 pro debut in the ORGANIZATION as well as in his GPE debut in 2015 in the ORGANIZATION. He's developed a lot in terms of his game-calling and his overall receiving skills.The ORGANIZATION know better than to give up on catching prospects because there's so much more that goes into their development. PERSON will be just 20 years old for all of 2017 and there's plenty of time for him to develop as an all-around backstop. PERSON case, he has the chops to be a very good defensive backup.

The ORGANIZATION gave PERSON $690,000 to sign out of GPE in July 2013 hoping he would develop into a solid all-around, if a bit defensive-minded catcher. The defense has definitely been there, but the bat has been slow to come and his first taste of full-season ball in 2017 ended in late July with a broken hamate.There are absolutely no questions about PERSON's ability to defend. The 21-year-old is way behind at the plate. He does have decent contact skills and doesn't strike out a lot, but has absolutely no power to speak of and after posting solid batting averages in the ORGANIZATION and PERSON in 2014 and 2015, he hasn't been able to replicate those results and doesn't show much of a feel to hit right now.Defensive-minded backups don't have to hit a ton, but they do have to show some abilty to handle the bat to get there. | Overall:45One of the better all-around prospects in GPE, PERSON was ranked No. 19 on MLBPipeline.com's Top 30 International prospects list heading into this year's July 2 signing period. Some scouts do think a move to third is in his future, where he could be an outstanding defender. A switch-hitter, he does have work to do at the plate, with a need to clean up his hitting mechanics. When organizations sign young pitchers, the hope is there will be growth into the kind of pitcher they ultimately can become. With PERSON, who was ORGANIZATION's No. 15 prospect on the Top 30 ORGANIZATION list heading into the July 2015 signing period and signed for $762,500, it's been quite literal. He'll throw his fastball in the 92-95 mph range while still learning to create movement on a consistent basis, along with fastball command. His secondary stuff is progressing, starting with a curveball that could be above-average in time, a pitch PERSON has confidence in throwing at any point in thte count. His changeup is behind, but there's some feel for it to work with. The teenager is around the strike zone and should get to average control in the future.PERSON has become stronger and more durable as he's grown, with a loose, flexible and athletic delivery. Ranked No. 15 on MLBPipeline.com's Top 30 ORGANIZATION list heading into the July 2015 signing perioid, the ORGANIZATION gave the right-hander $762,500 to sign. The highest-priced member of the GPE's 2014 international class, PERSON signed for $900,000 out of the ORGANIZATION. PERSON commanded the largest bonus in the FACILITY' 2014 international class, signing for $900,000 out of the ORGANIZATION. Even before they gave PERSON $31.5 million, the ORGANIZATION already had blown well past their bonus pool for the 2014-15 international signing period. The ORGANIZATION had to wait patiently until GPE's 16th birthday to sign him, which they did for $900,000 in August 2013. The ORGANIZATION believe they landed one of the top players in the 2013 international free agent class in GPE, who signed for $900,000 on his 16th birthday. Among the top players in the 2013 international free agent class, GPE was one of the youngest and had to wait until his 16th birthday in GPE to sign with the Nationals. Signed for $100,000 out of the ORGANIZATION in 2014, PERSON created trade interest with other clubs almost as soon as he made his GPE debut two years later. He's learning that he doesn't have to sell out for home runs, and when he does his whippy left-handed swing gets too long and he piles up strikeouts and harmless flyballs. If he develops more patience and uses the entire field, he could hit for a decent average while still hitting 15-20 homers on an annual basis.PERSON has more than enough arm for shortstop but his speed and range are average, so it's unclear if he'll stay at the position. He's too young to move yet, though he did see extensive action at second base last year and has played sporadically at third base in the past. With a more consistent approach at the plate, he'd have no trouble profiling offensively at either position.

Shortly after PERSON made his GPE debut last summer, the ORGANIZATION started receiving trade inquiries about him from clubs intrigued by his offensive potential. Signed for $100,000 out of the ORGANIZATION in 2014, he tied for the Rookie-level PERSON lead with six triples in just 32 games and then tied for fourth in the short-season LOCATION with eight homers in just 23 contests. He finished the year with 34 extra-base hits in 66 games, an impressive showing for an 18-year-old.PERSON has surprising power for someone listed at 5-foot-11, generating easy plus raw pop from the left side of the plate thanks to his quick hands and wiry strength. His whippy stroke has considerable bat speed and he has some natural hitting ability, giving him the chance to hit for a solid average as he matures. To do so, he'll have to quiet his approach, tighten his strike zone and use the opposite field more often.It's unclear whether PERSON will remain at shortstop. He has a plus arm but his range and speed are closer to average, and he'll need to improve his consistency. Because GPE has several young shortstop prospects, he'll also get time at second and third base, and his bat has a chance to be special and profile wherever he plays.

Other teams started asking about PERSON in trade talks as soon as he made his GPE debut in 2016. Signed for $100,000 out of the ORGANIZATION Republic two years earlier, he immediately demonstrated enticing power potential for a middle infielder. He ranked second in total bases (205) and fifth in homers (19) as a 20-year-old in the Class A Advanced PERSON last year, though his 2019 season ended in last May when he injured his non-throwing shoulder while sliding into a base.PERSON stands just 5-foot-11, but his combination of wiry strength, whippy swing and bat speed could develop into plus power. To get all the way there, he'll have to improve as a hitter, because he still gets too aggressive and pull-happy instead of letting his home runs come naturally. A natural left-handed hitter who has scuffled against southpaws in pro ball, he resumed switch-hitting in 2019 after previously batting from both sides as an amateur.PERSON significantly upgraded his defensive profile last season, erasing any doubts that he could stay at shortstop. Though he's an average runner, he has improved his instincts and range. His plus-plus arm allows him to make throws and plays that many shortstops can't.

Signed for $100,000 out of the ORGANIZATION, PERSON spent his first pro season in the Rookie-level ORGANIZATION and returned there to start 2016 before coming to the GPE and breaking out. He tied for the Rookie-level PERSON lead with six triples in just 32 games and before tying for fourth in the short-season LOCATION with eight homers in just 23 contests. All the more impressive, he was only 18 years old.PERSON has easy plus raw power from the left side of the plate and more home run upside than most middle infielders. He has quick hands and surprising strength for someone listed at 5-foot-11 and 160 pounds. In order to hit for average at higher levels, he'll need to tighten his strike zone and do a better job of using the entire field.PERSON has average speed and solid arm strength, and the ORGANIZATION believe he can stay at shortstop if he works on his defense. He also has seen action at second and third base, and he could profile offensively at both positions.

In three years at ORGANIZATION, PERSON went from focusing solely on making contact to trying to get the most out of his raw power while moving from first base as a freshman to shortstop as a sophomore before settling in at the hot corner as a junior. After hitting eight total home runs during his first two season, PERSON doubled his combined total as a junior, slugging 16 homers in 56 games for the ORGANIZATION while maintaining his feel to hit and on-base skills. The ORGANIZATION made him their third-round pick in June, and PERSON began his pro career in the Class A ORGANIZATION. PERSON has good hand-eye coordination, controls the strike zone extremely well and makes consistent contact from the right side of the plate. He turned his stroke loose more often during his junior campaign, but continued to walk nearly as much as he has struck out while producing more power. He's a well below-average runner who can clock some bottom-of-the-scale times down the line when he takes a big swing.Though he lacks quickness, PERSON has good reactions at third base and should be at least an adequate defender with more experience there. His reliable hands and solid arm strength fit at the hot corner, as does his offensive profile. First base is probably his only other option in pro ball because his speed would make him a liability on an outfield corner.

As a high school junior in 2015, GPE helped PERSON win the ORGANIZATION, then went on to join the GPE pitching staff. After a freshman season spent largely in the bullpen, he jumped on the national radar as a sophomore All-American starter. He kept on performing as a junior as the ORGANIZATION' Friday night starter and signed for slot value after the ORGANIZATION selected him in the fourth round of the 2019 Draft.While he's not the prototypical starting pitcher in terms of height, the 6-foot right-hander does have a lot of arm speed and strength. And he's worked hard to turn himself into more of a pitcher compared to the thrower he was earlier in his amateur career. He can still go get 96-97 mph at times, but is more comfortable sitting in the 91-94 range with a fastball that has cutting and some sinking action to it. He throws both a slider and a curve, and while the former might be a tick ahead of the latter, some feel he might be better served focusing on the curve to differentiate from his fastball more. He sells a future average changeup well and knows how to pitch backwards when needed.While GPE doesn't have the cleanest arm action, with a little stab in the back, he repeats his delivery well and tends to be in sync, leading to a lot of strikes. That gives him the chance to stick in a rotation long-term, with the ceiling of a No. 4 type starter.

Ranked No. 19 on MLBPipeline.com's Top 30 ORGANIZATION list heading into the July 2015 signing period, PERSON received $1.2 million from the ORGANIZATION to sign out of Venezuela.PERSON reminds some in the organization of fellow ORGANIZATION shortstop PERSON in terms of his maturity and feel for the game at such a young age. He has a good feel for hitting with a line-drive approach. PERSON is quick to the ball and makes consistent hard contact, showing an ability to drive the ball to the gaps. While he's only 5-foot-11, he has some strength and bat speed, and it's not out of the question that he'll develop some power in the future. PERSON is a very smooth fielder, potentially a touch better than PERSON, with excellent hands, actions and plenty of arm. He runs well, which gives him ample range and should allow him to be an excellent baserunner. PERSON is just getting started in pro ball and will be 17 for all of the 2016 season. For a system deep in shortstop prospects, he gives them one more with a ton of upside.

The ORGANIZATION have never shied away from pushing young infielders up the organizational ladder if they felt they could handle the challenge, with players like ORGANIZATION and PERSON making their big league debuts at age 21 in recent years. PERSON, who signed in July 2015 for $1.2 million and made it to Double-A in 2018 before he turned 20, appears to be on a similar path.PERSON might be among the most unassuming-looking top prospects in the game given his small frame, but he has tools on both sides of the ball. He can flat-out play shortstop, and should be able to play there long-term thanks to his strong arm, excellent hands, range and plus instincts for the position. While he's not a burner, he has above-average speed, and he maximizes it both defensively and as a hitter, leading the organization in stolen bases in 2018. He has a very good approach at the plate that leads to consistent contact, and he's shown he's not afraid to draw a walk. He may never win a home run derby, but the 2018 Futures PERSON showed more extra-base thump in '18, with a bit more to come.In another system, PERSON would be the heir apparent at shortstop. With PERSON there in the big leagues, PERSON got a lot of time at second base in the ORGANIZATION last fall, perhaps a sign of things to come.

When teams acquire young international talent, as the ORGANIZATION did by giving PERSON $1.2 million to sign in July 2015, it often comes with the understanding that while the raw tools might be plentiful, it might take time for them to be refined and the player to mature. When a teenager shows tremendous skills and beyond-his-years maturity, that's when an organization thinks it might have someone special. And that's how the ORGANIZATION feel about PERSON.During his pro debut in the ORGANIZATION, the ORGANIZATION shortstop finished second in batting average and third in ORGANIZATION, and the ORGANIZATION feel the numbers are legit. That's largely because of his advanced approach, one that saw him walk twice as often as he struck out in 2016. The left-handed hitter has plus bat speed with the chance to be a 60 hitter when all is said and done. While he's never going to have a ton of power, he's not a slap hitter, either. PERSON is definitely a shortstop long-term, using his above-average athleticism and speed well in the field as well as on the basepaths.While PERSON might not be the pure tool package that PERSON is, he has the chance to be a really good up-the-middle player. Because of his off-the-charts makeup, the ORGANIZATION felt comfortable pushing him and he had a solid GPE debut in the full-season LOCATION League in 2017 at age 18.

Ranked No. 19 on ORGANIZATION's Top 30 international prospects list in 2015, PERSON signed with the ORGANIZATION that July for $1.2 million. His pro debut in the ORGANIZATION, where the infielder led the circuit in on-base percentage and finished second in batting average and third in ORGANIZATION, gave the ORGANIZATION confidence to leap him all the way up to the full-season LOCATION for his GPE debut in 2017. He more than held his own as one of the youngest position players in the league.PERSON has an advanced approach at the plate that belies his age and experience. He works counts and draws walks while making consistent hard contact with a simple and quick swing from the left side of the plate. PERSON needs to continue to add strength, and while over-the-fence power will likely never be a huge part of his game, he should mature into impacting the ball more with extra-base authority, eventually becoming a plus hitter. He has above-average speed at present, which helps him on the basepaths and in the field. He has the arm, hands and range to play shortstop long-term and his makeup should allow him to maximize his tools.Now on a faster track because of the aggressive promotion in 2017, PERSON's skills and maturity should allow him to keep streaking up the system. The ORGANIZATION obviously have Amed PERSON at short in GPE, and while the organization doesn't have to worry about it just yet, no one worries about PERSON's ability to slide to second base if needed.

Before reversing course this June, the FACILITY had shied away from taking high school arms with early picks since drafting PERSON in 2014's second round. They grabbed GPE right-hander PERSON in the second round and doubled down with PERSON in the third, signing them for a combined $4.1 million. One of the few pleasant surprises in a down LOCATION prep class, he landed a $2 million bonus. PERSON viewed PERSON as a projectable right-hander with a nice delivery but not enough present stuff to buy him away from an GPE commitment until his fastball jumped to 91-95 mph during his senior season. He uses four-seamers at the top of the strike zone and two-seamers at the bottom, with his extension creating deception that's more notable than the life on his heater. He has a lot of projection remaining in his 6-foot-1 frame and could continue to add more velocity.PERSON gets good depth on a mid-70s curveball that should become a solid offering once he adds more power. He also has a slider and changeup but didn't use them much as an amateur. He's athletic and possesses a whippy arm action that allows him to fill the strike zone.

PERSON went from an unheralded northern GPE high schooler to the best hitter in college baseball during his three years at GPE, batting .374/.495/.688 with 50 homers in 160 games. The ORGANIZATION winner as a sophomore in 2018, he surpassed PERSON as the highest drafted player in GPE history when the FACILITY took him No. 3 overall this June. He signed for $7,221,200, a GPE record for both the franchise and for a corner bat.PERSON has a sweet right-handed swing, plenty of bat speed and strength and no discernible flaws at the plate. He's a natural hitter with natural power to all fields and he doesn't try to do too much. He uses the entire field and won't chase pitches when opponents try to work around him, and he could be a .300 hitter with 30 homers and 80 walks on an annual basis.Though PERSON worked out at third base for some clubs before the GPE, he likely will be limited to first base. He's a below-average runner but moves well enough around the bag. He does have some arm strength and ran his fastball into the low 90s when he pitched early in his college career, but the majority of his value -- and it will be considerable -- will come from his bat.

Signed as a teenager in October 2013, the switch-hitting PERSON didn't start getting really noticed until a robust 2017 in the ORGANIZATION when he slashed .345/.390/.472 in 62 games. A hamstring issue really hampered him during his full-season debut with PERSON in 2018, though he did make some good strides in the second half.A very lean kid listed at 170 pounds, PERSON has some surprising 50-60 level raw power on the 20-to-80 scouting scale and ran into some balls last year that left the ballpark quickly. He has shown solid bat-to-ball skills from both sides of the plate, though he was much better from the left side, where he also has more extra-base ability. Although his leg injury compromised his best tool, he is an above average base runner with speed that makes him a basestealing threat. PERSON can also cover a lot of ground in the outfield. Not an instinctive defender, he has the arm for the corner spots but could still hold his own as a center fielder.It remains to be seen if PERSON's 6-foot-2 frame can support more weight and muscle, but he somehow needs to find more strength to take advantage of his raw power ability. With his offensive skills, he projects as a fourth outfielder.

PERSON, a native of GPE, really put himself firmly on the map during the ORGANIZATION home run derby held over the 2015 All-Star Game weekend in GPE, advancing to the finals and getting to swing with the Major Leaguers in the main event on Monday. PERSON's annual tour through GPE this spring gave PERSON the chance to raise his stock, and he took advantage, landing in the second round and getting full pick value -- $1,214,100 -- to sign with the D-backs.PERSON's left-handed power is what stands out the most, as he consistently squares up the baseball. He's more power than hit, but it's easy power, and while he may never hit for a high average, the home run pop should play in games. His play behind the plate is a bit more crude. He has an average arm that's accurate, even though he needs to improve his footwork. His hands work decently, and he should become an adequate overall receiver in time.The D-backs let PERSON jump over the rookie-level ORGANIZATION to go to the ORGANIZATION for his debut, where he was teaming up to make a very good catching trio with fellow 2016 draftee PERSON and ORGANIZATION prospect PERSON.

Developing catching can be a tough task for any farm system. Helping a high school catcher reach his potential? That can be an even longer process, especially when that young backstop comes from a cold-weather climate like GPE. But the D-backs' scouting staff liked PERSON's left-handed power bat enough to take him in the second round and preach patience to the player development staff.They are more than willing, especially given PERSON's plus work ethic and makeup. He's strong with good bat speed and has the makings of a good swing that should continue to evolve. He's more power over hit currently and will improve as he incorporates his lower half more, refines his approach and improve his pitch recognition. PERSON's defense is a work in progress -- he committed 20 passed balls during his pro debut -- though he made strides during his first summer and at instructs last fall. His average arm should be playable, especially as he continues to improve his footwork and release.The D-backs knew it would be a long game to get PERSON headed in the right direction defensively, but with the improvements they've seen already, there is no reason to move him from behind the plate, with the hope being he becomes an offensive-minded big league regular behind the plate.

When the D-backs took PERSON in the second round of the 2016 Draft out of the GPE high school ranks, they were excited to bring his power potential into the organization and knew it might take time for the other parts of his game to develop, especially behind the plate. True to projections, PERSON's bat is starting to show up, and then some. Now it's a question of whether his catching can keep up.After struggling during his pro debut in 2016, PERSON showed the ability to make adjustments, see pitches and start tapping into his considerable raw power. He drew walks and drove the ball to all fields in the ORGANIZATION in 2017 and if that continues, his plus raw power will show up more consistently in games. Defensively, PERSON has solid arm strength, and has thrown out just over 30 percent of potential basestealers in his young career heading into 2018, but his receiving, blocking and game-calling still have a ways to go.The D-backs are pleased with the strides he's made defensively and he reported to Spring Training with a transformed body, looking much leaner and more athletic. If that helps him behind the plate, then PERSON could develop into the big league regular catcher, albeit a bat-first one, the D-backs envisioned.

Seven of the ORGANIZATION' eight most expensive signings on the 2018 international market were shortstops, no surprise for an organization that stockpiles middle infielders every year. That group included PERSON, whose father PERSON caught for eight years in the big leagues. Signed for $500,000 out of the ORGANIZATION, he has impressed in his pro debut in the Rookie-level ORGANIZATION in 2019.Though PERSON will need time to add strength and to develop, he's a switch-hitter with intriguing offensive potential. He has a sound, quick swing from both sides of the plate and uses a mature approach. He could grow into solid raw power once he matures physically, giving him more pop than most of GPE's infield prospects. It's evident that PERSON grew up around the game because his instincts allow him to play quicker than his average speed on the bases and in the field. With his solid arm strength, he's capable of playing anywhere in the infield. He has divided his first pro season among second base, third base and shortstop while PERSON (who signed for $2.1 million) gets most of the ORGANIZATION reps at short.

An unheralded international prospect when the ORGANIZATION signed him out of the ORGANIZATION in January 2016, PERSON spent his first two pro seasons in GPE ball before finally getting his first full-season exposure with PERSON in 2018. He's done nothing but excel since then, showing improved stuff while making a relatively quick climb through the ORGANIZATION' system. He broke out in earnest in 2019, earning midseason All-Star honors in the ORGANIZATION State League before advancing to Double-A in mid-May. While PERSON has long shown a loose, quick arm, his stuff has really begun to tick up as he's added strength to his durable frame. He generates easy velocity, sitting 92-94 mph and bumping 95 in most outings, and is a candidate to add a few more ticks based on his remaining physical projection. His hard slider, while above average, can be inconsistent, at times featuring more curveball-like action than true slider bite, but it's still a very effective pitch for him that should continue to improve. His changeup, much like his breaking ball, is a bit of a work-in-progress, though he does impart good diving action on that pitch. He generates a healthy number of whiffs both inside and out of the zone, especially with his fastball-slider pairing, and consistently avoids hitters' barrels.To go along with his improving stuff, PERSON also has proved a workhorse early in his career and pitches deep into games. He shouldn't have any problems sticking as a starter, provided he can make gains with control and command and continue to refine his secondary arsenal, and it's almost a given that PERSON's stuff would play up in shorter bursts should the ORGANIZATION ever move him to the bullpen.

At 6-foot-5 and 204 pounds, PERSON was one of the most physically imposing players on the 2017 international market when he signed for $500,000 as a 16-year-old Dominican that July. His body and reputation grew in his first year in pro ball, as he added 25 pounds and topped the Rookie-level Gulf Coast League with 10 homers last summer.A switch-hitter, PERSON is more effective left-handed but his gargantuan raw power is obvious from either side of the plate. He has an extremely aggressive approach and a naturally long swing, which resulted in a 41 percent strikeout rate during his pro debut. While it's easy to dream on his bat speed and strength, he's going to have to make much more contact to deliver on his power potential. Though PERSON moves surprisingly well for his size, he already has lost a step since signing and could slow further if he continues to get bigger. He could become an average defender on either outfield corner if he works diligently on his defense and maintains his current athleticism. His arm earns average to solid grades from evaluators.

PERSON's notoriety as a switch-hitter and switch-pitcher who could throw in the upper 80s with equal effectiveness with either arm sometimes overshadowed the fact that he was one of the best catchers in the 2018 Draft. GPE made him the first prep backstop selected, signing him for $2,815,900 as the 23rd overall pick. If he reaches the big leagues, he'll join PERSON as the only members of the ORGANIZATION to do so.The ORGANIZATION often prioritize slugging over hitting ability and defense at catcher, but PERSON doesn't fit their usual profile. He's extremely athletic for his position and could develop into a ORGANIZATION behind the plate. He has promising receiving and framing potential, and his plus arm plays even better because he has such a quick transfer.A proficient hitter from both sides of the plate, PERSON controls the strike zone and drills line drives to all fields. He has a contact-oriented approach with solid bat speed, and while he's not loaded with raw power, he has the hitting ability to get the most out of what he has. He's close to an average runner and has good instincts on the bases and in all phases of the game.

PERSON attracts attention because he's a switch-hitter as well as a switch-pitcher who can throw in the upper 80s and is equally effective with either arm. However, his ambidextriousness isn't as significant as his considerable all-around ability as a catcher. The ORGANIZATION made him the first high school backstop selected in the 2018 Draft, signing him for $2,815,900 as the 23rd overall pick.Proficient from both sides of the plate, PERSON consistently makes hard contact and uses the entire field. He needs to get stronger but his hitting ability and solid bat speed eventually should translate into double-digit home run totals. With close to average speed, he's faster than most catchers and shows good instincts on the bases and in all phases of the game.Agile behind the plate, PERSON has promising receiving and framing skills. He has a quick transfer that helps his arm play as plus at times. PERSON athletic for his position, he elicits comparisons to PERSON and could profile as an everyday player at second base if desired.

The ORGANIZATION (ORGANIZATION, GPE) featured one of the best position player/pitcher combinations in the 2019 Draft, though both PERSON and right-hander PERSON came with strong commitments to ORGANIZATION and high price tags. The ORGANIZATION selected them both, signing PERSON for $2,740,300 as the 30th overall pick and taking a fruitless 20th-round flier on Leiter. While some clubs rated PERSON as a second-rounder because he lacks a true plus tool, GPE saw him as a worthy first-rounder who combines a chance to be a solid hitter and defender with a high baseball IQ.PERSON demonstrates nice feel for the barrel, using a compact right-handed swing to drill lines drives to all fields. He does have the bat speed to grow into double-digit home run power once he gets stronger, though he understands his priorities are to make contact and get on base. He got a little quicker as a high school senior, flashing plus speed at times and continuing to show good instincts on the bases.Though PERSON's range and arm don't dazzle at shortstop, he makes all the plays. He positions himself well and has soft, quick hands that help him get rid of the ball quickly. PERSON adore his makeup and have no doubts that he'll get everything he can out of his physical ability.

PERSON was a late popup before the 2018 Draft as an Illinois high schooler, impressing scouts enough with his size and projectability that the ORGANIZATION made a run at signing him to an over-slot bonus in the 13th round. He chose instead to attend PERSON (Ill.) CC, where he led national ORGANIZATION pitchers with 19.1 strikeouts per nine innings. While some teams passed over PERSON due to the sizable gap between his ceiling and floor, the Brewers were thrilled to find him still on the board in the second round and signed him for slot value. PERSON's fastball topped out in the low 90s as a high school senior, but after adding 20 pounds and cleaning up his delivery, he's reaching 98 mph and showing the ability to work at 94-97 mph for innings at a time. PERSON look at his 6-foot-6 frame and how easy and loose his arm looks while pumping mid-90s heat, and many of them come up with the same physical comparison: a young PERSON. He still has room to add more strength and to further improve his mechanics, so it's easy to project him topping 100 mph in the future.The quality of PERSON's secondary arsenal lags behind his heater. His mid-80s slider is below average and he struggles to land it for strikes, but the Brewers like the pitch's action and believe it'll improve as he develops better feel. His changeup is non-existent and will be an area of focus in pro ball. His control is surprisingly good for a hurler with such long levers, and it's easy to envision him making further gains on that front given his fluid delivery. PERSON's development will require a ton of patience and he ultimately may be more of a reliever than a starter, but he has a rare arm.

GPE gave seven-figure bonuses to three Venezuelans in 2017: catcher PERSON ($3.1 million), who died of cancer four months later; and infielders GPE ($1.4 million) and PERSON ($1.6 million), who quickly emerged as two of the best position prospects in a rebuilding farm system. GPE was advanced enough offensively and defensively to make his GPE debut at age 17 last summer, though he missed six weeks after straining his left shoulder on a swing. One rival club told the ORGANIZATION Sox they considered him the best prospect in the organization.With a controlled but quick right-handed swing and an advanced approach for a teenager, GPE should hit for a high average. He controls the strike zone and employs the entire field, and his hitting ability and deceptive strength give him the chance to develop 20-homer power. While he's only an average runner and could lose a half-step as he matures physically, he has good instincts on the bases.GPE also shows nice savvy in the field, where he covers more ground at shortstop than his speed might suggest. He's a fluid defender with soft hands and the arm strength to make all the required throws at short. In the event he slows down and requires a shift to third base, he has the offensive potential to profile there.

One of three Venezuelans to receive seven-figure signing bonuses from the ORGANIZATION in 2017, GPE turned pro for $1.4 million. He's no relation to PERSON, who died of cancer four months after signing for $3.1 million. His tools are fairly similar to those of C.J. PERSON's, GPE's top shortstop prospect, though GPE is much further away from the big leagues.Though GPE receives more praise for his instincts than his tools, he has the ability to contribute both offensively and defensively. He has good actions at shortstop, where his savvy allows him to cover more ground than his fringy speed would suggest. He has the arm strength for the position, though he needs to be mindful not to drop his arm slot and lose accuracy on his throws.With a nice right-handed swing and signs of an advanced approach, GPE should hit for average. He's not very physical but has some loft in his stroke and should develop some gap power once he gets stronger. He won't be a basestealer, but runs the bases well.

After the ORGANIZATION missed out in the ORGANIZATION sweepstakes, they used their surplus international bonus pool money to land PERSON ($1.85 million) and PERSON ($1.35 million) last December. PERSON and signed as a catcher, PERSON had unusual tools for the position and moved to center field for his pro debut. He needed just a week in the Rookie-level ORGANIZATION to persuade the ORGANIZATION that he was ready to come to the GPE, where he has thrived in the Rookie-level Gulf Coast League.Based on the early returns, PERSON's bat could play almost anywhere on the diamond. He's advanced in terms of his patience, plate discipline and ability to make repeated contact. He offers promising power potential as well thanks to his bat speed and strength, and he should hit more home runs once he adds some loft to his right-handed swing.PERSON's best tool is his speed, which earns 65-70 grades on the 20-80 scouting scale, and his worst is his fringy-to-average arm. As a result, GPE deemed him a better fit in center field than behind the plate. He's still in the early learning stages in the outfield, but once he improves his reads and hones his instincts, he should be at least an average defender in center.

When the ORGANIZATION failed to sign PERSON after the 2017 season, they regrouped and spent their surplus international money on GPE position players Raimfer GPE ($1.85 million) and PERSON ($1.35 million) in December. PERSON and signed as a catcher, PERSON had atypical athleticism for the position and moved to center field before his 2018 pro debut. He showed enough in one week in the Rookie-level ORGANIZATION for GPE to decide he needed a tougher challenge and to bring him to the GPE at age 17.PERSON has advanced discipline and bat-to-ball skills for a teenager. His bat speed and strength also give him plenty of raw power, which translated into him topping the Rookie-level Gulf Coast League with a .555 slugging percentage. He should develop even more pop as he adds more loft to his right-handed swing.PERSON's speed earns well-above-average grades from some evaluators, a major factor in the ORGANIZATION' decision to move him from behind the plate. He's still learning as a center fielder but should become at least an average defender once he improves his reads and routes. He has average arm strength and enough offensive ability to profile as a regular if he has to shift to a corner.

The most electric arm in the state of GPE for the 2015 Draft, PERSON didn't show a ton of feel for harnessing his stuff until late in the season. It was enough for the ORGANIZATION to take him in the second round and sign him away from GPE with a bonus slightly above pick value.PERSON has a strong 6-foot-3, 240-pound frame and a very quick arm, and when he keeps his mechanics under control he looks like a future ace. PERSON can work at 93-95 mph fastball and hit 98, with some late life when he keeps it down in the zone. His curveball can be a true 12-to-6 hammer and reach the mid-80s. The problem is that PERSON can't hold his delivery together, often flying open and overthrowing. That causes his fastball to straighten out and his curve to lose its shape, and prevents him from keeping either pitch near the strike zone. He has yet to show much aptitude for throwing a changeup.

The best prospect from the ORGANIZATION' spending spree during the 2015-16 international signing period, PERSON landed a $2 million bonus out of the ORGANIZATION. He made his pro debut last summer in the Rookie-level ORGANIZATION, where he hit .254/.366/.316 with more walks (34) than strikeouts (28). He stood out by showing more polish than a typical 17-year-old. An advanced left-handed hitter with a mature approach, PERSON already recognizes pitches well and uses the whole field. He lacks size and strength but understands his limitations, focusing on stroking line drives and not worrying about driving the ball. With his hitting ability and bat speed, he could grow into double-digit home run power while providing high batting averages and on-base percentages. PERSON has solid speed and already shows some savvy on the bases. He has good instincts in the field as well and should be able to stay at shortstop. He's not the flashiest defender, but his feet, hands and arm all work well.

GPE invested heavily in the international market during the 2015-16 signing period, with PERSON receiving the third-largest bonus in its crop at $2 million. Extremely mature for his age, the ORGANIZATION made his full-season debut last August at 18 and didn't look out of place in the low Class A ORGANIZATION. While he may not have as high a ceiling as former top PERSON infield prospects PERSON, PERSON and PERSON, he still offers plenty of upside and has a high floor.Despite his struggles in high Class A this year, PERSON is an advanced hitter who already recognizes pitches, uses the whole field and doesn't try to do too much. He makes repeated contact, drilling line drives to all fields while managing the strike zone well. Though he lacks size, he has a quick left-handed swing and some sneaky power that could translate into 12-15 homers annually once he adds some muscle.PERSON has average speed but plays quicker than that on the bases and in the field because of his instincts. He's still learning as a basestealer but already shows a propensity for making plays at shortstop. His hands, range and arm are all solid and should allow him to play a variety of positions if needed.

The ORGANIZATION ranked second behind only the ORGANIZATION in international spending during the 2015-16 signing period, handing out $16.4 million in bonuses. PERSON missed the entire showcase circuit last summer and fall after he tore the anterior cruciate ligament and meniscus in his left knee in May 2016. The Royals have a former First Presbyterian Day School (ORGANIZATION, Ga.) left-hander knocking on the door of the big leagues in PERSON and another in their pipeline after signing PERSON for an over-slot $447,500 as a fifth-rounder in June. PERSON ORGANIZATION has produced a handful of big leaguers, most recently reliever PERSON, and might best be known recently for producing first-round pick PERSON, now with the ORGANIZATION. PERSON was a standout on the summer showcase circuit in 2017, but an uneven spring as a senior raised questions about his bat and caused his stock to fall a little. PERSON's $600,000 bonus was the largest given to any left-hander during the 2015-16 international amateur signing period. PERSON burst onto the prospect scene last spring at FACILITY CC, and he might have gone in the first three rounds of the 2018 Draft if his asking price hadn't pushed him to PERSON.
