The highest-drafted Alabama prepster since ORGANIZATION went fourth overall in 1971, PERSON gave up a ORGANIZATION scholarship to sign for $4,145,900 as the ORGANIZATION. 7 choice in 2016. He had one of the best curveballs and some of the best polish in his high school crop, creating expectations that he could move quickly. But he made just four starts in his 2017 pro debut before undergoing PERSON surgery and missing all of last season.If he can regain his health and previous stuff, PERSON could be the best pitcher in the ORGANIZATION system. Before he got hurt, he not only had an upper-70s curveball with tight spin and impressive depth, but also showed the aptitude to land it for strikes or use it as a chase pitch. He also had a 90-94 mph fastball and showed similar velocity when he logged a few innings in GPE's instructional league program last fall, and he could add more power to his heater as he gets stronger.PERSON's changeup gives him a solid third offering with which to attack hitters. All of his pitches play up because he commands and mixes them well. The ORGANIZATION expect to turn him loose in 2019 and hope he can reach his ceiling as a ORGANIZATION. 2 starter.

GPE's best prep pitching prospect since PERSON went 12th overall to the ORGANIZATION in 2006, PERSON helped PERSON win the 18U World Cup in GPE in September. He has been better than ever this spring, impressing a throng of scouts with a shutout at the ORGANIZATION in March en route to posting a 0.53 ERA and with 131 strikeouts in 65 1/3 innings for ORGANIZATION. Despite some signability concerns, the PERSON selected PERSON with the seventh overall pick and then lured him away from a ORGANIZATION commitment with an above-slot, $4,145,900 bonus. PERSON featured one of the better curveballs among high schoolers in the 2016 Draft class, a 76-80 mph bender with good depth, though he can fall in love with his breaking ball at times. He also throws an 88-94 mph fastball with deceptive angle and some late life. Both pitches figure to add more velocity once PERSON strengthens his athletic frame.PERSON has feel for a changeup that has shown signs of developing into a plus pitch as he has used it more as a senior. With his loose, whippy arm and clean delivery, he shouldn't have trouble remaining a starter in pro ball. PERSON has a ceiling of a No. 2 starter and a relatively high floor for a high school pitcher.

GPE looks like one of the better investments in the ORGANIZATION's deep 2017 international class, signing for $28,000 out of the ORGANIZATION at the relatively advanced age of 18. In his 2018 pro debut, he finished among the Rookie-level ORGANIZATION leaders in GPE (0.73, second), opponent average (.162, third) and K/BB ratio (6.8, sixth). PERSON deemed him suitably advanced to bring him to the GPE for the Rookie-level Gulf Coast League playoffs.Though GPE is very much a work in progress and has been knocked around in Class A this year, he displays the potential for three solid or better pitches. His fastball presently sits at 91-93 mph and touches 96 with some sink, and he could add more velocity as he gets stronger. His low-80s slider stands out more for its velocity than its bite but he will flash some sharp ones.GPE also shows some feel for a changeup with some fade, though it's not as consistent as his other offerings. While he was a bit old for the ORGANIZATION, his ability to throw strikes and keep the ball down in the zone was apparent. He has a ceiling of a mid-rotation starter but will need plenty of development time to get there.

Ranked No. 8 on MLB.com's Top 30 ORGANIZATION list in 2014, the toolsy PERSON was signed to a $1.85 million bonus by the ORGANIZATION shortly after the July 2 signing period began. He made his organizational debut in the ORGANIZATION League 2015. If everything comes together, PERSON could display top-of-the-chart type tools. PERSON strong right now, he has room to add strength as he physically matures. There's more pop in the bat than you might think now, with more to come in the future. Right now, he's more of a line-drive hitter to all fields. He has good instincts for his age and has a decent approach from both sides of the plate. An above-average runner, he plays a very solid center field, covering a good amount of ground with a solid average arm. It will take some time to discover exactly what PERSON can become, but he has the chance to be a very good all-around center fielder down the road, with a move to right field -- depending on how he matures -- not out of the question.

One of the top prospects in the 2014 international class, the toolsy PERSON was signed to a $1.85 million bonus by the ORGANIZATION shortly after the July 2 signing period began. He made his organizational debut in the ORGANIZATION in 2015 and then returned there this year before advancing to the ORGANIZATION. PERSON is all projection right now, but he'll flash all five tools. The switch-hitter already has some pop in his bat, and there surely will be more to come as he fills into his wiry strong frame. A line-drive hitter who uses the whole field, he has good instincts for his age as well as a decent approach from both sides of the plate. He's an above-average runner who plays a solid center field, where he covers a good amount of ground and shows a slightly above-average arm.Just 18 years old, PERSON will need time to come into his own as a player. That said, he has the chance to be a very good all-around center fielder down the road, with a move to right field -- depending on how he matures physically -- not out of the question

One of the top prospects in the 2014 international class, the toolsy PERSON received a $1.85 million bonus from the ORGANIZATION shortly after the July 2 signing period began. He made his organizational debut in the ORGANIZATION in 2015 and earned All-Star honors there the following year before opening the '17 season in the ORGANIZATION. But it will now be up to the ORGANIZATION to further PERSON's development after they acquired him and right-handers PERSON, PERSON and PERSON from GPE in July in exchange for PERSON Phelps.PERSON is all projection right now, but he'll flash all five tools. He tried switch-hitting during his pro debut but exclusively hit from his natural side in 2016 at the request of the ORGANIZATION. A line-drive hitter who uses the whole field, he has good instincts for his age as well as a quality approach. Meanwhile, scouts believe he'll show more power in games as he grows into his wiry strong frame. PERSON's speed translates well in center field, where he profiles as a future plus defender with plenty of range and a plus arm.Though PERSON likely will need time to refine his all-around game and come into his own as a player, he already shows the makings of becoming an everyday center fielder. PERSON's development at the plate in the coming years will help to bring his ultimate ceiling into focus, but it goes without saying that the ORGANIZATION, much like GPE, believe it could be considerable.

While many international amateur free agent pitchers are signed because of big arms and the hope of premium velocity, PERSON stood out for his advanced feel for pitching at his age, not to mention his left-handedness, and the ORGANIZATION gave him $300,000 to sign at the start of the 2017-18 signing period. He was as advertised during his pro debut in the ORGANIZATION in 2018.Just 18 for the 2019 season, PERSON had a really good delivery and pitchability as he entered pro ball, but he lacked physicality. He's started to add strength, and his stuff is starting to tick upwards. His fastball usually sits in the 88-91 mph range, but he reaches back for 92-93 mph with ease. He throws a little across his body and the ball jumps out of his hand, with the ride on his fastball, thanks to high spin rates up in the zone, allowing the pitch to play above-average. He throws two distinct breaking balls, both are legitimate weapons, and he has some feel for his changeup as well.It's a small sample size, but PERSON did fill up the strike zone during his debut in the ORGANIZATION. Now he's coming to the GPE to see how his feel for pitching will allow him to climb the ORGANIZATION' ladder.

The GPE landed PERSON during the same 2017-18 international signing period that also netted the organization rising prospects PERSON and PERSON. While those two players were both plagued by injuries in '18, PERSON excelled in his first taste of pro ball at age 17, beginning in the ORGANIZATION and then moving stateside to the Rookie-level PERSON, where he was named a postseason All-Star after producing a .343 average, the circuit's third-best mark.The switch-hitting PERSON possesses one of the more advanced bats in GPE's system, as some evaluators have pegged him as a plus hitter. He has preternatural feel for finding the barrel from both sides of the plate to go along with an advanced approach and present pitch recognition. And while he's currently lean and somewhat undersized, PERSON does have a projectable frame that portends modest game power in future years.PERSON's speed is another plus tool, one that gives him impact potential on the basepaths and translates to above-average range at shortstop, where he's an above-average defender with average arm strength. What's more, club officials are quick to praise the teenager's maturity, makeup and intelligence, qualities that they believe help make him a special player.

The ORGANIZATION' 2017 international class has a chance to be special, highlighted by three potential impact hitters in PERSON, fellow ORGANIZATION switch-hitting shortstop PERSON and GPE outfielder PERSON. His $125,000 bonus was a fraction of what PERSON paid GPE ($1.5 million) and GPE ($1.3 million), and he already looks like a bargain. PERSON hit his way to the GPE as a 17-year-old last summer, finishing third in the ORGANIZATION batting race (.343) as the rookie circuit's third-youngest qualifier.PERSON has advanced feel for hitting and pitch recognition, along with a sweet swing from both sides of the plate. He commands the strike zone but makes contact so easily that he doesn't draw many walks. While he's small and not physically mature, he has quick hands and snap in his wrists that should produce at least gap power.PERSON has plus speed and is very aggressive on the bases, so he could be a prolific basestealer once he improves his reads and jumps. His quickness and instincts give him solid range at shortstop, though his arm is merely average and might prompt an eventual move to second base. The ORGANIZATION love his makeup and he has earned the nickname "The Professor" for his high baseball IQ.

Because he wasn't a regular on the high school summer showcase circuit, PERSON didn't attract a lot of scouting attention until he impressed with his arm speed and projectability at the World Wood Bat Association World Championship last October. He followed with a strong senior season as a two-way player, pitching himself into the fourth round and signing for an above-slot $497,500.PERSON has added significant fastball velocity during the last year and now works in the low 90s and peaks at 96 mph with some sink and run. He has a quick, clean arm action and plenty of room to add muscle on his 6-foot-4 frame, so he has the potential for consistent mid-90s heat once he's fully developed. His size and high three-quarters arm slot create steep downhill plane that add to the difficulty of barreling his fastball.PERSON's slider also is trending up, showing the potential to become a solid pitch in the low 80s with some depth. He didn't use his changeup much as an amateur and will need it to keep left-handers in check. While he'll require time to develop, he's so young and projectable that the payoff could be worth the wait.

The Rockies have brought PERSON along slowly since signing him for $100,000 out of the ORGANIZATION in November 2013. He spent his first two pro seasons in the Rookie-level ORGANIZATION league and began 2017 by repeating the Short-Season Northwest League before advancing to low Class A in July.While he's far from a finished product, PERSON has the best fastball/breaking ball combination of any left-handed starter in GPE's farm system. He deals at 91-95 mph with ground-ball-inducing sink on his heater and pairs it with a hard curveball. He also shows promising feel for his changeup.PERSON has a compact delivery and repeats it easily. He's making strides with his control but will need to refine his command to succeed against more advanced hitters. He projects as a possible No. 4 starter and perhaps more than that if his stuff continues to improve.

Signed for $100,000 out of the ORGANIZATION in 2013, PERSON spent his first two seasons in the Rookie-level ORGANIZATION and began his next two in the short-season LOCATION. He made the jump to full-season ball last July, making eight starts before getting shut down with a strained oblique. He made just three starts in 2018 before going down with an elbow injury that required PERSON surgery.Prior to getting hurt, PERSON showed signs of developing a plus fastball and curveball, though both offerings need more consistency. He worked at 92-94 mph and tops out at 96 mph with good sink on his heater and his curveball featured power and depth. His changeup had its moments too, though it wasn't as effective as his top two pitches.PERSON has a very compact delivery and is learning to repeat it efficiently. He should have at least average control but his command isn't yet as advanced, so he's more hittable than a lefty who can provide three solid pitches should be. If he can return to health and make the necessary refinements, he could be a No. 3 starter.

The athletic and projectable PERSON was a multi-sport star at ORGANIZATION (Va.) High, where he played football, basketball and golf to go along with his exploits on the diamond. However, the right-hander didn't see his ORGANIZATION stock take off until his senior campaign, when he went 7-0 and posted a 0.78 ERA. Having already selected pitchers with three of their first four picks, the GPE drafted PERSON, an LOCATION commit, in the fourth round and signed him for slightly more than pick value at $500,000.PERSON typically works in the 88-91 mph range with his heater and touches 93, but scouts believe more velocity will come as the right-hander adds strength to his lean, 6-foot-4 frame. He features a low-80s slider that flashes above average, as well as a raw, work-in-progress changeup that will need to be developed in the professional ranks.PERSON's secondary pitches lag behind his fastball, but with time on his side and plenty of physical projection remaining, the right-hander gives the GPE plenty on which to dream.

A four-sport standout during his time at ORGANIZATION (Va.) High, PERSON blossomed on the mound as a senior before going to the GPE in the fourth round of the 2016 Draft. He signed for slightly above slot value, forgoing his commitment to GPE. While a minor back injury prompted the GPE to delay his pro debut until 2017, PERSON showed no ill effects as he posted a 2.75 ERA, second among GPE farmhands, in the ORGANIZATION York-Penn League. He built upon that progress at ORGANIZATION A Delmarva in his first full season, finishing among the top five in the circuit in both ERA (2.86) and innings pitched (132). PERSON compensates for his lack of a true plus offering by demonstrating advanced feel for his craft. His arsenal is centered on a bowling-ball fastball that registers at 91-94 mph with exceptional late sinking action that has helped him to record ground-ball rates of 58 and 55 percent in his first two seasons, respectively. PERSON's low-80s slider flashes above average, and he has good feel for locating, and he rounds out his arsenal with a changeup that plays nicely off his fastball and has average potential. Everything he throws plays up on account of his advanced pitchability and command.Tall and athletic with projection remaining, PERSON has a smooth delivery, clean arm action and uses his height to his advantage, consistently creating angle to the plate. He has all the ingredients to stick in the rotation and possesses a blend of stuff, feel and durability that point to a future as a No. 4 starter.

The athletic and projectable PERSON was a multi-sport star at ORGANIZATION (Va.) High, where he played football, basketball and golf to go along with his exploits on the diamond. However, the right-hander didn't see his ORGANIZATION stock take off until his senior campaign, when he went 7-0 and posted a 0.78 ERA. Having already selected pitchers with three of their first four picks, the GPE drafted PERSON, an LOCATION commit, in the fourth round and signed him for slightly more than pick value at $500,000.PERSON typically works in the 88-91 mph range with his heater and touches 93, but scouts believe more velocity will come as the right-hander adds strength to his lean, 6-foot-5 frame. He features a low-80s slider that flashes above average, as well as a raw, work-in-progress changeup that will need to be developed in the professional ranks.PERSON's secondary pitches lag behind his fastball, but with time on his side and plenty of physical projection remaining, the right-hander gives the GPE plenty on which to dream.

PERSON was the definition of a multi-sport standout as a prep, playing baseball, football, basketball and golf at ORGANIZATION (Va.) High. He came into his own on the mound during his senior year, and the GPE made him their fourth-round PERSON pick that June, giving PERSON a slightly above-slot bonus of $500,000 to forego his GPE commitment. After having his pro debut pushed back to 2017 to account for a back injury, PERSON impressed when he finally took the mound in the Class A Short PERSON York-Penn League by posting a 2.75 ERA that ranked second among GPE farmhands. PERSON can bump 94 mph with his heavy fastball but usually sits in the 88-92 mph range. He knows how to use his height to create plane to the plate, while the nearly 58 percent ground-ball rate he posted in 2017 speaks to the overall effectiveness of his sinker. A low-80s slider that flashes above average and fringy changeup comprises PERSON's secondary arsenal, and everything he throws plays up on account of his advanced pitchability and command.Scouts believe PERSON's velocity will tick up as he adds strength to his lean, 6-foot-5 frame. His smooth delivery and clean arm action lend credence to that thought, giving the young righty a solid foundation to start long term. It's a likely No. 4- or 5-starter profile at maturity, though PERSON could very well surpass that projection with improved velocity and better feel for his secondaries.

For the second time in six GPE, scouts flocked to see a left-hander at GPE (Ill.) High. PERSON landed late third-round money ($426,000) after dropping to the 15th round because he needed PERSON surgery. PERSON, the top prospect in the state of GPE, didn't come off the board as high as PERSON, though he did receive a larger bonus ($500,000) as the ORGANIZATION' fourth-round pick.PERSON usually operates at 88-91 mph and tops out at 93 with his fastball. He commands it well, generates some armside run and should have a plus heater once his 6-foot-4 frame adds muscle. He does a good job of selling his fading changeup, which shows signs of becoming a plus pitch.PERSON exhibits much more feel for his changeup than his slurvy breaking ball. It's more of a soft curveball at this point, and he may be better off working with a harder slider in the future. More strong than athletic, he repeats his delivery and lives in the strike zone.

GPE of a GPE (Calif.) High program that has spawned 15 big leaguers as well as Phillies shortstop prospect J.P. Crawford, PERSON missed all of his senior season in 2015 after breaking his left wrist in a golf-cart mishap. Because they liked what they had seen of him on the showcase circuit, the ORGANIZATION selected him in the fifth round and paid him second-round money ($918,600). He spent most of his first two full seasons in low Class A, earning a promotion to high Class A in late July -- a week before the ORGANIZATION landed him as part of a three-prospect package for PERSON Darvish.PERSON offers both a high ceiling and a low floor. He already shows some bat speed and feel for hitting, with the promise of more once he packs some much-needed strength onto his skinny 6-foot-4 frame. He also has an overly aggressive approach at the plate and won't translate his upside into production unless he becomes more disciplined. PERSON than most shortstops, PERSON has fringy speed and lacks the quickness typical of the position. He made 20 errors in 80 games at shortstop last year, looking more comfortable at third base. His range is better suited for the hot corner, where he has the hands and arm to become a solid defender, and he has also seen extensive action at second base this year.

GPE of a GPE (Calif.) High pipeline that has produced 15 big leaguers (including PERSON d'Arnaud and PERSON) and has another on the way in top Phillies prospect J.P. Crawford, PERSON missed his entire senior season after breaking his left wrist in a golf-cart accident. The ORGANIZATION had seen enough of him on the showcase circuit the previous summer to take him in the fifth round last June and sign him for $918,600 -- $605,000 over the assigned value for his No. 162 slot.PERSON is one of the most dynamic and projectable athletes in the system. He has good feel for hitting and a lot of leverage in his skinny 6-foot-4 frame. He has average bat speed and raw power and should develop more once he adds some much-needed strength. He already has added 15 pounds since turning pro.Though PERSON has below-average speed and lacks typical middle-infield quickness, GPE believes he has a chance to play shortstop after stationing him there in his pro debut. He has good hands and instincts and he makes strong, accurate throws. If he can't make it at shortstop, he'd profile well at third base and has seen time there in 2016.

PERSON is the latest phenom from GPE (Calif.) High, which has produced 15 big leaguers (including PERSON d'Arnaud and PERSON) and has another on the way in stud Phillies shortstop prospect J.P. Crawford. PERSON missed his entire senior season after breaking his left wrist in a golf-cart accident, but the ORGANIZATION still took him in the fifth round in June and signed him for $918,600 ($605,000 over the assigned value for his No. 162 slot).PERSON pairs feel for hitting with average bat speed, and he could develop into a power threat once he adds some much-needed strength to his 6-foot-4, 155-pound frame. Though he's a below-average runner, he does exhibit good instincts on the bases.While GPE had PERSON begin his pro career as a shortstop, he'll likely move to third base in the future. He lacks the quickness for the middle of the infield but would fit nicely at the hot corner. He has solid arm strength and makes accurate throws.

PERSON was an exciting, if a bit enigmatic, high school right-hander on the showcase circuit over the summer, one who showed glimpses of plus stuff and athleticism while struggling with consistency and command at times. As the spring wore on, PERSON was trending upward, with an impressive complete-game shutout for ORGANIZATION in front of a lot of scouts at ORGANIZATION's ORGANIZATION in early April really helping his stock.The LOCATION native who moved to ORGANIZATION for his senior year of high school has the makings of four solid pitches and improved consistency in using them throughout a start. He regularly runs his fastball up to 96 mph and has shown an ability to maintain that velocity deeper into starts this spring. He now features two distinct breaking pitches, with a plus slider a big reason for his step forward. It's a true out pitch and it's better than his average curve, which is a bigger 11-to-5 breaker when he maintains his high three-quarter arm slot. He has feel for his changeup, though he can slow his arm a bit on it at times.After starting the spring looking like the thrower he was over the summer, he's made strides toward being a more complete pitcher with improved command. Given his athleticism and easy arm action, it's easy to see him as a future right-handed power starting pitcher.

PERSON helped lead PERSON (PERSON, Ariz.) to the ORGANIZATION 6-A state basketball title in 2017, where he was named his region's defensive player of the year. He gave up hoops after a strong performance at the ORGANIZATION Games that summer convinced him he had a brighter future in baseball. PERSON agreed, drafting him in the second round this June and signing him for $1.1 million.PERSON' signature tool is plus-plus speed that could make him a devastating basestealer and quality center fielder once he improves his reads and instincts. It's also easy to dream on his power, because he has bat speed and an extremely projectable frame with long levers. His solid arm strength is better than most at his position.While he has a huge ceiling, PERSON also will need plenty of time to develop. He has improved his right-handed swing, but he still has more adjustments to make and also must hone his pitch recognition and plate discipline. The amount of progress he has made since focusing on baseball leads to optimism that he'll figure things out offensively.

PERSON starred in basketball, helping PERSON (PERSON, Ariz.) win the 2017 GPE 6-A state basketball championship while earning region defensive player of the year honors. He gave up hoops, however, after performing well at the ORGANIZATION Games that summer and deciding he had a brighter future in baseball. One of the best athletes in the 2018 Draft, he battled hamstring injuries during his senior season but still went in the second round and signed for $1.1 million.PERSON already has made improvements to his right-handed swing and has performed well in Class A, showing the tools to become a 30-30 player if he hits. With his bat speed and the leverage and projectable strength in his 6-foot-4 frame, he can punish the ball when he connects. He's also a well above-average runner who should wreak havoc on the bases once he hones his instincts.With his quickness, PERSON should have little trouble staying in center field, though he still needs to refine his reads and routes. His solid arm strength gives him the ability to play all three outfield spots if needed. He has made significant progress since committing to baseball and the ORGANIZATION believe he'll continue to improve.

As a 19-year-old high school senior, PERSON was considered "old" for his GPE class and fell out of first-round consideration for some teams as a result. The ORGANIZATION were not one of them, as they selected the ORGANIZATION recruit with the ORGANIZATION. 12 pick in June after he led all prep players with 19 home runs while also batting .615 with 50 RBIs, 44 walks and nine strikeouts in 37 games as a FACILITY HS (PERSON, GPE) senior. His selection marked the first time that the ORGANIZATION had taken a third baseman in the first round since PERSON in 2001.PERSON's raw power was among the best in the 2019 GPE, the product of bat speed, strength and loft in his left-handed swing. He's more of an advanced hitter than just a pure masher, one who makes repeated hard contact, isn't fooled by breaking pitches and doesn't get caught selling out for power. It all points to a high offensive ceiling for PERSON, who projects as an above-average hitter who could develop plus game power.Though he clocks below-average running times, PERSON is a better athlete than his lack of speed might indicate. He played basketball at FACILITY and could remain a third baseman if he improves his agility and maintains the conditioning on his big frame. There's no question about his arm because he has registered fastballs up to 92 mph off the mound.

PERSON entered last summer as perhaps the top player in the entire class, and certainly among the high school set. A combination of a relatively pedestrian summer showcase performance and an extremely high expectation bar, a trend that continued for him in the spring, caused his star to fade. He was still viewed as one of the better prep players in the nation heading into the 2018 Draft, and the ORGANIZATION were pleased to find PERSON still on the board for them with the ORGANIZATION. 21 pick. Despite concerns about PERSON's signability as an ORGANIZATION commit, the ORGANIZATION were able to ink him for $3,411,100 during the week before the signing deadline. PERSON does everything fairly well, though a lack of a true plus carrying tool is one reason why scouts were a bit down on him. Most feel he has the chance to be a plus hitter with an advanced approach at the plate using a high-contact, line-drive spray kind of approach. With a lean frame, there is some question about how much strength he'll add, with believers thinking power will come. Most feel he is a long-term shortstop, though some don't see it as a slam dunk.Some feel PERSON was hurt more from being seen for so long that he was bound to get knocked simply for not being the best player on the field at all times. Others haven't seen him dominate the way they feel a top-of-the-Draft prospect should in high school.

The ORGANIZATION didn't expect PERSON to still be on the board when they made their first pick well into the first round of the 2018 Draft. But after a senior year during which evaluators had soured on him a bit, even though he previously was viewed as one of the top prep players in the country, PERSON was still available for PERSON with the ORGANIZATION. 21 overall pick. Despite concerns about his signability as an ORGANIZATION commit, the ORGANIZATION were able to ink PERSON for $3,411,100 during the week before the signing deadline. He rewarded the club for their risk by reaching the ORGANIZATION during an impressive pro debut. PERSON does everything fairly well and could have four average-or-better tools once he's fully developed. He has the chance to be a plus hitter with an advanced approach at the plate, using a high-contact, line-drive spray approach. With a lean frame, there is some question about how much strength he'll add, and whether he'll offer anything more than below-average game power. PERSON's plus speed is his strongest tool, and he isn't shy about putting it to use on the basepaths. He has the athleticism, hands and arm strength needed to stick as a shortstop. The son of former big league outfielder PERSON, GPE is more advanced and polished than the typical high school pick and could move through the Minors relatively faster than his peers. He has the upside of an everyday shortstop who hits for average, swipes some bags and plays solid if unspectacular defense at a premium position.

PERSON was an under-the-radar international signing in the summer of 2014, one who pitched sparingly in the ORGANIZATION in 2015. He was set to make his GPE debut in 2016, but an elbow injury that required PERSON surgery put that off until 2017, but he was back impressing in the ORGANIZATION this summer.The Twins think the teenager has the chance to be a starter long-term. He has a premium fastball, one that has improved considerably since he's signed. He'll sit in the 95-98 mph range and can occasionally touch triple digits. He features two breaking balls that both have the chance to be better than average, an 86-87 mph slider and a curve he throws in the 80-82 mph range. He has a changeup, but it's not a real weapon at this point.PERSON's command and control are a work in progress, unsurprising given his age and his proximity to elbow surgery. As he puts that further in his rearview mirror, he might have the highest ceiling of any arm in the system.

The Twins have had their fair share of large international expenditures, like PERSON and current shortstop prospect PERSON. Then there have been smaller signings, like PERSON, who got just $150,000. After missing the 2016 season due to PERSON surgery, PERSON had a breakout GPE debut in 2017, finishing with a strong outing in the GPE League playoffs and putting him firmly on the prospect map.PERSON has exciting raw stuff that was clearly too much for Rookie-level hitters. His fastball now sits at 95-98 mph and he can touch triple digits. He throws two distinct breaking balls and both are viable weapons, with his slider having the chance to be a wipe out plus pitch down the road. His changeup is behind those two secondary offerings, but he has a feel for it and it could be PERSON average in time.PERSON has definitely been control over command, with his pure stuff helping mask any issues in that regard at the lower levels. But the Twins are very encouraged with the strike-throwing strides he made in 2017 and feel he could climb the ranks as one of the better pitching prospects in baseball as he ascends through the organization.

After signing in the summer of 2014 for just $150,000, PERSON pitched sparingly in the ORGANIZATION League the following year, then missed all of 2016 because of PERSON surgery. He eased his way back with a solid performance across two rookie levels in 2017, then really jumped on the prospect radar by excelling at two levels of full-season ball, topping 100 innings for the first time and helping ORGANIZATION Myers win the ORGANIZATION State League title in 2018.PERSON's stuff continues to get better the more he matures and the further removed from surgery he gets. His fastball touches triple digits and will often sit in the 96-98 mph range, with an ability to maintain velocity deep into starts. Throwing with plenty of sink, PERSON misses bats and gets a ton of ground-ball outs off of his fastball. When he committed to throw the harder version of his slider, in the 87-89 mph range, it trended toward plus, but he would back off of it at times. GPE (Ill.) PERSON graduated the tallest man in recorded history (PERSON, who grew to 8-foot-11) in 1936, and 79 years later it produced a towering pitcher. He has tremendous athleticism and coordination for a still-growing pitcher his size, so his control and command should be fine despite some struggles in those areas this summer.

The best Illinois high school pitching prospect since the ORGANIZATION took PERSON in the first round in 2010, PERSON went in the third round in June and signed for $1.1 million. With his arm action, athleticism and projection, he could regularly work in the mid-90s in the future. He has the beginnings of a changeup but didn't need it much in high school and doesn't trust the pitch.

GPE' best high school pitching prospect since the ORGANIZATION made PERSON a first-round pick in 2010, GPE signed for $1.1 million as a third-rounder in 2015. He's a product of GPE (Ill.) High, which graduated the tallest man in recorded history (8-foot-11 PERSON) in 1936, and GPE towers over most players at 6-foot-8. He has good athleticism and body control for his size, so he's equipped to figure out his delivery and improve his control and command. His ceiling remains sky-high, though it may take him longer to develop than initially expected.

PERSON expected to sign with the Brewers at the start of the 2015 international signing period that July, but a groin injury squashed that deal and he wound up joining the ORGANIZATION for $25,000 six months later. After displaying advanced pitchability in the past, he saw his walk rate jump from 3.0 per nine innings in 2017 to 7.3 last year, but he's back to throwing strikes. He has the upside of a mid-rotation starter.

Though he was eligible to sign out of GPE in July 2015, PERSON had to wait six months before the ORGANIZATION offered him a $25,000 bonus. PERSON was eligible to sign out of GPE in July 2015 but didn't find any takers until the ORGANIZATION offered him a $25,000 bonus six months later. A part-time starter as an GPE freshman in 2017, PERSON exploded as a sophomore. PERSON, a ORGANIZATION high school product signed away from going to Vanderbilt by the Cardinals in the second round of the 2015 Draft, really struggled during his pro debut in the ORGANIZATION. The ORGANIZATION went high school heavy at the start of the 2015 Draft, using their first three selections for three from the prep ranks. He has more than enough strength to drive the ball the other way and when he stays up the middle, he makes hard contact. PERSON pitch selection and strike zone knowledge will help as well. He would profile well from an outfield corner should a move be necessary.For now, the ORGANIZATION will let PERSON stay at third and see if he can make progress. Either way, it's his bat that will eventually push him up the organizational ladder.

The second of four accomplished hitters the ORGANIZATION selected in the first four rounds of the 2015 Draft, PERSON went 66th overall and signed for $1.2 million. He doesn't have the quickness for the hot corner, and his footwork and throwing accuracy need a lot of work.

GPE shortstops with solid all-around tools aren't always easy to find in any Draft class. That's why PERSON, who looks and plays a lot like ORGANIZATION shortstop PERSON, was high on lists entering this spring. Even when he's off-balance, he keeps his hands back and shoots the ball the other way to left field. And while he'll never sell out his hit tool for power, he'll show pop in batting practice and it's easy to dream on 15-18 homers annually at the next level.While PERSON does show off a plus arm at times, the one area there's a split camp might be his ability to play shortstop in the big leagues. A quarterback recruited by LOCATION football programs, PERSON totaled 3,860 yards and 43 touchdowns while leading McGill-Toolen High to the GPE state 7-A championship game in the fall of 2016. He has impressive hand-eye coordination and bat speed from the right side of the plate, though he's still working on pitch recognition and plate discipline and lost some needed development time in 2019 to a broken hamate and an ankle injury. He's starting to drive the ball more consistently and could produce 25 or more homers annually as he gets stronger.PERSON's most obvious tool is his well-above-average speed and he shows the aptitude to become a premium basestealer. His reads and jumps are less polished in center field, though he has the quickness to outrun a lot of his mistakes and should get better with more experience. His solid arm strength fits anywhere in the outfield.

PERSON quarterbacked McGill-Toolen High to the GPE state 7-A championship game in the fall of 2016, totaling 3,860 yards and 43 touchdowns while drawing football scholarship offers from GPE and GPE. He committed to GPE for baseball only, but that didn't matter after he played his way into 2017's first round and signed for a slightly under-slot $2.1 million as the ORGANIZATION. 26 overall selection. Though he was bothered by tendinitis in his knees during his pro debut, his upside was apparent.For an athlete who divided his attention between multiple sports, PERSON isn't nearly as raw as might be expected. His impressive hand-eye coordination should allow him to make consistent contact from the right side of the plate, and his pitch recognition and selectivity are surprising considering his inexperience. PERSON entered his senior season unsure about his power potential, but he began to drive the ball more consistently and has the bat speed and strength for average pop. PERSON's well above-average speed and his strong arm can make him a quality defender anywhere in the outfield. He's still learning as a basestealer and needs to upgrade his reads and routes in center field. The ORGANIZATION are known for their ability to polish high-ceiling prospects, and he could be a 20-20 up-the-middle player when fully developed.

A star quarterback, PERSON totaled 3,860 yards and 43 touchdowns as a senior while leading McGill-Toolen High to the GPE state 7-A championship game. PERSON and PERSON offered him football scholarships and several colleges wanted him to play two sports, though he committed to GPE for baseball only in February. That didn't matter because he played his way into the first round and signed for $2.1 million as the ORGANIZATION. 26 overall choice.Unlike many athletes who have divided their time between two sports, PERSON doesn't look raw on the diamond. He has good feel for the barrel and the bat speed to do damage from the right side of the plate. PERSON entered the spring unsure of his power potential, but he began to drive the ball more frequently and now projects to hit 15 or more homers per season.PERSON's well above-average speed and strong arm make him an asset anywhere in the outfield. While he's still refining his reads and routes in center field, he's a lock to remain there. The ORGANIZATION do a nice job of finding and developing high-ceiling athletes, and he definitely fits that mold.

When the D-backs took ORGANIZATION in the fifth round in 2017, they made him the first player to be drafted out of GPE (N.J.) High since PERSON in 2009. PERSON signed for $500,000, forgoing his commitment to GPE, then showcased innate feel for squaring up the baseball during his pro debut. That continued for him in 2018 with a move up to the ORGANIZATION, where PERSON produced a .327/.396/.465 line and garnered honors as a mid-season All-Star. PERSON may be stocky and lacking in physical projection, but there is plenty to like about his offensive profile. His quick bat and excellent control of the barrel enable him to make consistent line-drive contact from the right side, where he covers the plate well and shows a discerning eye. Those qualities should help him succeed at higher levels and, in general, give him the upside of an above-average hitter who's capable of hitting 15-plus homers and reaching base at a high clip. A better athlete than his stout frame suggests, PERSON is an average runner with good instincts on both sides of the ball. He impressed club officials last year with his improvements at third base, and he'll likely add more positions to his resume going forward as the D-backs look to increase his versatility.

PERSON was well known within scouting circles entering his senior season at ORGANIZATION (Ala.) High, but the difference between his present stuff and his projection was wide enough that he was expected to continue his career at ORGANIZATION rather than turn pro. The industry's perception of PERSON changed quickly when he showed better velocity in the spring, and he vaulted up teams' Draft boards as a result. In the end, it was the Brewers who secured the rights to the young right-hander's promising future, signing him for $1.45 million after selecting him in the second round. After topping out at 91 mph with his fastball on the summer showcase circuit, PERSON operated at 90-93 mph as a senior and touched 97, while also impressing scouts with his ability to create leverage to the plate using his 6-foot-6 frame. In terms of secondaries, PERSON' slider shows more potential than his curveball, and he'll flash a changeup as well. PERSON, like so many young pitchers, struggles to repeat his arm slot, making it difficult for him to stay on top of his breaking pitches and control his entire arsenal. He should gain better feel for his mechanics as he begins to fill in to his slender frame.

PERSON was a known quantity entering his senior season at ORGANIZATION (Ala.) High, but the difference between his present stuff and his projection was wide enough that he figured to continue his career in college at ORGANIZATION. That changed during the spring, as his velocity soared and caused his ORGANIZATION stock to do the same, leading to his selection in the third round by Milwaukee.As a regular on the showcase circuit, PERSON topped out at 91 mph with his fastball. This spring, his heater sat at 90-93 mph and climbed as high as 97. His 6-foot-6 frame and low three-quarters delivery create difficult angle and sink, increasing his fastball's effectiveness.PERSON struggles to repeat his arm slot, which makes it difficult for him to stay on top of his breaking pitches and control his entire arsenal. His slider shows more potential than his curveball, and he'll flash a changeup as well. Packing more strength onto his slender frame would help him maintain his mechanics better while theoretically adding even more power to his fastball.

PERSON PERSON in GPE is a powerhouse that has produced a number of big leaguers, most recently ORGANIZATION slugger PERSON, and the school is also known as the school where PERSON's son played his high school football. GPE, a 2015 graduate of the school, might not add that kind of cool factor, but after three years at FACILITY State that included a ORGANIZATION World Series title in 2018, GPE is ready to see if he can join his high school's predecessors as a big league middle infielder after signing with PERSON for $1.8 million as the ORGANIZATION. 37 overall pick. As a three-year starter with the ORGANIZATION, GPE established himself as one of the best defensive shortstops in the college game. There is no doubt he can stay at the premium position long-term, with an outstanding internal clock, good hands and above-average speed. He has excellent range and more than enough arm to make throws from anywhere on the infield. The bigger question is about his offensive game. GPE put up better numbers as a junior, albeit without much hard contact. He does have bat speed and a little pop to his pull side, but he tends to be off-balance often when he swings.At worst, GPE has a career as a defensive-minded utilityman ahead of him, with the upside of being a glove-first regular at shortstop. The ORGANIZATION believe there's enough bat there for him to grow into the latter role.

A product of prep baseball powerhouse PERSON in GPE, GPE honored his commitment to PERSON rather than sign with the Cardinals as their 21st-round pick in the 2015 Draft. He was a three-year starter for the ORGANIZATION and helped lead the program to a ORGANIZATION World Series title in 2018, when he won the ORGANIZATION as college baseball's top shortstop. The ORGANIZATION made GPE the ORGANIZATION. 37 overall pick that June, signed him for $1.8 million and then sent him straight to Class A Delmarva for his professional debut. GPE is a gifted defender at shortstop, with the range, actions and arm strength, as well as the soft hands and outstanding internal clock, needed to stay at the position long-term. There are questions about GPE's bat, though, and he didn't assuage any concerns by hitting .216 with an elevated strikeout rate in his pro debut. That said, he does have bat speed and a little pop to his pull side, with solid understanding of the strike zone. The ORGANIZATION believe GPE's emphasis on making contact early in the count instilled an element of panic in his swing, and they worked with him in during hitter mini camps in the fall on developing a better foundation to hit. At worst, GPE has a career as a defensive-minded utilityman ahead of him, with the upside of being a glove-first regular at shortstop. The ORGANIZATION believe there's enough bat there for him to grow into the latter role.

Hailing from the baseball powerhouse PERSON in the ORGANIZATION area, ORGANIZATION entered his senior season as one of the better pure bats in the prep class. He struggled that spring and slid to the second round of the 2017 Draft. While he definitely hit the proverbial wall during his first full season of pro ball, overall he's looked very much like the advanced bat the ORGANIZATION hoped was still in there when they selected him.A LOCATION League All-Star in 2018, ORGANIZATION has an innate ability to barrel the ball in the strike zone, with an approach that gives him the chance to be a plus hitter in the future. The ORGANIZATION would like to see him impact the ball a bit more, and while some power did show up in his first full year, there might be more in there with a high percentage of line drives and fly balls a good indicator of what's to come in the future as he gets stronger. Added strength and better knowledge of what it takes to play a full season should help ORGANIZATION offset the fatigue he felt at the end of '18.The bat is going to have to play because of his fringe-average defense. Both his speed and his arm are scraping average, meaning he's likely destined for left (though right field would be a fit in ORGANIZATION). The good news is it looks like his offensive profile should fit just fine for an outfield corner spot.

The last PERSON catcher to make it to the big leagues was PERSON. While the Mariners don't expect PERSON, taken in the third round of the 2018 Draft after a solid offensive junior season with the GPE, to reach that All-Star level, his very strong pro debut on both sides of the ball have them encouraged about his potential.PERSON has some baseball bloodlines, with a dad who played and coached college ball and an uncle with a long professional resume. It shows in his advanced approach at the plate, with the ability to control the strike zone enough to tap into his considerable raw power from both sides of the plate. He entered pro ball with a reputation as an offensive-minded backstop and though his bat is ahead of his glove, the Mariners were pleasantly surprised with his defensive tools, particularly his framing and game-calling, not to mention excellent leadership skills.The one part of his defensive game that's behind is his arm, but PERSON was on a throwing program during the offseason and worked on using his lower half more. If that part of his game improves, he has the chance to join PERSON as a big league regular behind the plate.

PERSON comes from a baseball family, with a father and uncle who both played at LOCATION. His dad went on to coach at his alma mater and at ORGANIZATION, while his uncle spent 10 years in the ORGANIZATION. The younger PERSON jumped on the map as a freshman at ORGANIZATION, scuffled as a sophomore, but bounced back with a strong junior season, hitting 13 home runs and while pacing the ORGANIZATION in batting (.326), hits (75), ORGANIZATION (54) and slugging (.583). A dearth of college catchers further pushed him up teams' Draft boards, and the ORGANIZATION were pleased to find him available ahead of their third-round pick. The switch-hitting backstop swung the bat well in the second half of his junior season, using an advanced approach at the plate to hit for average and power while drawing a ton of walks. It's a power-over-hit profile from both sides of the plate, though some question whether PERSON will hit enough at the next level to tap consistently into that raw pop. His defensive game, however, lags behind his bat. The big-bodied catcher lacks agility behind the plate, with blocking, receiving and catch-and-throw skills that leave something to be desired. PERSON catching is always hard to find, and PERSON did it for three years at ORGANIZATION. His bat is his calling card to the ORGANIZATION and gives him a chance to develop into a offensive-minded backstop if can also make gains on the other side of the ball.

No one roots for a high school player to struggle, especially not in his Draft year. But sometimes such adversity can work to a team's advantage. Case in point is PERSON, who entered his senior year at powerhouse PERSON in GPE as one of the best prep bats in the country. When he scuffled for a chunk of the season, his stock fell and the ORGANIZATION were thrilled he slipped far enough for them to grab him in the second round with the 50th overall pick in the 2017 Draft.PERSON did look more like the hitting prospect people thought he was during his pro debut in the ORGANIZATION. He has an advanced approach at the plate and drew a ton of walks, controlling the strike zone very well for his age, with the chance to be a Major League average, if not better, hitter from the left side of the plate. There is plenty of power to tap into, though trying to muscle up led to him being too pull happy in high school, one of the main reasons for his struggle. The ORGANIZATION tend to preach hit over power in the Minors, so that should be a good fit.The bat will have to play because he's an average defender with a fringy arm who is likely limited to left field as a pro. The good news is it looks like he's rediscovered his swing and should have the profile for an outfield corner spot in the future.

PERSON PERSON has produced some serious big league talent like PERSON and PERSON. PERSON entered the spring looking like the next in that line, but an uneven senior season hurt his stock, causing him to last until the 50th overall pick, where the ORGANIZATION signed him for full pick value.Over his impressive summer showcase circuit performance, PERSON looked like one of the best pure prep hitters in the class. A change in his approach this spring, perhaps to try to show more power, hurt his results. He was too pull-happy, while he was able to drive the ball to all fields previously. His bat is his carrying tool, as he is a fringy runner and an average defender in left field.PERSON's track record, rather than his senior season, is what the ORGANIZATION were banking on when they took him so early. He's now working to rediscover the approach that was so successful for him earlier in his amateur career.

A classic grinder who gets the most out of his tools, GPE improved in each of his three college seasons at ORGANIZATION. He earned all-star honors in the ORGANIZATION in 2018, a prelude to a breakout junior season in which he batted .397/.478/.651 and topped ORGANIZATION Division I with 29 doubles. PERSON's first pick (second round) in the 2019 Draft, he signed for $1.3 million as the 43rd overall choice.GPE's strong suit is his ability to make consistent line-drive contact from the right side of the plate. He manages the strike zone well and has developed reliable gap power with the potential for perhaps 15-20 homers per season if he turned his swing loose more often. He shows average speed out of the batter's box and more quickness once he gets going, but he's not much of a threat to steal.GPE played both second base and shortstop for the ORGANIZATION and spent most of his time on the Cape at third base. Though PERSON deployed him at shortstop at the beginning of his pro career, he's best suited for second base because his arm strength is merely average. He has reliable hands and his overall game has drawn some comparisons to GPE Dozier's.

PERSON has emerged as one of the more intriguing pure arms in the ORGANIZATION' system since signing for $100,000 out of the ORGANIZATION in October 2015. He has added significant velocity as a pro and averaged 14.2 strikeouts per nine innings in GPE ball during his GPE debut last year. He has continued to miss bats at a high rate while making the jump to full-season ball in '18.PERSON's fastball can be unhittable at times, usually ranging from 92-97 mph and topping out at 99 mph. Besides its velocity, his heater also stands out for its natural life, cutting and running to either side of the plate. PERSON depends heavily on his fastball because his slider is still a work in progress.Used exclusively as a reliever, PERSON has a fastball suited for high-leverage situations, but also will require a lot of development. In addition to refining his slider, he also needs to improve his control and command. While he has impressive arm speed, he also has a lot of effort in his delivery and that impedes his ability to provide consistent strikes.

Opponents pitched around PERSON so much during his 2017 senior season at ORGANIZATION (ORGANIZATION, GPE) that he drew 57 walks, the ninth-highest total in prep history. The first position player drafted by the ORGANIZATION last June, he signed for a slightly over-slot $497,500 in the fourth round. He led the Rookie-level Gulf Coast League with 46 free passes in his pro debut, then stumbled in his 2018 encore before getting back on track in low Class A this year.PERSON has the bat speed, strength and discipline to hit for power and average from the left side of the plate. He struggled last year when he got away from his approach, but he's thriving now that he has regained his patience and is driving the ball to all fields. Unlike some prospects who pile up walks, he's not overly passive and looks to do damage when he gets a pitch to hit.A quarterback in high school, PERSON has a stocky build with deceptive athleticism. He shows fringy speed out of the batter's box but is an average runner underway. With solid arm strength, he's capable of playing either outfield corner and did some catching in high school.

PERSON was one of the better hitters in his GPE class as a GPE prep star in 2016, but concerns about his size and his lack of an obvious defensive home, on top of his strong commitment to GPE, caused him to fall to the ORGANIZATION in the 20th round. The ORGANIZATION took him in the third round two years later as a GPE-eligible sophomore, after PERSON had hit 27 home runs with a .378 OBP in two seasons with the ORGANIZATION, and signed him for a little more than $1 million. PERSON, if any, scouts, question PERSON' ability to hit. He has an innate knack for barreling the ball up from the left side and a long track record of doing it against quality competition. PERSON is listed at 5-foot-7, but he has above-average raw power and gets to it in games because his barrel control is exceptional. His frame is a bit thick, however, and PERSON has below-average speed. After manning left field in college, PERSON spent his professional debut at second base, showing fringy range but solid hands and instincts, as well as adequate arm strength. The ORGANIZATION think he can become a passable defender there -- at least good enough so any defensive shortcomings don't detract from his power-over-hit, bat-first profile.

Most of the international signings that make a splash involve six or seven figures and a 16-year-old with a ridiculous ceiling. PERSON has the ceiling right, but he signed at age 19 and received just $15,000 to sign in July 2016 out of GPE. His 2017 pro debut in the GPE League was up-and-down, but he started showing why the Royals are excited about him with a move to full-season ball in 2018, though his season was delayed by a death in the family early and cut short by some fatigue at the end of the summer. â¢ 7/10: PERSON returns in rehab startUndrafted out of high school, PERSON honored his commitment to ORGANIZATION and blossomed into one of the top college pitchers in the nation. PERSON PERSON became the ORGANIZATION. 1 overall pick in the 2017 Draft as a shortstop at ORGANIZATION (PERSON, GPE), but the year before he played second base in deference to PERSON. GPE and raised in the GPE, GPE went to high school in GPE for several years before moving to GPE for his senior campaign in 2016. The ORGANIZATION were excited about PERSON's upside and feel for pitching when they went above slot to sign him in the fourth round of the 2016 Draft out of the Miami-area high school ranks. GPE opened many eyes before the 2016 Draft with a strong performance in the GPE state high school All-Star game, helping convince the ORGANIZATION to not only take the Miami-area right-hander in the fourth round, but to give him a well-above pick value bonus of $850,000 to sign. GPE development people know better than to get too fired up about a high school draftee after just 11 1/3 innings of professional work, so the ORGANIZATION are trying hard to temper their enthusiasm for PERSON, their fourth-round selection from the ORGANIZATION high school ranks last June. The ORGANIZATION went to LOCATION (Winter Garden, Fla.) for infielders in consecutive Drafts, taking PERSON in the third round in 2016 and PERSON in the first round last year. PERSON is the highest Draft pick ever out of GPE PERSON (Winter Garden, Fla.), which has produced a pair of big leaguers in GPE Fontana and PERSON as well as ORGANIZATION 2016 third-rounder PERSON. PERSON reportedly had an agreement in place with the ORGANIZATION on a $2.1 million signing bonus well before the 2014 international period began, but the deal never came to fruition, which allowed the ORGANIZATION to land the then-17-year-old for $375,000. The best prospect to come out of ORGANIZATION (ORGANIZATION, Ga.), a program that has produced big leaguers PERSON and PERSON, and 2010 first-rounder PERSON, PERSON' speed and athleticism set him apart from most others in the 2019 Draft, and he was also viewed as one of the better prep hitters in the class. The ORGANIZATION not only have PERSON in their rotation, but also the next version of him coming through their system in GPE, who patterned his delivery after the four-time All-Star's and started earning comparisons to him in high school. Though he's athletic and repeats his delivery, his control and command are still works in progress. He walked 5.7 batters per nine innings in his first two pro seasons, and if he can pound the strike zone more efficiently once he returns to health, he could become a No. 2 starter.

GPE PERSON (ORGANIZATION, Fla.) has produced four quality prospects in the last three GPE, starting with PERSON third-round outfielder PERSON and GPE fourth-round left-hander PERSON in 2014. PERSON drew comparisons to PERSON but not the commensurate amount of GPE buzz as a GPE high school senior in 2018. PERSON's combination of hitting ability and athleticism were enticing, but his Draft status was clouded this spring by an injury to his non-throwing shoulder and his strong commitment to ORGANIZATION. The first athlete to win PERSON state PERSON of the ORGANIZATION in two states, PERSON transferred from PERSON (GPE, Colo.) to GPE (Calif.) PERSON in 2018. GPE's ORGANIZATION of the Year as a junior in 2017, PERSON transferred to GPE (Calif.) PERSON to face better competition and enhance his GPE profile for '18. PERSON missed most of his sophomore high school season in 2017 with a broken leg, then bounced back to play well in his next two years. PERSON was a teammate at ORGANIZATION in GPE with PERSON, who went from having PERSON surgery his senior year to becoming the top left-handed pitching prospect in the game. The best position prospect to come out of PERSON (GPE, Fla.) since PERSON, PERSON led the Eagles to their first-ever state championship this spring even though they lost ace PERSON to PERSON surgery. GPE of a Stoneman PERSON (GPE, Fla.) program that has produced big leaguers PERSON, PERSON and PERSON, PERSON led the ORGANIZATION to the ORGANIZATION 9-A state title and a No. 1 national ranking in 2016. The best position prospect to come out of PERSON (GPE, Fla.) since PERSON, PERSON led the ORGANIZATION to the state 9-A championship and a No. 1 national ranking in 2016. His bat speed and leverage in his right-handed swing could translate into 20-homer power once he adds strength. The son of former big leaguer PERSON, a pitcher who appeared in 49 games over parts of three seasons, PERSON showed scouts everything they wanted to see from him as a high school senior in 2016, but was widely believed to be difficult to sign given his strong commitment to GPE. He saw time at all three outfield positions in 2017. PERSON took a huge step forward at FACILITY (ORGANIZATION, GPE) last spring, though doubts regarding the GPE-commit senior's signability persisted leading up to the GPE. In 2018, he made a concerted effort to make more contact and utilized a shorter, less-fluid swing that in turn zapped both his raw and game power, as he followed up his 22-homer campaign by tallying 34 extra-base hits over 118 games in Class A Advanced. PERSON's above-average speed and strong instincts are qualifiers for him on the basepaths and in center field, and he has the arm strength -- he generated 90-mph fastballs off the mound in high school -- to play either corner spot. PERSON is the son of PERSON, one of four big league pitchers on GPE' 1983 College World Series championship club. The ORGANIZATION ended up taking him in the fifth round, and then surprised many when they signed him for pick value.Scouts praise PERSON's makeup, billing him as a grinder with tools. He dedicated himself to conditioning during the fall and winter and emerged as a significantly stronger and faster player. More of a gap-to-gap hitter at this point, he might develop average power when he starts turning on more pitches. Though he has the speed and instincts to play center field, PERSON deploys him in right field, where he has a strong arm that has delivered 90-mph fastballs off the mound.

The ORGANIZATION went high school heavy at the top of the 2017 Draft, taking a prep player with each of their first four picks. The outfielder is more power over hit at this point, with some strength and leverage in his right-handed swing. A solid athlete who runs fairly well, PERSON played center field in high school. He's likely to mostly play in an outfield corner as a pro, where his plus arm, not to mention his power profile, will play very well.

After giving up a potential future as a college football quarterback following his sophomore year, PERSON's baseball stock took off and he developed into one of the toolsier high school players in the 2017 Draft class. He was able to refine his mechanics during his senior season though, and was more consistent as a result, using the entire field and quieting concerns about his ability to hit enough to tap into that power.PERSON runs well, though he could lose a half-step as he fills out. A center fielder in high school, he played right in his one game in the field in the ORGANIZATION, where his plus arm would play extremely well. He'll get the chance to truly show what he can do in 2018.

H.B. PERSON in GPE has churned out more than its fair share of GPE talent, none more famous than ORGANIZATION of ORGANIZATION. He can defend in the outfield to go along with a plus arm that produced a fastball up to 93 mph as well as a decent curve on the mound as a prep.With his speed and power potential, PERSON has drawn comparisons to GPE outfielder PERSON as well as current PERSON, PERSON. The latest standout from ORGANIZATION (Tampa), which produced ORGANIZATION of ORGANIZATION and nine other big leaguers, PERSON was the first outfielder taken in the first round by the PERSON since PERSON in 2010. He can go get the ball in center field and use his quickness to chase down balls from gap to gap. From a physical standpoint, PERSON, with his 5-foot-10 frame, didn't jump off the page as a GPE prospect. Better known as a catcher, PERSON created a stir among scouts when he took the mound at a 2014 Area Code Games tryout and flashed a 97-mph fastball and a curveball with depth. He's more slugger than hitter right now, so he'll need to make adjustments to his approach to tap into his power on a consistent basis. His home run ceiling ranks among the best in GPE's system.PERSON has to learn a new position because he immediately converted from catcher to first base after turning pro. GPE (Ga.) PERSON in GPE last had a first-round pick come from its baseball program back in 2008 when PERSON was the GPE. 1 overall pick. Back in 2015, PERSON approached the Draft as one of the best pure hitters in the class, especially among the high school set. In his three full seasons of pro ball, he's had fairly extreme first-half/second-half splits, always taking a long time to get going, but posting a .279 second half average over those three years. When he's going well, as he did again in July and August in GPE last year, he has a good, quick bat from the left side of the plate with some pull power. Originally an infielder, the move to left field has been an adventure at times, but the ORGANIZATION feel he'll be an adequate defender.One problem is that PERSON has gotten caught in between what kind of hitter he is, starting out as a pure hitter, then changing his approach to tap into more power. The ORGANIZATION are hopeful that a new hitting program and instructor will help the still-young PERSON figure it out and find some consistency at the plate.

PERSON was thought of as one of the best pure high school hitters in the 2015 Draft class and wowing the ORGANIZATION in a workout cemented his place as the ORGANIZATION. 10 overall pick, nine spots after fellow PERSON alum PERSON went in 2008. PERSON rewarded the ORGANIZATION' faith in him by leading the ORGANIZATION in ORGANIZATION during his debut, though his development was slowed in 2016 with a shouler injury that forced him out of action for two months.It will be PERSON's bat that will get him to the big leagues, and it has the chance to be a special one. He has a very advanced approach at the plate, especially for his age, with outstanding plate discipline from the left side of the plate. He can hit the ball with authority to all fields and will hit for power, thanks to outstanding bat speed. That's the part of his game that needs the most work, but he should be capable enough in left for the long term.Assuming PERSON continues to adjust to life in the outfield well, his bat could push him up the ORGANIZATION' ladder fairly quickly.

It's been a little tough to get a true read on who PERSON is as a professional player ever since he was the ORGANIZATION. 10 overall pick in the 2015 Draft from the same GPE high school that produced former ORGANIZATION. 1 overall pick PERSON. He was thought to be the best pure prep hitter in that 2015 class and he hit like it during his summer debut in the ORGANIZATION.
