He did not take that with him for much of the 2018 season in GPE, though he was swinging the bat better in the second half of the season.The increased power output was by design, as PERSON changed his hitting philosophy, going from a middle-to-opposite field approach type of hitter to one who learned how to turn on pitches and pull them out of the park. While he still drew walks, his strikeout rate spiked and his average suffered, but learning to drive the ball to the right-center gap and out will serve him well as he tries to reincorporate his natural tendency to use all fields. PERSON is going to have to hit because he is limited to left field only. He won't ever be a ORGANIZATION, but he's worked to be adequate there.As a corner outfielder, his ability to hit and hit for power become that much more important. He didn't put up the big numbers some expected in GPE, but if he can put the two versions of himself together, he still has time to develop into a run-producing threat.

Taken No. 10 overall as perhaps the best pure high school bat in the 2015 Draft class, PERSON had a big debut that summer in the ORGANIZATION. He wasn't able to back it up with a move to full-season ball in 2016, with a shoulder injury knocking him out of action for two months and perhaps keeping him from tapping into his offensive potential.At times during his disappointing first full season, the ORGANIZATION saw what amateur scouts saw in PERSON in the ORGANIZATION high school ranks. He had a good feel to hit with a middle-opposite field approach while learning to pull and drive the ball more on the inner third of the plate and taking a fair share of walks. He has a strong, compact body that can lend itself to inflexibility, so he will have to continue to work on his conditioning. A young player who loves to hit, PERSON is beginning to understand the need to play on both sides of the ball, and the former infielder was more invested in his outfield play as the year went on. He has the chance to be an average defender.More than anything, the ORGANIZATION wanted to see a healthy PERSON in 2017. After a slow start, he started to show more of his offensive potential in the ORGANIZATION State League.

PERSON wasn't highly regarded coming out of the ORGANIZATION, signing for $10,000 in March 2015, 20 months after he first became eligible. The ORGANIZATION kept him in GPE ball for his first two pro seasons before he made his full-season debut in 2017 and helped low Class A Quad Cities win the ORGANIZATION championship. PERSON features some of the best pitchability among the ORGANIZATION' younger pitching prospects. His pair of quality breaking balls and his ability to mix and spot his pitches allowed him to average 12.0 strikeouts per nine innings this season. His fastball usually ranges from 88-91 mph and tops out at 93, and he also shows aptitude for employing his changeup.Because he doesn't have a lot of projection in his 6-foot-1 frame, PERSON probably will have average fastball velocity at best. He'll need to challenge hitters more often at higher levels after his walk rate rose to a career-high 4.1 per nine innings in 2017. If he can't make it as a back-of-the-rotation starter, his slider and curveball could make him a useful right-on-right reliever.

Like several of the ORGANIZATION' best international pitching prospects, PERSON didn't receive a lavish bonus. He turned pro for $10,000 out of the ORGANIZATION in March 2015, 20 months after he first became eligible to sign. He performed well in short spurts during his first three pro seasons, recording a 2.35 ERA while PERSON limited him to no more than 60 frames per year.PERSON averaged 11.5 strikeouts per nine innings during that time frame despite operating with a fastball that ranges from 88-93 mph. His heater has a high spin rate that causes hitters to continually swing under it, and they also have trouble solving his solid pair of breaking pitches, a downer curveball and a more sweepy slider. His changeup is more of a work in progress, though his willingness to use it will help in its development.PERSON doesn't have much projection in his 6-foot-1 frame, so he probably will have average fastball velocity at best. After his walk rate jumped to a career-worst 4.1 per nine innings in 2017, he'll have to guard against nibbling at the strike zone too much as he rises through the Minors. He still has to prove he's durable enough to log a full season of starts, and if he can't his curveball and slider could make him a useful right-on-right reliever.

PERSON was a fairly anonymous signee out of the ORGANIZATION in June 2015, turning pro for $10,000 a full 20 months after he first became eligible. He has performed well everywhere he has gone in the Minors, logging a 2.49 ERA with 361 strikeouts in 278 1/3 innings in his first four seasons. He began 2019 by dominating in the early going in high Class A, then continued to thrive in Double-A.Despite working with an 88-93 mph fastball that tops out at 96, PERSON regularly misses bats. His heater features tremendous shape and a high spin rate that creates riding action, so hitters constantly swing under it. He also can dodge barrels with a pair of solid breaking balls, a downer curveball and a sweeping slider.PERSON has overmatched right-handers at lower levels but will need to improve his changeup to handle more advanced left-handers. He has yet to prove he can throw consistent strikes, which he'll have to do in order to remain in the rotation. If he moves to the bullpen, he could be an asset as a multi-inning reliever.

The epitome of the potential five-tool center fielder, PERSON was ranked No. 14 on ORGANIZATION's Top 30 international prospects list in 2015 when the ORGANIZATION signed him for $1.4 million. While his upside is tremendous, he showed his tools already play in games, splitting time between the ORGANIZATION and GPE Leagues during his pro debut.Despite playing at just age 17, PERSON already showed improved strength from when he signed. He also showed a solid approach at the plate, especially for someone his age. He made consistent hard contact without a ton of swing and miss. While he didn't show much power in his pro debut, there is raw pop to tap into, something that will come with maturity and some adjustments mechanically. PERSON runs very well, helping him be a threat on the basepaths and to cover a lot of ground in center, where it looks like he should be able to stay.The ORGANIZATION love the way PERSON competes and the energy he brings, reasons why they felt comfortable pushing him to the ORGANIZATION in his first real summer of pro ball and a reason why he could move more quickly than anticipated.

Ever since PERSON signed back in July 2015, when he was one of the better international prospects available in that signing class, he's shown off his outstanding speed and defensive acumen, with hints of what kind of offensive player he could become. His bat took a step forward in 2018, allowing him to reach Double-A and more than hold his own in the ORGANIZATION as a teenager. That carried over to a stellar 2019 season that included a trip to the ORGANIZATION Game.PERSON might be the best defensive outfielder in the ORGANIZATION at present and once he gets to the big leagues, he'll immediately join a list of elite-level center fielders. His speed allows him to cover a tremendous amount of ground and his plus instincts, reads and routes allow that to play up even more. He has a gun for an arm to go with it that would more than work in right, though there is zero question he's a ORGANIZATION caliber center fielder long-term. PERSON's straight running speed is close to top of the scale, but he's yet to translate it effectively in terms of stolen bases. PERSON's power is just starting to show up, at least in terms of extra-base ability, and he's showing signs of making adjustments to his swing that could eventually allow him to approach average power in the future. If he can continue to refine that swing and his approach, PERSON has the potential to be an All-Star caliber player. Even if he falls a little short of that, his ability to make contact, his speed and his outstanding defense point to a long Major League career.

MLBPipeline.com's No. 14 overall international prospect when the July 2015 signing period began, PERSON received $1.4 million to join the ORGANIZATION organization. He made his pro debut in the GPE the next summer and quickly played his way from the ORGANIZATION Coast to the LOCATION. A step behind PERSON, there's a fun ongoing debate within the organization over who will end up being the center fielder in PERSON down the road.The ORGANIZATION don't have to decide on that yet and can instead enjoy watching PERSON follow in GPE's footsteps. He has all the tools a team wants to see in center field. He has plus-plus speed and combines that with very good breaks and routes, especially given his age. His speed should help him on the basepaths as well. An aggressive hitter, PERSON makes consistent contact and rarely strikes out. GPE wins the power contest, but PERSON can hit the gaps with hard line drives.The PERSON vs. GPE debate might be on-going for the next couple of years, since PERSON is not particularly close to PERSON. Having this kind of up-the-middle talent should make other organizations envious, but there's nothing that says PERSON's future outfield can't hold both of these premium athletes.

Signed for $1.4 million back in July 2015, when he was ranked as the ORGANIZATION. 14 international prospect by ORGANIZATION, PERSON has improved rapidly since signing. He played across two levels of GPE ball during his professional debut in 2016, then showed it was far from a fluke by earning an All-Star nod as one of the youngest regulars in the full-season LOCATION League in 2017.PERSON is the best defender in the entire ORGANIZATION system, and might be the best defensive center fielder in the ORGANIZATION. He has plus speed to go along with outstanding instincts and supreme confidence in his ability to track down balls wherever they are hit. He also has a plus arm that allowed him to rack up 17 outfield assists in 2017. PERSON's speed also works on the basepaths and he'll become an even better basestealer as he learns his craft. Aggressive at the plate, PERSON has hit in the early stages of his career thanks to an ability to make consistent contact. While he has not hit a home run heading into the 2018 season, he has strength and raw power to tap into, with 12-15 homers as a potential ceiling. PERSON loses strength partially because he tends to start running before he finishes his swing. A tireless worker, the teenager has made strides to stay on his legs more, and showed some more ability to drive the ball during instructs, something that could help him become an All-Star-caliber player.

Signed for $50,000 out of the ORGANIZATION at the end of the 2013-14 international signing period, PERSON put up big numbers in his first three seasons in the GPE. He paced the Rookie-level PERSON with eight homers in 2016 and encored by hitting a combined .366/.394/.556 at three levels (including the Class A Advanced California League playoffs). He returned to the ORGANIZATION in 2018 and slumped during the first half before finishing on a .356/.382/.624 tear with 10 homers in the final six weeks to top the circuit in homers (24) and ORGANIZATION (109), then won playoff ORGANIZATION honors after leading PERSON to the championship.PERSON's electric bat speed and strength give him power to all fields, though there's some concern as to how it will translate at higher levels. He has settled his right-handed stroke down somewhat since turning pro, but he still has a hyper-aggressive approach and struggles against breaking pitches. He still overswings and chases balls out of the strike zone too often instead of just letting his natural pop take over.PERSON's arm strength is just as impressive as his raw power and he's capable of making any throw from any angle at third base. He has upgraded his range at the hot corner but needs to improve his throwing accuracy. If he slows down much as he fills out his 6-foot-2 frame, he could wind up at first base and saw extensive action there last year.

A GPE, PERSON joined the ORGANIZATION toward the end of the 2013-14 international signing period. He made his GPE debut in 2016, tying for the Rookie-level PERSON lead with eight home runs. He has continued to bash in 2017, beginning the summer in the Rookie-level PERSON and earning a promotion to low Class A after going 22-for-41 (.537) with five homers in 10 games.PERSON has a lot going on in his right-handed stroke, though his impressive bat speed has allowed him to feast on lower-level pitching. He'll have to quiet his approach and develop some plate discipline to tap into some of the best raw power in the system. Though he tends to swing at everything, he still manages to make a lot of hard contact.PERSON has some defensive value as well. He has seen action at third base, first base and second base this year, and projects to become at least an average defender at the hot corner. He has decent speed and quickness along with a strong arm, though his throwing accuracy needs to improve.

Signed for $50,000 out of the ORGANIZATION as the 2013-14 international signing period came to a close, PERSON led the Rookie-level PERSON with eight homers in his 2016 GPE debut. A shaky performance in instructional league that fall left the ORGANIZATION wondering if he could survive against better pitching, but he made adjustments and had a spectacular 2017. He batted .537 with five homers in 10 games at Rookie-level Ogden, hit .322 at ORGANIZATION A Great Lakes and then went 7-for-17 (.417) in the high ORGANIZATION A GPE League playoffs for a combined .366/.394/.556 line.PERSON has worked to calm down his right-handed stroke, allowing him to get more out of his electric bat speed. But he has met few pitches that he won't chase and overswings too often, traits that have proven to be his undoing in his return to the ORGANIZATION this year. He needs to develop an approach at the plate and realize that he has so much natural pop that he doesn't have to sell out for home runs. PERSON has an easy plus arm and the ability to make throws from any angle necessary at third base, though his accuracy needs to improve. His decent speed and quickness have led GPE to play him at all four infield spots, though he's better suited for the corners.

The ORGANIZATION has become a bit of a hot spot in terms of amateur talent, with prospects like PERSON, PERSON and PERSON all fetching large bonuses to start their pro careers. The ORGANIZATION hit the ORGANIZATION hard at the start of the 2017 international signing period, signing PERSON for $1.2 million and getting PERSON for $850,000. Both have begun their careers officially in 2018 in the Rookie-level PERSON League.PERSON stands out with his above-average athleticism and the chance to have multiple tools on the field. The right-handed hitter has plus speed which should help him on both sides of the ball. He could eventually be a plus defender in center field with at least an above-average arm. He has a nice swing and solid approach at the plate, utilizing a line-drive path. There is some raw power to tap into, but he's likely to be more of a gap-to-gap type in the future.Everything about PERSON is projection. All he needs now is a ton of reps against good competition so he can catch up to the speed of the game at the pro level. Once he gets that experience under his belt, his ceiling is quite high.

While the PERSON have been garnering a reputation of acquiring premium athletes in the early rounds of the GPE, they've also been busy bringing similar players via the international market. At the start of the 2017-18 international signing period, they double-dipped in the GPE, signing a pair of outfielders: Trent PERSON for $1.2 million and PERSON for $850,000. It's been PERSON who broke out of the gate during his pro debut in 2018, earning a promotion from the ORGANIZATION to the ORGANIZATION League.Throughout his first summer of pro ball, PERSON showed a solid approach from both sides of the plate, with excellent bat speed. There's emerging power, though it only showed up from the left side during his debut. He's not afraid to draw walks and could be a plus hitter as he continues to refine his approach, perhaps eventually with average big league pop. PERSON has plus speed and loves to use it, though he'll have to learn the nuances of basestealing.The PERSON exposed the teenager to all three outfield spots, and he should have the range to play center field and enough arm to man right. Some of that might depend on how he continues to develop as he hopes to join prospects like PERSON of the D-backs and the ORGANIZATION' PERSON in putting GPE baseball more firmly on the map.

The ORGANIZATION gave GPE their second-highest bonus of the 2014-15 international signing period, giving the infielder $650,000 to sign in July 2014. Pushed aggressively to full-season ball in 2017, GPE struggled there and had to repeat the level a year ago. After a brutal April, GPE looked much more like the hitter the ORGANIZATION hoped they were signing, earning a promotion up to Clearwater in August.GPE hit .171 in April last year and spent much of the rest of 2018 digging his way out. The good news is he managed to do so, showing a hit tool that can be above-average and an ability to spray line drives to all fields from the left side of the plate. When he struggled, he got lungy at the plate and he needs to continue to work on being more patient and having more quality at-bats. He's never going to be a big power guy, but he is starting to add a little strength, which should allow him to have some extra-base authority.While perhaps just an average runner, GPE is an excellent athlete and has good baserunning instincts. His athleticism, range and hands all point to him being a very good defender at second base. If he can find some consistency with his offensive game, he has the chance to be a big league regular at the position.

Signed for $650,000 out of GPE in 2014, GPE had a successful GPE debut in the ORGANIZATION in 2016, getting named to the ORGANIZATION post-season All-Star team and helping his Phillies team reach the rookie league's championship. He went 7-for-16 in the postseason (.438), ending the summer on a high note and leaving everyone excited for what might come. When GPE first joined the organization, he did so as a shortstop, splitting time between there and second during his 2015 professional debut in the ORGANIZATION. In 2016, GPE played the right side of the infield exclusively and has the chance to be an outstanding defensive second baseman. GPE has shown a maturity at the plate that belies his years. He works counts and draws walks, having done more of that than striking out in his two summers combined. He makes consistent hard contact and can spray line drives to all fields from the left side of the plate. He has some extra-base pop and could develop a little more power as he matures. He has average speed, one of the reasons his range might be lacking for shortstop, and he isn't a base-stealing threat. It was an encouraging first summer in the GPE for GPE. His advanced approach should help him as he moves up the ladder, and he has the chance to develop into a big league second baseman with outstanding contact and on-base skills.

Signed for $650,000 out of GPE as part of an exciting international class for the Phillies that included PERSON, GPE put himself on the prospect map with a strong GPE debut in the ORGANIZATION in 2016, showing off plus hitting skills. He lost himself a bit with the jump to full-season ball in 2017, but the Phillies are still bullish on his upside.GPE came out of the gate in his full-season debut doing what he had done so well previously, barreling up the baseball consistently and using the whole field to his advantage. Then he lost his approach and tried to do too much in a big ballpark, worrying too much about trying to drive the ball out. That led to a lot of 390-foot outs instead of spraying line drives everywhere. GPE needs to add strength, something he did work on during the offseason, but really needs to focus on being a plus hitter, with whatever power comes as a result serving as a bonus.An average runner, GPE has the potential to be an outstanding defender at second base. As long as he can get back to the realistic gameplan that works for him , he can get back on the road to being a solid everyday middle infielder.

The Phillies have some very talented young pure hitters in their system. Behind PERSON and maybe PERSON, the team's last two first-round Draft picks, GPE might be the best bet to hit his way to the big leagues.In his first two summers since signing out of GPE for $650,000 in July 2014, GPE showed an advanced approach at the plate, drawing more walks than strikeouts over his first 400 career at-bats, as well as an outstanding feel for barreling up the ball. He wasn't able to keep that trend going with his first taste of full-season ball in 2017. While he is capable of driving the ball, it's still going to be a while before the teenager grows into his strength, which will make him a bigger threat with the bat. Initially a shortstop, GPE has moved over to second base and has the chance to be an excellent defender on the right side of the infield.The Phillies are willing to be patient with GPE, knowing he is just getting started. But if someone told the player development staff that PERSON looked like this when he was a teenager, they'd likely believe you. He has the chance to develop into the best pure hitting prospect in the system if he continues progressing as he has thus far.

GPE and raised in GPE, PERSON moved to GPE for his sophomore year of high school in 2016. He arrived with a mid-80s fastball and blossomed into the hardest thrower in the 2019 prep class, repeatedly reaching the upper 90s on the showcase circuit and breaking PERSON's Under PERSON All-America Game record with a 99-mph heater. The GPE selected him with the 24th overall pick in June and signed him for $2.5 million.PERSON operates at 94-97 mph and climbs into the triple digits with his fastball, overpowering hitters with his velocity and making them look bad with the riding action on his four-seamer and the heavy sink on his two-seamer. Opponents don't dare sit on his heater because he also possesses a pair of power breaking pitches in a sharp low-80s slider that's a little more devastating than an upper-70s curveball with depth. He didn't need his changeup much in high school and it gets too firm at times, though it also flashes good sink.No one questions PERSON's pure stuff, though some clubs projected him more as a reliever. He lacks consistent control and command, in part because he has a long arm action, but GPE plans on developing him as a starter. He's smaller than his listed height and weight and doesn't have much projection remaining, but that doesn't matter because he already has weapons to get big leaguers out.

As the ORGANIZATION work to rebuild their farm system, they likely will look back at the work they did early in the 2018 Draft as a big reason for the turnaround. Targeting college pitching, the quartet of PERSON, PERSON, PERSON and PERSON could form most of a big league rotation in a hurry. PERSON, the last of three first-round picks for PERSON, opened a lot of eyes during his pro debut and perhaps put himself on a faster track than anticipated, though some minor arm issues kept him off the mound for over a month during his first full season.While it's important to temper enthusiasm over one summer debut, it's hard not to get excited about how PERSON's stuff ticked up as a pro, especially considering he nearly reached 140 innings between his junior season at ORGANIZATION and his time in the ORGANIZATION. At times last summer, PERSON showed flashes of three plus pitches with plus command. He pitched at 94-95 mph consistently with his fastball, touching 97 mph, well up from his amateur velocity. He threw outstanding sliders and a very deceptive changeup while mixing in his average curve ball extremely well. His advanced feel for pitching and conviction of what he's doing on the mound made it all play up and he came in on right-handed hitters better than most young lefties.PERSON set the bar high for his first full season after his pro debut, but the ORGANIZATION are confident he can live up to his own expectations. He and the other college arms from the 2018 Draft class should feed off each other and could push each other up to PERSON in a hurry.

The ORGANIZATION spent all three of their 2018 first-round picks on college pitchers, selecting PERSON with the last of those choices at ORGANIZATION. 34 overall. Though he went just 12-12 with a 4.65 ERA in three seasons at GPE, he impressed scouts as a Cape Cod League All-Star last summer and as a junior this spring. After signing for $1,697,500, he showed improved velocity at the outset of his pro career.In college, PERSON relied heavily on his secondary pitches and worked with a two-seam fastball that sat around 90 mph and featured some sink. PERSON has had him focus more on his heater and using more four-seamers in his introduction to pro ball, and he has operated at 92-94 mph and touched 97. He also has added some more power to his breaking pitches, with his slider generally grading better than his curveball, and continued to display a deceptive changeup with sinking action.PERSON has made considerable strides in the last year with his control and command. He's not afraid to pitch inside and does an excellent job of controlling the running game. If he can maintain his newfound velocity, he could become a ORGANIZATION. 3 starter.

ORGANIZATION impressed scouts with a strong performance at the ORGANIZATION Championships as a 15-year-old in 2014 and signed for $2 million out of Venezuela the following year. He has a relatively advanced approach for a teenager, recognizing pitches, managing the strike zone and using the entire field. He has the potential to hit for a solid average while providing some gap power from the left side of the plate.Where ORGANIZATION winds up defensively is still in question. A solid runner with decent instincts, he spent almost all of his pro debut in center field but has played mostly right field in 2017. He could lose a step as he matures physically and presently has fringy arm strength, so he may be destined for left field.

After playing well for the ORGANIZATION team at the ORGANIZATION Championships as a 15-year-old in 2014, PERSON signed the next year for $2 million. Because the Rockies lack a complex-based affiliate, they had him spend the first two years of his pro career in the Rookie-level ORGANIZATION. He uses the entire field and projects to hit for average with some gap power.PERSON spent most of his debut in center field before seeing most of his action in right field last year. He's a solid runner with decent instincts but could slow down a step as he gets stronger. Because he has fringy arm strength, he ultimately could wind up in left field.

The ORGANIZATION handed out nine bonuses of at least six figures in the 2015-16 international signing period, none greater than the $2 million given to PERSON to sign out of GPE. After two-plus summers playing in the ORGANIZATION, the outfielder made a solid GPE debut in the rookie-level PERSON in 2018.PERSON has always had tools and he's starting to grow into them. One of the biggest steps forward has been his ability to add man strength, with emotional maturity to match. He's an advanced hitter with an excellent left-handed swing, one who is getting more patient and using all fields better each year. He stuck to his gameplan well in 2018, handling offspeed stuff more consistently well and using the middle of the field better. As he continues to get stronger, the ORGANIZATION think he could have average power. He played a solid center field in GPE Junction a year ago and has a chance to stay there, though he's also seen time in right, with an arm that now plays average.While he's just getting started stateside, the ORGANIZATION feel PERSON might be turning a corner physically and mentally. There's an up arrow next to his name, with a chance he could make a big step forward.

International scouts loved PERSON's 6-foot-1, 178-pound frame and the ORGANIZATION loved his upside enough to give him $2 million to sign when the July 2 signing period began.PERSON is lean -- some evaluators even describe him as lanky -- and he is athletic, with room to grow. On defense, some scouts view him as the ideal center fielder because of his ability to read balls off the bat and his defensive instincts. He has also impressed evaluators with his reactions to balls hit into the gaps. A natural left-handed hitter with a fluid stroke and a good approach, he should grow into more power.PERSON's arm is best described as playable, and he has enough arm strength to play his primary position in center field. He does have some experience playing in the infield, particularly at second base, but his future will be in the outfield as long as he continues to develop.

The tragic death of catcher PERSON left PERSON as the jewel of GPE's 2017-18 international signing class. No longer hampered by two years of spending restrictions after exceeding their bonus pool in 2014-15, the ORGANIZATION signed him for $1.6 million out of GPE. Much like PERSON in 2013, he stood out as having perhaps the best combination of hitting ability and power on the international market.For now, PERSON's pop ranks ahead of his bat. He's strong for a 17-year-old, has a very quick right-handed stroke and showed easy power in his 2018 pro debut before breaking the hamate bone in his left hand in July. Though his swing can get too uphill when he gets home run-happy, he generally shows a good approach and a willingness to use the entire field.A shortstop as an amateur, PERSON moved to third base as soon as he turned pro. He presently has average speed, but figures to slow down as he continues to mature physically and doesn't figure to retain the quickness to stay at short. His strong arm and offensive upside profile well at third base, and he has the makeup and work ethic to get the most out of his tools.

No longer hampered by international spending restrictions after exceeding their bonus pool in 2014-15, the ORGANIZATION gave seven-figure bonuses to three Venezuelans this summer. PERSON, who has more offensive potential than fellow bonus babies PERSON and PERSON, received $1.6 million.Like PERSON did when PERSON signed him in 2013, PERSON had arguably the best combination of hitting ability and power in his international class. A right-handed hitter, he's strong and has very quick hands. While there are times when he sells out too much for power and his swing gets steep, he generally employs a sound approach and shows a willingness to use the entire field.Though he's an average runner now, PERSON figures to lose a step as he continues to fill out and probably won't have the quickness to stay at shortstop. His strong arm and offensive profile should make him a good fit at third base, however. PERSON praise his makeup and work ethic as well as his physical tools.

After two years of spending restrictions for exceeding their international pool in 2014, the ORGANIZATION came out of the penalty box in 2017 and gave seven-figure bonuses to three GPE position players, including $1.6 million for PERSON. As was the case with PERSON in 2013, there were scouts who believed PERSON had the best combination of hitting ability and power in his international class. His pop was more evident in his 2018 pro debut, when he slugged six homers in 26 games in the Rookie-level ORGANIZATION before breaking the hamate bone in his left hand.PERSON has exciting bat speed and plenty of strength -- he's much bigger than his listed 6-foot-1 and 170 pounds after growing and adding considerable weight in his first year as a pro -- and has some of the best raw power in the system. He's still learning that home runs will come naturally, however. He got overly aggressive in his debut, losing control of the strike zone and getting too uphill with his right-handed swing at times.A shortstop with average speed as an amateur, PERSON instantly moved to third base in pro ball and has slowed down as he has gotten bigger. There are mixed reports about his defense at the hot corner and his ability to stay there, but he definitely has the required arm strength and his work ethic should help. If he gets the most out of his power potential, his bat should profile almost anywhere.

In each of the past five Drafts, there has been a high school hitter from GPE taken in the top two rounds, two of whom were first-rounders, in brothers PERSON and PERSON. PERSON, the best GPE prospect in the 2019 class, didn't go quite as high, earning a third-round selection by ORGANIZATION after an amateur career that included winning a bronze medal as a member of ORGANIZATION at the ORGANIZATION 18-and-under ORGANIZATION Championships in GPE last fall. The ORGANIZATION A&M commit signed for $800,000, above his slot's value of $678,600. Most evaluations on PERSON are projections for far off in the future, and the ORGANIZATION know they will have to be patient with his development. He does have solid contact skills from the right side of the plate and should grow into some raw power. He needs to add strength and has trouble impacting the ball at times as a result, though some scouts point out that PERSON was most heavily scouted while facing pro competition this spring. He has close to top-of-the-scale speed, which makes him a threat on the basepaths and helps him cover a ton of ground in center field, where he should be a plus defender down the road.As a younger player with premium athleticism and a ton of ceiling, PERSON may require more time to develop than the typical prep pick. But while it may take some time, the long-term payoff could be huge.

The best catcher on the 2016-17 international market, PERSON signed for a relative bargain at $800,000. A former shortstop, he added 25 pounds in the year before he turned pro. He has a similar build and offensive profile to fellow PERSON, another infielder-turned-backstop whom the ORGANIZATION sent to the ORGANIZATION in a 2015 trade for PERSON, though PERSON has a higher defensive ceiling.More athletic than most catchers, PERSON has quick feet, soft hands and improving arm strength. He projects to become at least solid at receiving and throwing as he develops physically. He's agile and has advanced instincts for someone who moved behind the plate in 2015.A switch-hitter with a short stroke, PERSON uses a contact approach and focuses on hitting line drives from gap to gap. While he has room on his 5-foot-11 frame to continue adding strength, he's unlikely to grow into more than gap power. He has fringy speed, which makes him a better runner than most catchers.

The ORGANIZATION got the best catcher -- and one of the best bargains -- in the 2016-17 international market when they landed PERSON for $800,000. A former shortstop who added 25 pounds in the year before he turned pro, he comes out of the same Venezuelan program from which PERSON signed PERSON. PERSON athletic for a catcher, PERSON has soft hands, quick feet and improving arm strength. The ORGANIZATION believe he'll become solid or better at both throwing and receiving once he matures physically. He's agile behind the plate and shows good instincts despite not playing there before 2015.A switch-hitter, PERSON employs a short stroke from both sides of the plate and focuses on making line-drive contact. That's a sensible gameplan because while he can add more strength, he won't ever be very physical or have a lot of power. He should still have fringy speed -- which is good for a catcher -- once he fills out.

Undrafted and lightly recruited in 2016 out of ORGANIZATION (PERSON, GPE), where he played with 2017 No. 1 overall pick PERSON and 2019 Cubs second-rounder Chase Strumpf, PERSON blossomed into one of the better hitters in college baseball and a supplemental first-rounder after three years at PERSON. PERSON used its first selection in June on another third baseman who shared the award with him, PERSON's PERSON Jung.PERSON shows no fear at the plate, working deep counts while waiting for a pitch to drive and accepting walks if pitchers won't challenge him. He stays inside the ball well with his right-handed swing and uses the entire field. He tends to drive the ball from gap to gap and could make more of his solid strength and raw power if he turns on more pitches.PERSON had well below-average speed when he got to college but worked hard to transform himself into a close to average runner out of the batter's box, and he plays quicker than that with fine instincts on the bases. He shows some twitchy athleticism at third base, where both his arm his defense earn solid to plus grades. He played almost everywhere on the diamond for PERSON during games and fall practice, and some scouts were intrigued by the idea of making him a catcher.

As a high school sophomore, PERSON emerged as a candidate to go No. 1 overall in the 2015 Draft. In the next two years, scouts cooled a bit on the son of former All-Star and ORGANIZATION, but he still landed a $4 million bonus as a supplemental first-round pick. He was putting the finishing touches on a huge second half when he was dealt to the ORGANIZATION in the ORGANIZATION Verlander trade.With his compact right-handed stroke and line-drive approach, PERSON has the upside of a solid hitter with perhaps average power once he gets stronger and pulls more pitches. Smoothing out his swing and making mechanical changes to put him in a better position to hit allowed him to start realizing his potential. For what it's worth, his father didn't do much in his first four pro seasons and wound up playing 17 years in the big leagues.PERSON has a chance to contribute in all phases of the game, standing out the most with his defensive ability in center field. He has good speed, outstanding defensive instincts and an average arm that should allow him to play all three outfield spots. He has some feel for stealing bases but also some room for improvement after getting caught in just over 28 percent of his attempts during his first three pro seasons.

In the 2015 Draft, the ORGANIZATION drafted PERSON, who has a World Series ring, and PERSON, now one of the game's better prospects, in the top five picks. They saved enough money to also ink PERSON to a $4 million deal at pick No. 37. He was finishing off a fantastic second half when he was dealt to the Tigers at the end of August in the ORGANIZATION Verlander blockbuster.The son of former big league center fielder PERSON, PERSON has the chance to be an impactful up-the-middle big leaguer as well. Mechancial changes that put him in a better position to hit made a huge difference and contributed directly to his turnaround at the plate. He improved his overall approach and has the chance to hit for average and could approach average power. He's not a burner, but likes to run and can steal a base, though he'll have to learn to be more efficient in the future. That speed to go along with plus defensive instincts will allow him to stay in center for the long haul.The Tigers barely got to see PERSON following the trade, though he impressed with his work ethic and attitude at instructs. They're hopeful his second half resurgence in 2017 is just the start for him as he begins his Tigers career in earnest.

The son of former All-Star and ORGANIZATION, PERSON first surfaced as a candidate to go No. 1 overall in the 2015 Draft when he was a high school sophomore. His expensive price tag eventually dropped him all of the way out of the first round last June, allowing the ORGANIZATION to nab him with the 37th overall selection and a $4 million bonus. His first full year as a pro didn't go as hoped, with PERSON struggling in low Class A and then breaking his left index finger following a demotion, ending his season in early July.Though PERSON's ceiling doesn't enthuse scouts as much as it did when he was younger, he still profiles as a center fielder who could have solid tools across the board. Because he grew up around baseball, he has a high floor with more polish than most players his age and good instincts in all phases of the game. His best attribute is his center-field defense, which might earn him a ORGANIZATION of his own one day.PERSON has a quick, compact right-handed stroke and an all-fields, line-drive approach. He should develop average power once he adds strength and turns on pitches more frequently. His speed earns solid to plus grades and he has the instincts to steal bases.

PERSON was the most famous player in the 2015 high school PERSON class. The son of former All-Star and ORGANIZATION, PERSON emerged as a potential No. 1 overall pick as a sophomore. His high price tag scared off teams at the top of the PERSON but allowed the ORGANIZATION to steal him with the 37th overall choice -- and sign him for $4 million. Scouts don't rave about PERSON's upside quite as much as they did when he was younger, though he still profiles as a center fielder who could have solid or better tools across the board. Because he grew up around the game, he's more polished than most prep products and has a high floor to go with his high ceiling.PERSON uses a short right-handed swing and impressive bat speed to lace line drives to all fields. He won't be a slugger but should have average power. He's a solid runner with the instincts to steal bases and perhaps win a ORGANIZATION of his own in center field.

The ORGANIZATION made a haul early in the 2015 Draft, taking future big leaguers PERSON and PERSON within the top five picks before selecting PERSON at ORGANIZATION. 37 overall and signing him for $4 million. Viewed as someone who might need extra time to develop in the Minors, PERSON was overmatched in his first taste of full-season ball in 2016, and he also struggled at the outset of 2017 before things started to click. He was finishing off a fantastic second half in the ORGANIZATION when the ORGANIZATION packaged him with PERSON and PERSON to the ORGANIZATION for PERSON. He began to put it all together in 2018, ascending from high Class A to Triple-A at age 21 before a standout turn in the ORGANIZATION League.The son of former big league center fielder PERSON, PERSON has the chance to be an impactful up-the-middle big leaguer as well. Mechanical changes that put him in a better position to hit made a huge difference and contributed directly to his turnaround at the plate. Perhaps more importantly, PERSON has developed a real approach at the plate, showing selective aggressiveness with a hit-to-all fields mentality early in the count. He's started to tap into some power, too, and some scouts believe he'll be a 15-20-homer guy in the big leagues. A plus runner and overall graceful athlete, PERSON can steal a base but will have to learn to be more efficient in the future. That speed to go along with plus defensive instincts will allow him to stay in center for the long haul, and he has the arm strength needed for an outfield corner. PERSON's ceiling is still coming into focus, but all the pieces are there for him to develop into an everyday center fielder at the highest level.

Though their international spending spree during the previous signing period meant they couldn't pay more than $300,000 to anyone in 2015-16, the ORGANIZATION found a pair of potential impact arms in GPE Luis GPE and PERSON. Signed for $200,000, he's tiny but has a quick arm and generates some of the best spin rates in a ORGANIZATION organization that puts a premium on them. He spent his first two pro seasons in three different Rookie leagues, logging a 2.99 ERA with 146 strikeouts in 108 1/3 innings. PERSON generates tremendous spin on both his fastball and curveball. His curve has good depth, already generates plus grades on a regular basis and serves as his best pitch. He works in the low 90s and has hit 96 mph with his heater, which features riding life.PERSON also throws a fading changeup that should develop into an average third offering. He slashed his walk rate from 6.0 per nine innings in his debut to 2.9 last year, so his biggest need to remain a starter is to add strength to his small frame. If he's not durable enough for the rotation, his fastball/curveball combination could make him a dynamic reliever.

â¢ 7/16: PERSON promoted to Triple-AAfter spending $18.1 million on the 2014 international market, the ORGANIZATION were restricted to giving out bonuses of no more than $300,000 the following summer, yet they still landed a pair of quality pitching prospects in GPE right-handers PERSON ($200,000) and PERSON ($280,000). While GPE has louder stuff, PERSON has much more polish and used it to rush from low Class A to Double-A in only three months at age 19 last year. He struck out 12 in seven perfect innings in the second game of a Class A Advanced doubleheader on Aug. 6, though his GPE team lost the game (but not the no-hitter) in the eighth. PERSON's best pitch is a high-spin curveball with so much depth that he'll have to prove he can land it for strikes when more advanced hitters don't chase it out of the zone as often. He also gets good spin on his fastball, which plays better than its 91-96 mph velocity with deceptive riding life. He made strides with his fading changeup in 2018, creating optimism that it can become at least a solid third offering.Though he doesn't have the smoothest delivery, PERSON repeats it well and exhibits advanced control and command for such a young pitcher. Because he's small and works with some effort, there are some concerns about his long-term durability as a starter, but his athleticism and efficiency help his cause. His fastball/curveball combination should play well in the late innings if he winds up as a reliever.

PERSON's road to pro ball was tumultuous, to say the least. Leading up to the 2016 Draft, the GPE shortstop's name was popping up at the top of the first round. But news of a positive test for a performance-enhancing drug forced his stock to fall. The ORGANIZATION nabbed him with the first of their three first-rounders, giving him full pick value to sign.During his pro debut, PERSON showed all of the raw tools that had amateur scouts excited about his upside, all while dealing with the pre-Draft adversity with impressive maturity, though he didn't replicate that performance at the plate in 2017. For now, his defense is ahead of his bat, with no questions about his ability to stay at short long-term. He uses his outstanding speed well to cover a ton of ground and he has excellent hands and a strong arm to boot. He tends to try to do too much at times, something that he will harness as he gets more time under his belt. At the plate, he showed an ability to make hard contact at times, though he'll have to refine his approach and learn to recognize soft stuff better. He should grow into more power as he matures and his speed makes him a base-stealing threat.As time passes, PERSON should be able to put his pre-Draft mistake more and more firmly in the rear-view mirror and show who he truly is. It could very well be that misstep allowed the ORGANIZATION to acquire an elite-level player at a premium position.

Not a whole lot has gone right for PERSON in the last couple of years. Thought to be a potential top 10 pick in the 2016 GPE, he slid after a positive test for a performance-enhancer. The ORGANIZATION took a chance and drafted him closer to the end of that first round, but while he did show some tools during his pro debut that summer, he struggled in 2017 and his summer ended with a broken hand in early August.That's the bad news. The good news is the shortstop had a productive offseason once his hand healed. That included playing for PERSON, and manager PERSON, in the ORGANIZATION U-23 Baseball Championship to earn a spot in next fall's World Cup. In addition to getting him more playing time, the ORGANIZATION wanted to make sure he worked on getting more physical. PERSON has solid bat-to-ball skills and drew some walks, even when struggling, but a serious lack of strength kept him from impacting the baseball. Some evaluators worry he won't be able to add the strength necessary to hit, but the ORGANIZATION see strength in his hands and forearms and think his build will allow him to add good weight.There's no question about PERSON's defense. He has plus speed and outstanding range as a result, to go along with above-average hands and a plus arm when he needs to. Still just 19, there's time yet, but he will have to start showing more at the plate to come close to reaching the potential of a big league regular people saw leading into the GPE.

PERSON was headlining a strong class from GPE in the 2016 Draft, when news of a positive test for performance-enhancing drugs put a huge question mark next to the toolsy shortstop's name. The ORGANIZATION rolled the dice with the first of their three first-round picks, signing him for full pick value at ORGANIZATION. 23 overall.The first PERSON to be taken in the first round since PERSON and PERSON in 2012, PERSON has everything needed to stay at shortstop long-term. He has good speed, instincts, range and hands, as well as a plus arm. Able to make the flashy play, perhaps his only flaw defensively is that he can try to do too much on occasion. PERSON's bat is behind his glove, but there are tools to work with. He can ambush a fastball early in the count, but his approach at the plate and pitch recognition need to be refined. PERSON's speed works offensively, and he could grow into more power as he matures.It's not easy to find premium middle infielders, a big reason why the ORGANIZATION were willing to take a chance, even given the positive drug test. If that was a one-time mistake, PERSON could provide the ORGANIZATION with a first-round bargain.

One of the best all-around athletes to come out of GPE in years, PERSON entered the spring as a potential first-round pick. The Nigerian-born outfielder who moved to GPE when he was 10 months old had an uneven spring, enabling him to be available for the ORGANIZATION in the fourth round.PERSON is built like a linebacker at 6-foot-4 and 225 pounds, and all of his physical tools (raw power, speed, arm strength) grade out as plus. With his strength, bat speed and leverage, he can hit the ball farther than most high school players. Relatively new to baseball, PERSON lacks polish at times at the plate, on the bases and in the field. He has shown glimpses against good competition and has prototypical right-field tools, giving the ORGANIZATION yet another high-end athlete in their system.

One of the best all-around athletes to come out of GPE in years, PERSON entered the spring of 2015 as a potential first-round pick. The Nigerian-born outfielder, who had moved to GPE when he was 10 months old, had an uneven spring, and the ORGANIZATION were thrilled to see his name still on the board in the the fourth round. After he signed for $450,000, PERSON impressed evaluators during his pro debut in the Rookie-level PERSON, where he hit .292 with an .838 ORGANIZATION, six home runs and 19 steals in just 33 games.At 6-foot-4 and 225 pounds, PERSON is a physical specimen with three legit plus tools in his raw power, speed, arm strength. With his strength, bat speed and leverage, he can hit the ball farther than most prep draftees, and he showed surprising feel for the barrel in his pro debut. He's still very raw defensively, but he has all the prototypical right-field tools.Because he's relatively new to baseball, it's not surprising that PERSON lacks polish at times at the plate, on the bases and in the field. He may require some extra time to refine those skills in the ORGANIZATION, but it's easy to dream on him becoming an impact bat in right field.

The ORGANIZATION spent lavishly during the 2014-15 international signing period, handing a $72.5 million contract to GPE, giving a record $31.5 million bonus (and paying a matching tax penalty to ORGANIZATION) to PERSON and locking up the top amateur pitcher with a $1.8 million bonus for PERSON. After PERSON signed with little fanfare out of the ORGANIZATION in July 2014, he led the Rookie-level ORGANIZATION in K/BB ratio (21.0) and walk rate (0.4 per nine innings) in his 2015 debut and has pounded the strike zone ever since. He topped the short-season ORGANIZATION York-Penn League in wins (nine), ORGANIZATION (1.45), ORGANIZATION (0.95) and walk rate (1.0) last summer and has dominated in similar fashion in Class A this year.PERSON doesn't have a pitch that grades better than average but has been effective against lower-level hitters because he can locate four offerings wherever he wants and sequences them well. His fastball usually ranges from 88-92 mph with decent life, and he uses his 6-foot-4 frame and high arm slot to create steep downhill plane. His changeup is his most consistent secondary pitch, while his harder slider is more effective than his curveball, which has some downer action but lacks power.PERSON has precocious feel for pitching but doesn't have a lot of projection remaining, so he may not throw much harder. He has little margin for error and is vulnerable on the rare occasions he leaves pitches up in the strike zone. No GPE pitching prospect can match his performance since he has turned pro, though his ceiling may be no more than that of a No. 5 starter.

GPE spent more than $146 million on its 2014 international class, including a $72.5 million contract for ORGANIZATION and a record $31.5 million bonus (plus a matching amount in penalty tax) for PERSON. Signed with no fanfare for $90,000 out of the ORGANIZATION Republic that July, PERSON has pounded the strike zone and dominated everywhere he has gone since. The low Class A GPE ORGANIZATION named him its pitcher of the year in 2018, when he ranked second in the Minors in GPE (0.91), fourth in GPE (1.97) and K/BB ratio (7.6) and fifth in walk rate (1.1 per nine innings).PERSON derives his success from uncanny command, a knack for sequencing his pitches and deception. His fastball works from 88-92 mph with ordinary life, but plays better than its velocity because he uses his 6-foot-4 frame and high arm slot to create extension and downhill plane. His changeup is his most reliable secondary offering and his low-80s slider/cutter is more effective than his mid-70s curveball, which has shape but lacks power.PERSON has supreme pitchability but his body is fairly maxed out, so he probably won't throw much harder. He has little margin for error but rarely made mistakes while averaging 0.9 walks per nine innings during his first four pro seasons. While it's hard to give him a ceiling higher than a No. 5 starter, he's intelligent, determined and gets the most out of his ability.

Back in 2015, PERSON was ranked No. 27 on ORGANIZATION's Top 30 ORGANIZATION list as a potential future shortstop, with strong enough reports to warrant a $2 million bonus from the PERSON to sign that July. A strong pro debut in the ORGANIZATION pushed him to the GPE League that summer, but he's struggled to find his offensive footing since.The PERSON sent PERSON to full-season Rome to start 2017, and it was a mistake. The teenage switch-hitter was in over his head in the LOCATION League and got sent back down to the ORGANIZATION to try to hit the reset button. He still has solid tools and excellent athleticism, with his plus speed his true carrying tool. At his best, he's shown the ability to make consistent contact and spray line drives all over the field, more consistently from the right side than the left. While he was a shortstop initially, he moved over to second when he went back down to Danville a year ago and that's now his likely full-time home, where he should be a capable defender without his fringy arm causing issues.It's hard to put pressure on a 19-year-old by saying that it's a big year for him, but the 2018 season could be a huge one for PERSON. He has plenty of time to develop into a speedy everyday second baseman, but he needs to start showing what he can do.

PERSON was ranked No. 27 on MLBPipeline.com's Top 30 ORGANIZATION list in 2015, and the ORGANIZATION liked him enough to give him $2 million to sign. He hit so well during his Gulf Coast League debut that he earned a promotion up to the GPE League at age 17.PERSON didn't continue swinging a hot bat once he got to GPE, but the ORGANIZATION were impressed with how the teenager maturely dealt with adversity. He's still learning how to switch-hit; he's much better from his natural right side, and while his left-handed swing is workable, there is a chance he'll eventually stick to that side only. He does make consistent hard contact with some extra-base gap power, and he could grow into some more, though it's not likely to be a huge part of his game. His hitting will continue to improve as he refines his approach. He's a plus runner who will be a basestealing threat. His defense at short has improved tremendously, especially after working tirelessly with PERSON. The only thing in question about him staying there is his fringe-average arm, though physical maturity and confidence will aid that particular tool.PERSON is starting to grow into some man strength, which will only help him in all facets of his game. He'll play all of the 2017 season at age 18, already ahead of the curve developmentally.

PERSON was ranked No. 27 on MLBPipeline.com's Top 30 international prospect list in 2015, and the ORGANIZATION loved his athleticism and makeup enough to give him $2 million to sign in July of that summer. He responded to their faith with a strong GPE debut in the ORGANIZATION before earning a promotion up to the GPE League at age 17. The switch-hitting infielder is a stronger hitter from the right side, where he can make consistent contact with a line-drive swing. It's gap power right now, but he might grow into a little more in the future, especially as he refines his approach. His best offensive tool is his speed, and it's plus, which should allow him to be a basestealing threat. It also helps him cover a lot of ground in the infield, with his range and feet giving him a chance to stay at short. His arm might not. He has fringy arm strength and struggles with his mechanics at times, with some thinking he might end up at second or in center field. For now, he'll continue to get work at shortstop, where he'll continue trying to live up to the comps to Jose PERSON that were dropped on him when he was an amateur.

The ORGANIZATION spent more than $17 million during the 2014-15 international signing period, giving out seven-figure bonuses to seven different position players. Their biggest expenditure was $3 million for PERSON, the ORGANIZATION. 1 prospect on MLBPipeline.com's international prospect list.PERSON had the best raw power in the 2014-15 international class and regularly put on a show in batting-practice workouts. He could hit plenty of home runs by letting them come naturally, but he sells out for power so much that there are some concerns about how well he'll be able to handle pro pitching. PERSON has infield actions, soft hands and a strong arm, he's unlikely to remain at shortstop. He's a fringy runner who figures to lose a step as he fills out, making him better suited for third base. If he delivers on his power potential, he'll provide enough offense to profile at any position.

ORGANIZATION's top-rated prospect in the 2014-15 international crop, PERSON got the largest payout ($3 million) in a ORGANIZATION spending binge that exceeded $17 million in bonuses. Though power is his carrying tool, he didn't homer in his '15 pro debut before bouncing back with 30 homers in 120 games over the next two seasons. PERSON also struck out in 32 percent of his plate appearances, making him the biggest boom-or-bust prospect in the system.PERSON's outstanding bat speed and strength give him top-of-the-scale raw power, though it remains to be seen how much he'll be able to tap into it against more advanced pitching. He still has trouble with recognizing pitches and handling offspeed offerings, and he has yet to prove he can make consistent contact. PERSON has displayed a willingness to accept walks, though he still chases pitches out of the strike zone with alarming frequency.PERSON has plenty of arm strength for third base, but he's a well-below-average runner with limited range and a history of errors at the hot corner. He has seen most of his action at first base in 2018, but he may never be more than an adequate defender there. GPE has begun trying PERSON on the mound in bullpen sessions, during which he has shown a mid-90s fastball and some feel for spinning a curveball and using a changeup.

The ORGANIZATION. 1 prospect on MLBPipeline.com's international prospect list for the 2014-15 signing period, PERSON signed for $3 million -- the largest bonus in a ORGANIZATION spending spree that totaled more than $17 million. Considered the best power prospect in that international class, he didn't go deep in his 2015 pro debut but ranked second in the Rookie-level GPE League with 13 homers last summer.PERSON has exceptional bat speed and strength that create raw power which earns top-of-the-scale grade from some evaluators. He's as raw as he is powerful, however, as he has a long way to go with recognizing pitches, handling offspeed offerings and making consistent contact. He topped the ORGANIZATION with 79 strikeouts and a 34 percent whiff rate while also ranking second-to-last with a .206 batting average.A classic boom-or-bust type, PERSON will have to deliver on his prodigious power potential to have a big league career. He has a strong arm but is a well below-average runner with limited range and has provided erratic defense at third base. Though he's working to improve his agility and glovework, he probably will wind up at first base.

PERSON had hamstring issues during his senior year of high school in GPE, forcing him to miss the season, which led to him being available in the second round at pick No. 53, the ORGANIZATION' first selection in the 2015 Draft. The problems persisted that summer and into 2016, limiting the talented outfielder to just 236 at-bats over two summers. In 2017 he avoided leg injuries, but an elbow problem ended his season in July with ulnar nerve surgery and he spent time on the disabled list again in 2018.The good news is that despite all the missed time, PERSON still shows solid tools at the plate. Trouble seeing the ball led to a rough start during his first taste of full-season ball in 2017, but after that was addressed with a new prescription, he started to hit for average and power before his season ended, though that didn't carry over to the following season. He can drive the ball to all fields and will draw walks, albeit with a fairly high strikeout rate, though that improved with the sight adjustment. He still runs well, despite the leg issues, and while he was hesitant because of the injuries, he might get the green light more moving forward on the basepaths and it allows him to cover a lot of ground and play a solid center field. His arm is fine for center, but he'd likely have to move to left should he slow down.The first order of business is for PERSON to get a full season of reps in on both sides of the ball so he can continue refining his approach at the plate as well as his reads and routes in the outfield. If he can do that, then it might be easier to project his upside.

Hamstring issues have likely kept PERSON from being more known on the prospect landscape. Then again, the fact that he missed his senior year of high school with a hamstring injury is likely the only reason he was around for the ORGANIZATION to take him in the second round, a silver lining in that cloud.When PERSON is on the field, he might be one of the highest-upside players in the ORGANIZATION system. A tremendous athlete, the GPE prep product has the potential to eventually be a plus hitter with plus power. He can drive the ball the other way and will have over-the-fence power in the future. He has been working on refining his approach, though his strikeout rate was high in his first taste of full-season ball in 2017. He has plus speed, but his hamstring issues -- he not only missed his last amateur year, he lost some time in 2016 as well -- have been a concern and kept him from completely letting loose. An infielder in high school, Linday's still adjusting to life in center field, where the ORGANIZATION feel he'll eventually develop into an above-average defender. PERSON needs to stay healthy and get reps on both sides of the ball to progress and potentially move into a more impact-level prospect territory. He missed three weeks in 2017 but far surpassed his previous highs in games played and at-bats.

While a hamstring injury limited PERSON to just seven games during his senior season in the GPE high school ranks, the ORGANIZATION clearly saw enough of him over the summer and fall to feel comfortable making him their first selection of the 2015 Draft, the ORGANIZATION. 59 overall pick in the second round.With five-tool potential, there's a lot to like from PERSON when he's healthy. He can make consistent hard contact at the plate, with good bat speed which leads to the ability to drive the gaps now and with more power to come. PERSON and athletic, PERSON runs very well, which should serve him well on both sides of the ball. Mostly an infielder in high school, PERSON has the tools to handle the outfield, with some thinking he has the chance to play center field regularly.Especially since he missed so much time with the injury - his pro debut was delayed as well - it might some time for PERSON to get going. But the end result could be a very exciting player to watch.

Hamstring issues wiped out PERSON's senior year of high school in GPE, but the ORGANIZATION liked his tools and projection enough that they took him with their first overall pick (ORGANIZATION. 53 overall) in the 2015 Draft. PERSON's hamstring problems persisted that summer and into 2016, limiting the talented outfielder to 236 at-bats over two summers. When his legs were finally healthy in 2017, an elbow injury ended PERSON's season in July and required ulnar nerve transposition surgery. A flare-up in his elbow in '18 led to another trip to the ORGANIZATION, but he came back strong and impressed in the ORGANIZATION, showing some newfound power as part of his across-the-board tools. In the ORGANIZATION, PERSON consistently achieved a better point of contact with his swing, with bat speed and extension that allowed him to tap into his plus raw power. After homering three times in 360 plate appearances during the regular season, PERSON needed only 31 PAs to match that total in the ORGANIZATION. That ability to consistently impact the ball has been absent for much of PERSON's career, and the hope is that it will unlock his potential as someone who hits for both average and power. He can drive the ball to all fields and will draw walks, albeit with some swing-and-miss tendencies. PERSON still runs well, despite the leg issues, and while he's largely been hesitant on the basepaths because of the injuries, he should get the green light more moving forward provided he stays healthy. His plus speed allows him to cover a lot of ground and play a solid center field, where his average arm strength is a fit. Evaluators who have seen PERSON at his best are quick to note that his production as a pro does not reflect his tools and potential. If he can avoid the disabled list, PERSON could develop into a second-division regular in center field.

Because PERSON missed most of his senior season of high school with a hamstring injury, he was a bit difficult to evaluate before the 2015 ORGANIZATION. The ORGANIZATION saw him play really well the summer before, including at their own ORGANIZATION, making them confident enough to nab him in the second round, their first selection in the ORGANIZATION due to the ORGANIZATION signing.Once PERSON got on the field, he didn't disappoint, earning a promotion from the Rookie-level Gulf Coast League up to Class A Short-Season Brooklyn. The GPE prepster showed a good approach at the plate, with good bat speed and a willingness to work counts. He has some natural strength, and while his power is mostly gap-to-gap right now, there should be more to come. PERSON has excellent speed, which should allow him to be a dynamic player on both sides of the ball. A corner infielder in high school, he's making the switch to center field in pro ball. He has the tools to eventually be an average defender there.With athleticism to spare, PERSON has plenty of raw tools to work with. It may take him a while, but he has the potential to be an everyday center fielder at the big league level.

PERSON was a two-year starter at ORGANIZATION, where most scouts viewed him as a good college player who lacked an above-average tool and didn't fit the profile at second base. The ORGANIZATION took him in the fifth round of the 2018 Draft because they thought he had some upside if he could make some adjustments, though he hit just .240/.348/.332 in his pro debut. He has taken off in 2019, however, emerging as one of the most dangerous hitters in the Class A Advanced California League.In college, PERSON focused on making contact and getting on base. He since has added some muscle and GPE has gotten him to be more aggressive, use his legs more and add some loft to his right-handed swing. Now he's getting the most out of his strong 6-foot-3 frame and displaying at least average power to all fields.PERSON still has fringy speed but he has transformed himself on defense at well. After previously showing a subpar arm and range at second base, he has quickened his footwork and improved his arm strength. He now looks like a reliable second baseman and has proven himself capable of handling third base.

ORGANIZATION's top-rated prospect on the international amateur market for 2018-19, PERSON signed for $2.5 million out of GPE in July. His addition bolstered an already strong collection of ORGANIZATION catching prospects that ranks as the best in baseball. He won't make his pro debut until 2019 but is advanced enough to come to the GPE at age 17 when he does.PERSON draws repeated PERSON comparisons because of his large frame, defensive ability and strong makeup. He moves well for a tall guy behind the plate and demonstrates advanced receiving skills for his age. He has the arm strength and accuracy to keep the running game in check.One way in which he differs from GPE is that PERSON's hitting stands out more than his power. He understands the strike zone and recognizes pitches better than most teenagers, and he shows a willingness to use the opposite field. He has mostly gap power at present but could develop into a 15-homer threat as he gets stronger and turns on more pitches.

The ORGANIZATION have more catching depth than any farm system, and they added to it last July when they landed ORGANIZATION's top-rated international amateur in the 2018 class. They signed PERSON for $2.5 million out of GPE, banking on his potential to contribute on both sides of the ball coupled with strong makeup. He draws repeated PERSON comparisons and like the perennial All-Star and ORGANIZATION, PERSON was advanced enough to make his GPE debut at 17.Though he's taller than most catchers, PERSON is agile and moves well behind the plate. He already shows advanced receiving ability for a teenager and should fit in well in an organization that prioritizes framing skills. He also has a strong arm and makes accurate throws.PERSON's feel for barrel and the strike zone stands out for such a young player. He recognizes pitches well and is willing to use the opposite field, emphasizing making hard contact over selling out for power. As he learns to turn on pitches and use his lower half more in his right-handed swing, he could produce 15 or more homers per year.

After pitching at GPE (Ga.) PERSON as a freshman, PERSON transferred to PERSON (PERSON, Ga.) in 2016 and helped the program win a 5-A state title. He returned to GPE for his senior year, established himself as one of the top left-handed pitchers ahead of the 2017 Draft and became the fourth southpaw to come off the board when the PERSON took him with the ORGANIZATION. 21 overall pick. He signed for above slot at $3 million. Making his full-season debut in the Class A GPE ORGANIZATION in 2018, PERSON scuffled initially but dominated during the second half, posting a 0.84 ERA with 64 strikeouts and a .171 ORGANIZATION over his final 53 2/3 frames (11 appearances).PERSON already pitches with a plus fastball, sitting at 92-94 mph and reaching 96, with late life that makes the pitch difficult to barrel. His curveball is above average but can flash plus, thrown with a high spin rate that gives it late bite, and the same can be said about the fading changeup he's made strides in developing. Meanwhile, that he does a good job repeating his simple delivery and knows how to find his release point with each pitch suggests he could develop above-average command.The PERSON kept PERSON on a tight leash during his first full season and never allowed him to throw more than 90 pitches in a start. While the training wheels should come off a bit more going forward, it wouldn't be surprising if the club employed a similar approach to managing PERSON's workload in 2019. That could lead to a slower climb through the Minors for the young lefty, who has the upside of a mid-rotation starter at the highest level.

After two years at ORGANIZATION (PERSON, Ga.), PERSON returned to GPE (Ga.) High, where he pitched as a freshman. While he was gone, he helped PERSON win the 2016 state 5-A title and established himself as one of the top left-handed pitchers in the 2017 Draft. PERSON only confirmed that assessment this spring with an impressive senior campaign, and he became the fourth southpaw selected in the Draft after the ORGANIZATION took him with the ORGANIZATION. 21 overall pick in the first round. He signed for above slot at $3 million, forgoing a commitment to PERSON State.PERSON usually operates at 90-93 mph and can touch 95 with his heater, which has some running action but is more notable for his command than his life. His hard curve is often his best offering and features a high spin rate, though it can get slurvy at times. While his changeup is still in its nascent stages, it's showing improvement as he commits to throwing it more often.PERSON draws comparisons to PERSON for his build and live arm. He has a sound delivery, though his arm slot can wander and detract from his control and command. And while he isn't very big or physical, PERSON still has some room to add strength.

After two years at ORGANIZATION (PERSON, Ga.), PERSON returned to GPE (Ga.) High, where he pitched as a freshman. While he was gone, he helped PERSON win the 2016 state 5-A title and established himself as one of the top left-handed pitchers in the 2017 Draft. PERSON only confirmed that assessment with an impressive senior campaign, and he became the fourth southpaw selected in the Draft when the ORGANIZATION took him with the ORGANIZATION. 21 overall pick. The ORGANIZATION State commit signed for above slot at $3 million and then had an uneven professional debut in the ORGANIZATION, but he's looked every bit the first-round pick during an impressive full-season debut in the Class A GPE ORGANIZATION. PERSON already pitches with a plus fastball, operating at 92-94 mph and touching 95, and scouts expect him to add more velocity as he grows into his projectable frame. His curveball is at least an above-average offering, thrown with a high spin rate that gives it late bite, while his changeup, though still in its nascent stages, projects to be average. PERSON's arm slot can be inconsistent at times, thus limiting his command, though he did make strides in cleaning up his delivery during the club's fall instructional league.PERSON draws comparisons to PERSON for his build, live arm and overall upside. The ORGANIZATION, meanwhile, will be patient in developing the young southpaw, whom they view as a future mid-rotation starter.

When the ORGANIZATION signed PERSON for $175,000 back in July 2014 out of the ORGANIZATION, they knew the lefty was a bit of a project who might take some time to develop. While that process is still in its relative early stages, the early signs of progress have certainly been encouraging.PERSON projects as a future starter with a solid three-pitch mix. While his fastball is just average now, there is more in the tank, with the chance for it to be a future plus pitch. PERSON has had success throwing it with good sink to get ground-ball outs. He complements his heavy fastball with a solid curveball and changeup, and he has shown the ability to throw strikes with all three offerings. PERSON is athletic and repeats his delivery well.There's still a long way to go for PERSON, who has yet to hit full-season ball. But the 19-year-old has a ton of projection and appears headed in the right direction, with a potential future as a middle or back-end of the rotation type starter.

PERSON considered PERSON one of the top defensive outfielders in the 2016 prep class, but his lack of profile tools and commitment to PERSON left him undrafted. A three-year starter in center for the ORGANIZATION, he was their best hitter at the 2018 College World Series, where they lost to PERSON in the finals. As with his older brother PERSON, an infielder with the ORGANIZATION, his skills still stand out more than his pure physical ability. The D-backs took PERSON with the last of their seven picks on Day 1 of the 2019 Draft and assigned him straight to Class A Kane County for his pro debut.PERSON's best attribute is his play in center field. Though he's a fringy runner out of the batter's box, he's quicker once he gets going and has tremendous instincts that allow him to track down balls from gap to gap. He has displayed plus arm strength in the past, though it has played closer to average in 2019.PERSON has a power-based approach at the plate, and his strength and aggressive, pull-conscious mentality could produce 15-20 homers per season. He doesn't have the smoothest left-handed swing and he's a streaky hitter, but he makes consistent contact and should hit for a decent average. He has shown improved discipline at the plate this spring, though his offensive package may fit better for a fourth outfielder than an everyday player.

A prototypical projectable high school right-hander, PERSON's stock initially rose with a big PERSON Games performance in the summer of 2017. An uneven senior season after that hurt, though he was pitching well as the ORGANIZATION approached. The ORGANIZATION nabbed him in the ninth round and went way over pick value to sign him away from his GPE commitment for $800,000 and sent him out for his debut in the ORGANIZATION League.PERSON has the chance to have three average or better pitches when all is said and done. Tall and lean, the right-hander has a live and loose arm that currently throws a fastball anywhere in the 88-94 mph range.
