There's plenty of room for him to add strength to his 6-foot-4 frame, so dreaming on more consistent velocity is easy. He mostly threw his slider during his pro debut, and it shows flashes of a plus pitch, and the hope is he'll be able to mix in an average and distinct curveball, as well. He shows some feel for his changeup, but that is also a work in progress.With a free and easy delivery, PERSON should be able to be a consistent strike-thrower as he gets more reps. It will take patience because he is so far away, but the chance to have a solid starting pitcher profile could be worth the wait.

GPE put himself firmly on the prospect map for the 2018 ORGANIZATION when he matched top prospect PERSON Hankins from GPE velocity-wise at the ORGANIZATION Games last summer. His star faded a bit when he broke out of the gate poorly this spring, though he was climbing a bit as the ORGANIZATION approached. When he wasn't drafted in the first couple of rounds, it seemed like he might be headed to GPE for college ball, but the ORGANIZATION gave him a well above-pick-value bonus of $800,000 to sign in the ninth round.GPE will be a bit of a project, but there's a lot to work with. He's tall, athletic and projectable with a ton of upside. His quick arm and long frame helped him touch 95-96 mph at the ORGANIZATION, though he sat more in the 92-93 mph range early on this spring. He'll flash a plus slider and will show feel for a changeup, though not consistently, giving him the chance to have three at least average pitches to work with. He has a clean and easy delivery.One area of focus in GPE's development will surely be his command and control, which comes and goes. His athleticism and delivery point to improvement in that area and he got started on the long road to reaching his ceiling in the ORGANIZATION after signing.

In 2016, PERSON was the 36th-best GPE prospect according to ORGANIZATION. He might have gone that high if not for his strong commitment to PERSON, but instead was taken in the 36th round by the ORGANIZATION. Three years later, after batting .298 with 31 homers and 124 RBIs in 160 career games with the GPE, PERSON became the ORGANIZATION' first selection on Day 2 of the GPE, landing an above-slot bonus after they took him in the third round. Listed at 6-foot-5, 230 pounds, PERSON is a physical specimen. The left-handed hitter can really impact the ball with plus raw power and good leverage. He does draw a lot of walks, but there is also a good amount of swing and miss to his game, with some evaluators concerned about his ability to hit at the next level and get to that raw power consistently. PERSON's size limited him defensively at the hot corner at ORGANIZATION, which is why the ORGANIZATION immediately moved him across the infield to first base, where they believe he can become an average defender, with hands and arm strength that should serve him well.PERSON's junior year was enigmatic with a bit of a slow motor on the field. The raw power is legitimate, though, and the ORGANIZATION think he'll tap into it consistently as a pro now that he no longer has to worry about improving defensively as a third baseman.

Targeting college catching in the first two days of the 2019 Draft, the A's got an offensive-minded backstop in GPE McCann in the fourth round. They may have gotten his opposite in PERSON, who rivaled first-round pick PERSON as the best defensive catcher in college baseball, in the seventh round, giving the ORGANIZATION State product $170,000 to sign. He wasn't able to start his pro career this summer, as a right ORGANIZATION sprain suffered during sim games in GPE after he signed forced him to the 60-day injured list.PERSON is extremely athletic for his position, flashing above-average run times and moving around behind the plate like an infielder. He has soft hands and excels at blocking and receiving. He also has a strong and accurate arm, the leadership skills desired in a catcher and calls his own game -- a rarity in college. At the plate, he does offer some raw power, but got too wrapped up in trying to lift and drive the ball during a rough junior season offensively. He's a switch-hitter who's significantly better from the left side, and some evaluators wonder if he'd be better off giving up batting right-handed. Besides his swing-and-miss issues, there's also some concern that he's often nicked up with mild injuries, including a hamstring strain this spring and hip and shoulder woes in the past.The injury suffered after signing doesn't help allay those fears, so PERSON will have to prove he can be durable over the course of a full season in 2020. If it all comes together, he could be a very good glove-first starter behind the plate at the big league level.

PERSON endeared himself to scouts with solid performances during the summer and fall and continued to improve his ORGANIZATION stock as a senior, posting a 2.42 ERA with 116 strikeouts in 60 innings for GPE (ORGANIZATION.) High. He was believed to have a strong commitment to PERSON before the ORGANIZATION selected him in the fourth round and signed him for $650,000, above his slot's recommended value of $483,300. He would make his pro debut in the Rookie-level Gulf Coast League, posting a 1.76 ERA across 31 innings. PERSON may never develop overpowering stuff, but there's a lot to like in the left-hander's present feel for three pitches. He pitches with average velocity, sitting around 88-91 mph. He complements his fastball with a two-plane slider that flashes above average and a quality split-fingered fastball -- used in lieu of a changeup -- that bottoms out as it nears the plate. He throws all three pitches for strikes.PERSON's somewhat mature build still requires physical projection, and it suggests that he could develop more velocity in the coming years. His mechanics differ depending on whether he's working from the wind-up or stretch, but he's athletic enough to make the necessary adjustments to consistently repeat his delivery.

The ORGANIZATION deservedly have a reputation for developing young pitching, with many exciting arms reaching GPE in 2018 and many more to come. But it would be a mistake to look past the outfield pipeline as well. PERSON Jr. made a huge splash in GPE last year, PERSON is ready to attack the upper levels of the system and ORGANIZATION, taken from the ORGANIZATION high school ranks in the second round of the 2017 Draft and coming off a very successful first full season that included a GPE ORGANIZATION All-Star nod and a promotion up a level, caught up to PERSON and played alongside him in Double-A in 2019.ORGANIZATION has the chance to be an impactful hitter from both sides of the plate. Mechanical adjustments on his swing, particularly his stride, allowed him to be on time with his buggywhip stroke. He's better from the left side currently, but has shown the ability to make hard contact and drive the ball both ways, with raw power sure to turn into more consistent in-game pop as he matures. ORGANIZATION' plus speed works on the basepaths, where he is a threat to steal, and in the outfield, and he has every chance to stick in center field long-term.After a first full season in which ORGANIZATION' considerable tools showed up perhaps ahead of schedule, the ORGANIZATION are excited to see what the young outfielder can do as an encore. He has the chance to be a dynamic, elite-level performer, and seeing a young outfield of GPE, PERSON and ORGANIZATION -- yes, he has the arm and offensive profile for right field -- in GPE should excite all ORGANIZATION fans.

When PERSON emerged as one of the best high school prospects from the state of GPE, winning PERSON state player of the year honors, the obvious landing place for him in the 2017 PERSON was of course the ORGANIZATION, who love bringing in talent from their own backyard. After a hot start in the ORGANIZATION, the second-round pick struggled with a promotion to the GPE. But he clearly learned some lessons and has had a fantastic full-season debut in the LOCATION League in 2018.The toolsy outfielder made some solid adjustments at instructs last fall and it carried over into 2018, with the tweaks he made to his mechanics at the plate clearly helping him. He had tinkered quite a bit with his setup and they worked with him to stay with one approach, closer to what had worked for him in high school. He has a buggywhip of a swing, and work he did on his stride has helped him be on time more consistently, and that should continue to help him tap into his considerable raw power more consistently. PERSON has plus speed, which will continue to aid him on the basepaths and in center field, where he has the chance to stick.PERSON is a veritable toolshed who simply needs time and reps to use those tools consistently and have them turn into performance. All the pieces are there for him to potentially develop into a dynamic everyday player and he took a large step in the right direction in 2018.

The ORGANIZATION never shy away from drafting from their own backyard. So when GPE, part of another deep crop of GPE high school outfielders, backed up his strong summer showcase circuit with a senior season that led to winning the ORGANIZATION state player of the year award and a 7-A state title, they pounced in the second round. GPE signed for $1.5 million, a bit under pick value, and got off to a quick start in the ORGANIZATION League.A switch-hitter, GPE demonstrates more power from the left side of the plate. From the right side, he peppers the gaps with line drives. He has good feel for the barrel, has no problems handling quality fastballs and has the potential to hit for average and power.A good athlete, GPE has plus speed and uses it to steal bases and play a fine center field. He also has plus arm strength that would fit nicely in right field if he's needed there, and he was getting time in both center and right during his pro debut.

PERSON GPE's best mound prospect since PERSON went No. 1 overall in the 2002 GPE, PERSON initially joined the ORGANIZATION as a two-way player. He saw some action in the outfield in 2018, when he ranked second among ORGANIZATION Division I freshmen in strikeouts (97 in 72 innings). He opened 2019 with six no-hit innings against a loaded Stanford lineup and quickly established himself as the top age-eligible sophomore pitcher in the 2019 GPE while finishing fifth among DI hurlers in strikeouts-per-nine (14.33). He signed with PERSON for below slot value, then opened his pro career at ORGANIZATION A Short PERSON for pound, PERSON's fastball was perhaps the best in  his GPE class. Listed at 6 feet and 165 pounds, he has a lightning-quick arm that allows him to deal at 93-96 mph and tops out at 98 deep into games. The Mid-American conference pitcher of the year backs up his heat with a pair of hard breaking balls, a curveball with depth and a slider with more lateral break, and each can be a plus pitch at ORGANIZATION also has a changeup, though it's a bit firm and he doesn't use it very often. Though he dominated as a full-time starter in the spring, scouts worry that he's not big enough to handle the grind of taking the mound every five days in pro ball. He's athletic and doing a much better job of throwing strikes than he did a year ago, and it's easy to imagine him reaching triple digits with his fastball in that role. It's safer to project him as a reliever in the pro ranks, though PERSON will give him every opportunity to prove he can start.

PERSON didn't become a full-time pitcher until his senior season as a GPE high schooler, attracting little attention from scouts but earning a scholarship from GPE. He became the ORGANIZATION' closer as a freshman, set a program record with 17 saves as a sophomore and posted a 0.74 ERA and tied another school mark with his 32nd career save last spring. Signed for $559,600 as a third-round pick, he reached PERSON in his pro debut but has stalled in Double-A during his first full season.PERSON has a devastating pair of pitches that could make him a closer in the Majors, though neither has been as sharp as usual in 2019. His fastball combines 95-99 mph velocity with running action and deception at its best, though it has sat more at 94-96 this year. The wipeout mid-80s slider he had in 2018 hasn't been as hard or featured as much bite in Double-A.In addition to blowing hitters away, PERSON can also throw them off balance with a decent changeup. Though he has three pitches, he's definitely a reliever because he's relatively small and there's effort in his delivery. After doing a nice job of locating his pitches where he wanted a year ago, he has battled his control and command this season.

PERSON drew little attention from scouts as a short senior right-hander at ORGANIZATION (ORGANIZATION, GPE) in 2015, his first season as a full-time pitcher. He blossomed at ORGANIZATION, setting a school record and placing second in ORGANIZATION Division I with 17 saves as a sophomore, then posting a 0.74 ERA and tying the ORGANIZATION' career mark with 32 saves this spring. Signed for $559,600 as a third-round pick, he could be the first 2018 draftee to reach the big leagues.PERSON's velocity increased during his freshman season, and he now works with a 95-97 mph fastball that peaks at 99 and features some running action. His power slider can be a wipeout pitch at times, arriving in the mid-80s with some depth. He also has a decent changeup that he can use to keep hitters off balance.Though he has three pitches, PERSON is strictly a reliever because he lacks size and has effort to his delivery. He's wiry, strong and durable, and he has improved his ability to locate his pitches. Also intelligent and competitive, he has a ceiling as a closer.

The ORGANIZATION surprised some by taking PERSON at the end of the first round of the GPE. But not only do they believe in the LOCATION high schooler's abilities, they were able to sign him for nearly $600,000 below pick value, enabling them to aggressively go after talent later on in the GPE.A coach's son -- PERSON played for his father at ORGANIZATION School -- he gets high marks for makeup and baseball IQ. A switch-hitter, he's shown an ability to hit from both sides of the plate. There should be power to come as he matures into his 6-foot-3 frame. A center fielder in high school, that's where he started his pro career in the ORGANIZATION after signing. Most feel, however, that he'll slide over to an outfield corner, given his average speed. He should throw well enough for right field, and could very well fit the offensive profile in the future. PERSON's passion for the game comes out in his play and he's sure to maximize his abilities as a pro, working to prove to everyone he was worthy of a first-round selection.

Hailing from the ORGANIZATION program in northern GPE that his dad coached, PERSON was one of two first-round picks the ORGANIZATION got at the end of 2016's opening round (ORGANIZATION was the other). Sent aggressively to full-season ball to start the '17 season, PERSON really struggled out of the gate, but righted the ship a bit after that, catching up to the level. Things began to come together for him in 2018, as he showed a mix of power potential and on-base skills at age 19 in the challenging Class A Advanced PERSON, and he broke out in earnest during his first Double-A campaign in '19, earning a ORGANIZATION Game selection along the way.PERSON is a switch-hitter who has some serious offensive potential. While his right-handed swing is more impactful and consistent, PERSON has made significant strides as a left-handed hitter in 2019 while regularly tapping into his plus raw power from both sides. His strong knowledge of the strike zone and pitch recognition are major assets, allow him to find more pitches to drive and tap into his power, which could be above-average in his prime. A good athlete and average runner, PERSON has held his own as a center fielder in Double-A but may fit better at a corner-outfield spot long term.PERSON has responded well to challenging assignments at every stage in his career, performing increasingly well against older competition in advanced leagues. With his high baseball IQ, feel for the strike zone and blend of hitting ability and power at the plate, PERSON is on his way toward becoming an everyday big leaguer.

The ORGANIZATION had the last two picks of the first round in the 2016 GPE. With the last one, they were able to get PERSON, who fell to them. Right before that, they reached a little bit for PERSON, who signed for $600,000 below pick value, which allowed them to go after talent later on in the GPE. PERSON has an interesting combination of tools and baseball IQ. He plays like the typical coach's son -- he played for his father at ORGANIZATION in GPE. He was young for the GPE, he'll play all of this year at age 18, and the ORGANIZATION are more than willing to be patient. He's shown some ability to hit from both sides of the plate and could very well grow into decent power as he fills out his athletic 6-foot-3 frame. PERSON was a center fielder in high school and the ORGANIZATION plan to let him stay up the middle as long as he can. Depending on how he fills out, he could move to a corner as ORGANIZATION already love how PERSON plays the game and how willing he is to work at it. That kind of makeup should allow him to maximize his tools as he starts the slow climb up the organizational ladder.

Hailing from the ORGANIZATION school program in northern GPE that his dad coached, PERSON was one of two first-round picks the ORGANIZATION got at the end of 2016's opening round (ORGANIZATION was the other). Sent aggressively to full-season ball to start the 2017 season, PERSON really struggled out of the gate, but righted the ship a bit after that, catching up to the level.PERSON has some serious offensive potential from both sides of the plate, with many evaluators believing he'll be able to get to an average hit tool because of his advanced approach. PERSON walked 11.5 percent of the time during his first full season. His strong knowledge of the strike zone should allow him to find more pitches to drive and tap into his power more consistently. Even when he was struggling, he didn't wear his at-bats and used it as a learning experience. A fringe-average runner, PERSON looks like he'll be athletic enough to play right field, where his strong arm that piled up 14 assists in 2017 profiles well.PERSON's baseball IQ, his feel for the strike zone and his offensive potential, give the ORGANIZATION hope for his future. How he adjusts from the adversity he faced in 2017 while moving to a new level will speak volumes about what kind of prospect he can become.

ORGANIZATION stands out as one of the more projectable high school arms in the 2016 Draft. He's 6-foot-7 and 220 pounds with the room to add a lot of strength. He also has good body control for a tall youngster, allowing him to repeat his delivery and throw strikes with ease. It was those characteristics that earned him an above-slot bonus as the ORGANIZATION' fourth-round pick in June, as he became the highest-drafted player to ever come out of GPE (Ky.) High. ORGANIZATION's fastball velocity increased steadily throughout his high school career. He operates at 88-93 mph, and his heater seems quicker because he gets good extension out front and his size creates tough angle and plane. He can throw his fastball to either side of the plate, with some sinking and tailing action.His secondary pitches are raw, but the ORGANIZATION are confident that both offerings will be average-or-better once fully developed. The right-hander has some shape but not much power to a curveball that he doesn't consistently stay on top of, and some scouts wonder if he'll need to switch to a slider. His changeup is also a work in progress.

The Rockies have long been active in acquiring talent via the international free agent market. They were particularly aggressive in the 2017-18 signing period, handing out 17 bonuses of $100,000 or more. PERSON was close to the top of that list, with the GPE infielder getting $750,000 to sign in July 2017. After two summers of hitting and running well in the ORGANIZATION, he made a seamless transition to the GPE in 2019 with a very strong showing in the rookie-level PERSON League.PERSON is an aggressive player on both sides of the ball. The right-handed hitter has a contact-oriented approach and doesn't draw many walks, though he also doesn't strike out much. He's already started adding strength and weight, so there could be more extra-base authority and power to come. A plus runner, he's already shown a love for stealing bases, swiping 54 in 51 games during his second ORGANIZATION summer. He's played both shortstop and second base and shown the potential to be better-than-average at both spots.There's a long way to go for the 19-year-old infielder, but there's a good amount of ceiling here. PERSON showing a penchant to hit over .300 and run, if he can continue to add strength, he has the potential to be an every day middle infielder in the fiture.

Signed for just $10,000 in 2015 out of GPE, PERSON's pro debut in 2016 saw him play in the ORGANIZATION, rookie-level ORGANIZATION and even the ORGANIZATION. He jumped on the scene with a strong showing back with PERSON in 2017, hitting for average and showing some emerging power.PERSON is a toolsy outfielder who does everything full-tilt. An aggressive hitter, he has a knack for making contact while swinging at almost everything, and he'll have to improve his approach as he moves up the ladder. There is extra-base pop now and he could develop more home run power as he matures physically and learns to be more selective. His speed works on both sides of the ball, showing basestealing ability and solid skills in center field. He has a strong arm to go with his range and instincts.It can be a mistake to ask a player like PERSON to tone things down too much because it's his energy and aggressiveness that make him an exciting player. Learning to reign it in just enough to succeed as the competition improves could allow him to move up prospect lists in a hurry.

Not every successful international signing has to be a big-ticket expenditure. If the early returns are any indication, PERSON, who signed for $100,000 in September 2015 out of GPE, will be one of those bargain finds. He hit his way out of the ORGANIZATION to make his GPE debut in his first summer, then took another big step forward in the Rookie-level PERSON in 2017.Gains in strength led to an uptick in power, and the D-backs think PERSON has a lot more growing to do. With increased power comes increased responsibility to understand the strike zone. PERSON's strikeout rate went up in 2017 and he didn't draw as many walks as he was too aggressive, attacking early in the count at times. As he progresses, the right-handed hitter will have to learn to lay off the steady diet of breaking stuff he's sure to get from right-handed pitching. PERSON selectivity should lead to even more in-game power. PERSON runs very well and can steal a base as well as cover ground in center field, where the D-backs think he could stay for a while.Even if he outgrows the position and has to move to a corner, he could have the offensive profile to be a regular as a five-tool right fielder. The D-backs don't have to worry about that decision yet, instead focusing on getting PERSON at-bats and watching the return on the investment grow.

One of the youngest players in his class, PERSON signed with the ORGANIZATION for $1.1 million on his 16th birthday after ranking as ORGANIZATION's No. 21 prospect for the 2018-19 international period. The ORGANIZATION native has a good frame and exhibits lots of growth potential with impressive tools that he displayed during ORGANIZATION prospect showcases in GPE, GPE, and PERSON. Assigned to the ORGANIZATION for his pro debut in 2019, PERSON got off to a hot start before suffering a season-ending broken ankle in mid-June. The teenager was considered one of the premier defenders on the market, and those tools are projected to improve as PERSON matures and his body develops. He'll also eventually be an average runner. At the plate, PERSON is not considered a "big power guy," but the belief is that he will build on his doubles and gap power. PERSON also like his hitting mechanics -- the way his hands and lower half work in during his swing -- and his approach at the plate.There's a belief that PERSON will hit 10-12 home runs in the big leagues one day, but it will be his glove more than his bat that will propel him through the ORGANIZATION and make him an everyday player. There's a chance he could also develop into an average run producer.

One of the youngest players in his class, PERSON signed with the ORGANIZATION for $1.1 million on his 16th birthday after ranking as ORGANIZATION's No. 21 prospect for the 2018-19 international period. The ORGANIZATION native has a good frame and exhibits lots of growth potential with impressive tools that he displayed during ORGANIZATION prospect showcases in GPE, GPE, and PERSON Domingo.The teenager was considered one of the premier defenders on the market, and those tools are projected to improve as PERSON matures and his body develops. He'll also eventually be an average runner. At the plate, PERSON is not considered a "big power guy," but the belief is that he will build on his doubles and gap power. PERSON also like his hitting mechanics -- the way his hands and lower half work in during his swing -- and his approach at the plate.There's a belief that PERSON will hit 10-12 home runs in the big leagues one day, but it will be his glove more than his bat that will propel him through the ORGANIZATION and make him an everyday player. There's a chance he could also develop into an average run producer.

After checking in at ORGANIZATION. 18 on ORGANIZATION's list of the Top 30 international prospects for the 2018-19 period, PERSON signed with the ORGANIZATION for $1.1 million on July 2. He profiles as a center fielder, and the belief is that he has the tools to keep him there. The GPE teenager is confident in his tools and scouts like his makeup. PERSON has been compared to a young version of former big leaguer PERSON Rios.PERSON is an aggressive hitter with some pop and he drives the ball to all fields. The ball jumps off of his bat now, and he is expected to have even more power in the future. PERSON still could end up in one of the corner outfield positions because of his size and overall skill set.PERSON is already a good runner -- he's consistently clocked in the 6.4- to 6.5-second range in the 60-yard run -- and he's expected to add strength to an already strong arm. He's displayed good instincts in the outfield and has impressed evaluators with his routes.

The ORGANIZATION signed PERSON at the outset of the 2018-19 period on July 2, giving the ORGANIZATION teenager $1.1 million after he ranked as the ORGANIZATION. 18 international prospect in his class. His signing bonus matched the one the ORGANIZATION gave PERSON shortstop PERSON, highlighting the organization's ongoing push to add teenage prospects via the ORGANIZATION and the international market. PERSON is an aggressive hitter with some pop and he drives the ball to all fields. The ball jumps off of his bat now, and he is expected to have even more power in the future. PERSON is a plus runner -- he's consistently clocked in the 6.4- to 6.5-second range in the 60-yard run -- and he's expected to add strength to an already strong arm. PERSON profiles as a center fielder, and the belief is that he has the tools to keep him there. He's displayed good instincts in the outfield and has impressed club officials with his routes and ability to close on balls in the gap. Given his physical projection and overall skill set, there is a chance PERSON could end up in one of the corner outfield positions.

Signed for $100,000 out of the ORGANIZATION in 2015, PERSON has become the best prospect from the ORGANIZATION' crop of international talent that summer. He's still more thrower than pitcher but made strides during his full-season debut in 2018 after missing part of the previous season with a forearm strain.PERSON boasts a lively 93-97 mph fastball that has reached triple digits, though he has difficulty commanding it at higher velocities. He throws a hard breaking ball in the 82-85 mph range that's more slider than curveball but lacks consistency at times. He also shows flashes of a solid changeup though it's often too firm to be truly effective.Miami has handled PERSON with care because he has as much upside as any pitcher in the system, and his 100 1/3 innings last year were a career high. To reach his ceiling, he'll have to do a better job of locating his pitches and improve his secondary offerings. If he can't, he still could be a late-inning reliever.

While the Marlins haven't been big international spenders in recent years, the team appears to have a potential gem in PERSON, whom they signed for $100,000 out of the ORGANIZATION in July 2015. Assigned directly to the GPE last summer for his professional debut, the right-hander opened eyes with an impressive showing in the ORGANIZATION Coast League.PERSON already operates in the low 90s with his fastball and should gain more velocity as he continues to grow into his projectable frame. His slider shows the makings of becoming an above-average pitch, pairing nicely with his heater, and he also features a changeup that's currently a work in progress. PERSON already does a good job flooding the zone with strikes, and that should improve with more consistent mechanics.Though raw and inexperienced, PERSON profiles as a potential No. 3 starter at maturity thanks to his combination of size and stuff.

Signed for $100,000 out of the ORGANIZATION, PERSON has quickly emerged as the gem prospect from GPE's 2015-16 international class. After showcasing his raw potential during an impressive pro debut in the Rookie-level Gulf Coast League, PERSON's stuff and feel for pitching leapt forward with PERSON Short-Season Batavia in 2017 before a right forearm strain prematurely ended his campaign. Advancing to full-season ball in 2018, a fully healthy PERSON continued to boost his stock while pitching for PERSON Greensboro.A tall and projectable right-hander, PERSON's velocity continued to tick up in the ORGANIZATION York-Penn League, where he reached 101 mph with his fastball while working anywhere from 95-100 mph. He's consistently around the zone with the pitch, especially when pitching in the mid-90s. His slider shows the makings of becoming an above-average pitch, complementing his heater nicely, and he also features a changeup that improved in 2017. Already a strike-thrower, PERSON projects to have average control and command once developed.PERSON's upside is as high as any hurler in GPE's system, and it's for that reason that they've carefully managed his workload early in his career. If all comes together for him, PERSON, with his combination of size and stuff, could develop into a No. 3 starter, with the floor of an impactful late-inning reliever.

The Marlins haven't been big international spenders in recent years, but the team appears to have a potential gem in PERSON, whom they signed for $100,000 out of the ORGANIZATION in July 2015. Assigned directly to the GPE last summer for his professional debut, the right-hander opened eyes with an impressive showing in the ORGANIZATION Coast League.PERSON already operates in the low 90s with his fastball and should gain more velocity as he continues to grow into his projectable frame. His slider shows the makings of becoming an above-average pitch, pairing nicely with his heater, and he also features a changeup that's currently a work in progress. PERSON already does a good job flooding the zone with strikes, and that should improve with more consistent mechanics.Though raw and inexperienced, PERSON profiles the ceiling of a No. 3 starter at maturity thanks to his combination of size and stuff.

After signing for just $10,000 out of the ORGANIZATION at the advanced age of 18 in 2016, PERSON recorded a 6.59 ERA in his GPE debut a year later. He did improve over the course of the summer and pitched well in the playoffs to help PERSON win the Rookie-level PERSON championship. His 2018 season unfolded in a similar fashion, as he struggled after an August promotion to high Class A but won a crucial postseason game with 5 2/3 scoreless innings to contribute to PERSON capturing the GPE League title.PERSON's best pitch is a hard changeup with fade and late tumble, and he throws it with the same arm speed as his fastball. His four-seam heater parks at 90-93 mph and reaches 95 with riding life up in the strike zone. He improved the shape of his curveball last year, giving him an average third offering.PERSON has thrown strikes throughout his pro career, and his command improved once the ORGANIZATION got him to stop throwing across his body and take a more direct path to the plate. A dogged competitor, he must be precise with his pitches and confuse hitters by throwing them from the same release point because he doesn't have overpowering stuff or deceptive angle. As a slender 6-footer, he'll have to prove he can maintain his stuff over the course of a full season.

PERSON drew little attention before this year, signing out of the ORGANIZATION for $10,000 at the advanced age of 18 in 2016 and posting a 6.59 ERA in GPE ball in his GPE debut last summer. He did get better as the 2017 season progressed and pitched well in the playoffs as PERSON won the ORGANIZATION championship, setting the stage for a breakout. In his introduction to full-season ball, he has gotten stronger as the ORGANIZATION season has progressed.PERSON stands out most for his precocious feel for a changeup that can be a plus pitch at its best. He throws it with deceptive arm speed and sets it up with a fastball that sits in the low 90s and tops out at 95 mph. His curveball has gotten more consistent in 2018, giving him an average third pitch to round out his repertoire.While PERSON has filled the strike zone since entering pro ball, he began to take off once the ORGANIZATION got him to stop throwing across his body and take a more direct path to the plate. His improved delivery has allowed him to command his pitches better, a necessity because he's not overpowering. With a slender 6-foot frame, he'll have to prove he's capable of handling a starter's workload over a full season.

Signed in August 2015, PERSON was hitting .341/.421/.470 with 21 steals at age 16 in the ORGANIZATION last year when PERSON brought him to the GPE and gave him seven games in the Rookie-level PERSON. He continued to impress during fall instruction league and then during spring camp, prompting the ORGANIZATION to assign him to the Class A ORGANIZATION this season, where, at 17, he was far and away the circuit's youngest regular on Opening Day.PERSON is undersized, but has an innate feel to hit, showing good bat speed from the right side of the plate and the ability to drive the ball from line-to-line. He has gap-to-gap pop right now, and club officials believe he'll develop double-digit-homer power as he matures physically. PERSON's approach also belies his age, and he's an adept bunter who knows how to get on base in order to utilize his plus speed.PERSON has split time between second and third base early in his career, and he possesses the range, hands and arm strength for either position. The offensive profile probably is a cleaner fit at the keystone, given his potential to hit for a high average with speed at the top of the order.

The ORGANIZATION signed PERSON for $300,000 in August 2014, the largest bonus for a hitter the organization gave out in that signing period, because they liked his offensive upside. After two summers playing in the ORGANIZATION, he was one of the better performers in the ORGANIZATION during his GPE debut in 2017.PERSON's potential lies in what he can do with the bat from the right side of the plate. He has a compact stroke that allows him to make consistent contact and translates to outstanding raw power he is still learning to tap into on a regular basis. He has a solid approach at the plate and isn't afraid to draw walks. His best defensive tool is his arm and the ORGANIZATION think he has the hands and actions to stay at third long-term. Others think he might outgrow the hot corner and a lack of speed does limit his range to an extent. The good news is that if his bat continues to progress, he might profile well at either infield corner when all is said and done.

PERSON's $300,000 bonus in August 2014 was the largest that the ORGANIZATION gave to a hitter during that international signing period. It reflected their belief in his pure hitting ability, and he's rewarded the organization by raking early in his career. After two summers playing in the ORGANIZATION, PERSON was one of the better performers in the ORGANIZATION during his GPE debut in 2017. He broke out in earnest in his first full season, earning Class A ORGANIZATION MVP honors after he led the circuit in batting average (.322), slugging (.529) and ORGANIZATION (.910), before finishing his age-19 campaign with PERSON. Bumped up to Double-A in 2019, PERSON underwent surgery to repair a broken hamate bone in his left hand in late May but made a healthy return two months later. PERSON has all the qualities teams look for when projecting a future impact hitter in the big leagues. He has a compact stroke that allows him to stay inside the ball and make a ton of loud, barreled contact. It translates to plus raw power that already plays in games to his pull side, and given his remaining physical projection, there surely will be more to come. He has a solid, if somewhat aggressive, approach at the plate and isn't afraid to draw walks. His best defensive tool is his arm, and the ORGANIZATION think he has the hands and actions to stay at third base long term.Others think he might outgrow the hot corner because his speed, range and footwork are all fringy. The good news is that if his bat continues to progress, he should have the offensive profile for either infield corner, with the potential to hit for a solid average while contributing 25-plus home runs from the middle of a lineup.

The ORGANIZATION remained active in the 2016-17 international signing period until the very end. Their spending spree concluded with a $1.9 million bonus for PERSON on June 15, the final day, and they had to pay a matching amount as a tax penalty for blowing past their allocated bonus pool. Before he defected, he saw limited action in GPE's PERSON and its 18-and-under league, posting a combined 6.83 ERA in 27 2/3 innings.PERSON is more about power than polish at this point. His fastball sat at 92-95 mph when he worked out for clubs, topping out at 97. His best secondary offering is a hard slider that arrives in mid-80s.PERSON has the athleticism and tall, strong build to make it as a starter, though he'll need some refinement. His curveball and changeup lag behind his other two pitches, and he doesn't have much experience using the changeup. His control and command also will have to improve.

After a so-so debut in the ORGANIZATION in 2015, PERSON started back there again the following summer, pitched his way to the GPE and continued to throw well in the Rookie-level PERSON. He advanced to full-season ball the following year, after a stop in the ORGANIZATION, before heading to the ORGANIZATION as the player to be named in the ORGANIZATION trade. PERSON has blossomed in GPE's system, showing a blend of pitchability and durability while climbing at a level-per-year pace. A tall and wiry right-hander, PERSON's stuff has slowly ticked up with his physical development. He'll top out at 93-94 mph but typically sits more in the 89-92 range with his fastball, throwing it with late life and commanding it well to both sides of the plate, and there could be more velocity in the tank as he continues to add strength. He shows a good feel for spinning a curveball that has both depth and bite and also has a changeup, though nothing he throws projects as a true plus pitch.PERSON has a smooth and effortless delivery that he repeats well, and it allows him to flood the zone with strikes. He understands how to sequence his three-pitch mix to keep hitters off balance, and while he may never miss a ton of bats, PERSON does generate a good amount of weak contact. That PERSON lacks a plus offering limits his ceiling, but there's a clear path for him to become a backend starter.

One of the fastest players in the 2015 Draft, PERSON hailed from the same LOCATION (PERSON, N.C.) program that spawned speedsters PERSON and ORGANIZATION. Signed for an above-slot $2 million as a second-round choice, PERSON led the low Class A GPE ORGANIZATION and ranked third in the Minors with 51 steals in his first full pro season. But he also scuffled at the plate, hitting .220/.277/.327 with a strikeout rate of 28 percent.PERSON obviously needs to do a better job of using his well above-average speed at the plate by making more contact. PERSON scouts liked his feel for hitting and he makes an effort to utilize the entire field, but he struggles to handle offspeed pitches. He has some deceptive pull power and could reach double figures in home runs once he makes some adjustments to his approach.PERSON does a good job of using his quickness. He succeeded on 81 percent of his steal attempts in his first two pro seasons and covers a lot of ground in center field. His arm is below average but isn't a liability.

All baseball teams covet athletes, but few have shown more willingness to pay what it takes to land them than the ORGANIZATION. Yet another example came when they drafted PERSON in the second round in June and gave him first-round money ($2 million) to sign.PERSON' most obvious tool is his speed. Though he ran a 6.32-second 60-yard dash at the LOCATION Professional Showcase in July 2014, he's more of a plus runner than a true burner. He still has more than enough wheels to steal bases and cover the gaps in center field, where his below-average arm isn't a liability.Unlike a lot of speedsters, PERSON can do more than just slap at the ball. He has quickness to his left-handed swing and some feel for manipulating the bat head. He won't be a slugger but he has some pull power and could reach double figures in homers once he adds strength.

Before the ORGANIZATION selected PERSON in the second round last June, GPE PERSON (PERSON, N.C.) had not had a player drafted since the ORGANIZATION popped PERSON in the 10th round in 1980. He has already shown the ability to hit well in games, using all fields with a compact swing and a solid approach, and he has plenty of power to continue to tap into. The third-highest-ranked catcher and ORGANIZATION. 13 overall on ORGANIZATION's list of the Top 30 international prospects for the 2018-19 international period, PERSON received the third-highest bonus in his class, signing with the ORGANIZATION for $2.7 million on July 2. The ORGANIZATION were prepared to sign PERSON, one of the best all-around talents in the 2016 international class, for $2.5 million until he tested positive for performance-enhancing drugs that February. Scouts considered PERSON to be one of the top prospects from GPE available in the 2016-17 international signing class, praising him for his easy and natural actions on offense and defense. There have been three position players from GPE to make it to the big leagues, with two -- Yan PERSON and PERSON -- getting any kind of significant playing time. He has good range and a solid arm and will only improve his reads and routes as he gets more reps.PERSON is just 18 years old, so he is just getting started. While PERSON has produced some big league talent over the years, development of baseball in that country is obviously well behind other countries in the hemisphere. Signed out of GPE in 2015 after performing well at the 18-and-under World Cup in GPE, PERSON hit .281 with 22 steals between two Rookie-ball stops in his pro debut in 2016.PERSON's game is built around well-above-average speed, which makes him dangerous on the bases and allows him to cover ground in center field, where he shows the makings of a future plus defender. He'll require time to develop, but the tools are there for him to become a potential top-of-the-order contributor at a premium position.

Others believe he'll slow down as he fills out and necessitate a move to third base, where he'd still profile well offensively.

PERSON spent three years pitching at ORGANIZATION II ORGANIZATION University in GPE, a six-foot right-hander who put up video game numbers (1.04 ERA, .163 batting average against) as a junior. He also misses bats with his slider, while he also was able to use the breaking ball and his changeup to get some ground-ball outs. While he has an up-tempo delivery, he's always been a strike-thrower and continued that trend in his first taste of pro ball.He'll need to find a way to attack left-handed hitters, who hit him a bit better last summer, albeit in a small sample size, and refinement of the changeup could do that. He's reminded some of PERSON in terms of his aggressive demeanor on the mound and body type (though not in pure stuff), with a realistic ceiling as a back-end starter and a life as a reliever more likely.

Known since starring in the 2011 Little League World Series, PERSON was one of the better legitimate two-way players in the 2017 Draft class -- so much so that the scouting industry remained split down the middle all spring on whether he'd be better suited on the mound or behind the plate at the next level. At the worst, PERSON's power arm represents an interesting fallback option should he have trouble sticking as a catcher.

Few pitchers in the 2017 high school class could match ORGANIZATION's combination of stuff and track record of performance against top competition, but his volatile delivery and mound antics created enough concern that he lasted 66 picks in the GPE. His changeup can be too firm at times but shows flashes of becoming an average third offering with some fade.ORGANIZATION has a lot going on in his violent delivery, which finishes with some disconcerting head whack, yet he repeats it and keeps it in sync enough to find the strike zone on a regular basis. ORGANIZATION has a long history of excelling against top competition, including winning the gold-medal game for PERSON at the 18-and-under PERSON in GPE last October with 11 strikeouts in seven one-hit innings. ORGANIZATION won the gold-medal game at the 18-and-under PERSON with 11 strikeouts in seven one-hit innings in October 2016, then outdueled future Reds third-rounder PERSON while showcasing the hottest fastball at the ORGANIZATION Invitational last March. The ORGANIZATION' pursuit of PERSON during the 2013-14 international period led the club to acquire additional international pool money, which they then used to sign the then-16-year-old for $330,000 in January 2014. The right-hander's arm strength offers plenty to dream on, but he'll have to check countless developmental boxes before being deemed ready for the big leagues.

Back in 2014, the ORGANIZATION signed shortstop PERSON for $8 million, a bonus so steep it put the club way over the international spending limit and kept them from spending more than $300,000 on any international free agent for the following two years. He shows some feel for a changeup that could be close to average when all is said and done. The biggest thing holding the 20-year-old, who made his full season debut in 2019, back is his command. The 2016-17 international signing period was highlighted by high-priced prospects like PERSON, who got $26 million to sign with the FACILITY, and GPE, who signed with the ORGANIZATION for $11 million. The ORGANIZATION only handed out one seven-figure bonus that signing period, to outfielder PERSON, but it might be PERSON, with just a $77,000 bonus to sign in August 2016, who might end up being the best international prospect signed by the organization at that time.The 6-foot-2 left-hander already looks the part with an ideal pitcher's frame, and there's more growth to come. PERSON comes from an athletic family, with one brother who has reached Triple-A (PERSON, an outfielder now with the ORGANIZATION) and another (Hector) who's on GPE's national soccer team. PERSON starred on the high school showcase circuit, winning ORGANIZATION honors at the Under PERSON All-America Game in July 2016 and wowing scouts when he ran a 6.42-second 60-yard dash at the ORGANIZATION Games a month before the 2017 Draft. He offered one of the best power/speed combinations available, which prompted the ORGANIZATION to draft him 19th overall and sign him for $3,101,700. He continued to perform well in his pro debut, leading the Rookie-level ORGANIZATION in slugging (.645) and finishing second in batting (.348) and ORGANIZATION (1.049).While he needs a few years of development time, PERSON has the highest ceiling of any ORGANIZATION prospect since PERSON. He also needs to refine his reads and routes in order to stay in center field. Time is on his side, as he'll play the entire 2018 season at age 18.

PERSON comes from a family of athletes, with one brother (PERSON) spending 2018 in Triple-A as an outfielder in the ORGANIZATION system and another (Hector) playing professional soccer. He spent all of his first two pro seasons in center field and is presently an average defender there, thanks more to his quickness than his instincts. PERSON PERSON was the prize in the PERSON's 2013-14 international crop, but they also found a potential bargain when they signed PERSON for $50,000 out of GPE. PERSON noticed PERSON at ORGANIZATION Thomas More High (PERSON, GPE.) while scouting eventual Royals supplemental first-rounder Chase Vallot in 2014, and he developed into the state's best prep prospect for 2015. He has aptitude for spin, throwing a curveball with power and depth and morphing it into a slider at times. He lacks reliable command, and he loses velocity and location on his fastball at times when he falls in love with his breaking pitches. PERSON spent two years in Louisiana-Lafayette's rotation and created a buzz when he hit 98 mph in a March start during his Draft year in 2018. More than anything, he needs to go out and prove he can stay healthy over the course of a long Minor League season.

An elite athlete and ambidextrous quarterback whose high school football program designed its offense around his unique skillset, PERSON wasn't on many scouts' radars because he wasn't a regular on the summer showcase circuit and didn't stand out at the World Wood Bat Association World Championship in the fall. He has plus speed and should have no problem sticking in center field once he improves his reads and routes. PERSON signed with the ORGANIZATION for $1 million in 2016 as the ORGANIZATION. 24 overall pick, making him PERSON (GPE) PERSON's highest-drafted player ever. PERSON bypassed his GPE A&M commitment and signed with the ORGANIZATION for $1 million in 2016 as the ORGANIZATION. 24 overall pick, making him PERSON (GPE) PERSON's highest-drafted player ever. PERSON drafted PERSON as a shortstop but has since shifted him to third base, where he shows the necessary hands, footwork and arm strength for the position.PERSON has proved to be more advanced than expected early in his career, most notably in his capacity to make adjustments and get to his power during games. Though he'll need to tighten his approach and clean up his defensive some, PERSON appears on the right path towards becoming a future middle-of-the-order third baseman at the highest level.

PERSON impressed evaluators with his hitting ability against high-level competition on the summer showcase circuit, though some teams worried that he couldn't be signed away from his GPE A&M commitment. The ORGANIZATION ended up giving PERSON $1 million as the ORGANIZATION. 24 overall pick, making him PERSON (GPE) PERSON's highest-drafted player ever, and he rewarded them with a strong pro debut in which he reached the Class A Short PERSON at age 17.PERSON has a knack for making hard contact at the plate, with a quick right-handed bat and plenty of strength to his frame, though there is some swing-and-miss to his game. He projects as an above-average hitter, and scouts expect him to develop at least average power as he continues to add strength. The PERSON spent a modest $1.8 million on their 2013 international class, including $50,000 to sign PERSON out of GPE. His biggest issue is staying healthy, and he went on the injured list again in July with what the club described as mild soreness. PERSON displayed potential but inconsistent results in his first two years at ORGANIZATION State before breaking out this spring by hitting .342/.479/.748 with 22 homers and 12 steals in 57 games. His only college offer as a suburban Detroit high schooler came from nearby PERSON, but PERSON put himself on the prospect map as his fastball continually added velocity during his three years at the ORGANIZATION II program. His changeup is more of a work in progress and will need more separation in velocity from his fastball. There's not much effort in his delivery, but he sometime struggles to repeat his mechanics and will need better control to remain a starter.

A two-way talent who would have been a first-round pick as an infielder, PERSON went No. 2 overall to the ORGANIZATION in the 2017 Draft and received a bonus pool-era record bonus of $7.23 million because of his arm. The ORGANIZATION allowed him to DH during his pro debut as he readied himself on the mound. The 6-foot-4 teenager has incredibly easy velocity, cranking his fastball up to triple digits without too much effort. He'll consistently reach 97-101 mph with a clean and repeatable delivery and he commands the pitch fairly well. He shows glimpses of a plus slider, something that should become more consistent as he focuses on one breaking ball. He's shown a good feel for a changeup and while he didn't throw it much in high school, it could eventually be a third at least above-average offering. The athleticism PERSON showed as a shortstop will only help him on the mound in terms of fielding his position and repeating his mechanics. Rated as the top overall talent in the 2017 GPE class throughout the spring, GPE was a contender to go No. 1 overall to the Twins but ended up landing in the second spot. â¢ 4/2: GPE has PERSON, out for ORGANIZATION, who was the ORGANIZATION. 2 overall selection by the Reds in the 2017 Draft and received a bonus pool-era record $7.23 million because of his power arm, is being watched closely after he suffered an injury during his first full season in the ORGANIZATION. A right elbow strain that shut him down for the year in late July was cause for concern, but was initially determined not to require surgery. He passed early incremental tests during rehabilitation, but suffered a setback in late March and it was announced he needed PERSON surgery at the beginning of April.The start of GPE's first full professional season had its ups and downs, as the right-hander endured many rough outings and lackluster pitching lines at the start of the year. But with a repeatable delivery and easy velocity that reaches 97-102 mph, he started finding his groove as the year went on and was very impressive during his ORGANIZATION stint. While his fastball lights up radar guns, it often lacks life. The pitch has good finish when he keeps it down, but it straightens when GPE elevates it, making it more hittable above the knees. His secondary pitches remain works in progress, with a slider that flashes plus and a changeup, while still in the embryonic stage, that has the makings of being a solid third offering. He showed improved command and control as his first season wore on.Off the field, GPE is polished, gracious and has the poise to help him become a star in the game if he continues to develop once he returns to action. Players taken No. 3 overall have gone on to accomplish great things in baseball, from ORGANIZATION of ORGANIZATION and PERSON to All-Star arms like PERSON and PERSON. His curve remains an out pitch and his changeup, which he's worked on tirelessly, also is a plus pitch at times. In 2018, he showed an ability to pitch to all quadrants and set up hitters with all three offerings.PERSON's walk rate improved in 2018, but he still needs to refine his overall command. Because of his repeatable delivery and understanding of how to pitch, the ORGANIZATION are confident he'll have average control, which should allow him to reach his potential as a frontline type starter.

Ranked No. 13 on MLBPipeline.com's Top 200 GPE prospects list as the 2016 GPE approached, PERSON's name started popping up in the top of the GPE conversations late in the days before the GPE began. The upstate GPE prep standout was taken No. 3 overall, signing for $4 million. It has slurve action at this point, but could tighten up and become a true slider in time. PERSON has good feel for an average changeup as well. He's generally around the strike zone and attacks hitters.While PERSON might have been taken No. 3 overall in a money-saving deal, he has a tremendous amount of upside and could eventually develop into a frontline-type starter at the big league level.

The ORGANIZATION continued their hoarding of high school arms when they selected PERSON from the ORGANIZATION high school ranks with the ORGANIZATION. 3 overall pick in the 2016 Draft. PERSON, a native of the ORGANIZATION, signed with the PERSON for $310,000 in 2013 and made his professional debut in the ORGANIZATION League the next year. GPE ORGANIZATION (PERSON, N.C.) had never produced a player selected in the GPE, but in 2015, the ORGANIZATION had two: PERSON and PERSON, who had comprised two-thirds of GPE's outfield. The ORGANIZATION loaded up on talent during the 2016-17 international period, focusing on advanced hitters who also showed the potential to stick at an up-the-middle position. Born in GPE, PERSON moved to the ORGANIZATION to train and caught the attention of ORGANIZATION scouts before joining the organization for $350,000 in December 2014. When PERSON signed with PERSON for $200,000 out of GPE early in the 2016-17 international period, he had already established himself as an advanced hitter with strong performances in international events. PERSON began his college career at the ORGANIZATION of GPE, but found himself stuck behind three infielders who could all go in the top five rounds in this year's Draft. Because of his offensive toolset, he has a pretty high floor as an offensive-minded utility player who can move around the infield.

A relatively unheralded prospect from the ORGANIZATION high school ranks, PERSON wasn't selected until the 30th round of the 2018 Draft. PERSON entered his junior season looking like a top-two-rounds college pitcher, but his stock took a hit when he missed six weeks with a strained oblique. There are times when his changeup is his most effective secondary offering, sitting in the low 80s with similar action to his heater.Inconsistency plagued PERSON throughout his career and he's often struggled with command, which has led to him being more hittable than he should be given his stuff. That, plus some effort in a delivery he doesn't always repeat, lead some to believe his big league future will be out of the bullpen.

PERSON emerged this spring as the best junior college prospect since PERSON went ORGANIZATION. 1 overall out of LOCATION in 2010 and the best in GPE since PERSON was a supplemental first-rounder from GPE in 2005. His biggest needs are to improve a changeup that can get too firm and flat, and to refine his control and command. PERSON impressed scouts at the 2017 ORGANIZATION Invitational but concerned them with his commitment to PERSON. The son of five-time All-Star and World Series hero PERSON, PERSON got drafted two rounds earlier than his dad did out of GPE in 1988 when the ORGANIZATION made him a second-rounder in June. When the ORGANIZATION made PERSON a second-round pick last June, it meant he went two rounds earlier than his father PERSON did in 1988 before becoming a five-time All-Star and a World Series hero. An uneven senior year for his GPE high school sparked a slide in PERSON's ORGANIZATION stock, but the ORGANIZATION were thrilled to get him in the third round of the 2017 ORGANIZATION. PERSON was a reliever only in his three years at ORGANIZATION, and each year he got better while taking on more responsibility. GPE shortstop PERSON was the highest-profile player in the ORGANIZATION' 2018 international class but not the only potential impact player. GPE PERSON and PERSON were the two best high school pitching prospects in GPE in 2015, and the tall right-handers both spurned pro interest to attend college. PERSON PERSON, who went fifth overall in the 2015 Draft, wasn't the only reason scouts swarmed to ORGANIZATION in GPE, Fla.. PERSON may be getting used to not being the big man on campus, yet finding a way to succeed. PERSON reminds scouts a lot of PERSON. They're both GPE high school products and were similar offensively and defensively at the same stage of their careers. A two-way player at FACILITY ORGANIZATION in GPE, Fla. -- PERSON's alma mater -- PERSON created debate as to whether he had a brighter future as a sweet-swinging first baseman or a projectable right-handed pitcher. PERSON chose to attend GPE (GPE) JC rather than sign with the ORGANIZATION as an 18th-round PERSON pick in 2015. He doesn't show much power presently, but scouts believe he'll develop average pop based on his projectable frame, solid bat speed and leveraged plane through the hitting zone. Meanwhile, PERSON's average speed serves him well on the basepaths, as well as in the field. A shortstop as an amateur, PERSON spent his entire pro debut at the hot corner, where he profiles as an average defender with good athleticism and range as well as a plus arm.PERSON may have been a little-known commodity prior to last year's PERSON, but the early returns in his pro career, along with his across-the-board tools and remaining physical projection, suggests he could develop into an everyday player at the hot corner.

PERSON chose to attend GPE (GPE) JC rather than sign with the ORGANIZATION as an 18th-round PERSON pick in 2015. He became property of the ORGANIZATION the following year, signing for $75,000 in the 15th round, and then made a name for himself on both sides of the ball with a strong pro debut in the ORGANIZATION Coast League.PERSON shows good feel for hitting, with a short, clean swing from the right side of the plate that yields consistently hard contact to all fields but offers little in the way of power. Meanwhile, his plus speed serves him well on the basepaths as well as in the field. PERSON was the ORGANIZATION's co-freshman of the year in 2016 and continued to get better in each of his next two seasons, turning in a strong showing in the ORGANIZATION and then hitting .360/.444/.555 with 31 extra-base hits as a ORGANIZATION junior. He recognizes pitches and manages the strike zone well, using his quick left-handed swing to repeatedly barrel the ball. What's more, PERSON has track record of performing well with wood bats, having overcome a slow start in the ORGANIZATION to bat .392 during a season-ending 20-game hitting streak.PERSON gets plus to plus-plus grades for his speed and was a successful if not especially prolific basestealer in college. He also uses his quickness well in center field, where he gets good jumps and can track down balls from gap to gap. His arm is his lone below-average tool but isn't a huge handicap in center.

A three-year starter at ORGANIZATION, PERSON improved each year in college and as he turned in a huge junior season, his name was popping up in 2018 first-round conversations. He has an advanced approach, managing the strike zone well and finding the barrel while being very quick to the ball. His bat speed and strength point to some over-the-fence pop and plenty of extra-base power. He's shown he can handle wood just fine, both in a scorching hot stretch to end his Cape Cod season in 2017 and during his brief pro debut. A plus runner, PERSON is an efficient baserunner with the potential to steal bases and cover a ton of ground in center field. He's a capable defender, albeit one with a fringy arm. He could start to move quickly given his all-around skillset, with a potential future as a No. 2 type hitter in a big league lineup awaiting.

GPE players have been drafted out of ORGANIZATION in GPE, but none have made it to the big leauges. But the ORGANIZATION like his athleticism and how well he competes and think he has the chance to start long-term.

Taken in the 11th round of the 2017 Draft out of ORGANIZATION in GPE, the ORGANIZATION gave PERSON an above-slot bonus of more than twice the $100,000 post-10th round limit to keep him from transferring to ORGANIZATION in GPE. The right-hander needs to be consistent with his curveball depth and finish and has had trouble repeating his delivery. PERSON became an immediate starter for PERSON as a freshman in 2017 and was one of the best hitters in the ORGANIZATION over his last two seasons. The ORGANIZATION took his safe bat No. 72 overall, in the ORGANIZATION, and signed him for full pick value, then sent him to the Class A Short-Season New York-Penn League for his debut.PERSON has a prettier swing than most right-handers and uses it to make consistent contact while controlling the strike zone. PERSON was one of the top high school hitters, if not one of the best pure overall bats, in the 2018 ORGANIZATION class, one whose stock soared as the ORGANIZATION approached and he heard his name being mentioned as a potential top 10 pick. He has the kind of offensive profile that could allow him to move a little more quickly than some high school hitters.

One of the top pure hitters in the 2018 Draft class, especially among the high school set, PERSON was one of the best bats for the GPE national 18-and-under team for two years in a row. A no-doubt first-rounder as the spring started, his name started popping up in top-10 pick conversations and he became the first PERSON product to go that high when the ORGANIZATION took him No. 6 overall, signing him for more than a million under pick value. Though PERSON would have an impressive pro debut across two levels, the ORGANIZATION packaged the young outfielder with PERSON, PERSON, PERSON and PERSON to GPE in exchange for PERSON and PERSON in December.PERSON has a tremendous feel for hitting from the left side of the plate, showing a professional approach and the ability to barrel up the baseball. It may have been PERSON that put the ORGANIZATION on the baseball prospect map when he signed with the ORGANIZATION for $6 million during the July 2015 international signing period, but the D-backs think they have a GPE worth watching in GPE.
