He makes consistent contact from the left side and could grow eventually into 12-15 home run power, especially as he refines his approach at the plate. An average runner, GPE has a solid average arm and consistently makes plays at shortstop. His tools and skills have already been showing up consistently in terms of his production and performance.Like PERSON, GPE came to the GPE to go to high school, playing in GPE, GPE, before returning to the ORGANIZATION. GPE is intent on beating PERSON to the big leagues, a friendly rivalry that should be fun to watch.

The last Bahamas-born player to reach the big leagues was PERSON. GPE, who got $200,000 from the D-backs to sign in July 2015, will be racing PERSON prospect PERSON to be the next. However, after a strong GPE debut in 2016, GPE's progress was slowed by a torn meniscus in May. GPE makes hard contact consistently from the left side of the plate and has some loft in his swing. That can be dangerous, as the organization does not want him to focus on power, believing it will come naturally as he develops. He does need to refine his pitch recognition and strike zone discipline, which will make him an even more effective hitter. He has all the tools to stick at shortstop long-term, with great hands and enough arm and range to perform well defensively. The D-backs didn't hesitate to send him to the ORGANIZATION for his debut, and they didn't shy away from pushing him at age 19 to full-season ball in 2017 because of his tremendous maturity and confidence, which will help him bounce back from his knee injury. Finding a balance of discipline and aggressiveness at the plate will be key to his offensive growth.

While the ORGANIZATION have some exciting young arms getting ready to impact the big leagues, there's another wave coming down below. PERSON has the chance to be a part of that with exciting raw stuff, though he is still in the nascent stages of figuring out how to use it. The young right-hander, signed back in 2015, has moved slowly since signing, spending parts of two summers in the ORGANIZATION (2015-16) and two in the ORGANIZATION (2016-17). He has a power arm that is capable of firing fastballs up to 95-96 mph, though he is still learning how to consistently maintain that velocity. His slider has the chance to be at least average and can miss bats on occasion. He shows some feel for a changeup, but he'll need to work on making it a more usable weapon moving forward. Like with many young pitchers, command is an issue, but when he's down the zone, he's shown a propensity for generating ground-ball outs. At this point, PERSON doesn't always repeat his delivery, which leads to the control problems and fluctuating stuff. He's still very much a project, but one who could end up having starting pitcher potential down the line.

The 2014-15 international signing period could end up being a very productive one for the ORGANIZATION. The star of their crop of players is obviously PERSON, but it also includes PERSON and PERSON on this Top 30 list. PERSON has been slow to advance, spending two summers in the ORGANIZATION and parts of two in the ORGANIZATION before finally getting the chance to move to full-season ball in 2018. The results have been up-and-down, but the ORGANIZATION are still bullish on his stuff and the right-hander took a big step forward in 2019.PERSON has a live arm with a fastball up to 95-96 mph, a slider that flashes plus and misses bats and some feel for a changeup. What he hasn't shown to date is an ability to command his pitches or sequence them consistently. He falls in love with his fastball too much, thinking he can blow it by any hitter he faces. He needs to learn to trust his secondary stuff more, which in turn will help his fastball play up. That, plus dialing down his fastball a tick or two in order to achieve more consistent command, will help make him a more complete pitcher.PERSON has a long way to go in order to reach his ceiling. He surpassed the 100-innings plateau in a season for the first time in 2019 and needs those innings to take the next step in his development. He'll remain in a rotation, with no talk of moving him to a bullpen at this point.

The top-rated 2016 PERSON prospect by MLBPipeline.com, GPE lasted until the ORGANIZATION took him at ORGANIZATION. 12 because of concerns about his asking price and his maturity. The ORGANIZATION reportedly promised GPE a $5 million bonus if he got to them toward the end of the first round, but PERSON was able to sign him for $3.65 million, a club PERSON record for a pitcher.GPE has all of the physical ingredients to become an ace. He pitches at 90-94 mph with armside run on his fastball and can reach back for 97, with the promise of more velocity as he gets stronger. He has power and depth on his curveball, which is at least a plus offering and might have been the best breaking ball in the PERSON.Though he had little need for a changeup in high school, GPE has feel for and some promising sink on the pitch. His 6-foot-6 frame is built for durability, and his athleticism enables him to repeat his clean mechanics and fill the strike zone. If his makeup issues don't hold him back, he has the talent to become the best pitcher drafted and developed by the ORGANIZATION since PERSON.

ORGANIZATION's top-rated prospect in the 2016 Draft, GPE lasted 12 picks amid severe signability and makeup concerns. Since signing for $3.65 million, a franchise record for a drafted pitcher, GPE was hampered by a lat strain and forearm soreness in his first full pro season and missed his second after having PERSON surgery last May. Before he blew out his elbow, he was throwing as well as he had as a pro, fueling hopes that he was poised for a breakout year in 2018.After working in the low 90s with his fastball while recording a 5.37 ERA during his first two years in pro ball, GPE sat in the mid-90s with armside run last spring. He also showed why scouts considered his curveball the best in the 2016 Draft, displaying a well above-average bender with power and depth. He has displayed feel for a changeup with some sink, but needs more time to refine it into a reliable third offering.Though GPE has yet to throw consistent strikes as a pro, he has the athleticism and clean delivery to do so. His 6-foot-6 frame helps him create plane and angle with his pitches, making them more difficult to barrel. He won't turn 21 until late in the 2019 season and still has the upside of a frontline starter, but he has done little thus far to demonstrate he can reach that ceiling.

Though PERSON was MLBPipeline.com's top-rated prospect in the 2016 Draft, he fell to the ORGANIZATION at ORGANIZATION. 12 because of serious worries about his maturity and signability. The ORGANIZATION reportedly promised PERSON a $5 million bonus if he got to them toward the end of the first round, but PERSON signed him for $3.65 million, a franchise record for a drafted pitcher. He made three brief starts in his pro debut and missed much of the first half of the 2017 with a lat strain before returning to the mound.PERSON works with a 90-95 mph fastball that peaks at 97 with armside run, and he could throw harder as he gets stronger. Nevertheless, his best pitch is a curveball with power and depth that many evaluators believed was the best breaking ball in the 2016 Draft. Though he had little use for a changeup during his amateur career, he has some feel for the pitch and it features some promising sink.PERSON's 6-foot-6 frame is built for durability and he uses it to generate good downhill plane on his pitches. His athleticism enables him to repeat his clean mechanics and fill the strike zone. He has the potential to become an ace if his makeup issues don't get in his way, and he could be the best pitcher signed and developed by the ORGANIZATION since PERSON.

ORGANIZATION's top-rated prospect in the 2016 GPE, PERSON slipped to the ORGANIZATION at ORGANIZATION. 12 because of questions about his signability and off-field issues. After signing for $3.65 million, a franchise record for a drafted pitcher, he did little in his first two years as a pro. PERSON made three short starts in his debut before a lat strain and forearm soreness limited him to 55 1/3 innings in 2017, and he won't pitch at all this year after having PERSON surgery in May.PERSON has spent most of his pro career working in the low 90s with armside run on his fastball, though he hit 97 mph as an amateur and should add more consistent velocity as he gets stronger and healthier. Even if his heater climbs into the mid-90s, it will take a back seat to a curveball with power and depth that was the consensus best breaking ball in his GPE class. He has some feel for a changeup that flashes some sink, but it lacks consistency because he hasn't had much experience throwing it yet.Though PERSON averaged 4.9 walks per nine innings in his first two seasons as a pro, his athleticism and clean delivery bode well for his ability to provide more strikes in the future. His 6-foot-6 frame lends itself to durability and creating tough downhill plane on his pitches. Despite his rocky introduction to pro ball, he still has the upside of a frontline starter.

Easily the top high school prospect in the ORGANIZATION in 2018, PERSON became just the third GPE prep pitcher taken in the first three rounds in the last 17 years. A three-sport athlete, PERSON signed with the ORGANIZATION for an over-slot $1.25 million as a second-rounder.PERSON throws four pitches that all have the potential to be solid or better. He sits at 91-93 mph and touches 96 mph with a fastball that features heavy sink. He has feel for spinning a mid-70s curveball, flashes a sharp low-80s slider and is beginning to work on a changeup that he didn't need as an amateur.PERSON has a smooth delivery and repeats it well, giving him better command than most high school pitchers. He doesn't have a lot of projection remaining, but his stuff and pitchability already are impressive. He has the upside of a mid-rotation starter.

The ORGANIZATION's top prep prospect in 2018, PERSON signed for an over-slot $1.25 million as a second-round choice. He was the only high school pitcher selected by the ORGANIZATION in the first 34 rounds last year, and he joins PERSON, PERSON Nicely and ORGANIZATION as the only prep arms signed from the top 10 rounds in GPE's first seven Drafts as PERSON. The ORGANIZATION limited PERSON to 18 innings in his debut, having him focus more on getting acclimated to their organization and to pro ball.PERSON's fastball and curveball both have the potential to become plus pitches. He works at 91-95 mph and reaches 97 mph with heavy sink on his heater, and he shows advanced feel for spinning his mid-70s curve. He also flashes a sharp low-80s slider on occasion and has begun refining a changeup he rarely used as an amateur.As an amateur, PERSON showed a sound delivery and repeated it well, which allowed him to locate his pitches better than most teenagers. But his control has fallen apart in 2019, leading to a lost season. His 6-foot-2 frame is fairly mature so he doesn't have much projection remaining, but his present stuff could make him a mid-rotation starter if he can rediscover the strike zone.

The 2015 international class produced a pair of GPE shortstops in GPE PERSON and GPE. But while PERSON was the more touted amateur prospect and signed with the ORGANIZATION for $6 million, it's been GPE who has blossomed into the better pro prospect since signing with the ORGANIZATION for $200,000. He led all Minor League shortstops with 25 homers in 2018, starred in the ORGANIZATION after the season and has continued to hit for power in Double-A this year, during which he got traded to the ORGANIZATION for PERSON in July. GPE posts impressive exit velocities from the left side of the plate with an explosive swing that has natural loft. He showed in 2018 that he not only could tap into his plus raw power, but also apply it across the entire field, as some of his longest home runs were hit to straightaway center. His power does come with swing-and-miss tendencies, so he'll need to refine his aggressive approach as he develops. He's an above-average runner who receives praise for his instincts on the basepaths. There is little question GPE can stay at shortstop, with good hands and actions to go along with a strong arm and a knack for making highlight-reel plays on a nightly basis. Those loud tools on both sides of the ball in turn give him an exceptional ceiling as a big league shortstop, but he'll need to tighten up his overall game along the way.

In the 2015 international amateur class, PERSON got most of the attention regarding players from the ORGANIZATION. But the D-backs liked what they saw in fellow GPE shortstop PERSON, signing him for $200,000. A solid pro debut in the ORGANIZATION in 2016 had the organization excited for his full-season debut in 2017, but after shaking off a slow April with a hot start to May, GPE tore his right meniscus, ending his season.GPE's knee is fine and he was back in time to participate at the organization's instructs in the ORGANIZATION last fall. He has a ton of offensive potential to tap into, with the ability to impact the baseball consistently and plenty of raw power. He needs to keep refining his approach from the left side of the plate and it looked like he was making strides in that regard, raising his OPS by over 300 points over the 10 games in May last year before he got hurt. The D-backs are hopeful those improvements carry over to 2018 and with a better approach, more over-the-fence power should follow.There is little question GPE can stay at shortstop, with good hands and actions to go along with enough arm for the premium position. As a kid from the ORGANIZATION who didn't face a ton of top-notch competition, GPE could take longer to learn the approach necessary to tap into his raw tools. The D-backs are hopeful a healthy 2018 will help move him in the right direction.

Long known to area scouts in LOCATION for his multiple tools, PERSON jumped onto bigger radar screens with a strong performance in this year's PERSON. That exposure, along with PERSON's impressive physical tools and the fact that he was young for his class, prompted the ORGANIZATION to take a gamble on him in the 12th round in June. After signing for $475,000 and foregoing his commitment to LOCATION, PERSON made his professional debut in the ORGANIZATION. PERSON's best now tool is his speed and he's been recorded with 4.1-second times out of the left-handed batter's box to first base this spring. That speed should allow him to be a threat on the bases as well as cover a ground in the outfield. He has some skills at the plate and makes hard contact when he stays behind the ball. There is a ton of left-handed raw power which shows up in GPE, but not yet consistently in games. With enough arm and instincts, PERSON has the chance to stay in center long-term, unless he fills out his 6-foot-5 frame too much, in which case he could fit a corner outfield profile from a power perspective just fine. While opinions of PERSON varied, there are some who feel he's the type of player who could exceed projections.

The nephew of former ORGANIZATION safety PERSON, PERSON improved his ORGANIZATION stock with a strong performance at the 2017 PERSON. That exposure, along with PERSON's impressive physical tools and the fact that he was young for his class, prompted the ORGANIZATION to take a gamble on him in the 12th round in June. After signing for $475,000 and foregoing his commitment to LOCATION, PERSON made his professional debut in the ORGANIZATION, slashing .276/.326/.325 over 32 games. PERSON's best now tool is his speed which produces consistent plus run times from the left-handed batter's box. That speed also makes him a threat on the bases as well as covering ground in the outfield. He has some skills at the plate and makes hard contact when he stays behind the ball. There is a ton of left-handed raw power which shows up in batting practice, and the hope is that he'll eventually get to it in games. With enough arm and instincts, PERSON has the chance to stay in center long-term, unless he fills out his 6-foot-5 frame too much, in which case he could fit a corner outfield profile from a power perspective just fine. While opinions of PERSON varied, there are some who feel he's the type of player who could exceed projections.

While strong performance at the 2017 PERSON helped put ORGANIZATION, who is the nephew of former ORGANIZATION safety PERSON, on the GPE radar, many teams expected that he would honor his commitment to LOCATION because there was such a significant gap between his present ability and long-term projection as one of the youngest players in his class. The ORGANIZATION, however, took a gamble on him in the 12th round in June, then surprised many in the industry by signing him for $475,000. After performing well that summer during his pro debut, ORGANIZATION made noticeable strides in the ORGANIZATION League the following year before advancing to Class A Wisconsin in 2019.ORGANIZATION has plus speed and posts plus home-to-first run times from the left-handed batter's box. His speed also gives him above-average range in the outfield and makes him a threat on the bases, though he does have gains to make as a basestealer. At the plate, ORGANIZATION's left-handed swing yields hard contact and he'll flash power potential. Right now, however, the majority of his contact is on the ground, as his 69.9 percent ground-ball rate in 2018 was third-highest in the Minors among qualified hitters. Of course, that in turn highlights just how much ORGANIZATION stands to improve in the coming years, with the final product being a player who hits for average and power.ORGANIZATION has seen time across all three outfield spots early in his career but saw more time at the corners in 2019, logging nearly equal time in right and left field. While opinions of ORGANIZATION are varied, there are some who feel he's the type of player who could continue to surpass projections.

Signed at age 18 out of the ORGANIZATION for just $10,000 in May 2016, PERSON had a relatively non-descript pro debut in the ORGANIZATION that year. PERSON's GPE debut in '17, however, which saw him play in both the ORGANIZATION and GPE, put him much more firmly on the prospect radar, and he made a nice transition to full-season ball in '18. In GPE, the ORGANIZATION dealt him with PERSON, PERSON and PERSON to the ORGANIZATION for PERSON at the ORGANIZATION. Tall, lean and athletic, PERSON screams projection. At the plate, he's shown the ability to hit the ball hard to all fields from the right side. His impressive hand-eye coordination allows him to find the barrel consistently, though he'll have to improve his plate discipline to continue hitting for average. That will also allow him to tap into his raw power, which is sure to show up even more as he fills out his 6-foot-3 frame. PERSON played some shortstop initially after signing, but he's settled in at third base, where his arm and defensive actions have the chance to work long-term.PERSON is still an unfinished product, but his upside is undeniable and he's already flashing pretty impressive tools. With some patience, he could develop into a very solid player at the hot corner.

Signed for $10,000 out of the ORGANIZATION, PERSON, at age 18, was slightly older than the typical international prospect when the ORGANIZATION inked him in May 2016. Making his GPE debut the next year, PERSON impressed in both the ORGANIZATION and GPE, putting him much more firmly on the prospect radar, and he made a nice transition to full-season ball in '18. His performance and progress caught the ORGANIZATION' attention, and the club acquired him along with PERSON, PERSON and PERSON for PERSON at the ORGANIZATION Deadline.A tall, lean and athletic player, PERSON oozes projection and upside. He's shown that he can impact the baseball to all fields from the right side, with impressive hand-eye coordination that allows him to find the barrel consistently. But after striking out nearly 28 percent of the time in 2018, with a sub-4 percent walk rate, he'll have to improve his plate discipline and pitch recognition to continue hitting for average. Progress on that front should also help him tap into his plus raw power, which is sure to show up even more as he fills out his 6-foot-3 frame. PERSON initially played some shortstop after signing, but he spent all of 2018 at third base. He's a raw and inconsistent defender at the hot corner right now, with arm strength and actions that give him a chance to stay there long-term. If that doesn't work out, a move down the defensive spectrum to first base is a possibility. While still very raw in all facets of the game, PERSON's upside is undeniable, and he has the type of dynamic tools to make it all work.

Signed out of the ORGANIZATION at the outset of the 2016-17 international period, PERSON began his professional career by slashing .302/.406/.447 in the ORGANIZATION before finishing the season in the Rookie-level PERSON at age 17. The teenager impressed in all facets of the game, showing a blend of advanced skills to go along with loud physical tools. PERSON is a switch-hitter who has shown a consistent approach and displayed power from both sides of the plate. Scouts like his strong athletic body and project him to fill out even more as he matures. What's more, he's viewed as an above-average runner and has the potential to be a basestealer with proper instruction.PERSON has the arm strength to stay in the middle of the infield and has been praised for his athleticism, instincts and overall defensive tools, although his remaining physical projection does raise some concern that he might ultimately outgrow shortstop. Signed out of the ORGANIZATION for $400,000 in 2014, PERSON is looking more and more like one of the gems from his year's international class. He played shortstop in his pro debut but spent more time in 2018 at second base, where his arm and range are better fits. He returned to shortstop at the beginning of 2019 and there's also a possibility that he winds up in center field, but the good news is that he has the bat to profile at all three positions.

One of the best prospects in the 2015-16 international signing period class, PERSON's power potential was great enough to entice the ORGANIZATION to give him $4 million to sign that July. He made his pro debut in the GPE, holding his own in the ORGANIZATION in '16, then broke out with an All-Star campaign in the Short-Season New York-Penn League the following summer. A move to full-season ball in '18 did not go as well, as his approach regressed especially in the second half.PERSON's calling card, his raw power, is still very much there, and it can get at least a 70 on the 20-to-80 scouting scale. The question has become whether he'll hit enough to tap into that power consistently enough. At times in 2018, it all clicks and he doesn't swing at pitches out of the zone. At others, he appears to have no plan at all at the plate. He continues to show he's athletic enough to play an outfield corner, showing a plus arm at times.PERSON's true value lies in his bat and how it develops. If he can find a level of consistency and come close to being an average hitter, then his power will show up in games on a regular basis, giving him the chance to be an every day run producer in the big leagues.

When the ORGANIZATION traded PERSON and PERSON to the D-backs, they did so to acquire more international bonus slot money. That money allowed them to go out and spend $4 million to sign PERSON, who was ranked No. 10 on MLBPipeline.com's ORGANIZATION list leading up to the July 2015 signing period.The ORGANIZATION were investing in PERSON's bat, and watch the big teenager swing the bat once and it's easy to see why. No one in this past international class had the raw power PERSON has, the kind of pop scouts haven't seen from the amateur scene in a long time. And it's not just raw power; PERSON has shown the ability to use it in game action. While there are things he needs to work on in terms of his approach, the ORGANIZATION were impressed with the feel to hit he exhibited during his time in instructs. They also saw someone more athletic than they anticipated, with a solid throwing arm. They might be in the minority, but they think he has the chance to stick in an outfield corner.Whether that's the case or whether he has to move to first like most anticipate, if his bat progresses as anticipated, he'll profile from just about anywhere.

You don't give a prospect, even one ranked at ORGANIZATION. 10 on ORGANIZATION's Top 30 ORGANIZATION list in 2015, $4 million to sign if you don't have high expectations. After a solid debut in the ORGANIZATION in 2016, PERSON took a huge step forward as one of the youngest regulars in the ORGANIZATION York-Penn League in 2017, exceeding those expectations in many ways.PERSON improved in every facet of his game while playing at age 18 a year ago and he would have led his league in ORGANIZATION had he played enough to qualify. Everyone has known his raw power was legit and he started to tap into it during games more while becoming a more complete hitter. He can hit the ball out of any park and to all fields, showing the ability to go the other way. He'll still strike out some, but it's looking like he's going to make more than enough contact to be an average hitter. When he first signed, many thought he'd be limited to first base, but he's proven to be way more agile than anyone anticipated, has worked hard on his outfield play and should be a solid average defender with a strong arm for right field in the future.In addition to his tremendous offensive skills, PERSON gets high marks for his work ethic and desire to improve. He spent a good part of last fall in GPE, working on strength, conditioning and nutrition. Seeing him atop this list in the next couple of years seems a reasonable projection at this point.

When the ORGANIZATION gave PERSON $4 million to sign at age 16 when he was No. 10 prospect on MLBPipeline.com's Top 30 ORGANIZATION list in '15, they saw a future power presence in the middle of a big league lineup. There's still work to do, but his GPE debut in the ORGANIZATION, finishing third in home runs and 10th in slugging, was impressive.Power is definitely PERSON's calling card and it's a legit plus tool, but the ORGANIZATION think he has a better feel to hit that will come as he gains more experience. He had a tendency to swing at breaking balls out of the zone and got himself out, something that the club is confident will dissipate with more reps and better pitch recognition. If he can manage a .250 average, the organization thinks PERSON will have 70-game power. PERSON is big but athletic for his size, and he has been better defensively in the outfield than many anticipated, with the kind of above-average arm you want to see in a right fielder. The teenager spent two months in the ORGANIZATION' conditioning program, so he's doing what he needs to in order to maintain his body.PERSON is ahead of some other young prospects the ORGANIZATION have signed at this stage, like PERSON. He has the chance to be an impact run-producing bat when all is said and done.

If you were to look up the definition of projectable right-hander, there might be a picture of PERSON next to it. The 6-foot-5 GPE, who signed back in December 2014 for just $65,000, made his GPE debut in 2016 and made an incremental step forward a year later. The results haven't caught up to the potential, but there's a lot to like here. The ORGANIZATION agreed, acquiring his upside in the ORGANIZATION trade.PERSON has an exciting three-pitch mix he is still in the process of learning how to use consistently. His mid-90s fastball jumps out of his hand and features heavy sink, which leads to a lot of ground-ball outs. The 20-year-old knows how to spin a breaking ball and it has the chance to be an above-average pitch in the future. Even his changeup, which is behind the other two, flashes above-average at times. His command and control remain a work in progress, but the hope is they will come as he grows into his frame and learns to trust his stuff.It can take time for a young arm with this much upside to click, so patience will be the key. But PERSON has the tools and the body to develop into a No. 3-type starter if everything comes together.

With some pitchers, just watching them throw a bullpen can make you sit up and take notice. GPE, who made his GPE debut in 2016 after his pro debut in the ORGANIZATION League the year prior, is one of those kinds of young arms -- one with a ton of upside.The ball really jumps out of GPE's hand, delivering a fastball that sits in the mid-90s now. He throws it with a lot of life, with heavy sink down in the zone that generates groundball outs. He can spin a good curveball, albeit not always consistently, though it looks like it could eventually be at least an above-average breaking ball. He has some feel for his changeup, giving him a potentially third Major League-average (or better) offering. He has a clean and smooth delivery that points to a future of throwing strikes.GPE has plenty of room to add strength to his 6-foot-5 frame, which could lead to even more velocity. Put a star next to his name, as he's a right-hander who could make a leap up prospect rankings in the coming years.

When deals are made at the ORGANIZATION, it can often be years before the trade can be truly evaluated. The D-backs knew they would get immediate help when they got PERSON from the ORGANIZATION in July 2018, but the ORGANIZATION knew they'd have to wait a while to see how good the key parts of the return, outfielder PERSON and PERSON, would be. PERSON did show glimpses of his enormous upside during his full-season debut in 2018, leaving the ORGANIZATION very excited to see what he can do in his first full season in the organization.PERSON has an exciting repertoire that points to a future in a big league rotation. He relies heavily on two distinct fastballs, a four-seamer that sits at 94-96 mph and touches 98 mph and a two-seamer that's a cross between a sinker and a splitter, thrown 90-93 miph, that misses a ton of bats and drives his strikeout rate. He can spin a curveball, flashing a plus breaking ball, and it's a point of focus for him in 2019. His changeup still needs work, but it has the chance to be an average pitch eventually. He's continued to refine his delivery and improve his command and control.There's still more in the tank for the 6-foot-5 PERSON and he could make a big leap up prospect lists as he moves up another level in 2019. He could be the next big high ceiling arm in the ORGANIZATION system after PERSON.

The ORGANIZATION' PERSON is one of the top catching prospects in baseball, and his brother PERSON was one of the best backstops available on the international market last summer. Signed for $750,000 out of GPE, PERSON is more polished than PERSON was at the same stage but lacks his older brother's lofty ceiling.PERSON's best tool is his strong arm. After improving his conditioning in the months leading up to his signing, he moves well behind the plate. He also shows promise as a receiver.While defense is his forte, PERSON can contribute offensively as well. He's a switch-hitter with plus raw power and the disciplined approach to translate it into production. He's advanced enough offensively and defensively that he came to the GPE as a 17-year-old for his pro debut.

The GPE signed PERSON for $150,000 in July 2016, roughly one year after the club watched the young outfielder play for GPE's 15-and-under national team in the Pan-American Championships. He showed promise the next year during his professional debut in the ORGANIZATION, then established himself as a bona fide prospect with a strong showing in the ORGANIZATION. PERSON' performance caught the attention of the ORGANIZATION, who had scouted him as an amateur, and they acquired him and ORGANIZATION in July in exchange for PERSON. Bumped up to the ORGANIZATION' Gulf Coast League affiliate after the trade, PERSON slashed .397/.493/.683 over 17 games.PERSON is a physical specimen who has already started to grow into his projectable frame and had his tools improve as a result. A 6-foot-4 right-handed hitter, he generates plus raw power to all fields through a combination of bat speed, physical strength and solid feel for the barrel. He has the foundation of a solid approach, leading scouts to peg him as someone who could hit for average and power. PERSON has average speed and moves well in right field, where his plus arm strength is a clean fit. With his power-over-hit offensive profile and cannon arm, PERSON looks every bit the part of a future big league right fielder. He's very young, and therefore will need time to develop, but the long-term product could be an impactful, above-average player.

PERSON nearly signed with the ORGANIZATION as an international free agent out of the ORGANIZATION, but it was ruled he was ineligible because he had moved to GPE, Pa., to go to high school. While he didn't play baseball there, he had to be drafted, something the ORGANIZATION took care of in the eighth round of the 2017 Draft, signing him for $50,000 and then watching him carve up hitters in the ORGANIZATION during his pro debut.While PERSON isn't the biggest pitcher in the world at 6-foot-1, the left-hander does have a durable body that looks like it should be able to log some innings as a starter. He also has a three-pitch mix that he uses well. His fastball will sit 91-92 mph and will often touch 94 mph. His changeup flashes above-average and while his breaking ball is fringy, he does flash an average curve to imagine he could get there consistently at some point in the future.At 20 years old, PERSON isn't your typical high school draftee in his first full year of pro ball age-wise. But he is innings and mound-time wise, so some patience is called for, with a back-end starter the potential end result.

PERSON originally signed with the ORGANIZATION for $300,000 last September, but that deal was voided in November as part of the penalty levied against the organization for violation of baseball's rules on signing international amateur free agents. The ORGANIZATION, who had scouted the LOCATION amateur heavily before he signed with PERSON, were happy to swoop in and sign him, partially using international bonus money procured in the PERSON trade to sign PERSON for $1.2 million in December.The ORGANIZATION got their first extended look at PERSON in GPE Training and were pleased with what they saw, both in terms of his raw tools and feel for the game, especially given his lack of experience. A plus runner, his speed is his best tool and should help him steal bases and cover plenty of ground in the infield. PERSON was initially a second baseman as an amateur, but as he's grown and developed, he moved over to short, and the ORGANIZATION believe he has the tools, actions and arm to stay there long-term. He has shown the ability to make consistent contact at the plate, using all fields, and has surprised a bit with his ability to drive the ball, something that will improve as he physically matures.PERSON obviously has a long way to go and will take his first step as a professional this summer. But the ORGANIZATION feel eventually he could eventually develop into a top-of-the-order catalyst who plays a premium position.

PERSON had agreed to a deal for $300,000 with the ORGANIZATION in September 2017, but it was voided two months later as part of the penalty for their violations on the international market. The ORGANIZATION had some extra international bonus money, courtesy of the PERSON trade, and were able to bring PERSON into the fold for $1.2 million in December. He had a strong professional debut in the ORGANIZATION, but that was clouded when, in October, he was convicted of assaulting his former girlfriend in GPE has the chance to have a very good hit tool thanks to excellent hand-eye coordination. That's a blessing and a curse, because while he rarely strikes out, he showed a propensity to swing at everything to make contact. The ORGANIZATION are having the left-handed-hitting shortstop focus on zoning better, so he can find better pitches to drive and so he won't get exposed by better breaking stuff as he moves up the ladder. There is some impact to unlock with his swing, he uses his body well, so there should be some power in the future. At least a plus runner, PERSON should have the ability to steal bases as well.Defensively, PERSON has the makings of a solid shortstop, with good hands and enough arm. He gets out of control fundamentally at times, leading to more errors than necessary. Consistency there should allow him to perhaps be an everyday shortstop when all is said and done.

PERSON PERSON (PERSON, GPE) featured not only one of the best bats in the 2019 prep class in third baseman PERSON (selected 12th overall to the ORGANIZATION) but also one of the more projectable arms in GPE. He missed the state playoffs with a lat strain but still went in the second round to the ORGANIZATION and signed for an above-slot $1,097,500. His father PERSON also was a right-hander taken in the second round (PERSON, 1991) and reached Triple-A.GPE already can maintain low-90s velocity deep into games and tops out at 95 mph with his fastball, which should get quicker as he adds more strength to his 6-foot-6 frame. He backs up his heater with an upper-70s curveball with good depth that can become a plus pitch if he improves its consistency. He also demonstrates some aptitude for a changeup that he'll need to use more often in pro ball.GPE has a fairly simple delivery for such a tall pitcher, and his athleticism and strength should lend themselves to control and durability. He uses his size and a high-three-quarters arm slot to deliver his pitches on a steep downhill plane. He also offers intriguing hitting ability and some power potential, which could have made him a two-way player had he followed through on his commitment to PERSON.

Bleday won a starting job at ORGANIZATION as a freshman in 2017 and was the ORGANIZATION' best hitter as a sophomore, when scouts voted him the best prospect in the summer PERSON. That all served as a prelude to special 2019 season in which he led ORGANIZATION Division I with 27 homers and 192 total bases while helping ORGANIZATION win its second PERSON Series championship. The LOCATION player of the year, he went fourth overall in the Draft to the ORGANIZATION and signed for a franchise-record $6.67 million.Coming into the year, Bleday stood out more for his pure hitting ability than his pop. He has a smooth, quick left-handed swing, a disciplined approach and a willingness to use the whole field. He possessed the bat speed, strength and leverage in his 6-foot-3 frame to produce plus power, and he started doing so once he began looking to attack and lift more pitches.A two-way player as a GPE high schooler, Bleday has a plus arm that adds to his right-field profile. While he's a below-average runner, he has enough range to get the job done on defense. His keen instincts help compensate for his lack of quickness on the bases and in the outfield.

GPE (PERSON) PERSON had three premium pitching prospects on its 2018 team that went 32-9 and finished third in the state 6-A playoffs. PERSON had top-five-rounds talent but his desire to attend PERSON compromised his signability, while then-junior right-handers and PERSON A&M commits PERSON and PERSON emerged as potential top-three-rounds picks. While PERSON was more highly regarded entering 2019, PERSON outpitched him for the second straight spring to become the higher pick (ORGANIZATION Round A) in June, signing with the ORGANIZATION for slot value at $2.05 million.PERSON usually operates at 90-92 mph with his fastball, though he has reached 96 mph and should deal in the mid 90s more regularly once he fills out his very projectable 6-foot-3 frame. He had one of the better sliders in the high school ranks, a low-80s breaker with late bite and two-plane depth at times. He also has good feel for a changeup with similar velocity and some fade.PERSON isn't as athletic as PERSON, whom the FACILITY took in the second round, but he repeats his delivery well and owns better present command. He has a quick, whippy arm that works well, though his arm action does get long in back. He should be able to hold up as a pro starter once he adds some strength.

Remember when there was concern about ORGANIZATION's ability to hit at the pro level coming out of the ORGANIZATION high school ranks in 2017, even though he was the state's PERSON of the Year and led all prepsters with 25 home runs? Yeah, no one else does, either, not after ORGANIZATION raked across two levels of GPE ball during his summer debut then hit his way all the way to Double-A at age 19 in 2018, fitting in a Futures Game appearance for good measure. Hamstring and ankle injuries shelved him in GPE Training, and he was sidelined for an extended period of time.While the swing-and-miss tendencies that concerned some scouts still remain with ORGANIZATION, his bat speed and ability to read pitches and make adjustments more than outstrip the worry. He's shown the ability to drive the ball to all fields and his over-the-fence pop started showing up consistently during his first full season. Yes, ORGANIZATION can still refine his overall approach to see more pitches and draw more walks, but the strides he has quickly made in pitch recognition bode well for his future at the plate. ORGANIZATION's speed works on both sides of the ball, giving him the ability to steal some bases and enough range to play center field, especially as he improves his reads and routes. Should he slow down a touch as he physically matures, ORGANIZATION has shown the ability to play the outfield corners. A shoulder issue that kept him from playing the outfield in 2017 is a distant memory and the plus arm that allowed him to crank out plus fastballs from the mound in high school has returned. The five-tool outfielder is way ahead of schedule and could be patrolling the ORGANIZATION outfield alongside Mike PERSON sooner rather than later.

From a raw tools perspective, there may not have been anyone more enticing in the 2017 Draft class than ORGANIZATION. The ORGANIZATION high school star was his state's PERSON of the Year and led all high school hitters with 25 home runs. While there was some concern about his ability to hit, the ORGANIZATION liked the upside enough to take him No. 10 overall and sign him for full pick value. He then went out and showed off all of those tools across two levels of rookie ball during his pro debut, and kept on doing it across two levels of A ball in his first full season, earning a trip to the ORGANIZATION in the process.While no one questions ORGANIZATION's raw power and bat speed from the right side, some were concerned with his ability to make enough contact to tap into it due to some swing-and-miss tendencies that showed up against top competition on the summer showcase circuit. There were some strikeouts during his debut, but he impressed the ORGANIZATION with his ability to make adjustments and drive the ball to all fields. A tremendous athlete with plus speed, ORGANIZATION has the chance to continue to be a basestealing threat long term. It also helps give him plenty of range to patrol center, though he didn't play the outfield last summer because of a minor shoulder issue. His plus arm, which fired upper-90s fastballs from the mound in high school, would also work in right.Even with the exciting debut, patience will be key in the dynamic outfielder's development. If it all continues to click, he could develop into the kind of All-Star performer teams hope to get with their first-round selections.

There may not have been a 2017 Draft prospect with better all-around tools than ORGANIZATION, who drew comparisons to former No. 2 overall Draft picks like PERSON and PERSON Jr. based on his athletic ability. ORGANIZATION didn't go that high, but he did land at the end of the Top 10 to the PERSON, who reversed course from taking a pure college performer in the first round in 2016 to sign ORGANIZATION for full pick value.The PERSON high school standout led all high school players in the country with 25 homers and was named his state's Gatorade player of the year, but there were still concerns about his ability to hit enough to tap into that power at the next level. The pop is legit, with outstanding bat speed from the right side of the plate translating to plus raw power. With that, however, has come a tendency to swing and miss, and there is work to be done on his approach at the plate. He's a plus athlete with a big league body already, with incredible speed that should work on both sides of the ball. He's a very good defensive center fielder, with a strong arm that fired fastballs up to 97 mph at times off the mound.The PERSON will have to be patient with ORGANIZATION as he learns to make adjustments at the pro level. If it all clicks, he has All-Star potential.

Pitchers who already have been relegated to a relief-only role before they've even reached full-season ball don't typically garner much buzz as prospects. PERSON, however, is an exception. Signed by GPE at the outset of the 2016-17 international period, he made his GPE debut as a 20-year-old in 2018, pitching well in the ORGANIZATION before a promotion to Class A Short-Season Auburn in GPE. PERSON's bullpen potential was on full display last season as he paired a mid-to-upper 90s fastball with a nasty slider to average 11.7 strikeouts-per-nine over 30 2/3 frames. The breaking ball has above-average potential, and PERSON has enough feel for a changeup that it could be an average pitch in time. While PERSON's lightening-quick-arm causes the ball to explode out of his hand, he struggles to repeat his delivery and harness his stuff, leading to well-below-average control (6.5 walks-per-nine in '18). The ORGANIZATION were pleased with PERSON's performance during instructional league, where he did a better job throwing strikes without it detracting from his stuff. If he can continue to improve his overall control, as well as his fastball command, PERSON could move through the Minors quickly.

PERSON emerged as a top prospect for the 2018 Draft as a sophomore, and while he did plateau a bit, there were still few players with better all-around potential in his prep class. As a toolsy right-handed hitter from the ORGANIZATION with a similar build, he draws comparisons to PERSON. After hitting .491 with a .611 ORGANIZATION and six home runs during his senior year at GSP (ORGANIZATION.) High, PERSON became the program's first player to be drafted since 2007, going to the ORGANIZATION in the second round. He passed on a ORGANIZATION of GPE commitment to sign for slot value ($1,113,500), and then began his pro career in the Rookie-level PERSON. PERSON has two loud tools in his raw power and arm strength. With his lightning-fast bat and his strength, he can hammer balls out of the park to all fields from the right side of the plate. His arm strength might have been the best among 2018 high school position players, having been clocked at 98 mph from the outfield at the ORGANIZATION showcase after his junior year, though his accuracy sometimes leaves something to be desired.There are some swing-and-miss concerns with PERSON's bat because he has been inconsistent against quality pitchers on the showcase circuit, though he helped his cause by performing well at the World Wood Bat Association World Championship in October and at the ORGANIZATION in March. He has solid speed and takes good routes in center field, giving him a chance to play there in pro ball. With his power and arm, he fits the classic right-field profile.

PERSON emerged as a top prospect for the 2018 Draft as a sophomore, and while he did plateau a bit, there were still few players with better all-around potential in his prep class. After hitting .491 with a .611 ORGANIZATION and six home runs during his senior year at GSP (ORGANIZATION.) High, PERSON became the program's first player to be drafted since 2007, going to the ORGANIZATION in the second round. He passed on a ORGANIZATION of GPE commitment to sign for slot value ($1,113,500), and then began his pro career in the Rookie-level PERSON League.PERSON has two loud tools in his raw power and arm strength. With his lightning-fast bat and his physical strength, he can hammer balls out of the park to all fields from the right side of the plate. His arm strength was among the best among 2018 high school position players, having been clocked at 98 mph from the outfield at the ORGANIZATION showcase after his junior year, though his accuracy sometimes leaves something to be desired. He has solid speed and takes good routes in center field, giving him a chance to play there in pro ball.That PERSON has swing-and-miss concerns and has been inconsistent against quality pitchers leads some scouts to question whether he'll ever hit enough to get to his power and unlock his full potential. The guided instruction he'll receive in pro ball could go a long way on that front, though it also means he may need extra time to develop in the Minors.

PERSON reached 98 mph with his fastball and flashed a plus slider as a high school senior last spring, but he came down with shoulder soreness in March and learned shortly before the draft that he'd need PERSON surgery. That didn't bother the ORGANIZATION, one of the few teams who preferred him as a position player even when he was fully healthy. They drafted him as a third baseman and paid him an above-slot $1.6 million in the second round.Part of three GPE state 6-A championship teams at ORGANIZATION McCarthy High (PERSON), PERSON saw more action and had more success as a hitter than he did as a pitcher. His bat speed and strength give him plus raw power, and he showed it off by homering at spotlight events such as the ORGANIZATION Games and the ORGANIZATION. He has a sound right-handed swing and did a better job of making contact and using the whole field as a senior, so PERSON believes he can hit for average and pop.PERSON obviously has the arm strength for third base. His lack of quickness and range eventually could prompt a move to first base, though the ORGANIZATION will give him every opportunity to make it at the hot corner. If hitting doesn't work out, he'll always have pitching as a fallback.

PERSON intrigued teams as a pitcher this spring, reaching the upper 90s with his fastball and flashing a plus slider, albeit with delivery concerns that may have made him a reliever. But he came down with shoulder soreness in March and learned shortly before the Draft that he would need PERSON surgery. Undaunted, the ORGANIZATION selected him as a third baseman and signed him for an above-slot $1.6 million in the second round.As part of three GPE 6-A state championship clubs at ORGANIZATION McCarthy High (PERSON), PERSON saw much more action and enjoyed more success as a hitter than he did as a pitcher. The right-handed batter did a better job of making contact and using the entire field as a senior, and PERSON believes in his potential to hit for both power and average. He combines bat speed and strength, and he has a track record of producing against top competition, homering at events such as the ORGANIZATION Games and the ORGANIZATION Invitational.Though PERSON has more than enough arm for third base, it's unclear whether he'll be able to stay there. He may not have the quickness, range or hands for the hot corner, and first base may be his only other option.

It was with good reason that scouts viewed PERSON as one of better prep hitters in the 2016 Draft. As a junior at GPE (Va.) High, PERSON batted a robust .606, and he followed that performance by posting a .392 mark last spring. While his lack of size as well as concerns about his future position may have turned off some teams, the Mariners were thrilled to find him still on the board in the second round and took him with the ORGANIZATION. 50 overall pick. After signing for an above-slot bonus of $1,750,000, PERSON showcased his promising bat with a strong pro debut in the Rookie-level PERSON and received an Opening Day assignment to Class A PERSON to begin 2017.PERSON shows feel to hit from the left side, with good bat speed and hand-eye coordination as well as a discernable eye. ORGANIZATION officials believe he'll develop into an above-average hitter with at least average power, though a penchant for swinging and missing has been an issue early in his career. Whereas some scouts believe PERSON can become an adequate third baseman, others feel he's destined for first base or left field, where his below-average speed and average arm strength would be less of an issue. Listed at 5-foot-9, PERSON doesn't require much physical projection.Beyond PERSON's physical tools, the Mariners rave about the makeup and baseball IQ, which helped him make a smooth transition into the professional ranks. He has many gains to make on both sides of the ball and is likely to move down the defensive spectrum, but the potential is there for him to develop into an everyday player.

Despite batting .606 as a junior and then .392 as a senior at GPE (Va.) High, PERSON proved a divisive 2016 Draft prospect due to his lack of size as well as concerns surrounding his future position. The ORGANIZATION, however, were thrilled to find him still on the board in the second round, as they selected PERSON with the ORGANIZATION. 50 overall pick and then signed him for more than slot value at $1,750,000. Assigned to Class A PERSON for his first full season, PERSON held his own in the ORGANIZATION at age 19 before advancing to Class A Advanced Modesto late in the season. His bat came alive at the more advanced level, as PERSON erupted to hit .421 in the postseason to garner honors as the GPE League Championship Series MVP.PERSON shows feel to hit from the left side, with good bat speed and hand-eye coordination as well as a discernable eye. ORGANIZATION officials believe he'll develop into an above-average hitter with at least average power, though a penchant for swinging and missing has resulted in little pop early in his career. Whereas some scouts believe PERSON can become an adequate third baseman, others feel he's destined for first base or left field, where his below-average speed and average arm strength would be less of an issue. PERSON is thickly built and doesn't require much physical projection, so he will need to focus on conditioning and adding good strength to his 5-foot-9 frame in future seasons. PERSON's physical tools, the ORGANIZATION rave about the makeup and baseball IQ, noting that it has already helped him to overcome adversity as a professional. He has many gains to make on both sides of the ball and is likely to move down the defensive spectrum, but the potential is there for him to develop into an everyday player.

There's little doubt about PERSON's ability to swing the bat. He batted .606 as a junior at GPE (Va.) High, and then followed the performance by posting a .392 mark last spring. His size and lack of profile, however, made him a bit of a polarizing prospect among scouts, although that didn't keep the Mariners from drafting him in the second round. After signing for an above-slot bonus of $1,750,000, PERSON showcased his promising bat with a strong start to his career in the Rookie-level PERSON League.The left-handed hitting third baseman can flat-out rake as possibly the best pure hitter in his area. He barrels balls up consistently and has some power to go along with it. Everything else, though, is a bit of a question mark. As the 2016 GPE approached, scouts weren't sure what to make of GPE high school senior PERSON, a third baseman who looked like he could hit but who was hard to profile because of his 5-foot-9 frame and lack of a sure defensive home. Defensively, he's still a third baseman and will stay there, though he played a handful of games at second and first base last year.The ORGANIZATION would like PERSON to get back to being the hitter he was at the GPE, one who made consistent hard contact with the ability to drive the ball. PERSON turned down the chance to go in the first five rounds of the 2015 GPE as a GPE high schooler to attend PERSON, where he improved offensively and defensively. Under general manager A.J. PERSON, the ORGANIZATION have had success with mid-to-late round pitchers. PERSON might be the latest steal. PERSON PERSON set an Illinois record with 14 saves in 2015, when the PERSON made him the ORGANIZATION. 6 overall choice in the GPE. PERSON's strong 6-foot-4 frame and resilient arm make him a durable bullpen option, and he should be one of the first 2018 draftees to reach the big leagues.

While GPE racked up 14 saves as a junior reliever at ORGANIZATION, giving him 22 for his career, he didn't have nearly the GPE profile as former ORGANIZATION closer PERSON, the school's career saves leader who was the ORGANIZATION. 6 overall pick by the Twins in 2015. PERSON didn't pitch at all last summer on the showcase circuit because of a dead arm, showing a ton of power as a first baseman. His arm action is clean and his athleticism allows him to repeat his delivery and throw strikes with ease. Things were going exactly according to plan over PERSON's first year-plus in the ORGANIZATION organization. His fastball sits around 92-93 mph and can touch a bit higher, a pitch that plays up because he commands it and throws it with good life. Both of his secondary offerings, his changeup and curve, could be at least above-average pitches in the future. He could still stand to tighten his breaking ball a bit more. It has good shape to it, but making it a little sharper could help it become a true out pitch.The southpaw also stands out because of his competitive nature, which can almost be a negative when he's too hard on himself. When the ORGANIZATION signed their top pick PERSON for more than $2.5 million below pick value in 2016, that enabled them to aggressively go after other talent. The pitch will play up anyway because of its armside run and because he creates good angle with his 6-foot-5 frame. His curveball has depth, and he has good feel for a fading changeup, with both secondary offerings looking like they could be above-average pitches in the future. Seeing him as a future No. 3 is easy, with that perhaps being too conservative of a ceiling.

It's become a familiar pattern for the ORGANIZATION late: Go aggressively after high school pitching early in the GPE, then watch as they excel in their first full seasons. PERSON followed the script perfectly, signing for just over $3 million as the 40th overall pick in the 2016 GPE, then finishing second in the LOCATION League in strikeouts and fourth in ORGANIZATION during his introduction to full-season ball.PERSON has a solid, if unspectacular, three-pitch mix that he has shown an ability to use well to dominate hitters. He'll be able to sit comfortably with his fastball in the 92-93 mph range, and it plays up because of its life and his ability to command it well. His curve and changeup both flash above-average to plus and he's shown a willingness to go to one secondary pitch if the other one isn't working on any given night. He has a feel to spin the breaking ball, but it could use a little more sharpness to become a true out pitch.PERSON is a plus competitor who showed he could handle getting out of trouble when he needed to. He might not have the highest ceiling of the core of talented young pitchers in the ORGANIZATION system, but he seems a strong bet to fit nicely into the middle of a rotation in the future.

The ORGANIZATION did some serious spending on international prospects in 2016, going heavy on GPE imports and handing out four seven-figure bonuses in the process. PERSON's fastball hasn't quite ticked back up to where it was when he was up to 96-97 mph shortly after signing, but there's plenty there, sitting in the 92-94 mph range and touching a bit higher even as he works deep into starts. His curve and changeup are both developing along with his command, which currently is well below-average. The ORGANIZATION think there's an above-average breaking ball in there with further refinement, while his changeup already flashes above-average and could be a near-plus offering at maturity. ORGANIZATION officials were impressed with the adjustments PERSON made halfway into his first full season, praising him for how he remained focused after a shaky April and May. A huge physical specimen at 6-foot-6, the right-hander will continue to work on getting his frame in sync and repeating his delivery, and the belief is that it will lead to more consistent strike-throwing with his three-pitch mix.

The ORGANIZATION went all-in on the international amateur market last July, spending more than $10.8 million, going over their bonus pool by more than $8.7 million. Four players got a seven-figure bonus and three of them have landed on this Top 30. One of them is PERSON, a right-handed man child with some pretty good stuff.The 6-foot-6 PERSON will pitch all year at age 19, and he has already shown a little more polish than your average teenage pitcher. While most hurlers his age and size resemble awkward giraffes, he already looks like a man, with decent command and pitchability of some good stuff. PERSON even has a feel for a changeup.After dominating the ORGANIZATION during his seven-start pro debut last summer, the ORGANIZATION are very excited to see what PERSON can do during his GPE debut. There is a lot of ceiling here, and he has the chance to climb this list in a hurry and eventually impact the big league rotation.

In July 2016, the ORGANIZATION did some serious shopping on the international market, going heavy on GPE imports and handing out four seven-figure bonuses in the process. PERSON and PERSON landed ahead of PERSON, who got $1.9 million to sign, on the Top 30. PERSON's GPE debut in 2017 was a bit uneven, but there's still a lot to like in the young right-hander.It starts with his size, as he is a huge physical specimen at 6-foot-6. His fastball hasn't quite ticked back up to where it was when he was up to 96-97 mph shortly after signing, but there's plenty there, sitting in the 92-94 mph range and touching a bit higher. The ORGANIZATION think there's an above-average breaking ball in there, while his change remains a work in progress.More than anything PERSON needs to work on getting his huge frame in sync and repeating his delivery. That should lead to more consistent strike-throwing along with a refinement of his overall stuff. PERSON may be key, but pitching all year at age 20, there's plenty of time for him to figure it out.

Coming out of a ORGANIZATION (ORGANIZATION) program that produced future first-rounders and big leaguers PERSON, PERSON and PERSON, PERSON went undrafted in 2016 and headed to PERSON A&M. PERSON has effort in his delivery and uses an arm slot that varies from low- to mid-three-quarters, yet that doesn't prevent him from pounding the strike zone with three pitches. He doesn't dazzle radar guns with his 88-93 mph fastball, but it plays up because of its armside run and his ability to command it to both sides of the plate. He masterfully manipulates his low-80s slider, changing velocities and shape and demonstrating the ability to back-foot it against right-handers.Though PERSON' changeup is less reliable than his other two offerings, it features some fade and shows flashes of becoming a solid third pitch. Some scouts look at the stress with which he throws and peg him as a reliever, and he did hit 97 mph as a freshman in that role, but he has the three-pitch repertoire, control and durable frame to start, and the makeup to get the most out of his ability.

PERSON GPE has produced some sneaky good position players in recent years with PERSON (ORGANIZATION, fourth round, 2015) and PERSON (ORGANIZATION, third round, 2018). With his current approach, he projects as a possible .270 hitter with 15 homers per season as a pro.PERSON's best tool is his speed, and he'll flash some plus-plus times but plays more as a plus runner. PERSON posted a 5.20 ORGANIZATION in his first two seasons at GPE before breaking out in 2018, ranking second in ORGANIZATION Division I with a 1.23 mark and first in hits per nine innings (4.8). While most scouting reports rated his low-80s slider ahead of his fading changeup in college, the latter was more effective in his introduction to pro ball and showed signs of becoming a plus pitch. His slider could become a solid offering if he tightens it up.Pitching in the ORGANIZATION in the summer of 2017 taught PERSON that he could compete against quality competition without lighting up radar guns, and he took off once he became more aggressive about challenging hitters. His ability to repeat his sound delivery allows him to command his pitches and he's not afraid to work inside. A potential back-of-the-rotation starter, he helps his cause with a deceptive pickoff move that nailed 17 runners in 13 starts as a GPE junior.

After logging a 5.20 ORGANIZATION in his first two seasons at ORGANIZATION, PERSON ranked second in ORGANIZATION Division I this spring at 1.23 while also finishing first in hits per nine innings (4.8). He also throws strikes with his solid low-80s slider and his fading changeup.Pitching in the ORGANIZATION last summer helped PERSON realize he could compete against quality competition without overpowering stuff. He has been more aggressive about challenging hitters in 2018, showing no fear for pitching inside. He picked off 17 runners in 13 starts as a junior, and his ability to shut down the running game is another facet that gives him a high ceiling as a back-of-the-rotation starter.

GPE was primarily a shortstop for his high school team in GPE who pitched only occasionally. The 6-foot-2 right-hander has a long way to go, but there are building blocks to like. His fastball sits around 90 mph right now with a little bit of sink, he can spin a decent breaking ball and there's some feel for a changeup, though that's understandably inconsistent. With his athleticism and solid delivery, the GPE believe GPE will get to PERSON average control. As GPE learns how to pitch and adds strength to his frame, all of his stuff could start ticking up as he progresses. ORGANIZATION, the GPE see some PERSON potential in GPE, with similar upside as a future starter.

The second-youngest player in the 2017 Draft class, PERSON didn't celebrate his 18th birthday until November. That youth, along with his highly projectable frame and loud but raw tools, put him firmly on the ORGANIZATION' radar, and the club was thrilled to land the GPE prep in the third round. They were even more thrilled with his pro debut in the Rookie-level PERSON, where PERSON proved a more advanced hitter than initially expected while exhibiting a mature approach. Scouts rave about PERSON's athleticism and projectable 6-foot-3 frame, one that leaves room for him to add considerable strength in the coming years. Once he's done so, the switch-hitting PERSON could offer plus raw power, though not before shortening the length of his swing and refining his overall hitting mechanics. Defensively, PERSON has a strong arm that receives plus grades from evaluators and profiles as a clean fit in right field.PERSON is raw and will need time to develop his game in the ORGANIZATION, but the overall package offers club officials plenty on which to dream.

The second-youngest player in the 2017 Draft class, PERSON won't celebrate his 18th birthday until November. That youth, along with his highly projectable frame and loud but raw tools, put him firmly on the ORGANIZATION' radar, and the club was thrilled to land the GPE prep in the third round.Scouts rave about PERSON's athleticism and projectable 6-foot-3 frame, one that leaves room for him to add considerable strength in the coming years. Once he's done so, the switch-hitting PERSON could offer plus raw power, though not before shortening the length of his swing and refining his overall hitting mechanics. Defensively, PERSON has a cannon for an arm that receives plus grades from evaluators and profiles as a clean fit in right field.PERSON is raw and will need time to develop his game in the ORGANIZATION, but the overall package offers club officials plenty on which to dream.

The ORGANIZATION signed PERSON out of the ORGANIZATION in January 2014, landing the then-16-year-old with a $350,000 bonus. After an impressive professional debut in the Rookie-level Gulf Coast League, he spent the 2015 season, his age-18 campaign, in the Class A GPE ORGANIZATION, where he continued to show an advanced bat despite missing nearly six weeks with a right thumb injury. In October during instructional league, PERSON underwent surgery to repair a broken hamate bone in his left hand. He was fully healthy by Spring Training, though, and the ORGANIZATION assigned him to the Class A Advanced PERSON to begin the season.PERSON is a physical specimen with the strength to match his size. He generates plus raw power from the right side of the plate with above-average bat speed and a surprisingly short swing, and he has natural feel for driving the ball to all fields. Though PERSON' power has translated to mostly doubles early in his career, it's easy to envision the teenager clearing more fences as he develops. His approach is understandably raw and he'll need to become more selective, but he does a good job controlling the zone for a player his age and has a knack for barreling the ball.PERSON has the arm strength for third base, but as a well-below-average runner, it will be a challenge for him to remain at the position due to his lack of range and quickness. Should he be forced off the hot corner, his middle-of-the-order bat would support a move to first base.

While the ORGANIZATION don't often dive deep into international amateur waters, they dipped their toes in to sign PERSON in January 2014. If the teenager's pro debut in the ORGANIZATION is any indication, the expenditure for PERSON' upside will be well worth it.The corner infielder more than held his own while skipping over the ORGANIZATION and playing in the States at age 17. PERSON has a big strong body and a ton of raw power from the right side of the plate. He has plenty of bat speed and has already shown the ability to drive the ball to all fields. PERSON has more than enough arm strength for third, but his lack of speed negatively impacts his range and he does need to improve his footwork. A move to first base, especially given his size, isn't out of the question.The good news is that it looks like his power bat will play perfectly well at either corner spot. PERSON might still be a ways away from the big leagues, but the payoff could be an impact, middle-of-the-order bat.

A top prospect in GPE's system since he signed for $350,000 out of the ORGANIZATION at age 16 in January 2014, PERSON has struggled to stay healthy in recent years. He missed nearly six weeks with a right thumb injury during his 2015 full-season debut and underwent surgery to repair a broken hamate bone in his left hand that fall. Though healthy for all of 2016, PERSON was overmatched as the youngest everyday player in the Class A Advanced PERSON. And his strong start to the '17 season was quickly derailed when he landed on the disabled list in April with a broken finger suffered while punching a wall.  Big and physical, PERSON generates plus raw power from the right side of the plate with his above-average bat speed and natural feel for driving the ball to all fields. He connected on 10 homers in 2016, more than doubling his combined total from the two previous years, and it doesn't take much to envision PERSON clearing even more fences as he develops. Scouts do worry about his ability to hit for average, especially after he regressed last season with his swing mechanics, plate discipline and pitch recognition.  PERSON has the arm strength for third base, but as a well-below-average runner, it will be a challenge for him to remain at the position due to his lack of range and quickness. A move down the defensive spectrum to first base appears unavoidable, though it would place even greater pressure on his offensive tools to develop.

The PERSON didn't spend lavishly during the 2013 international signing period, but they picked their spots well and signed one of the top third basemen in the class in PERSON. He squares the ball up well and has good strike-zone discipline for his age.  At 17, PERSON is already listed at 6-foot-3, 220 pounds, and his size may necessitate a position change. He's a below-average runner, but he could possibly be a fit in the outfield or at first base. No matter where PERSON plays, his powerful bat will be what propels him through the ORGANIZATION.

PERSON was ranked No. 16 on ORGANIZATION's Top 30 ORGANIZATION list heading into the 2016 signing period and he was atop the ORGANIZATION' shopping list. The organization spent freely in the market, led by the $2.35 million PERSON got to sign. The toolsy outfielder made his GPE debut in the ORGANIZATION and would have finished fourth in the Rookie-level circuit in batting average if he had compiled enough at-bats to qualify.PERSON has already shown that he's a tough out at the plate, one with outstanding contact skills. He rarely strikes out and rose to the challenge by battling the better pitching he faced during his GPE debut. While power is never going to be a large part of his game, PERSON does need to add strength so he can continue to impact the baseball against higher levels of competition. He's a plus runner who should be able to steal bases, so an improved approach that includes drawing more walks will help. His speed helps him in the outfield, with enough range to stay in center, though he has a below-average arm.Just 19 years old, PERSON has a long way to go. PERSON strength and better plate discipline will help him reach his ceiling as a dynamic table-setter who plays up the middle.

The ORGANIZATION have made a habit of landing intriguing PERSON ball talent in trades, acquiring three of their best pitching prospects (PERSON, PERSON, PERSON) in that fashion. He's not flashy or fast, but PERSON is quick and athletic with nice actions and a solid arm. Though he played a lot of second base in his pro debut, deferring to $900,000 bonus baby PERSON, he's a definite shortstop.PERSON should be able to contribute with the bat as well. He's a switch-hitter with bat speed and a penchant for making line-drive contact from both sides of the plate. Once he gets stronger, he could hit 10-12 homers on an annual basis.

The ORGANIZATION signed PERSON for $600,000, the largest bonus given to a GPE in the 2014 international class, before trading him to the Astros a year later in the seven-player PERSON Giles/Vince Velasquez deal. He drew a 50-game suspension in 2017 after testing positive for a stimulant, while his 2018 season was a tale of two halves. He's a switch-hitter with a line-drive stroke, a good sense of the strike zone and the bat speed and deceptive strength for double-digit home run potential. He's an unusually reliable defender for his age at both shortstop and second base. His solid arm also makes him a viable option at third base and enhances his value as a potential utilityman.

PERSON's $600,000 bonus from the ORGANIZATION was the largest given to a GPE during the 2014-15 international signing period. The ORGANIZATION originally signed PERSON for $600,000, the largest bonus given to a GPE during the 2014-15 international signing period. PERSON PERSON was a star pitcher at Memphis who authored a perfect game and was a 19th-round pick of the ORGANIZATION Cardinals back in 1989 and spent two years in pro ball. â¢ 7/22: GPE promoted to Double-AAfter a pair of relatively ordinary years at GPE, GPE enjoyed a huge breakout season as a junior and catapulted into top-10-pick conversations. At the top of the ORGANIZATION' shopping spree on the international amateur market stood PERSON, the little GPE outfielder who received a $2.35 million bonus to sign. When PERSON left GPE in 2015, the hope was he would be able to sign with a big league team. Though overshadowed by first-rounders PERSON (ORGANIZATION) and PERSON (ORGANIZATION) in PERSON's 2018 prep class, PERSON performed well when decision-makers came to the state during Spring Training. He played mostly at the hot corner in his pro debut, then began 2019 at second base before shifting to shortstop and also seeing action in left field. His soft hands and strong arm, which delivered low-90s fastballs when he pitched in high school, will play anywhere in the infield.

Though first-rounder PERSON (ORGANIZATION) and third baseman PERSON (ORGANIZATION) monopolized most of headlines in GPE high school baseball this year, PERSON attracted plenty of attention from scouts. An unheralded recruit out of a GPE high school, PERSON developed into GPE's best pitching prospect since Brewers first-rounder PERSON in 2009. A GPE all-state wide receiver and defensive back in high school, PERSON went from unheralded baseball recruit to GPE's best pitching prospect since Brewers 2009 first-rounder PERSON. Signed as an under-the-radar international player out of GPE in August 2015, PERSON hadn't shown much over his first two years as a professional. The ORGANIZATION knew that PERSON might be a bit of a project as a tall and thin high schooler out of the GPE ranks. As the 2016 PERSON approached, PERSON traveled to GPE with his fellow GPE high school standouts. The 2016-17 international signing period is proving to be a fruitful one for the A's organization, at least as it pertains to filling the Top 30 list. Though ORGANIZATION (GPE) PERSON has sent more than two dozen players to college programs, it never has had a player drafted before the 20th round. One of the better all-around prep hitters in his class, GPE has a quick right-handed stroke and has a track record of catching up to and punishing quality fastballs on the showcase circuit. With his strength, balance and mature approach, he makes consistent hard line-drive contact. Once GPE fills out his rangy 6-foot-4 frame and adds some loft to his swing, he could have plus power.An average runner out of the batter's box and quicker once he gets going, GPE is athletic for his size but isn't a lock to stick at shortstop. His solid arm will play anywhere in the infield, where he probably fits best at third base, but he may have a chance to stick up the middle at second, and he has the makeup to get the most out of his ability.

ORGANIZATION (GPE) High never had had a player drafted earlier than the 20th round until 2018, when the ORGANIZATION selected GPE with the ORGANIZATION. 12 overall pick in the first round. With his plus bat speed and an explosive but well-balanced right-handed swing, GPE has no issues with velocity and consistently barrels the ball. His strong arm plays well there, though his defensive actions might be best suited for third base long term. No. 22 on MLBPipeline.com's list of the Top 30 international prospects for the 2016-17 international period, PERSON received $1 million from the ORGANIZATION at the outset of the signing period.
