There have been some who have lamented the fact that baseball keeps losing top tier athletes to football. A two-sport standout who intrigued with his athleticism, PERSON really put his name on the map with a breakout performance last March at ORGANIZATION's ORGANIZATION. He employs a big leg kick and doesn't have much track record offensively, but he has the upside of a solid hitter with 15-20 homers per year. His best tool is his speed, which earns top-of-the-scale 80 grades from some evaluators. Just with his sheer quickness, PERSON can steal bases and cover a lot of ground in center field, and he potentially could be elite in both areas as he turns his full attention to baseball. He has fringy arm strength, which is more than playable in center, and it could improve if he got on a throwing program.PERSON' upside is as high as anyone's in this Draft class given his athleticism, raw tools and previously divided focus. The D-backs were aggressive in the international market at the start of the 2017 signing period, with PERSON the big catch, getting a seven-figure bonus. His strong instincts serve him well on the bases and in center field, where he profiles well even with less-than-blazing speed.PERSON has a long way to go before it's clear what kind of player he will be. If he continues to progress, he has the chance to be a top-of-the-order type in center field.

Having already exceeded their international pool with the signing left-hander PERSON for $11 million, the ORGANIZATION proceeded to add another high-profile GPE talent to its system in PERSON, inking the 19-year-old outfielder for a reported $7 million bonus the day after he was declared a free agent by PERSON Baseball.A physical specimen, PERSON, ranked No. 8 on MLB.com's list of the Top 30 international prospects, stands out on the field for his muscular and projectable body. However, with speed that's a tick below average and a strong arm, he seemingly is best suited for a corner spot. PERSON might be years away from reaching the ORGANIZATION, but he has all the ingredients needed to become a prototypical right fielder at the highest level.

The ORGANIZATION blew past their allotted international bonus pool in 2016 to sign many of the top prospects, but none were bigger than GPE PERSON and PERSON. While the lefty PERSON commanded the largest bonus at $11 million, the then-19-year-old PERSON, ORGANIZATION's No. 8 international prospect at the time, received a $7 million bonus the day after he was declared a free agent by PERSON. He made his GPE debut in 2017, earning PERSON All-Star honors with PERSON Wayne.A physical specimen, PERSON stands out on the field for his muscular and projectable body. At the plate, the right-handed hitter combines strength and bat speed to generate plus power, and he's shown the ability to drive the ball out of the park across the entire field. PERSON already demonstrates a polished approach that caters to his strengths, and he projects as an average hitter, though some evaluators worry about the length and stiffness in his swing. He's played all three outfield positions, but he is a destined for an outfield corner, where his below-average speed, strong arm and power profile are all clean fits.PERSON might be years away from reaching the ORGANIZATION, but he has all the ingredients needed to become a prototypical right fielder at the highest level.

Though international players become eligible to sign at age 16, PERSON was 19 years and seven months old when he caught on with the ORGANIZATION for $10,000 in October 2016. Like many pitchers in the system, he has added significant fastball velocity since turning pro. He has picked up 5 mph this year alone after reaching full-season ball for the first time.After operating with an 89-93 mph fastball when he made his GPE debut in 2018, PERSON is now dealing at 93-97 and hitting 99. His secondary pitches are very much works in progress, however. His mid-80s slider does show some promise and he's working to gain feel for a changeup that features splitter action.While ORGANIZATION has developed PERSON as a starter to this point, his delivery and arm action are more suited for relief work. He also has yet to prove that he can provide enough strikes to work deep into games. He does have one of the more intriguing fastballs in the system, so the ORGANIZATION will give him plenty of time to figure everything else out.

Purchased from the ORGANIZATION's PERSON in a July 2015 deal worth $1.5 million, PERSON made his pro debut 11 months in a Rookie-level ORGANIZATION start that featured seven strikeouts in four scoreless innings and created a ton of buzz in the scouting community. Forearm tightness precluded him from pitching in a game again until last summer, when GPE never let him work more than five innings in 10 starts. He made his full-season debut at age 19 this April but his control quickly disintegrated to the point where the ORGANIZATION had to shut him down for a month.PERSON possesses easily the best changeup in the system, earning plus-plus grades at times because he sells it so well and it seems to disappear at the plate. He sets it up with a 93-95 mph fastball that he can push to 97 and spot on either side of the plate when he's going well. He'll also flash a plus curveball at times, though it's less consistent than his other two pitches because he uses it less often.Before he lost the ability to find the strike zone, PERSON showed some feel for adding and subtracting from his pitches. He continued to battle his control after returning in June, and it won't matter how impressive his pure stuff is if he can't throw it over the plate. His delivery has gotten out of sync and he lost confidence once his troubles snowballed.

It's unlikely that any pitcher ever created as much intrigue with a four-inning pro debut in GPE ball than PERSON did last summer. Purchased from the ORGANIZATION's PERSON in a July 2015 deal valued at $1.5 million, he made just one ORGANIZATION start last June before GPE shut him down as a precaution with forearm soreness. That lone appearance was enough for scouts inside and outside the organization to believe he has as much upside as any ORGANIZATION pitching prospect.PERSON not only has a fastball that sits at 93-95 mph and can reach 97, but he already can locate it on either side of the plate. That's not even his best weapon, a distinction that belongs to a changeup he also commands well and that many evaluators project as a double-plus offering. His breaking ball still is slurvy enough that it gets described alternately as both a curve and a slider, though he does have some feel for spin.While PERSON isn't very physical or projectable, he has an exceedingly quick arm. He has advanced command for a teenager, as well as the aptitude to add and subtract from his pitches. He'll need time to develop but could become the homegrown frontline starter the ORGANIZATION have been looking for.

PERSON originally signed with the ORGANIZATION's PERSON before the ORGANIZATION purchased his rights in a July 2015 deal valued at $1.5 million. He looked spectacular in his GPE debut in 2016, striking out seven in four one-hit innings. He came down with soreness in his forearm shortly afterward, so GPE decided to shut him down until instructional league as a precaution.PERSON doesn't have a ton of projection remaining in his 6-foot-1, 185-pound frame, but he doesn't need it because his present stuff already is impressive. He operates with a 93-95 mph fastball and can reach 97, showing the ability to throw it for strikes on both sides of the plate. He's still refining his secondary pitches but already flashes a well above-average changeup and a solid slider.More advanced than the typical teenaged pitcher, PERSON has good command of his pitches and can add and subtract from them. He's years away from PERSON at this point, but he has the upside of a frontline starter if he can stay healthy.

The cousin of ORGANIZATION third basemen PERSON, PERSON signed with the ORGANIZATION for $250,000 in 2016 and made his GPE debut the next year following a short stint in his native ORGANIZATION. He impressed evaluators with his defense at shortstop, offensive potential and overall feel for the game in the Rookie-level Gulf Coast League, and the ORGANIZATION packaged him with flame-thrower PERSON to the ORGANIZATION in December to land 2017 ORGANIZATION MVP Giancarlo PERSON. One of the youngest everyday players in the Class A GPE ORGANIZATION on 2018 Opening Day, GPE has continued to show tools and skills that bely his age. GPE has the requisite defensive tools to stick at shortstop. He's an athletic and agile defender there, one with soft hands, slick footwork and arm strength that has already improved in the professional ranks. Though he stands out more for his glove than bat, GPE is no slouch at the plate, showing good feel to hit and some power potential from the left-handed box. His discerning eye at the plate and patient approach translate to strong on-base skills, and he knows how to use his above-average speed once on base.GPE projects as a glove-first shortstop who can also hit for a respectable average while adding value with his baserunning. It may not be the sexiest of profiles, but it's one that could make him a big leaguer for many years.

A cousin of PERSON, PERSON signed with the ORGANIZATION for $250,000 out of the ORGANIZATION in 2016. After his first season in pro ball, the PERSON acquired him along with PERSON and right-hander PERSON for PERSON in December 2017. He held his own as one of the second-youngest regulars (age 18) in the low Class A GPE ORGANIZATION during his first season in the ORGANIZATION system and even made a two-game cameo in high Class A.In sharp contrast to his cousin, ORGANIZATION stands out much more for his glove than his bat. He has advanced instincts at shortstop, along with quick feet and solid arm strength that has improved since he turned pro. He was shut down at the end of the 2018 season with shoulder fatigue and missed nearly three months this summer with a forearm strain, though neither should be a concern going forward. ORGANIZATION is one of the best contact hitters in the system and employs an unusually disciplined approach for his age. He has yet to drive the ball with his flat left-handed swing and slender frame, so the PERSON had him focus on strength training during the offseason and he added 20 pounds. He has some sneaky pop but never will be much of a slugger, so he's looking to make better use of his plus speed.

The ORGANIZATION spent four of their first five picks in the 2015 Draft on right-handers, concluding with PERSON in the fifth round. The first player selected from GPE in 2015, he signed for $330,000. Though he lacks physicality at 6 feet and 170 pounds, PERSON has intriguing arm strength. His fastball sits at 88-91 mph and can reach 93 with more projection remaining. His curveball also has the makings of a solid pitch, though he'll have to upgrade his changeup.PERSON is relatively polished for a high schooler and had little trouble breaking into pro ball in the Rookie-level Gulf Coast League. He allowed just one run in his first five outings while demonstrating feel for throwing strikes and pounding the bottom of the zone.

GPE was the highest-drafted player out PERSON in 2015, going to the ORGANIZATION in the fifth round and signing for $330,000. He then made a strong impression during his pro debut in the Rookie-level Gulf Coast League, posting a 0.96 WHIP with 31 strikeouts in 34 1/3 innings while holding opposing hitters to a .198 average.At 6-feet, 170 pounds, GPE is an undersized right-hander who lacks physicality. He has good arm strength, however, with a fastball that sits 88-91 mph and can reach 93 with room to add a few more ticks. His current breaking ball has the makings of an above-average pitch, and the ORGANIZATION have had him working on a true curveball this season. He has a decent changeup and throws strikes with his entire arsenal.GPE may not involve much projection, but he's distinctly polished for a recent prep PERSON pick. His background as an infielder shows in his athleticism on the mound, and it's for that reason some scouts believe the right-hander could move through the Minors at an accelerated pace.

The ORGANIZATION signed PERSON, an undersized infielder, out of GPE back in July 2013, and after a relatively ordinary debut in the ORGANIZATION in 2014, he started what would become a trend in his career by hitting over .300 in a return ORGANIZATION engagement. He turned the trick again during his GPE debut in 2016 and again in his full-season debut a year ago when he was dealt to the Phillies in the ORGANIZATION trade last July.PERSON doesn't have loud tools, but he does have a very good feel to hit, with low strikeout rates, that has led to a .312 career average heading into the 2018 season, something he didn't continue to do in the ORGANIZATION State League in 2018. He's continuing to work on adding strength, something he'll need so he can impact the baseball more consistently as he moves up the ladder. An average runner, PERSON is aggressive on the basepaths and likes to steal, though he gets caught too frequently. He's moved all over the infield for much of his career to date and while he played more shortstop than anywhere else the last two seasons, the Phillies plan to go back to having him play there, second and third.PERSON is the kind of player who won't wow you the first time you see him, but over time you'll notice his feel for the game and his ability to do the little things. PERSON strength will make him a more interesting prospect, but he at least can be a solid-hitting utilityman in the future.

Following two seasons in the Rookie-level ORGANIZATION, PERSON opened eyes in his GPE debut last summer. He led the Rookie-level PERSON in hits (98) and contact rate (92 percent) while ranking second in batting (.367). In addition to his hitting ability, he also impressed with his maturity and energy as one of the youngest regulars (age 19) in the league. He was replicating his performance in his full-season debut when he was sent to the Phillies in GPE's PERSON deal.PERSON has a very disciplined approach at the plate, using a controlled right-handed stroke and rarely deviating from his plan to hit line drives from gap to gap. He's not very big, so while he can add some strength he still may top out at 10 homers per season. An average runner, he stole 55 bases in 199 games during his first three pro seasons but succeeded in just 63 percent of his attempts.PERSON played all four infield positions in the ORGANIZATION, spending most of his time at third base before shifting to shortstop in 2016. His internal clock helps him make plays, though his merely average quickness and arm strength make it unlikely he'll stay at short in the long run. He profiles best as a sweet-swinging utilityman and could be a regular at second base if his bat continues to be as good as it has looked the last two seasons.

The ORGANIZATION were thrilled to be able to sign PERSON, an exciting infielder from GPE, for close to $5 million at the end of the 2016-17 signing period. Then they had to wait 10 months to see him play in real competition, after he hadn't played for quite some time after defecting, challenging him with an assignment to full-season ball. After stumbling out of the gate, fans got to see what the fuss was all about in the second half of 2018.Despite some concerns of pushing him too hard, PERSON was skipped over rookie ball and sent straight to the ORGANIZATION with PERSON. The ORGANIZATION were glad that they did. After he struggled at the plate the first three months, PERSON started to figure it out in the second half, hitting for average and showing some power, with five of his six homers for the season. He has shown a balanced set-up at the plate and the ability to send line drives to all fields, though he'll have to continue to refine his overall approach. He did deal with a left shoulder injury as well, but it was not too serious.PERSON's plus speed and athleticism allows him to have very good range, and he has more than enough arm for the position. He largely played second base for the GPE junior national team but played a majority of his games at shortstop for PERSON and the reviews have been good. The organization feels he has the makings of a solid Major League shortstop, with a caveat. If he continues to grow into his 6-foot-2 frame, he could outgrow the position and need to be moved.

GPE splurging on an expensive sports car, but not getting to drive it on the open road for a year. That's kind of where the ORGANIZATION are with PERSON, the exciting GPE infielder they signed for close to $5 million right at the end of the 2016-17 international signing period. Needless to say, they're excited to see what he can do in competition.PERSON is a plus athlete who largely played second base for the GPE junior national team, but has been getting very good reviews at shortstop by people like PERSON within the organization as they've seen him get work in at the premium position. His plus speed allows him to have very good range and he has more than enough arm for the position. In the past, he has shown a balanced set-up at the plate and the ability to send line drives to all fields. It's still gap power right now, but there should be more as he fills out his 6-foot-2 frame, and he attended the ORGANIZATION' strength camp over the winter to help.The ORGANIZATION have peeked under the hood and really like PERSON's engine. Now it's time to let him loose on PERSON competition and see how fast he can move.

The ORGANIZATION continued to be at the forefront of aggressive signings of GPE players when they signed PERSON for close to $5 million in June. PERSON, a past member of the GPE junior national team, joins shortstop PERSON and PERSON as big-ticket GPE prospects to join the organization as part of the ORGANIZATION' 2016-17 international signing period spending spree.A 6-foot-2 middle infielder, PERSON played a lot of second base for the GPE national team, but the ORGANIZATION believe he has the goods to stick at shortstop long-term. His plus speed -- the ORGANIZATION have him with 6.4 and 6.5 times in the 60 -- allows him to cover plenty of ground and while he'll have to break the habit of a lowered arm slot and flips to first, he has shown more than enough arm for the left side of the infield. At the plate, he has a balanced set-up and makes hard contact to all fields. PERSON will battle through at-bats with an advanced approach at the plate and mostly shows gap power right now, but his athletic 6-foot-3 frame looks like it should add strength. With that should come at least some over-the-fence pop.PERSON will spend the rest of this season in the ORGANIZATION. He should join his fellow countryman in the GPE for instructs in the fall and will make his official GPE debut in 2018.

The ORGANIZATION have had some success mining the considerable talent in GPE over the years, drafting PERSON in 2010 and PERSON in 2012. They got PERSON in the second round of the 2016 Draft and after struggling out of the gate, he went on to be an GPE ORGANIZATION All-Star in 2017 and have a solid full-season debut last year, making it seem more likely that he will join his island-mates in GSP has one of the best pure swings in the organization with the chance to be a plus hitter down the line thanks to outstanding bat-to-ball skills and plate discipline from the right side of the plate. He rarely strikes out and can spray the ball to all fields. He's shown more power than expected, with most of his over-the-fence damage coming to his pull side. He's played mostly second and third, and should continue to see an even split between the two spots going forward, though the ORGANIZATION got him a little time at shortstop in 2018, where his range is limited, but his hands and arm work fine.PERSON's tweener profile limits his ceiling a bit, and he might be a utilityman when all is said and done as a result. But if his bat keeps progressing, he could hit his way into a regular spot in a big league lineup.

Back in 2012, PERSON had a pair of first-round picks, headlined by ORGANIZATION. 1 overall selection PERSON. The island didn't have another selection in the top two rounds until 2016 when the ORGANIZATION took PERSON in the first round and the ORGANIZATION took PERSON in the second. PERSON scuffled during his pro debut, but bounced back as one of the better hitting prospects in the GPE League in 2017, finishing tied for the home run lead.PERSON was really able to settle in and adjust to pro ball in his second summer after looking unprepared in the ORGANIZATION League the year prior. He showed off outstanding bat-to-ball skills, striking out less than 10 percent of the time while showing good overall plate discipline. For that reason, many feel he'll be an above-average hitter in time, one who can drive the ball to all fields and approach PERSON average power. He's not much of a runner, but he has the chance to be an average defender at second. He's also played some third base and he might move around a bit defensively.The ORGANIZATION feel they saw the player they drafted in 2017 and there is excitement to see how those adjustments play in full-season ball. Regardless of where he plays defensively, it's his offensive upside that should help him move up the ladder.

The ORGANIZATION blew well past their allotted bonus pool for the 2016-17 international to sign a trio of promising 16-year-old shortstops in GPE, PERSON and PERSON, who signed for $950,000 on July 12. But while PERSON and PERSON may be regarded as the more advanced of the trio, it's the ORGANIZATION who requires the most projection. PERSON's compact swing and present feel for going the other way gives him a chance to hit for average, and he should show more power as he grows into his lean and athletic frame. He also shows good instincts on the bases, though his speed is only solid-to-average. On defense is where PERSON truly shines. He has good hands and fluid actions at shortstop, as well as confidence that allow him to make challenging plays appear easy. He has shown good footwork at an early age and that part of his game will improve as he develops and receives daily instruction in pro ball. He'll need time to develop, but PERSON shows the makings of becoming an everyday shortstop in the big leagues.

The ORGANIZATION made a haul on up-the-middle talents during the 2016-17 international period, signing a trio of promising 16-year-old shortstops in GPE, PERSON and PERSON, the latter of whom signed for $950,000 out of GPE on July 12. While PERSON and GPE have already emerged as the gems of that group, PERSON, with his slick defense and remaining projection, continues to excite club officials. PERSON's plus defense is his calling card. He shows good hands, fluid actions and plus arm strength at shortstop, as well as confidence that allow him to make challenging plays appear routine. At the plate, PERSON's compact swing and present feel for going the other way gives him a chance to hit for average, and he should develop some power as he grows into his lean and athletic frame. He also shows good instincts on the bases, though his speed is only average.Playing on the same infield as PERSON and GPE in the Rookie-level Gulf Coast League, PERSON saw time at second and third base in addition to his work as a shortstop. Though he's a clean fit at the latter position, a utility infield role could be PERSON's ticket to the ORGANIZATION.

Angels pitching prospects fall into two categories, for the most part. There are the pitchability guys, with PERSON, PERSON, PERSON and PERSON leading the charge. Then there are the higher upside guys, led by PERSON. PERSON, after a very strong GPE debut in 2017 in the rookie-level ORGANIZATION and PERSON, fits firmly into the latter camp.PERSON, signed for the modest sum of $70,000 in March 2016, has one of the most electric arms in the system. His fastball averaged just over 93 mph in 2017 and touched 96-97 mph at times, and there's reason to believe there could be more in the tank as he fills out his 6-foot-3 frame. His fastball-curve combination is one of the best two-pitch combinations in the organization, as PERSON can really spin his breaking ball, which flashes plus at times. His changeup is his third pitch, but there is confidence it can eventually be an average offering.PERSON has already put on good weight and strength, leading to the extra velocity that showed up in 2017. He has a very good delivery that he just needs to work on repeating more consistently, which should lead to better overall command. All the ingredients are there, with patience mixed in, for PERSON to grow into at least a mid-rotation starter.

There are international signings that make a huge splash in terms of huge bonus figures. Then there are those who sign for less and look like a bargain deal with a strong start to their career. PERSON fits the latter category, signing for $70,000 in March 2016 and then making a strong GPE debut in 2017, earning a promotion from the ORGANIZATION to the ORGANIZATION in the process.PERSON is an intriguing combination of stuff and projection. The 6-foot-3 right-hander currently throws his fastball in the 92-94 mph range, occasionally touching 95, and there could very well be more in the tank as he fills out his frame. The teenager can really spin a curveball, and with some feeling it could eventually be a plus pitch. PERSON's changeup is his third pitch, but he has feel for it and it has the chance to be a third average offering. He's typically around the strike zone and has done a job getting ground-ball outs in his nascent pro career.A good arm action and a clean and repeatable delivery give PERSON a better chance to develop from a pure power guy into a more complete pitcher. He might have a ways to go, but the ORGANIZATION are thrilled with the progress PERSON has made so far.

PERSON signed for just $70,000 in March 2016 and based on his upside alone, that might already be a bargain. After PERSON's stellar GPE debut in '17, the ORGANIZATION pushed PERSON to full-season ball after extended spring training in 2018, where the teenager struggled at first, but finished relatively strongly.PERSON screams projectability and high ceiling, and he's starting to put his considerable tools together on the mound. His electric fastball will touch 97-98 mph and there's still room for more consistent velocity as he grows into his 6-foot-3 frame. He's always been able to spin his breaking ball, but he improved the consistency in throwing it effectively as it trends towards being a plus pitch. The ORGANIZATION pushed him to throw his changeup more, and he did it 15 percent of the time in 2018, and it took a big step forward as a result, showing a much better feel for the off-speed pitch.While PERSON's walk rate spiked in 2018, there is confidence he'll get to average command and control eventually thanks to a very athletic delivery. All he needs are innings and the gloves should come off a bit in 2019, with a chance for him to make a nice leap up this list.

The GPE system is loaded with sweet-swinging middle infielders, including three from their 2017 international class in GPE PERSON and ORGANIZATION and PERSON. The nephew of 16-year big leaguer PERSON, PERSON signed for $400,000. He had no problem adapting to pro pitching in his 2018 debut and has continued to hit in his first foray into the GPE this summer.PERSON lacks physicality but make repeated hard contact from the left side of the plate. Though he won't ever be a slugger, he can drive balls to the gaps and his first two professional homers went to the opposite field. He possesses average speed and is aggressive on the bases.PERSON should be able to stay at shortstop with his quick first step, dependable hands and solid arm. While PERSON and GPE have higher offensive ceilings, PERSON may be the best defender of the trio. PERSON's surplus of young shortstops means they all see time at other positions, and he has proven capable at second and third base as well.

PERSON has long stood out for his defensive chops at shortstop, but he also improved offensively in each of his three seasons at ORGANIZATION, culminating with a junior campaign in which he finished second among the ORGANIZATION Division I leaders in average (.402), hits (108), runs (85) and triples (10). When the ORGANIZATION took PERSON in the fourth round in June, he became the second Aggies player in as many years to be selected in the round and the first position player from the school to go in the top five rounds since the ORGANIZATION took outfielder PERSON in the fifth back in 2016.PERSON's best quality is his ability to stay at shortstop long-term. He has really good hands and first-step quickness to go along with enough arm to stick at the premium position. The right-handed hitter has a solid approach at the plate with very good bat-to-ball skills that yield a lot of contact. He should be able to hit for average at the next level, though the power he has shown is a bit of a hitter-friendly environment and conference mirage.A bit undersized, PERSON doesn't have loud tools but can do a little bit of everything on the field. But as someone who receives high marks for work ethic and leadership skills to go along with his defensive chops and contact skills, he could be an overachiever who surprises in the pro ranks.

The ORGANIZATION took catchers with their first two picks in 2018, signing PERSON for $2,815,900 in the first round and PERSON for an over-slot $1,497,500 in the second. The consensus top junior college prospect in the Draft after spurning the ORGANIZATION as a 36th-rounder in 2017, PERSON hit 37 homers in two seasons at ORGANIZATION (GPE) CC. He played through an elbow issue this spring that prevented him from catching for a month and limited him to four innings on the mound, where he has been clocked up to 100 mph.PERSON has an aggressive right-handed swing that generates uncommon bat speed and well above-average raw power. While his max-effort approach didn't result in excessive strikeouts at the juco level, his lack of patience could be exploited in pro ball. He did prove that his pop can play with wood bats and against better competition by ranking fifth in the ORGANIZATION with six homers last summer.PERSON left scouts skeptical that he could catch when they saw him as a freshman, but he cleaned up his defense this spring and now projects as at least an adequate receiver. Though his cannon arm is an asset, he needs to improve the accuracy of his throws. While he can dazzle radar guns, his violent delivery makes it unlikely he would hold up as a full-time pitcher.

The ORGANIZATION used their first two 2018 Draft picks on catchers with different profiles in 2018, a polished athlete (PERSON) in the first round and a raw slugger (PERSON) in the second. The consensus top junior college prospect after turning down the ORGANIZATION as a 36th-rounder in 2017, he slammed 37 homers in two seasons at ORGANIZATION (GPE) CC. He also reached 100 mph with his fastball as a reliever for the ORGANIZATION, though elbow issues limited him to four innings and prevented him for catching for a month as a sophomore.Extremely aggressive at the plate, PERSON has well above-average bat speed, strength and raw power. While his approach has yet to result in excessive strikeouts, pro pitchers exploited it and held him homerless and to a lot of weak contact in his 30-game debut last summer. He had shown that his pop will play with wood bats and against better competition when he ranked fifth in the ORGANIZATION with six homers in 2017.Though PERSON improved significantly behind the plate from his freshman year to his sophomore year at ORGANIZATION, he still requires more polish to become a dependable receiver. Despite his pure arm strength, he threw out just nine percent of basestealers in his first taste of pro ball and won't be able to control the running game until he improves his throwing accuracy. Pitching is less of a fallback than it might seem because he has a violent delivery that would make it difficult to keep him healthy.

PERSON batted .343/.455/.577 with 33 homers in three season at ORGANIZATION, driving the ORGANIZATION to a pair of PERSON Series appearances and winning Big 12 Conference award for freshman of the year in 2017 and co-player of the year in 2019. ORGANIZATIONrmally a third baseman, he moved to shortstop in the second half of his junior season and sparked PERSON to its best finish ever (tied for third at the ORGANIZATION). The second first-round pick in school history, he signed with the ORGANIZATION for $4.4 million as the ORGANIZATION. 8 overall choice.One of the best all-around hitters in the 2019 Draft, PERSON has a controlled approach and a sound right-handed stroke. He routinely barrels balls to all fields, doesn't sell out for power and has the bat speed and strength to produce 25 or more homers per season. He controls the strike zone and has no holes in his offensive game.Though PERSON is a below-average runner, he has enough athleticism and instincts to make plays at third base. He won't play shortstop in pro ball but upgraded the ORGANIZATION defensively when he moved there. He has reliable hands and more than enough arm strength for the hot corner.

A two-way standout in high school, PERSON garnered PERSON player of the year honors as a senior and was one of the more impressive all-around athletes available in the 2016 Draft. The ORGANIZATION liked him more as a hitter and selected him with the 13th overall pick, then lured him away from a ORGANIZATION State commitment with a $2.6 million bonus. He overcame a sluggish start in his full-season debut the next year and ultimately finished on a high note, hitting .296/.350/.415 with 24 extra-base hits and 14 steals over his final 72 games. The performance led to high expectations for PERSON's 2018 campaign, though he was unable to build upon that progress in the ORGANIZATION State League, where his feel to hit backed up and resulted in below-average production. PERSON's athleticism and physical tools suggest he'll eventually make an impact at the plate, but right now he's still figuring out what type of hitter he is. He knows how to create leverage through the hitting zone and has added some loft since signing, though, so far, it hasn't yet translated to any uptick in usable power. But even as he's scuffled at the plate, PERSON has worked to improve his approach and become more selective. That progress was evident in 2018, as he trimmed his strikeout rate by nearly 3 percent from the previous year while simultaneously improving his walk rate from 8.3 to 10.3 percent. It gives him a solid foundation for further offensive development, and club officials are still bullish about PERSON's potential to hit for average and power. After struggling at third base during his pro debut, PERSON was shifted to center field and immediately proved a natural, covering huge amounts of ground with his plus speed and long, graceful strides. He's developed into the best defensive outfielder in the system and looks like a lock to stick in center field, where his offensive profile offers the most value.

After starting at third base as a freshman on PERSON's 2017 College World Series runners-up, PERSON was supposed to take over at shortstop but a stress reaction in a lumbar vertebra limited him to just six games as a sophomore. He returned in 2019 and showed he was completely healthy by leading the ORGANIZATION in all three slash categories (.346/.433/.533) and in stolen bases (20). He signed with the ORGANIZATION for $976,700 as a second-round pick.PERSON isn't flashy but does a lot of things well. He makes consistent contact from the left side of the plate, using the entire field and managing the strike zone. He has solid raw power and drives the ball enough to hit 15 or more homers on an annual basis, and he also has solid to plus speed and knows how to use it on the bases.PERSON's instincts also are apparent on defense, giving him a chance to stay at shortstop even if many scouts project him as a second baseman in the Majors. He provides steady glovework at shortstop with reliable hands and enough arm to make the necessary throws. He may not have a true plus tool, but he has no obvious holes in his game and should become at least a utilityman.

PERSON entered 2018 as a candidate to go in the early rounds of the ORGANIZATION, but his stock dipped early in his junior season at ORGANIZATION when he let the pressure get to him and his swing got out of whack. He recovered to go on a tear as the ORGANIZATION approached, hitting his way into the second round and a $1.1 million bonus from the ORGANIZATION. After his steady pro debut, PERSON swapped him to the ORGANIZATION in January for second-base prospect PERSON, who had just been acquired from the ORGANIZATION along with a 2019 Competitive Balance A ORGANIZATION pick in exchange for PERSON and left-handed pitching prospect Reiver Sanmartin.PERSON took off once he smoothed out his right-handed stroke and took a more direct path to the ball. He's at his best when he tries to hit line drives to all fields, and while he isn't a power hitter, he has enough pop to produce 12-15 homers per year as a pro. PERSON has an extremely patient approach and a knack for stealing bases.Scouts give PERSON solid-to-plus grades for his speed, yet there's mixed opinion on whether he can stick in center field at the next level. With his big and athletic body, along with his projectable frame and tools, it's easy to see why PERSON ranked as ORGANIZATION's No. 9 prospect for the 2017-18 international signing period. PERSON bounced between the starting rotation and bullpen during his three years at ORGANIZATION and spent most of his junior year pitching in relief. PERSON has rapidly blossomed in the role, pitching well in the Class A Advanced PERSON to begin his first full season before moving up to Double-A in mid-July.PERSON doesn't have the type of power stuff that his 6-foot-5 frame might suggest, but he knows how to be effective with his three-pitch mix and masks everything he throws with natural deception. A talented two-way player as a high schooler in GPE -- one many teams preferred as a left-handed pitcher -- PERSON's athleticism and offensive upside appealed to the ORGANIZATION, who drafted him in the third round of the 2016 Draft and went over pick value to sign him. Though he had a low-90s fastball and a promising slider, intriguing several clubs as a left-handed pitching prospect, the ORGANIZATION liked his multitool ability more. PERSON drew interest from clubs as both an outfielder and a left-handed pitcher in the 2016 Draft. PERSON made PERSON's weekend rotation as a freshman, became its No. 1 starter as a sophomore and bolstered his reputation with strong summers in the ORGANIZATION and with PERSON. After cracking PERSON's rotation as a freshman, becoming its No. 1 starter as a sophomore and starring in the ORGANIZATION and with the GPE national team, PERSON positioned himself as a likely first-round pick entering 2018. PERSON batted just .243/.332/.392 as a part-timer in his first two years at GPE, then made a surprising leap into the first round of the 2019 Draft. ORGANIZATION was an offensive force during his two years at ORGANIZATION CC (PERSON, GPE), batting .398/.471/.569 with 50 extra-base hits, 150 runs and 83 steals over 113 games while leading the ORGANIZATION to their first ORGANIZATION appearance in nearly 20 years in 2018. Those qualities, along with his explosive swing, give PERSON a chance to be at least an average hitter. He isn't big, but there is power there, and his swing reminds some of PERSON's. ORGANIZATION committed to PERSON as a high school junior even though the ORGANIZATION had two premium catching prospects, PERSON and PERSON, in the recruiting class ahead of him. The ORGANIZATION love to go aggressively after high school pitching and they did that with PERSON in 2016, taking him in the second round of that June's PERSON and then going over slot to sign him for $2.5 million. A talented two-way player in high school who contended for the national high school lead in home runs this past spring, PERSON was even more impressive as a pitcher, putting him into first-round consideration in the 2016 Draft. The ORGANIZATION like pushing their young high school arms to full-season ball the season after they are drafted, and they've done so with positive results of late.
