His breaking ball regained some of its shape, showing some good downer action with tight spin, and his changeup showed glimpses of depth. When he's right, he uses his 6-foot-6 frame very well on the mound.Not every pitcher can follow the same exact development path, and PERSON may greatly benefit from not being pushed too aggressively. His move to full-season ball will be a good test to see how far he's come.

A tremendous athlete and two-way player during his high school career in GPE, PERSON was the ORGANIZATION of the Year in 2016. He parlayed his strong senior season into being the 44th overall pick of the ORGANIZATION, in the second round, and received an above pick-value bonus of $2.5 million to sign rather than head to the ORGANIZATION of GPE to both pitch and hit.As a pro, PERSON's future is undoubtedly on the mound, though he's already shown an eagerness to swing the bat whenever he's given the chance. PERSON pitched sparingly during his debut, but he was effective even though his velocity was down a bit from the low-90s-to-95 mph spike he showed in high school. PERSON uses his 6-foot-6 frame extremely well, throwing downhill and with sink. He also has good deception in his very repeatable delivery, so hitters do not square him up very often. His secondary stuff is inconsistent right now, but he does flash a plus breaking ball at times and has a good feel for a changeup with fade and tumble. Given his size, stuff, feel for pitching and athleticism, not to mention that he's focusing on pitching for the first time, PERSON brings a lot of upside to the table. Watching him, PERSON and PERSON develop together could be a whole lot of fun.

PERSON put himself on the map for 2019 as a Stanford sophomore the previous year by finishing second on the team in homers, slugging percentage and ORGANIZATION. He raised his profile even more by showing he could put up similar numbers with wood bats, finishing fifth in the ORGANIZATION in batting average and tied for fourth in home runs. He didn't quite replicate that success during his junior season, but was coming on a bit stronger to climb out of his early-season funk before the ORGANIZATION took him with the ORGANIZATION. 71 overall pick in the June Draft. PERSON' power is legitimate, with the ability to drive the ball to all fields with good bat speed, and he showed enough ability to make contact to hit .326 in the Cape over the summer. There is length in his left-handed swing, however, leading to some swing and miss issues at times, including 34 strikeouts in 34 Cape League games. A solid athlete who runs well enough, PERSON has largely stuck to the outfield corners in college, though he did some time in center field as a junior. He may continue to receive reps up the middle in pro ball, though most see left field as his likely long-term home.Power is always a hot commodity, especially from a college left-handed hitter, and the ORGANIZATION are hopeful that PERSON' will translate in the professional ranks. He has the raw offensive tools, including plus bat speed and leveraged swing, needed to profile at an outfield corner at the highest level.

There's an assumption that a pitcher who stands nearly seven feet tall is going to be a flame-thrower, a la PERSON. PERSON, who got an over-slot bonus of $225,000 to sign out of the ORGANIZATION, GPE, high school ranks as a 22nd-rounder in 2016, bucks conventional wisdom by thriving thanks to his feel for pitching, not his pure stuff. PERSON inflammation limited him to just under 60 total innings in what was supposed to be his full-season debut in 2018, and he made just four outings in 2019 before needing PERSON surgery.PERSON uses his long levers and his outstanding command to allow him to succeed despite not having eye-popping stuff. Velocity-wise, his fastball is below-average, thrown in the 86-91 mph range, but it's on the plate when he releases it, he throws it with excellent life to elicit ground-ball outs and commands it well, all of which makes it play up. He mixes in an average breaking ball and changeup as well, though he needs to continue to work on the consistency of his secondary stuff.As PERSON continues to add strength to his enormous frame, there is the chance he could add a few ticks to his fastball. But it's really going to be his height, life, deception, command and feel to pitch that will carry him up the organizational ladder.

From a town known as PERSON, GPE, rode a pitcher with potential for a three-pitch mix. His age, and his size, made the PERSON roll the dice, taking PERSON in the 22nd round of the 2016 Draft and go over pick value to sign him away from attending PERSON. He pitched well in his brief summer debut and then pitched exceptionally well in the ORGANIZATION York-Penn League in 2017. He was having similar success with the move to full-season ball in 2018, though he was shelved with elbow inflammation.PERSON is a 6-foot-10 southpaw, but unlike with many pitchers that big, and that young, he has tremendous control of his body. That allows him to repeat a good, solid delivery and fill the strike zone with all three of his pitches. His fastball sits average velocity-wise right now, but it plays up because of his extension and his ability to command it, and it's easy to see more in the tank. He throws what will be at least an average slider and he shows some feel for a changeup, though that's behind his other two offerings. It's been a small sample size so far, but in his first 92 professional innings, PERSON has walked just 1.7 per nine.The PERSON knew it would be a longer process of getting the tall, lanky high schooler up to speed, and to his credit, PERSON has been very committed to the program, spending extra time in Clearwater working on gaining strength and his pitching craft. He could take a nice step forward in 2018.

The best athlete in the 2015 Draft, PERSON drew first-round interest from several clubs but opted out of the process because he was also the nation's top-rated dual threat quarterback prospect and wanted to play football and baseball at PERSON A&M. Despite playing regularly as a freshman for the ORGANIZATION, he opted to transfer to GPE, where he had to sit out 2016 before backing up PERSON winner PERSON last fall. After looking overmatched at the plate in his return to baseball with the ORGANIZATION and in the ORGANIZATION, PERSON made drastic improvements as a redshirt sophomore, posting an .954 OPS with 10 homers and 10 steals. Targeting PERSON's tremendous upside, the A's selected him with the ORGANIZATION. 9 pick in June and then signed him for $4,660,000, under the condition that he'd be allowed to play football in the fall of 2018 before transitioning to baseball full time.PERSON's gains were obvious during his breakout spring as he made better contact, showed better aptitude for recognizing spin and did a better job of controlling the strike zone. He has the plus-plus speed to create havoc on the bases and the bat speed and strength to produce average power. The son of former PERSON A&M quarterback and ORGANIZATION farmhand PERSON and the nephew of two-time first-rounder and five-year big leaguer PERSON, PERSON still needs to reduce his strikeouts further and is a work in progress defensively. He's still learning reads and routes but has the quickness to outrun his mistakes and eventually could become at least a solid center fielder. His arm has regressed on the diamond and currently plays below average.Oakland's decision to allow PERSON to play football in the fall comes with obvious risk, as any injury suffered on the gridiron likely would further delay the start of PERSON's baseball career. If he can stay healthy, PERSON, with his tools and the surprising progress he has made on the diamond, could one day provide the A's with a huge return on their investment.

GPE was one of the youngest players in the 2019 ORGANIZATION class, one who doesn't turn 18 until November. Combine that with an all-around tools package that rivaled that of nearly all the shortstop prospects in the class, and it's no surprise the ORGANIZATION, who have made no secrets about aggressively pursuing top-level athletes in the ORGANIZATION, took him in the second round of the ORGANIZATION and gave him a bonus slightly over pick value ($1.4 million) to sign him away from his commitment to GPE has a sound right-handed swing and employs a line-drive, all-fields approach. He's not very physical right now but has some quickness to his bat and deceptive strength that could develop into 12-15 home run power. He'll flash some plus run times and is aggressive on the bases.GPE shows smooth actions and soft hands at shortstop. He has a solid arm and good instincts that enable him to make plays. If he doesn't provide enough offense to make it as a regular, he has the athleticism and tools to play a variety of positions in a utility role.

When the ORGANIZATION signed PERSON out of GPE in Nov. 2014, he was a scrawny 5-foot-8 lefty who tipped the scales at about 165 pounds. The southpaw with an excellent feel for pitching is now 5-foot-11 and around 180 pounds, and that physical maturity has translated to his performance on the mound, though he spent time on the disabled list in 2017 with a forearm strain.Held back in GPE Spring Training until last June to monitor his workload, PERSON' strong performance at age 19 in the ORGANIZATION was one of the pleasant surprises in the ORGANIZATION' system and enabled him to jump up to the ORGANIZATION State League in 2017. He has average stuff across the board, starting with a fastball that now sits 90-91 mph. His changeup is a tick above average and his breaking ball should give him a third Major League average offering. All of it plays up because of his outstanding command and an understanding of how to mix his pitches to keep hitters off-balance.PERSON isn't going to blow anyone away with his stuff, but there are plenty of lefties in the big leagues who fit a similar profile. Just 20 for all of 2017, his feel for pitching could let him move a little more quickly, with the end result being a back-end starter at the highest level.

The Twins are no strangers to scouting for talent in GPE. There was PERSON back in 1997, PERSON in 2002, PERSON in 2007 and, more recently, left-handed pitching prospect PERSON. PERSON came on the GPE-to-Twins system pipeline in August 2014 and had a very strong GPE debut in the ORGANIZATION in 2015. He didn't pitch competitively in 2016 until late June, but when he did so, he went straight to the full-season ORGANIZATION, where he competed very well as a 19-year-old lefty starter.Small and wiry, PERSON doesn't look like much on the mound but he's shown a combination of pitchability and command that are intriguing. He's also seen an uptick on his stuff. PERSON was throwing in the mid-80s during extended spring training a year ago, but had a close-to-average fastball by the end of the year. There could be more in the tank if he can add some strength. His changeup is ahead of his curveball right now, a more reliable weapon, but both should be at least PERSON average. He throws strikes with all three pitches and his delivery comes with a good amount of deception.Just 5-foot-8, PERSON' ceiling might be somewhat limited, but if it all clicks he could be a crafty lefty who fits nicely into the back of a big league rotation.

PERSON wasn't a big name in scouting circles leading up to the 2017 Draft, but he still intrigued enough with this tools and remaining projection to earn a selection in the fifth round by the ORGANIZATION. A two-way player at FACILITY (GPE) High, he signed for slot value, passing on a commitment to ORGANIZATION Community College.PERSON shows a quick bat with present raw power from the right side of the plate, though there is some length to his swing that leads evaluators to question the future utility of his hit tool. In the outfield, he has the speed and range to stick up the middle, while the well above-average arm he showcased on the mound as a prep would also make him a clean fit in right.The ORGANIZATION have had success in the past with drafting and developing raw, high-ceiling outfielders, with PERSON and PERSON serving as current examples. PERSON will need time to refine his game in the Minors, but the ORGANIZATION are hopeful he can follow a similar path.

Another in a line of GPE pitchers to come out of the GPE, PERSON was compared to 2015 ORGANIZATION first-round pick PERSON. He wasn't quite as advanced as the ORGANIZATION prospect was coming out of high school, but he showed enough during the spring to land in the second round, where the ORGANIZATION signed him for more than $400,000 below pick value.The 6-foot-4 right-hander has the makings of a solid three-pitch mix. He can touch 94 mph with his fastball and sits comfortably around 92 mph, throwing it with good sink and without a ton of effort. His 78-80 mph curveball is an average breaking ball now and he has a good feel for his 79-81 mph changeup. He's around the zone with all three offerings and he's a decent athlete, so he should continue to repeat his delivery well. There is some drop and drive in his mechanics at times, but nothing that can't be corrected. PERSON's room to add strength combined with coming from a colder climate add up to a good amount of projection. It may take some time, but with patience he could end up being better than many of the high school arms taken in front of him.

PERSON endeared himself to international scouts with his across-the-board tools and his athletic projectable body and ranked as the ORGANIZATION. 14 prospect on ORGANIZATION's list of the Top 30 International Prospects for the 2017-18 signing period. PERSON made the then-16-year-old GPE outfielder its top priority, inking him with a $1.8 million bonus on July 2. He showed a high-risk/high-reward profile during his pro debut, hitting for power but also striking out at a high rate in the ORGANIZATION before heading stateside and finishing in the ORGANIZATION. The switch-hitting PERSON has an aggressive approach from both sides of the plate that he will need to tone down in order to make consistent contact at higher levels. He's a superior hitter as a left-handed hitter and slashed .282/.328/.491 from that side in his pro debut, compared to .150/.227/.150 as a righty. PERSON generally think he has a chance to hit for power, at least from the left side of the plate, as he develops physically. An average-or-better runner, PERSON shows raw speed on the bases and could eventually become a basestealer.On defense, PERSON has the speed and instincts to play center field, but like most prospects his age, he will have to work on improving his routes and angles to fly balls. The belief is that he has the potential to become an above-average defender, and there's hope that he will develop more arm strength once his body matures.

No. 14 on MLBPipeline.com's Top 30 ORGANIZATION list for the 2017-18 signing period, PERSON endeared himself to international scouts with his across-the-board tools and his athletic projectable body. PERSON made the 16-year-old outfielder their top priority and inked him with a $1.8 million bonus on July 2.On defense, PERSON has the speed and instincts to play center field, but like most prospects his age, he will have to work on improving his routes and angles to fly balls. The belief is that he has the potential to become an above-average defender, and there's hope that he will develop more arm strength once his body matures.Offensively, the switch-hitting PERSON has a good approach at the plate and likes to drive the ball into the gaps. He has a chance to hit for average and power from both sides of the plate as he develops physically, but he is considered a better left-handed hitter at the moment. Known as a speedy runner, the hope is that PERSON will be able to use his raw speed on the bases and eventually become a basestealer.

No. 14 on ORGANIZATION's Top 30 ORGANIZATION list for the 2017-18 signing period, PERSON endeared himself to international scouts with his across-the-board tools and his athletic projectable body. PERSON made the 16-year-old outfielder its top priority and inked him with a $1.8 million bonus on July 2.The switch-hitting PERSON has a good approach at the plate and likes to drive the ball into the gaps. He has a chance to hit for average and power from both sides of the plate as he develops physically, but he is considered a better left-handed hitter at the moment. Known as a speedy runner, the hope is that PERSON will be able to use his raw speed on the bases and eventually become a basestealer.On defense, PERSON has the speed and instincts to play center field, but like most prospects his age, he will have to work on improving his routes and angles to fly balls. The belief is that he has the potential to become an above-average defender, and there's hope that he will develop more arm strength once his body matures.

One of the more high-profile GPE players to hit the market in recent years, PERSON was declared a free agent on Jan. 11 and was expected to make a decision on where he was going to sign on Feb. 10. However, things took a turn when his agency, Culture 39, refused to represent him after allegedly receiving a death threat. After seeking out new representation, the 17-year-old outfielder signed with GPE for $3 million at the start of the 2016-17 international period. Ranked No. 4 on MLB.com's list of the Top 30 international prospects, PERSON is a dynamic talent who stands out for his power, speed and overall athleticism. Though his bat speed is undeniable, his uppercut bat path through the zone, as well as a few holes in his approach, will need to be ironed out in the professional ranks. He's capable of playing either center or right field, with the necessary athleticism and arm strength for either position. On defense, PERSON likely will be given every chance to prove he can stick in center field, though some scouts already wonder whether he fits better at a corner outfield spot given his overall skill set.

PERSON was one of the top international prospects according to ORGANIZATION in 2016 and the A's liked him enough to go over the spending threshold, incurring penalties when he signed with the A's for $3 million. He had a solid pro debut making his way to the GPE and the rookie-level ORGANIZATION in 2017, then showed glimpses of his tools during a full-season debut that was interrupted by injury.PERSON has the chance to have four at-least average tools at the ORGANIZATION level. He has plus bat speed that makes it easy to project the ability to hit for average with potentially plus power down the road. He's not afraid to see pitches and draw walks, though he needs to continue to refine his overall approach and pitch recognition in order to cut down his strikeout rate, which was 33.8 percent in 2018. While he does have excellent speed, he is expected to slow down some as he matures. He's largely played left field, likely his long-term home given his fringy arm strength. That puts pressure on him to be a corner outfield type bat, but he has the potential to easily fit that profile.

One of the more high-profile GPE players to hit the market in recent years, PERSON was declared a free agent on Jan. 11 and was expected to make a decision on where he was going to sign on Feb. 10. However, things took a turn when his agency, Culture 39, refused to represent him after allegedly receiving a death threat. After seeking out new representation, the 17-year-old outfielder signed with GPE for $3 million at the start of the 2016-17 international period. He made his professional debut in 2017 in the ORGANIZATION, where he appeared in just six games before heading stateside for the ORGANIZATION League.Ranked No. 4 on MLB.com's list of the Top 30 international prospects, PERSON is a dynamic talent who stands out for his power, speed and overall athleticism, with the combination giving him the potential for average-or-better tools across the board. Though his bat speed is undeniable, his uppercut bat path through the zone, as well as a few holes in his approach, will need to be ironed out in the professional ranks. PERSON is capable of playing either center or right field, with the necessary athleticism and arm strength for either position. He likely will be given every chance to prove he can stick in center field, though some scouts already wonder whether he fits better at a corner outfield spot given his current size and remaining room for physical growth.

Ranked No. 4 on MLB.com's list of the Top 30 international prospects, PERSON was expected to sign in February 2017 until his agency, Culture 39, refused to represent him after allegedly receiving a death threat. After finding new representation, the then-17-year-old GPE outfielder signed with GPE for $3 million at the start of the 2016-17 international period. He made his professional debut the next year in the ORGANIZATION, where he appeared in just six games before heading stateside for an impressive showing in the Rookie-level PERSON League.PERSON stands out for his hitting ability, raw power, speed and overall athleticism, the combination of which gives him the potential for four average-or-better tools. His bat speed is explosive and fuels his projection as an average hitter with above-average power, though his bat path through the zone, as well as his approach and overall plate discipline, will need to be ironed out.PERSON is expected to lose some of his speed and athleticism as he continues to grow into his already physically strong and mature frame. He's best-suited long term for left field, where his below-average arm strength is a clean fit. That doesn't leave much room for defensive flexibility, but PERSON has the offensive upside to easily offset those concerns.

GPE state has produced some quality high school arms in recent years, most notably PERSON, the ORGANIZATION. 3 overall pick in 2016, and PERSON, a second-round pick back in 2014. After a standout career at ORGANIZATION, PERSON is set to follow in the footsteps of the two right-handers after the ORGANIZATION's commit signed with the GPE for $1.35 million as the ORGANIZATION. 41 overall pick in the 2018 Draft. PERSON put his name more firmly on the national radar with strong showings at ORGANIZATION, the ORGANIZATION of PERSON and by pitching in the ORGANIZATION All-American Classic Game. He cemented his spot by coming out of the gate and showing similar arm strength this spring. The right-hander will sit around 93 mph right now and can touch 96-97 mph, and it's easy to dream on more velocity consistently in the future, especially given he's just 17 years old. PERSON has a slider that could be a future plus pitch, though he doesn't always show it now, dominating his competition with his fastball. He'll also fiddle with a changeup in the bullpen that has some arm side fade, but he doesn't use it in games.Like with many young pitchers, PERSON is more control over command right now, but he tends to throw strikes. He has the ingredients to remain a starter in the professional ranks, especially if he can make progress in developing a quality changeup, though there are some evaluators who peg PERSON as a future reliever.

PERSON wasn't a big name at the start of the showcase circuit in 2017 but that changed when he repeatedly pitched in the low 90s all summer leading into his high school senior season. He continued to bring the heat last spring and worked his way into the supplemental first round, where he signed for a below-slot $1.35 million. He surprised the Indians by proving to be more advanced than they expected during his brief pro debut, especially considering he was one of the youngest players in the 2018 Draft.With a lightning-quick arm, PERSON effortlessly works at 92-95 mph and touches 98 with riding life on his fastball. His low-80s slider has the makings of a plus pitch with power and high spin rates. He didn't need an offspeed pitch as an amateur but shows some feel for a changeup with a bit of fade.PERSON' athleticism helps him repeat his delivery and find the strike zone, though his command isn't as sharp as his control. He's a bit undersized for a starter, so his ability to hold up under a pro workload was a concern even before he succumbed to PERSON surgery in May. ORGANIZATION officials love his maturity and intelligence, two more assets that help his chances of remaining in the rotation once he returns to health.

While PERSON has hogged most of the headlines from the FACILITY' 2016-17 international class, PERSON has developed into one of the system's best middle-infield prospects. Signed for $325,000 out of GPE in July 2016, he has a chance to develop average tools across the board. He has yet to break out offensively, however, in part because he has been one of the youngest regulars in his league in each of his three pro seasons.A right-handed hitter with fine hand-eye coordination, PERSON has been able to make consistent contact against more experienced pitching. With his ability to barrel that ball, combined with his strength and bat speed, he could develop 15- to 20-homer power. To reach his offensive potential, he'll need to adopt a more disciplined approach and drive more balls in the air.Because PERSON has average speed and figures to slow a bit as he matures physically, it has been assumed that he'll wind up at second or third base. But he may have a better chance to stick at shortstop than initially expected because his instincts help him make plays. His strong arm will fit anywhere in the infield, enhancing his utility profile if he doesn't hit enough to be an everyday player.

The ORGANIZATION outspent every other club by paying $8.4 million on bonuses during the 2013-14 international signing period, blowing past their pool allotment and getting barred from paying more than $250,000 for any player in 2014-15. They had no restrictions last year and were aggressive again, starting with a $2.1 million bonus for PERSON, one of the best all-around athletes in his international class.Like his cousin, former big leaguer PERSON, he stands out most for his speed. PERSON is more of a plus runner while PERSON was a burner, but the younger PERSON has the potential to do more damage at the plate. He's a switch-hitter with a good stroke from both sides of the plate and the potential to produce 15 or more homers per year once he matures physically.Signed as a 16-year-old from the ORGANIZATION, PERSON is both raw in many phases of the game and advanced for his age and background. He'll need to improve his pitch recognition and his center-field defense, and the ORGANIZATION are so confident that he'll do so that they brought him to the GPE during his pro debut in 2016. He also has a solid arm that will allow him to play all three outfield positions if needed.

One of the best athletes in the 2015 international class, PERSON signed for $2.1 million out of the ORGANIZATION. The cousin of former big league stolen-base champ PERSON, he spent the entire 2018 season in Class A Advanced and played in the ORGANIZATION All-Star PERSON as a 19-year-old. Advanced for his age, PERSON has perennially been one of the youngest regulars in his leagues, but he batted just .253/.315/.351 in his first three pro seasons.A switch-hitter, PERSON has been slightly more effective as a lefty but has a good swing from both sides of the plate. He has advanced bat-to-ball skills but needs to get stronger and more selective so he can make more quality contact. While he won't ever be a slugger, he has the bat speed and projectable frame to develop at least 15-homer power.PERSON' basestealing is also a work in progress, as he's still learning how to use his plus speed on the bases. He's already one of the best outfield defenders in the Minors, a no-doubt center fielder whose solid arm is better than most at the position. His game presently resembles that of PERSON, though the ORGANIZATION believe he'll develop at the plate and reach a higher offensive ceiling.

When the ORGANIZATION aren't hampered by penalties for overspending, they're as consistently aggressive as any club on the international market. They spent $2.1 million in July to secure the talents of PERSON, one of the best all-around athletes in the 2015 international class.A cousin of former big leaguer PERSON, he's a switch-hitter with a nice swing from both sides of the plate. Once he adds strength, he could develop the power to hit 15 or more homers on an annual basis. His best tool is his plus speed.As someone who signed as a 16-year-old out of the ORGANIZATION, PERSON is still raw in many phases of the game, such as pitch recognition and center-field defense. At the same time, he's advanced for his age and background. He should be able to remain in center, but if not his solid arm will play well in right field.

A cousin of former big leaguer PERSON, PERSON was one of the best athletes available on the 2015-16 international market. After signing for $2.1 million out of the ORGANIZATION, he had an impressive pro debut in 2016. He hit .385 in a short stint in the Rookie-level ORGANIZATION, ranked as the ORGANIZATION. 1 prospect in the Rookie-level PERSON and short-season GPE leagues, and established himself as the top position prospect in the ORGANIZATION system.Taveras is a legitimate five-tool center fielder. A switch-hitter with a good stroke from both sides of the plate, he understands the strike zone and already shows a feel for recognizing pitches. He has bat speed and makes consistent hard contact, so he could develop into a high average/high ORGANIZATION player with average power once he fills out.Taveras' plus speed makes him a basestealing threat, though he's still learning the nuances of that art. He's already a fine center fielder who makes good reads and easily chases down balls in the gaps. With his solid throwing arm, he's capable of playing anywhere in the outfield.

A cousin of former big league stolen-base champ PERSON, PERSON signed for $2.1 million out of the ORGANIZATION as one of the top athletes on the 2015-16 international amateur market. The ORGANIZATION brought him to the GPE at age 17 and have promoted him aggressively, making him the youngest regular in the short-season LOCATION during his 2016 debut, the third-youngest in the low Class A GPE ORGANIZATION last season and the second-youngest in the high Class A ORGANIZATION this year. While he hasn't posted huge numbers, he also hasn't been overmatched and his tools have been obvious.Taveras is a switch-hitter with a good swing from both sides of the plate -- the consensus is that he's better as a left-handed hitter -- and he already displays command of the strike zone and the ability to recognize pitches. Add in his plus speed and he should have little difficulty hitting for average. With his easy bat speed and projectable strength, he also could grow into at least average power once he matures physically.While Tavares still is learning how to translate his quickness into stolen bases, he already uses his speed well in center field. He gets good reads and jumps, allowing him to chase down balls from gap to gap. He also has solid arm strength that fits well at any of the three outfield spots, though he won't have to move from center.

PERSON was already well known for his exploits on the field as a GPE amateur when he signed with the ORGANIZATION for $825,000 in July 2017. He represented his country at the 12U World Cup in GPE in 2013, the ORGANIZATION 14U Championship in '15 and the ORGANIZATION 16U Championship the following year.PERSON is a sum-of-all parts player who stands out more for his all-around game than any specific tools. He makes consistent contact from the right side of the plate with a swing that's direct to the ball and fuels his middle-away approach. He has present pop to the gaps and could grow into some over-the-fence power, though it will never be a major part of his game.Defensively, PERSON, an average runner, is solid if unspectacular at shortstop, where he's an instinctual player who makes all the routine plays and is fundamentally sound. While not explosive in his actions, PERSON is athletic and earns praise from club officials for his intuitiveness and positioning.

PERSON made a name for himself as a GPE amateur with strong performances at the 12U World Cup in GPE in 2013, the ORGANIZATION 14U Championship in '15 and the ORGANIZATION 16U Championship the following year. The ORGANIZATION signed him for $825,000 in July 2017, then pushed him straight to the ORGANIZATION last year for his pro debut. At age 17, PERSON was nearly three years younger than the circuit's average player. He held his own, though, hitting .250 with a near equal number of strikeouts (17) and walks (16) over 37 games. PERSON is a sum-of-all-parts player who stands out more for his all-around game than any specific tools. He makes consistent contact from the right side of the plate, showing feel for hitting the ball back up the middle and the other way with a swing that's compact and direct to the ball. He'll never offer much, if anything, in the way of over-the-fence power, but PERSON should tally his share of doubles and triples once he gets stronger and finds the gaps more consistently.Defensively, PERSON, an average runner, is a solid defender at both middle-infield positions. He is praised for his instincts, is fundamentally sound and can make all the routine plays. While not explosive in his actions, PERSON is athletic and earns praise from club officials for his intuitiveness and positioning.

Some clubs considered GPE the most athletic prospect on the 2013 international amateur market, and his five-tool potential earned him a $1.4 million bonus out of the ORGANIZATION. The ORGANIZATION brought him straight to the GPE for his pro debut as a 16-year-old, and though his bat has yet to get going, scouts remain dazzled by his potential.GPE's quick right-handed bat and his projectable strength give him the potential for plus power. While he has yet to enjoy much success at the plate, he shows signs of pitch recognition and doesn't swing and miss excessively. Add in his plus speed, and he could be a 20-20 player once he matures physically and as a hitter.GPE's speed and well-above-average arm allow him to play any of the outfield positions. He's still learning how to make proper reads and routes but should be able to stay in center field. While he requires a lot of development, time is on his side because he'll play most of this season at age 18.

Few players can post a .528 OPS in their pro debut and still earn positive reviews from scouts, but few players can match GPE's raw tools. They were evident even as he struggled as the youngest batting qualifier in the Rookie-level Gulf Coast League in 2014, and they earned him a $1.4 million bonus when he signed out of the ORGANIZATION Republic the year before.Though GPE still has to make plenty of adjustments to handle pro-caliber pitching, time is very much on his side because he'll play most of the 2015 season at age 17. He has the bat speed and projectable strength to develop plus power. His right-handed swing isn't the smoothest, but he shows the makings of plate discipline and doesn't swing and miss wildly, so he could hit for average as well.While GPE already has started to fill out and has lost a step since signing, he still grades as a plus runner. His reads and routes need some work but he should be able to stay in center field and has a quality arm for the position.

Not one of the big, headline-grabbing international signings back in July 2014, PERSON began his ORGANIZATION career in 2015 with a fairly non-descript debut in the ORGANIZATION. He headed back there in 2016, but hit his way to the GPE that summer and managed to work his way up to the ORGANIZATION in 2017.An undersized middle infielder, PERSON has shown an ability to hit for average, with a line-drive approach and excellent plate discipline that belies his teenage years. He does lack strength and his ability to impact the ball could become an issue as he moves up the ladder if he can't add some to his 5-foot-11 frame. He does have solid speed, which helps him on both sides of the ball. He has the range and footwork for shortstop, though whether his arm has enough carry to stay there long-term remains to be seen.The ORGANIZATION did have PERSON move around quite a bit during the early part of his career, as he saw time at three infield positions and the outfield. A utilty role is a likely outcome, but he has been seeing more time at short the past two summers, which does positively impact his value.

There's a stereotype about young Latino players and the way they hit, that they are aggressive free-swingers who aren't familiar with plate discipline. PERSON, who signed with the ORGANIZATION out of GPE back in 2014, has flown in the face of that misconception, using an incredibly advanced approach at the plate to reach full-season ball as a teenager in 2017.PERSON has plus on-base skills that stand out especially given how young he is. He walked more than he struck out in 2017 and didn't lose his approach at all with the promotion to the ORGANIZATION and brings a career .420 on-base percentage with him into the 2017 season. A switch-hitter, PERSON is small, but isn't frail and is considered one of the stronger players, pound-for-pound, in the system, though power is never going to be a part of his game. His speed will be and he's already shown aptitude for being an efficient basestealer. With an above-average arm, good hands and plus instincts, PERSON can handle playing shortstop on a daily basis if needed.At age 20 for all of 2018, PERSON will still see a lot of time at the premium position, but will continue to work at other positions, partially because of the presence of players like PERSON, but also to improve his value via versatility. He could be a utility man when all is said and done, but if he settled in as an everyday middle infielder, no one would be surprised.

PERSON signed with the ORGANIZATION out of GPE for a modest $40,000 back in July 2014 and while he's moved slowly, he immediately stood out because of his advanced approach at the plate and unusual plate discipline. A very solid 2017 season that saw him reach full-season ball for the first time as a teenager had the organization excited for what might come next, but the middle infielder struggled to find his footing in a full ORGANIZATION season in 2018.One thing PERSON did not lose was his ability to see pitches and draw walks. In fact, he finished second in the ORGANIZATION with 84 free passes, but with that came a huge strikeout spike. Given his lack of power, a 25 percent K rate isn't going to fly, with the switch-hitter perhaps being too selective at the plate at times and not choosing good pitches to hit. While he doesn't lack strength, he didn't impact the ball as successfully as he had previously. He does have the speed to steal some bases, but wasn't particularly efficient on the basepaths in 2018.PERSON has split time between shortstop and second thus far in his career, though he saw more much more time on the left side of the infield in GPE. He has the arm, hands and instincts to stay there, but unless he steps forward with the bat, he's destined to a role as a defensive-minded utility man.

PERSON was emerging as a top high school prospect in GPE Virginia when he made the move to ORGANIZATION in GPE after his sophomore year. He took advantage of the opportunity, showing off premium arm strength against top competition. He also became good friends with shortstop PERSON, who he now gets to call a professional teammate after the D-backs took PERSON in the 11th round and PERSON in the eighth, giving the right-hander an above-pick-value bonus of $350,000 to sign.Right now, PERSON is all about a big fastball. He sat 92-93 mph consistently and was up to 95 mph at times this spring. His slider, which has 10-to-4 action with solid bite and depth, gives him a breaking ball that will be at least average. It can get slurvy at times, but he made strides with it this spring. He didn't use a changeup in high school games, though he has shown some feel for a fringy one in bullpen sessions. ORGANIZATION has been an issue at times for the big right-hander, with some feeling his high-tempo delivery and mindset point to a future in the bullpen. The D-backs didn't sign him to make him a reliever right away and he'll be given every chance to develop as a starter.

PERSON was emerging as a top high school prospect in GPE Virginia when he made the move to ORGANIZATION in GPE after his sophomore year. He took advantage of the opportunity, showing off premium arm strength against top competition. He also became good friends with shortstop PERSON, who he now gets to call a professional teammate after the D-backs took PERSON in the 11th round and PERSON in the eighth, giving the right-hander an above-pick-value bonus of $350,000 to sign. PERSON rarely sends its high school picks straight to full-season ball, but that's precisely what it did with PERSON, who responded to the challenge with an eye-opening showing in Class A Kane County's starting rotation. A 6-foot-4 right-hander with a pair of plus pitches and plenty of room for growth, PERSON has all the ingredients teams look for when projecting a future big league starter. He sits at 92-94 mph and bumps 95 mph with his fastball and has present feel for commanding it to both sides of the plate. His two-plane slider is a legitimate swing-and-miss offering that registers in the low-to-mid 80s with hard bite, and he's made strides in learning to command the pitch in his first full season. PERSON's changeup is a distant third pitch right now, but he throws it with splitter-like action that plays nicely off of his heater, and scouts expect it to be at least average once fully developed. PERSON's high-tempo delivery led to questions about his control and command profile and many evaluators pegged him as a future bullpen piece coming out of the GPE. But the big right-hander has already simplified his mechanics in pro ball by working exclusively from the stretch, and in turn he's already made gains with his command.

PERSON was ranked No. 10 on MLB.com's Top 30 international amateur prospects rankings prior to the 2013 signing period. The ORGANIZATION loved his offensive potential and signed him for $1.4 million on July 2 of that year.PERSON's ceiling lies completely with his bat. He has the kind of swing that could allow him to hit for a lot of power. He's shown some feel to hit with a solid approach as well, drawing walks during his ORGANIZATION debut in 2014, though he struggled a bit more during his first time in the GPE a year ago. Big and left-handed, PERSON reminds some of PERSON. Initially an outfielder as an amateur, he quickly moved to first base due to his well-below-average speed. He's a capable defender with a solid arm.If PERSON can watch his conditioning and continue to refine his approach, he could fit the profile of a run-producing first baseman in the future.

The ORGANIZATION signed PERSON out of the ORGANIZATION in 2013 for $1.4 million, then watched him struggle a bit during his pro debut in the ORGANIZATION in 2014 and again in the ORGANIZATION in 2015. Things really started to click in the GPE League in 2016 and he made a successful move to full-season ball that included a ORGANIZATION All Star nod in 2017. He didn't back that up with a strong performance in the ORGANIZATION State League in 2018 and a fractured right thumb sidelined him in late July. A return to the level in 2019 seems to have done wonders for PERSON, and he reached Double-A for the first time in June, then was sent to the ORGANIZATION in return for PERSON reliever PERSON and PERSON pitcher PERSON close to the ORGANIZATION Deadline.PERSON's value lies in his offensive potential from the left side of the plate. He had shown an ability to make consistent contact and drive the ball to all fields in the past, though lost his way in 2018. He rediscovered his stroke in 2019 and is starting to tap into his tremendous raw power, especially to the pull side, setting a career high in home runs. Even when PERSON struggled, he kept his strikeout rate low and never really tried to sell out for power. A below-average runner, PERSON will be a first baseman only and should be capable enough to not be a liability there.A return to a much more refined approach at the plate has helped PERSON get back on the prospect radar. Just 22 years old for all of 2019, there's still plenty of time for him to fit the profile of a run-producing first baseman.

The ORGANIZATION loved PERSON's offensive potential when he was an amateur coming out of the ORGANIZATION in 2013 so much that they gave him $1.4 million to sign. He scuffled a bit during his first two summers in the organization, but took a big step forward in the GPE League in 2016, finishing second in the Rookie-level circuit in both slugging percentage and OPS.PERSON is still far away from GPE, but it's easy to dream on his upside with the bat. He has tremendous raw power, as much as anyone in the system. And he's starting to show he's more than just an all-or-nothing home run hitter. He has the abilty to make solid contact, squares the ball up pretty consistently and can drive the ball to all fields, which should allow him to tap into that power in games even more consistently. While he's played some right field and has a solid enough arm for that, he will be confined to first base in the future. The good news is he's more than capable defensively there and his bat is looking like it should profile just fine.PERSON will have to continue to watch his conditioning so he doesn't become a DH-only type, but all signs are pointing in the right direction with a solid full-season debut in 2017.

The ORGANIZATION signed PERSON out of the ORGANIZATION in 2013 for $1.4 million, then watched him struggle a bit during his pro debut in the ORGANIZATION in 2014 and again in the ORGANIZATION in 2015. Things really started to click in the GPE League in 2016 and he made a successful move to full-season ball that included a ORGANIZATION All Star nod in 2017. He didn't back that up with a strong performance in the ORGANIZATION State League in 2018 and a fractured right thumb sidelined him in late July.PERSON's value lies in his offensive potential from the left side of the plate. Over the past two seasons, he's shown an ability to make consistent contact and drive the ball to all fields. He has tremendous raw power that he is still learning to tap into and it has been really encouraging that he has kept his strikeouts low and hasn't sold out to try to hit the ball over the fence. A below-average runner, PERSON will be a first baseman only and should be capable enough to not be a liability there.As long as PERSON continues to watch his conditioning and continues to refine his approach at the plate, he should fit the profile of a run-producing first baseman in the future. He'll play all of the 2018 season at age 21.

Signed for $475,000 out of the ORGANIZATION at the outset of the 2017 international signing period, PERSON made his pro debut the following year, beginning in the ORGANIZATION before shifting stateside and finishing the season as a 17-year-old in the ORGANIZATION. Challenged with an assignment to the ORGANIZATION in 2019, PERSON established himself as yet another promising, up-and-coming prospect in GPE's system, showing advanced hitting ability and a mature approach while also holding his own defensively at shortstop. PERSON has the chance to be a special hitter. He has an impactful swing from the right side of the plate, with plus bat speed that enables him to smash good velocity and make consistent barreled contact, and it's easy to envision him developing some game power as he adds strength to his projectable frame. He has an advanced approach for a teenager and already shows the ability to recognize spin and control the strike zone, with his plus speed that aids him on both sides of the ball.A pure shortstop in the eyes of the D-backs, PERSON has already made huge strides defensively and has the actions, hands and arm strength needed to stick at the position long term. While his remaining physical projection could lead to a move off of the position down the road, PERSON's bat could enable him to profile at a host of positions on the diamond. For now, though, he'll be given every opportunity to stick up the middle.

PERSON was part of the ORGANIZATION' 2016-17 signing period international haul, signing right on July 2 along with top international prospect PERSON, earning a $1 million bonus in the process. The ORGANIZATION shortstop made his pro debut in the ORGANIZATION and then was declared a free agent in the wake of GPE's international rules violations. The ORGANIZATION signed both GPE and PERSON once the window opened for them to do, giving PERSON $850,000 to join the organization.PERSON's carrying tools are on defense. With a live and lean athletic body, the middle infielder has outstanding instincts at short, with soft and steady hands and more than enough arm to stay at the premium position long-term. The teenager does have a solid approach at the plate, walking more than he struck out during his ORGANIZATION debut. He does make consistent contact with a line-drive approach, but at present, lacks the strength in his small frame to truly impact the baseball.Just 17, there is time for PERSON to develop physically, and patience will be important. Added strength could allow PERSON to reach his ceiling as an everyday shortstop at the big league level in the future.

PERSON GPE wasn't the only former ORGANIZATION shortstop prospect declared a free agent in the wake of the organization's international rules violations to then sign with the ORGANIZATION. ORGANIZATION, who initially signed with PERSON in July 2016 for $1 million out of GPE, received $850,000 in December to join GPE in GPE Angeles.ORGANIZATION made his pro debut in the GPE last summer, playing in the ORGANIZATION and while the slash line of .225/.332/.254 doesn't exactly jump off the page, there were some things to like with ORGANIZATION's first offensive foray into pro ball. The teenaged infielder showed a really advanced approach, especially that he was 17 years old at the time, walking more often than he struck out. He makes a lot of contact with a line-drive approach, but lacks current strength to do much more than put the ball in play. Believers feel he will be able to add to his frame, which will allow him to become a more impactful hitter. Defensively, ORGANIZATION has a strong arm and good hands, with the chance to be a plus defender at a premium position.Given his age and lack of physicality, it's clear ORGANIZATION has a long way to go before being a finished product. With time, patience and weight training, he could eventually develop into an everyday shortstop at the big league level.

PERSON ORGANIZATION might have been the marquee name the ORGANIZATION picked up from the pool of former ORGANIZATION prospects who became free agents when PERSON was penalized for international signing violations, but it would be wrong to sleep on Soto. The infielder, who initially signed for $1 million with PERSON in July 2016, got $850,000 in December 2017 to join the ORGANIZATION, then went out and surprised many with a very productive organizational debut in the Rookie-level ORGANIZATION.Soto showed an advanced approach at the plate, especially given his age, from the get-go in his pro debut with the ORGANIZATION in 2017. He rarely struck out and drew plenty of walks, but didn't have much to show for it production-wise because of a lack of strength. By the time he reached the ORGANIZATION with the ORGANIZATION, he had gotten much more physical, and while he's never going to be a home run hitter, the added strength allowed him to impact the ball more consistently to the point where some feel he could be an above-average hitter if he continues to commit to that part of his development.While he played on both sides of second base in 2018, there's no question he can handle shortstop with a strong arm and terrific hands. If the advancements with the bat are for real, he could be an everyday shortstop, with a pretty high floor thanks to his glove.

GPE school players taken in the 26th round of a Draft are easy to lose sight of. PERSON went that late back in the 2015 Draft out of the ORGANIZATION high school ranks and outside of his ridiculously low walk rates, wasn't really opening many eyes over the first two-plus years of his career. Back with PERSON in the Class A Advanced California League in 2019, some increased velocity has made some sit up and take notice of the undersized right-hander. PERSON thrives with plus plus command of a four-pitch mix. Velocity-wise, his fastball is average, though he's throwing harder than he has previously, in the 90-94 mph range. But it plays up thanks to his pinpoint control and good riding life. His changeup is below-average, but he plays it well off of his fastball with a little arm-side run and good late bottom to it. He manipulates his above-average slider in the zone and adds shape to it when expanding it late in counts. His curve doesn't have a ton of shape to it, but he can put it wherever he wants. He'll throw all four of his pitches at any point in the count to keep hitters guessing. PERSON's ceiling is limited given his stuff, but he pitches to his strengths and always sticks to his gameplan. At best, he could be a No. 5 starter, with more of a long or middle relief/swingman look to him. It will be interesting to see if his ability to pitch will allow him to have continued success as he moves up the ladder.

As a GPE high schooler, PERSON emerged as an early-round prospect for a handful of teams late in the 2016 Draft process. He ultimately turned down the ORGANIZATION as a 30th-rounder to attend ORGANIZATION, where his father PERSON had played en route to a big league career. Much like former ORGANIZATION star PERSON, an GPE first-rounder in 2018, PERSON has confounded evaluators with the dichotomy between his success with metal bats (.939 ORGANIZATION, 42 homers in two-plus years with the ORGANIZATION) and struggles with wood (.570 ORGANIZATION, three homers in two summers in the ORGANIZATION). The A's believed in his bat enough to take him in the first round and give him full pick value, $2,424,600, to sign.A switch-hitter, PERSON has had some timing issues at times at the plate and a swing that can get long, leading to strikeouts. His strength and leverage do generate plus raw power and there should be more in-game pop as he fills out his lanky 6-foot-3 frame. He runs well, producing plus run times occasionally, and can use his speed to steal bases and cover ground at shortstop. While he's a little tall for the position, his athleticism and strong arm should allow him to stay there long-term, and that's where he played exclusively during his pro debut in the short-season ORGANIZATION York-Penn League.If scouts had been convinced that PERSON was going to hit with wood, he probably would have been the first college shortstop taken in June's first round. His athleticism and offensive potential still made him the fifth one taken and if he can figure things out with his swing, he could be a dynamic up-the-middle player.

The two best draftees ever out of PERSON are currently carving up hitters in the big leagues. PERSON, whom the ORGANIZATION took in the middle of the first round after a slightly up-and-down junior season as he pitched through a bout of mono, hopes to be the next in line after PERSON and PERSON ORGANIZATION. The right-hander didn't pitch at all in his first summer as a pro after signing for full pick value.PERSON has a strong track record of using a solid four-pitch mix and throwing them all for strikes. He showed just what he's capable of when 100 percent healthy while winning PERSON of the Year honors as a sophomore, then being named a ORGANIZATION Cod League All-Star that summer. He sat in the mid-90s, touching 97 mph on the ORGANIZATION and then saw his velocity dip while he was sick, though it ticked back up closer to GPE time. He's gotten bigger and more physical this offseason, so don't be surprised to see some 70-grade fastballs in there in 2019. He can throw two distinct breaking balls, with the harder slider better than the curve, and can mix in an effective changeup as well.With a history of throwing strikes, PERSON could have plus control when all is said and done. He did something Kluber and ORGANIZATION didn't: get taken in the first round. Now it's time for him to get going towards catching them in the big leagues.

After a strong sophomore season at PERSON that included PERSON of the Year honors, PERSON turned in an All-Star showing in the ORGANIZATION over the summer. He started out his junior year without the same velocity he showed on the GPE, but his fastball ticked back up as the spring progressed and he performed well enough to be among the better college pitching options available, finishing with a 11-2 record, a 2.76 ORGANIZATION and an ORGANIZATION I-leading 163 strikeouts as part of a PERSON staff led all DI programs with a 2.66 ORGANIZATION. PERSON became the ORGANIZATION' first first-round pick in June, going to the ORGANIZATION 14th overall and then signing for slot value ($3,883,800). PERSON sat in the mid-90s and touched 97 mph over the summer, but he pitched more in the 91-92 mph range and touched 94 mph early on before creeping back toward the mid-90s late in the spring. At times his two breaking balls can blend together, but his slider is better than his slower, "get me over" curveball. PERSON's changeup might be his best pitch, though some scouts would like to see him use it more frequently. His arm and delivery works well and he throws strikes.The ORGANIZATION hope that PERSON -- the first pitcher PERSON has drafted in the first round since PERSON in 2011 -- will follow in the footsteps of former PERSON products PERSON (ORGANIZATION' fourth-rounder, '07) and PERSON ORGANIZATION (ORGANIZATION ninth-rounder, '10) and one day headline a big league rotation. Meanwhile, with his impressive four-pitch mix and track record of durability, PERSON could be one of the first hurlers from his class to reach the Majors.

PERSON replaced two-way star PERSON (the ORGANIZATION. 4 overall pick in the 2017 Draft) at first base for ORGANIZATION in 2018 and ranked third in ORGANIZATION Division I in walks in each of his seasons as a starter, drawing 63 as a sophomore and a school-record 72 last spring. He led the ORGANIZATION with 29 walks in 40 games during the summer in between, establishing himself as one of the most patient hitters and top first-base prospects in the 2019 Draft. The ORGANIZATION drafted him in the second round and signed him for a well-below-slot $997,500.PERSON's offensive game resembles that of ORGANIZATION, who has had more success as a pitcher in pro ball. He's a left-handed hitter with plus raw power who focuses more on making contact and getting on base. He has good feel for hitting, controls the strike zone and could develop 20-plus home run power if he adopts a more aggressive approach and starts driving more balls in the air.While PERSON has well-below-average speed, he's not a terrible athlete. He shows soft hands and a decent arm while getting the job done at first base. Some scouts who saw him as an amateur though he had a chance to play left field while others didn't think that was feasible.

The 2015 international amateur class was headlined by a group of GPE prospects who received seven figure bonuses to sign. PERSON, a GPE outfielder, was a little more under the radar, though he was the ORGANIZATION' biggest signing that period with a $450,000 bonus. His 2016 debut in the ORGANIZATION was somewhat pedestrian, but his combination of tools and feel for hitting during his GPE debut in the ORGANIZATION in 2017 opened many eyes. He didn't replicate that production with a jump to full-season ball in 2018.PERSON has shown an advanced feel for the strike zone and ability to barrel up the baseball that belies his age. The teenager walked more than he struck out in the ORGANIZATION and showed an ability to drive the ball to all fields. While he's not particularly big, his bat speed does help him generate more power than expected, with all of his over-the-fence pop coming to his pull side at present. He's at least a plus runner and should be a basestealing threat, especially as he learns more about reading pitchers. That speed also plays in center field, where he could be a plus defender long-term, with an above-average arm.It's easy to get excited about PERSON's tools and upside, but it's important to be patient and not pile too many expectations on him based on those projections. His advanced feel for the game may make it hard to pump the brakes as he could play his way up the organizational ladder.

Signed by the ORGANIZATION in July 2015 out of the ORGANIZATION for $450,000, GPE burst on the prospect scene with a very strong GPE debut in the ORGANIZATION in 2017, leaving everyone excited to see what he would do as an encore. The speedster did finish fourth in the organization with 30 steals in 2018, but did not respond well overall to an aggressive push to the full-season LOCATION League.GPE's kryptonite in 2018 was the offspeed pitch. He hits fastballs very well and feasted on them in the ORGANIZATION, but once he started getting a steadier diet of breaking balls and changeups, he often found himself diving and not seeing them come in because of head movement. He's working on fine-tuning his swing so he can stay centered and on his backside longer so he can recognize and respond to the soft stuff better. There is still confidence that the more he sees off-speed pitches, the more he'll learn to recognize it and get back to looking like the top-of-the-order catalyst he was in 2017. The rest of his game is still very good, from the speed to wreak havoc on the basepaths, to playing a very good defensive center field.GPE will be playing at age 20 for most of the 2019 season, so there's still plenty of time for him to figure things out. He did end the 2018 season on an upswing. If he can carry that over, in addition to the other adjustments he's working on, he can get back to reaching his potential as an every day sparkplug who plays up the middle.

A month before the ORGANIZATION spent $63 million in bonuses and penalties to sign PERSON, they found a bargain on the international market in PERSON. They signed him out of GPE for $35,000 in February 2015, and moved him to center field after he had worked out for clubs as a shortstop. He has transitioned to his new position well and led the Rookie-level Gulf Coast League in hits (62) and doubles (14) during his 2016 GPE debut.PERSON's signature tool is his well above average speed. He's still learning to make the most of his quickness on the bases but it already plays well in center field, where he shows advanced instincts. The solid arm strength that he displayed at shortstop is an asset in center.At the plate, PERSON displays impressive bat-to-ball skills. He won't ever have a lot of power, though he can sting some balls into the gaps and might hit 10-12 homers annually in his prime. He makes a lot of contact but could use some more patience at the plate to enhance his on-base ability and give him a chance to use his speed.

A month before the ORGANIZATION spent $63 million in bonuses and tax penalties to land PERSON, who became the centerpiece in the ORGANIZATION trade, they signed PERSON for a bargain $35,000 out of GPE in February 2015. After working out for clubs as a shortstop, he moved to center field and was named the organization's Latin GPE program player of the year in his first taste of pro ball. His GPE debut in 2016 also went well, as he led the Rookie-level Gulf Coast League in hits (62) and doubles (14).PERSON has a chance to have four solid or better tools, with his well above-average speed (which projects as plus once he's physically mature) standing out the most. While he's still refining his skills as a basestealer, his quickness already plays well in center field, where he shows advanced instincts. The solid arm strength he showed at shortstop is an asset in center and also will allow him to play either corner.PERSON has uncanny bat-to-ball skills for a teenager and could develop into a high-average hitter. While he makes easy contact, he could use more patience to improve his on-base ability and maximize the use of his speed. That will be important because he's not very physical and won't ever be a power hitter, though he can sting some balls into the gaps.

The ORGANIZATION had four Draft picks over the first two rounds of the 2015 Draft. The quartet of picks turned out to be a GPE Clemente High School sandwich, with PERSON going in the first round and his battery mate, PERSON, being the last of the four chosen. While PERSON has moved quickly, PERSON was slowed by a torn meniscus during his pro debut, then struggled to hit in the LOCATION in 2016. Known as a glove-first backstop, PERSON tore his meniscus during his pro debut in 2015 then struggled to hit during his first full season in the LOCATION, though he fared a bit better in his return to the level in 2016.There is no question about PERSON's catch-and-throw skills. He's very agile, blocks well, has great hands and a strong arm that plays up even more because of his quick release and accuracy. He's taken quickly to things like game-calling, having done some of it in high school, and has excellent leadership skills and an ability to work well with pitchers. PERSON has struggled to hit, but he has strong hands and raw power at the plate but needs to continue to refine his approach and plate discipline to get to it.PERSON doesn't have to hit a ton to move up the ladder and he's shown he works well with the young arms in the ORGANIZATION system. He will have to get the bat going a little in order to catch up with them.

The ORGANIZATION spent a lot of time at FACILITY in the spring before the 2015 Draft. PERSON was their first-round pick and they took his batterymate PERSON one round later. The catcher tore his meniscus in the third game of his pro debut and while he recovered enough to return at the end of the year, the ORGANIZATION decided to err on the side of caution.PERSON was one of the better defensive catchers in the 2015 Draft class, with excellent all-around skills behind the plate. He's very agile and has good hands, already has game-calling experience and gets high marks for his leadership ability. Arm-strength wise, he's a tick above average, but he is as accurate as there is behind the plate, and he could even get better with some corrections to some small mechanical issues. PERSON is far from a glove-only catcher. He has very strong hands and wrists with good power from the right side of the plate.The ORGANIZATION believe PERSON has the chance to be an everyday catcher who makes major offensive contributions. He could be part of the up-the-middle success the farm system provides, joining infielders ORGANIZATION and PERSON along with center fielder PERSON to create a solid cornerstone.

Known initially as the guy catching PERSON in high school. PERSON made a name for himself as one of the best defensive catchers in the class of 2015 before joining his batterymate in the ORGANIZATION organization.PERSON has all the skills necessary to excel behind the plate. He has excellent catch and throw skills to go along with the natural leadership teams covet in a catcher. He moves well behind the plate, with excellent hands and blocking skills. While he is definitely defensively-oriented, he's certainly not a zero with the bat. He takes a clean path to the ball with a simple setup, using his extremely strong hands and wrists to drive the ball at times. PERSON was the fourth catcher taken in the 2015 Draft and has the chance to be one of the better ones, with a profile of a solid glove-first regular with some pop.
