PERSON didn't hook up with a team at the outset of the 2014-15 international signing period, waiting seven months before the ORGANIZATION gave him a $90,000 bonus. The ORGANIZATION had shoulder surgery following his 2015 pro debut and missed all of the next season before showing flashes of a mid-90s fastball when he returned. When the ORGANIZATION needed roster space after signing PERSON in March 2018, they designated PERSON for assignment and traded him to ORGANIZATION for PERSON.PERSON's big arm stands out in a system filled with big arms, because he regularly operates at 94-98 mph and can reach 101 mph with his four-seam fastball. He keeps his velocity deep into his starts and can blow his heater by hitters up in the strike zone. He can also miss bats with a power curveball that has exceptional spin rates and has begun to work on a changeup that has a long ways to go.The fact that PERSON didn't reach full-season ball in his first four years as a pro testifies to how he's very much a work in progress. He has trouble keeping his delivery in sync and repeating his release point, which makes it difficult for him to harness his overpowering stuff. GPE will keep feeding him innings as a starter because he needs experience, but he may wind up as a dynamic late-inning reliever.

When he signed out of the ORGANIZATION, PERSON received far less acclaim than some of his fellow right-handers in the ORGANIZATION' 2014-15 international signing class, which included $800,000 bonus baby PERSON and current Top 100 Prospect PERSON. He had shoulder surgery after his pro debut and missed all of 2016, then returned to the mound and flashed a mid-90s fastball last summer. After the ORGANIZATION signed PERSON in March and made room for him by designating PERSON for assignment, they dealt PERSON to ORGANIZATION for PERSON.PERSON has continued to light up radar guns with his new organization, regularly working at 95-98 mph with his fastball and topping out at 101. He has shown the ability to maintain his velocity throughout his starts and get swings and misses with his heater up in the zone. He also eludes bats with his low-80s curveball, which features a high spin rate. He has begun work on adding a changeup to his arsenal.PERSON can overwhelm hitters with his fastball and curveball but he can't always harness them. He's athletic enough to repeat his delivery and doesn't throw with much effort, so there's hope that he can figure out control and command. If not, he still could become an electrifying reliever.

In a perfect world, every trade acquisition takes a step forward in development following the trade. That's what's happened with PERSON, who originally signed with the D-backs in October 2013 for $160,000. The right-hander joined the ORGANIZATION organization via the 2017 PERSON deal for PERSON. In his first full year with the ORGANIZATION, the ORGANIZATION hurler was a ORGANIZATION All-Star, earned a promotion up to the GPE, performed very well there and earned a spot on the 40-man roster.The 6-foot-3 right-hander saw his stuff tick upwards in 2018 and the results followed suit. His fastball is trending up, and he was sitting low-90s last year, touching 94 mph, throwing the pitch with sink to get ground-ball outs. He gets swings and misses with it and his above-average slider also misses bats, with the sharpening of his stuff leading to a higher strikeout rate. His changeup is developing and is behind the other two offerings.PERSON has always been a good strike-thrower, and he didn't lose that with the uptick in his stuff. The next step will be command within the zone so he doesn't get hit as much as he has, but even that was trending in the right direction. He could have a chance to start, but that fastball-slider combination could play well coming out of the bullpen.

The ORGANIZATION haven't had much success on the international market in recent years, but they hope their 2018 class could signal a change. PERSON ($2.6 million) and outfielder PERSON ($1.1 million) landed the largest bonuses and most of the hype, but PERSON also has plenty of promise. Signed for $725,000 out of GPE, he has destroyed Rookie-level ORGANIZATION pitching during his 2019 pro debut.PERSON' forte is making consistent line-drive contact from the right side of the plate. He has a sound approach but puts the barrel on the ball so easily that it may cut into his walk totals. Listed at 5-foot-11 and 160 pounds, he's not imposing yet he has deceptive strength and the bat speed to develop average power once he matures physically.PERSON earns solid to plus grades for his speed and has the aptitude to steal bases. He reads balls well in center field and his solid arm strength will play in right should he lose a step and have to move to a corner. He developed advanced instincts in all phases of the game while growing up in a family that includes several cousins in pro ball, most notably FACILITY outfielder PERSON and ORGANIZATION shortstop PERSON.

There may not be a prospect in baseball with a bigger gap between his ceiling and floor than PERSON. He first reached triple digits with his fastball shortly before he signed for $280,000 out of the ORGANIZATION in 2015, but he remains much more thrower than pitcher four years later. He logged a 6.25 ERA with 46 walks in 36 innings while repeating the Rookie-level GPE League last season.PERSON has electric arm speed that generates 95-100 mph fastballs with little effort, peaking at 102 with some cutting action. His high-spin curveball gives him a second plus-plus pitch at its best, combining power in the low 80s with sharp break. His low-90s changeup has splitter action and gives him a third weapon that can make hitters look silly. PERSON is athletic and has no glaring flaws in his delivery, helping his chances of developing at least the decent command he'll need to succeed. Some observers believe his strike-throwing issues are more mental than physical. He has the upside of a frontline starter with a more realistic expectation of becoming a difference-making reliever, and the ORGANIZATION will give him plenty of time to figure things out.

After spending more than $17 million during the 2014-15 international signing period, the ORGANIZATION were prohibited from spending more than $300,000 on any international prospects the next two years. That didn't stop them from landing an explosive arm in July 2015, when they inked GPE for $280,000 out of the ORGANIZATION. He began flashing a triple-digits fastball shortly before he signed and has done so more frequently since.GPE has an exceptionally quick arm that consistently generates 95-100 mph heat. Both of his secondary pitches have a chance to be plus pitches as well. He has advanced feel for spinning a power curveball and shows aptitude for using a changeup.As exciting as his stuff is, GPE is still just 18 and extremely raw. He's more thrower than pitcher at this point, and he's still in the early stages of figuring out how to harness his overpowering arsenal. Though he's not very physical and his control will need to improve significantly, GPE will develop him as a starter for now.

As a penalty for blowing well past their 2014-15 international bonus pool by shelling out $17 million in bonuses, the ORGANIZATION were limited to spending no more than $300,000 on any individual international prospect during the next two signing periods. They still remained active and may have found a bargain when they landed GPE for $280,000 out of the ORGANIZATION in July 2015. He began hitting 100 mph with his fastball shortly before he turned pro and now has the best pure stuff in the system.GPE isn't physically imposing but has an exceptionally quick arm that repeatedly delivers 95-100 mph fastballs that top out at 102 and feature some cutting action. Both of his secondary pitches have a chance to be at least plus pitches as well. He has a power curveball with a high spin rate and a 90-92 mph changeup with splitter action that can devastate hitters, especially if they're trying to sit on his heater.GPE is still young and extremely raw, so he'll need time to reach his lofty ceiling as a frontline starter. He's has yet to learn to tame his electric stuff, though GPE believes he can develop at least average control and command because his delivery doesn't feature much effort. The ORGANIZATION are loaded with quality pitching prospects, and he could be the most successful of them if he can add some polish.

PERSON PERSON wasn't the only promising outfielder whom the FACILITY landed in their 2016-17 international class. Signed for $428,000 out of the ORGANIZATION, PERSON is still a work in progress but offers intrigue as a potential prototypical right fielder. He made his GPE debut in 2018 but probably won't advance to full-season ball until next season.It's easy to dream on PERSON' power potential because he has a physical 6-foot-3 frame, a nice left-handed stroke and the ability to make consistent contact. He needs to refine his approach at the plate, however, because he swings at everything and often puts pitches into play that he'd be better off avoiding. He has the upside of a .260 hitter with 25 homers per season.Though he's a below-average runner who doesn't offer much on the bases, PERSON showed enough athleticism and instincts to get most of his playing time in center field during his first two pro seasons. He has shifted to right field in 2019 and has the plus arm strength for the position.

PERSON trained in the same Venezuelan program that produced GPE rotation stalwart PERSON, and the two right-handers had similar stuff and builds at the same stage of their careers. Signed for $375,000 in 2015, PERSON topped the Rookie-level PERSON in strikeout rate (12.2 per nine innings) in his GPE debut two years later. He was leading the short-season ORGANIZATION York-Penn League in whiff rate (11.4) last summer before he was promoted to low Class A at age 19 in August.PERSON's projectability appealed to GPE and he already has started to deliver on it, with his fastball increasing from the upper 80s when he signed to the mid 90s with a peak of 98 mph and quality sink in 2018. His advanced changeup is his best secondary offering and could develop into a second plus pitch. The GPE have encouraged him to throw his curveball more often and he also has a harder slider, both of which are solid at their best.Though he repeats his delivery better than most young, tall pitchers, PERSON has seen his control regress in 2019. In the past, he threw consistent strikes from a three-quarters arm slot that creates angle and movement. He has the upside of a No. 3 starter but will need to do a better job of locating his pitches to fulfill that potential.

Signed for $375,000 out of GPE at the outset of the 2015-16 international period, GPE made his professional debut the next year in the ORGANIZATION. He made the jump stateside to the Rookie-level PERSON in 2017 and opened eyes with his bat-missing ability, as GPE ranked among circuit leaders with 12.2 strikeouts-per-nine (first), a 28 percent strikeout rate (first) and 70 strikeouts (second). Promoted to Class A Short PERSON in 2018, GPE set a franchise record by striking out 12 batters in his third start of the season. PERSON of a 90-mph fastball when he signed, GPE now operates at 91-94 and routinely tops out at 96-97 mph. The fact that GPE gets good extension over his front side makes his heater play up and nets him whiffs inside the strike zone. He has good feel for a trio of secondary offerings, and each of them could grade as average-or-better offerings once fully developed. While some evaluators prefer his curveball to his slider, and others vice versa, they all agree that GPE's changeup could wind up being his best secondary pitch. Listed at 6-foot-4, 170 pounds, GPE is physically advanced for his age but still requires some projection, and some scouts expect him to add even more velocity as he adds strength to his frame. The GPE will bring the teenage righty along slowly, but the final product could be that of a mid-rotation start if all clicks.

PERSON may not have come with the type of fanfare like the other players signed by the ORGANIZATION during their 2016-17 international spending spree, but the GPE right-hander could end up being the best of the bunch. After finishing his 2017 pro debut as a 17-year-old in the Rookie-level PERSON, PERSON made the jump straight to the Class A ORGANIZATION and dominated against older hitters before hitting his workload limit and being shut down for the season late in August.PERSON is both athletic and physically strong for his age, with present feel for throwing and locating four pitches. His quick right arm generates a fastball that's been up to 98 mph and usually sits in the low-to-mid-90s with late life thanks to his extension toward the plate. PERSON's power slider in the upper 80s is a swing-and-miss offering, and he also shows aptitude for executing an above-average curveball as well as a changeup that stands to improve as he gains experience. He's consistently around the zone and could have at least above-average command once fully developed.PERSON already shows durability and holds his velocity deep into starts. His delivery and arm action require further refinement like so many young, live-armed hurlers, but he has the requisite athleticism and physical tools needed to make the proper adjustments.

PERSON looks like yet another promising prospect to emerge from the ORGANIZATION' 2016-17 international spending spree. Signed out of GPE, PERSON made his pro debut in 2017 in the ORGANIZATION before advancing stateside and thriving in the Rookie-level PERSON at age 17. The ORGANIZATION deemed PERSON ready for full-season assignment in 2018, and he quickly rewarded the organization with stellar showing as an 18-year-old in the ORGANIZATION. PERSON is both athletic and physically strong for his age, with present feel for throwing and locating four pitches. His quick right arm generates a fastball that's been up to 98 mph and usually sits in the low- to mid-90s with late life thanks to his extension toward the plate. PERSON's curveball is a swing-and-miss offering that he throws with good depth and late, top-to-bottom bite, and he also shows aptitude for executing an improving changeup as well as a power slider that he throws in the upper 80s. PERSON already shows durability and will hold his velocity deep into starts. His delivery and arm action require further refinement, but he has the requisite athleticism to make the necessary adjustments.

The most touted GPE prospect since PERSON, PERSON joined his former national team teammate in the FACILITY organization when he signed for $26 million in GPE (the FACILITY also paid a matching overage tax penalty). That's the second-highest bonus ever given to an amateur, behind only the $31.5 million the ORGANIZATION paid PERSON two years earlier. PERSON has a long track record of success in international tournaments and GPE leagues, including batting .401/.526/.687 as an 18-year-old in GPE's PERSON in 2016.While they play different positions, PERSON has a lot of similarities to PERSON. A right-handed hitter, PERSON pairs electrifying bat speed that should translate into considerable power with well above-average speed. Both come with some swing-and-miss concerns, though PERSON's didn't really surface until he reached Double-A.Considered more of a solid runner when he defected, PERSON has gotten quicker and recorded sub-6.3 second times in the 60-yard dash. His lean 6-foot-3 frame figures to add more muscle, so he probably will slow down some once he matures physically. He has a chance to remain in center field and enough arm strength to easily handle right field should he move to a corner.

Five months after acquiring PERSON from the ORGANIZATION in the ORGANIZATION trade at the 2016 Winter Meetings, the FACILITY signed the outfield version. They paid a $26 million bonus -- the second-highest ever given to an amateur, behind PERSON's $31 million -- and a matching amount as a penalty for exceeding their bonus pool to land PERSON, a five-tool athlete who hit .401/.526/.687 as an 18-year-old in GPE's top league in 2016. He has performed well in pro ball when healthy, but he had minor knee and ankle injuries in 2017 and has missed much of this season after damaging ligaments in his left thumb.PERSON has the advantages of being a switch-hitter and an infielder, but otherwise PERSON is quite similar to him. A right-handed hitter, he has a lightning-fast bat with well above-average raw power and speed to match. He also comes with some swing-and-miss concerns, though he mitigates them somewhat with his willingness to take walks.Considered more of a solid runner while in GPE, PERSON got faster after defecting and posted sub-6.3 second 60-yard dashes while trying out for teams. His lean 6-foot-3 frame has plenty of room for additional muscle, so he'll probably slow down some as he matures physically. He could remain in center field and has the solid arm strength to profile in right field if he has to move to a corner.

â¢ 7/18: PERSON off to hot start in Triple-AShortly before new rules severely curtailed international bonus payments, the FACILITY signed PERSON for $26 million -- the second-highest ever for an amateur -- and a matching amount as a tax penalty in May 2017. They expected him to move quickly after he had batted .401/.526/.687 as an 18-year-old in GPE's top league in 2016, but his first two pro seasons were shortened by knee, ankle and thumb injuries. He finally began to showcase his exciting package of tools in the ORGANIZATION last offseason, a prelude to putting up monster numbers in 2019 while rising from PERSON to Triple-A.Though he's not a switch-hitter or an infielder, PERSON has a lot of similarities to PERSON, who set the amateur bonus record with $31 million from the ORGANIZATION before they sent him to GPE in the ORGANIZATION trade. He has electric bat speed, well above-average raw power and speed, and the upside of solid or better tools across the board. Also like PERSON, the right-handed hitter comes with some swing-and-miss concerns and will need to improve his plate discipline to realize his offensive potential.PERSON went from showing solid speed in GPE to clocking sub-6.3-second 60-yard dashes during the tryout process, and even if he loses a step as he matures physically, he could be a 30-30 player. He's still a bit raw with his reads and jumps in center field but he has the physical ability to become a solid defender up the middle with more experience. If he has to move to a corner, his strong arm and offensive profile will fit well in right field.

PERSON began boxing in the ORGANIZATION before he played baseball, leaving the sweet science behind when he signed for $200,000 in 2016. After two years in the Rookie-level ORGANIZATION, he came to the GPE in 2018 and ranked third in the Rookie-level GPE League in on-base percentage (.446) and fifth in batting (.348). When the ORGANIZATION determined they didn't have a role for J.D. PERSON on their big league roster, they sent him and infield prospect Cody Bohanek to GPE in a January trade for PERSON, outfielder PERSON and catcher PERSON Manea.PERSON has exceptional bat-to-ball skills, as evidenced by his .329 average with a mere 9 percent strikeout rate in his first three pro seasons, and he displays good patience and the ability to use the entire field. Despite standing 5-foot-8, he has a quick right-handed swing and deceptive strength that could translate into 12-15 homers per season if he can start driving more balls in the air. He tends to dive toward pitches, which means that a lot of his hard contact comes in the form of ground balls.An average runner who plays with lots of energy, PERSON has good instincts on the bases and in the field. He's a reliable if unspectacular defender at second base. He has seen some action at third base this year, though his below-average power and arm make it tough for him to profile there.

PERSON was eligible to sign out of the ORGANIZATION in 2015 but didn't land a contract until the following summer, when the ORGANIZATION gave him a $200,000 bonus. He made an impressive GPE debut in 2018, ranking third in the Rookie-level GPE League in on-base percentage (.446) and fifth in batting (.348). The ORGANIZATION acquired him in January, along with outfielder PERSON and catcher PERSON in exchange for J.D. PERSON and infielder PERSON Bohanek.Two things stand out with PERSON: his knack for contact and his high-energy play. His career has been brief, but he's always hit, with a quick swing and very few strikeouts. He might never be a huge power guy, but he is capable of driving the ball with more strength than you'd expect, and he already is showing a very advanced approach at the plate and a willingness to draw walks. He's an average runner who should be capable enough at second defensively.PERSON loves to compete and his makeup, when combined with his hit tool, gave the ORGANIZATION confidence to jump him over the ORGANIZATION up to the ORGANIZATION in 2018. That ability to swing the bat should carry him up the ladder, and if he can maintain that approach, a future as an everyday offensive-minded second baseman awaits.

Restricted to giving out no more than $300,000 in individual international bonuses in 2017, the ORGANIZATION paid the maximum amount to seven different prospects. The best of that group is ORGANIZATION, a Dominican who ranked third in the Rookie-level ORGANIZATION with 10 homers in his 2018 pro debut.Despite that slugging display, ORGANIZATION's hitting ability and approach may be better than his power. He shows good feel for the barrel from the left side of the plate and walked in 19 percent of his plate appearances in the ORGANIZATION. He has nice loft in his swing, drives the ball in the air and could have 20-homer pop once he adds more strength.Though ORGANIZATION is a below-average runner, PERSON believes he'll be able to remain at third base and may give him a chance to show what he can do at second base. His strong arm fits at the hot corner and his soft hands are another asset. He still makes youthful errors, no surprise because he'll be 18 all season, but should develop into an average defender.

PERSON was an intriguing two-way high school prospect heading into the 2015 Draft, one who asked ORGANIZATION teams not to take him because he was intent on heading to PERSON. After one year pitching and hitting, an arm strain led to him focusing on his offensive skills. While productive, he's also had a string of scary injuries: a hairline fracture and ligament/muscle damang in his left arm in 2017, then a broken fibula and torn ankle ligaments in his left leg this past spring. The ORGANIZATION liked PERSON's power potential enough to take him No. 75 overall, and he returned to health and reached full-season ball quickly during his pro debut.PERSON has tremendous strength and leverage thanks to his 6-foot-4, 265-pound frame. Coupled with good bat speed, he has legitimate power to all fields. Yes, there's length to PERSON's right-handed swing, but he displays solid control of his swing and walked more than he struck out during his ORGANIZATION career, rarely expanding the zone when he was pitched around.A solid athlete for his size, PERSON is nonetheless limited as a runner and defender. He does have a plus arm that once delivered low-90s fastballs, but he is decidedly a first baseman only. The good news is it's looking like PERSON's bat will profile just fine at the position.

PERSON was an intriguing two-way high school prospect heading into the 2015 Draft, one who asked ORGANIZATION teams not to take him because he was intent on heading to PERSON. After one year pitching and hitting, an arm strain led to him focusing on his offensive skills. While productive, he's also had a string of scary injuries: a hairline fracture and ligament/muscle damage in his left arm in 2017, then a broken fibula and torn ankle ligaments in his left leg as a junior last spring. The ORGANIZATION liked PERSON's power potential enough to take him No. 75 overall, and he returned to health and reached full-season ball quickly during his pro debut.PERSON has tremendous strength and leverage thanks to his 6-foot-4, 265-pound frame. Coupled with good bat speed, he has legitimate power to all fields and finished his three-year college career with a .347 average, 28 home runs and 129 RBIs. There is some length in PERSON's right-handed swing, but he has advanced barrel control and is comfortable hitting to all fields. His advanced approach led to more walks than strikeouts during his ORGANIZATION career, and he demonstrated patience and managed the zone well even when he was pitched around.A solid athlete for his size, PERSON is nonetheless limited as a runner and defender. He does have a plus arm that once delivered low-90s fastballs, but he is decidedly a first baseman only. The good news is it's looking like PERSON's bat will profile just fine at the position.

The Reds have been about as good as anyone using the bonus pool to their advantage. In 2018, like they did in 2016 with PERSON in the first round, they took a college bat in GPE India and signed him for below pick value. Those savings allowed the club to aggressively go after high school talent, including PERSON, the second rounder who signed for just under $2 million.The PERSON area prepster was primarily known as an outfielder before emerging on the mound in his senior year. The 6-foot-2 right-hander was up to 96-97 mph with his fastball at times, sitting comfortably in the 93-94 range. His breaking ball can be inconsistent; some scouts have seen two distinct pitches, others have seen them blurring into one slurvy offering. But he's shown enough glimpses of an above-average 78-83 mph breaker to think he'll get there consistently with more reps. He'll show a usable changeup in the bullpen but doesn't throw it much in games.PERSON's athleticism helps him on the mound and he should continue to repeat his delivery and find the strike zone consistently as he develops. Still learning how to pitch, there's a good amount of upside potential for him to tap into.

By signing first-round Draft selection PERSON at below slot value in 2018, there was some extra money that enabled the ORGANIZATION to aggressively go after high school talent with larger bonsuses. One of those who benefited was PERSON, who signed for just below $2 million in the second round.Converted from outfielder to pitcher during his senior year in the ORGANIZATION area of GPE, PERSON hit 97 mph with his fastball ahead of the 2018 Draft. But during his first pro exposure at Rookie-level GPE, the right-hander did not display his best velocity on his fastball or breaking ball and rarely threw his slider. After he was looked over by doctors and being diagnosed with a sore elbow, the organization used maximum caution to shut him down just ahead of season's end. When healthy, he's shown two distinct breaking balls, though they run together at times, and he has a feel for a changeup he'll need to start using more in games.With his athleticism and an ability to repeat his delivery, the ORGANIZATION like PERSON's upside well enough to still feel confident that he can find his way, though his first order of business will be to stay healthy.

GPE (N.C.) HS had a nice GPE run in the mid-1980s, with first-rounders and future big leaguers PERSON (1985) and PERSON (1986) plus third-rounder PERSON (1987). The ORGANIZATION's best prospect since then, PERSON posted video-game numbers as a junior, going 12-1 with a 0.08 ORGANIZATION and 174 strikeouts in 83 1/3 innings. He did the same thing as a senior, going 11-0 with a 0.19 ORGANIZATION and a 158-to-5 strikeout-to-walk ratio in 74 1/3 innings en route to being named the 2017 ORGANIZATION of the Year. Many scouts regarded PERSON as the top prospect in his class, and the ORGANIZATION were ecstatic to land the southpaw with a $6.7 million signing bonus after selecting him with the ORGANIZATION. 3 overall pick. After PERSON's fastball sat at 89-92 mph and reached 94 last summer, it jumped about 3 mph this spring. He maintained his newfound velocity into the late innings and continues to show feel for spotting his heater on both sides of the plate. His curveball has emerged as a true plus pitch and the best of his secondary offerings, which also include a hard slider and a tumbling changeup that also grade as plus at their best.Scouts love PERSON's athleticism and competitiveness. He employs a big leg kick and gets good extension in his delivery, creating a deceptive look that can throw hitters off. All in all, the young lefty has a legitimate front-of-the-rotation ceiling, and he could make a quick rise from the high school ranks to the Majors compared to his GPE class peers.

PERSON posted gaudy numbers as a GPE (N.C.) HS junior, going 12-1 with a 0.08 ORGANIZATION and 174 strikeouts in 83 1/3 innings, and then did the same thing as a senior, when he went 11-0 with a 0.19 ORGANIZATION and a 158-to-5 strikeout-to-walk ratio in 74 1/3 innings en route to being named the 2017 ORGANIZATION of the Year. As a result, many scouts viewed PERSON as the top prospect in his class, and the ORGANIZATION were ecstatic to land the southpaw for $6.7 million after selecting him with the ORGANIZATION. 3 overall pick. He rewarded them immediately, turning in a stellar professional debut in the Rookie-level PERSON, and then made a smooth transition to full-season ball in 2018 despite battling blister issues early in the year. An uptick in velocity during PERSON's senior year carried over into his pro debut, where he impressed evaluators with his feel for commanding a 92-95 mph fastball. His mid-70s curveball is a true plus pitch and nets him plenty of whiffs, while his low-80s hard slider and tumbling changeup could also grade as plus offerings at their best. Meanwhile, PERSON's entire arsenal plays up due to his big, athletic leg kick and because he gets good extension toward the plate, both of which help create a deceptive look for hitters on both sides of the plate.ORGANIZATION officials are quick to praise PERSON's competitiveness and overall aptitude on the mound, believing that those qualities, along with his potential for four above-average-or-better offerings, could make the young lefty a future front-of-the-rotation piece. Already on his way toward achieving that projection, PERSON stands to rise quickly through the Minors compared to his Draft-class peers.

As a GPE (N.C.) HS junior, PERSON went 12-1 with a 0.08 ORGANIZATION and 174 strikeouts in 83 1/3 innings. He somehow improved upon those results the next year, going 11-0 with a 0.19 ORGANIZATION and a 158-to-5 strikeout-to-walk ratio in 74 1/3 innings en route to 2017 ORGANIZATION of the Year honors. The ORGANIZATION viewed PERSON as the top prospect in his class and were ecstatic to land the southpaw with the ORGANIZATION. 3 overall pick, signing him for $6.7 million. Assigned to Class A Fort Wayne in 2018, PERSON was plagued by a blister issue on his throwing hand that twice landed him on the disabled list, and the ORGANIZATION decided to shut him down for the season in August after another flare-up.Though he pitched with slightly diminished stuff last season due to injury, PERSON still showed the makings of developing a front-of-the-rotation-caliber arsenal. His fastball sits at 93-95 mph and can touch 96, often playing above its velocity due to its late life. He has a pair of breaking balls in a mid-70s curve, a plus pitch and nets him plenty of whiffs, and a hard slider in the low 80s. The ORGANIZATION expect both offerings to be sharper as PERSON distances himself from the blister issue. He rounds out his arsenal with a tumbling changeup that has plus potential, and everything he throws plays up due to his big, athletic leg kick and because he gets good extension toward the plate, both of which help create a deceptive look for hitters on both sides of the plate.PERSON is lauded for his competitiveness and overall aptitude on the mound. Those qualities, along with his potential for four above-average-or-better offerings, could make the young lefty a future front-of-the-rotation piece. Already on his way toward achieving that projection, PERSON stands to rise quickly through the Minors compared to his Draft-class peers, as long as he stays healthy.

PERSON was known in international scouting circles because he was a standout in GPE's youth national leagues and one of the stars of the 2016 15U World Cup in GPE, where he posted the tournament's top batting average (.667) while leading GPE to a gold medal. Facing signing restrictions in '18 after spending heavily on international talent the year prior, the ORGANIZATION managed to sign PERSON for $300,000 in July 2018. Subsequently assigned to the ORGANIZATION, PERSON hit .415/.497/.774 with 13 home runs and 59 RBIs in 44 games to win the circuit's triple crown.PERSON is physically mature for his age, with a broad, thick frame that's loaded with strength. It helps him generate plus raw power that he should be able to get to in games because he's also an advanced hitter with a plus bat speed, feel for the barrel and a swing that stays in the zone for an extended period of time. He recognizes pitches and demonstrates an understanding of the strike zone, albeit with an aggressive approach. PERSON is more athletic than he appears and has the above-average arm strength needed for third base, but it might be a challenge for him to remain there on account of his below-average speed and fringe glove.Players who are physically strong tend to excel in the ORGANIZATION, and PERSON's impressive production there should be viewed in that context. ORGANIZATION stood out on the summer showcase circuit more with his feel for pitching than plus velocity. PERSON opened eyes with his bat as a GPE amateur, and many scouts viewed him arguably as the best overall hitter in the class. One of the most fundamentally sound shortstops available during the 2014-15 international signing period, GPE landed a $1 million bonus out of GPE. A reliable defender with soft hands and an accurate arm, he also has seen action at second base. A utility role could be a fallback, but he has the tools to profile as an everyday player.

PERSON looked up to PERSON growing up in the greater GSP area. Now the toolsy outfielder has the chance to be just like PERSON after the ORGANIZATION took him in the fourth round of the 2018 Draft but gave him first-round money ($2 million) to sign him away from his commitment from the ORGANIZATION of Virginia.PERSON played for, and won gold with, ORGANIZATION's 18-and-under team for two years, showing off his tools in international competition. The ORGANIZATION thought he could handle a challenge, skipping him over the rookie-level ORGANIZATION and sending him to the GPE League to begin his pro career.

In a 2017 Draft thin in catching prospects, PERSON stood out with his defensive brilliance and flashes of power. His stroke can get too long and uphill, however, leading to a 30 percent strikeout rate in his first taste of pro ball and questions about how consistently he'll produce at the plate. He has close to average speed now, but figures to slow down as he gets bigger and endures the rigors of catching.

The son of college coach PERSON, PERSON moved from the ORGANIZATION (ORGANIZATION, Ala.) to the ORGANIZATION (Miami) for his senior year after his dad changed jobs from PERSON to ORGANIZATION. He has a quick left-handed stroke and shows some aptitude for making adjustments and using the whole field. He has close to average speed but figures to lose a step as he matures physically.

PERSON headed into the 2017 PERSON ranked as the ORGANIZATION. 72 prospect by ORGANIZATION. In a class that lacked catching prospects, PERSON stood out, and the ORGANIZATION took him ORGANIZATION. 52 overall and gave him a bonus north of $2 million, well above pick value, to sign him away from playing for his father, GPE, the coach at ORGANIZATION. PERSON is very athletic, running better than most catchers, and uses that agility behind the plate. He is an excellent blocker and already shows an ability to work with pitchers to call a good game. His plus arm allowed him to throw out nearly 42 percent of potential base stealers in 2018.Developing high school catching is often a crapshoot, but PERSON, thanks to his all-around skills and having grown up around the game, has a chance to buck the trend, though he'll have to erase a rough 2019 season. PERSON there's time as he played all season at age 20.

Signed for $40,000 out of GPE in 2015, PERSON improved in each of his first two seasons in pro ball before moving up to full-season Class A Bowling Green and breaking out in 2018. PERSON's power does come with a heavy dose of swing-and-miss, which in turn raises concerns about his hitting ability, but scouts who saw him last season were impressed by his feel for the barrel and believe he'll make more contact as his pitch recognition improves. He's an average runner, perhaps a tick above, and moves well underway, though he's likely to lose a step or two as he continues to add strength. PERSON fits better in left field than right because his arm strength is only slightly above average. Evaluators believe he'll be an average defensive corner outfielder once he improves his reads and routes, though it's widely agreed that it will be PERSON's bat that dictates his development. PERSON PERSON (PERSON, Ga.) produced two of the better shortstops in the 2019 Draft in PERSON and his predecessor with the Screaming Eagles, PERSON. He has smooth actions, quick hands and feet plus the arm strength to make any throw from any angle. A contact-oriented switch-hitter whose swing is better from the right side, he offers little in the way of power. He knows how to use his well above-average speed on the bases and he understands his role is to get on base.

PERSON played at FACILITY (Fla.) High in 2016 before getting declared ineligible and moving back to GPE. He could deliver 30 or more homers annually from the right side of the plate, provided he makes enough contact. He's very raw at the plate with an aggressive, pull-heavy approach and struck out in 31 percent of his ORGANIZATION plate appearances.While his power is his most obvious tool, PERSON is far from a one-dimensional masher. He's a solid runner out of the batter's box and shows plus speed underway. He played all three outfield positions during his pro debut and should fit well in right field with his quickness and arm strength.

PERSON played at FACILITY (Fla.) High as a junior in 2016, then moved back to GPE after he was ruled ineligible. One of the few teams with a full-time area scout on the island (former big leaguer PERSON), the ORGANIZATION fell in love with his tools early and paid him an over-slot $400,000 bonus in the fifth round of the 2017 Draft. Overmatched in low Class A at the start of his first full pro season, he rebounded to finish fifth in the short-season LOCATION with 11 homers.PERSON has the most raw power in GPE's system, as well as some of the best bat speed, strength and all-around tools. He could pile up home runs by letting them come naturally, but instead he uses an overly aggressive and pull-happy approach. He struck out in 30 percent of his plate appearances during his first two seasons and he won't make enough contact to survive against more advanced pitching unless he makes some adjustments.While PERSON can show solid speed out of the batter's box and plus speed underway, he has already lost a half-step as he has begun to mature physically and likely will wind up as an average runner. He has played all three outfield spots in pro ball and needs to improve his jumps and reads. His prodigious power and his strong arm fit the right-field profile.

For however long PERSON plays baseball, he's going to have to answer questions about his size. Perhaps the best defensive player in the 2017 GPE, the A's put aside concerns about PERSON's strength at the plate and gave him a well-above-slot $2 million bonus in the third round of the GPE. His lack of offensive production has added to the worries about his profile, though he did show improvement in the second half of his first full year.PERSON certainly did struggle in the first half of 2018, hitting just .198 with a. .513 OPS in the ORGANIZATION before the All-Star break. In the second half, PERSON corrected a little drift in his swing and started impacting the baseball more, posting a .274 average and .679 OPS after the break. His walk rate went up and his strikeout rate dropped as his pitch recognition improved. He also stopped worrying about trying to lift or drive the ball, understanding that consistent contact and on-base skills, combined with his plus speed, are his ticket. There's never been any question that PERSON's glove will carry him to the big leagues. His arm is strong and accurate and he can throw from any angle to go along with his plus range and outstanding hands. A greater understanding of who he is offensively could help him become a defensive-oriented regular.

There might not have been a player in the 2017 Draft class more universally liked by area scouts than PERSON. But as a 5-foot-9 shortstop with a strong commitment to LOCATION, PERSON's signability posed as a deterrent for many teams. The A's, however, weren't one of them, as they drafted the GPE prep in the third round and then lured him away from his ORGANIZATION commitment with a $2 million bonus, more than double slot value ($697,500) for the ORGANIZATION. 81 overall pick. The one thing no one questions is PERSON's ability to stick at shortstop. He is a plus defender with outstanding range and more than enough arm to make throws from all over the diamond, making highlight reel plays with regularity, even on big stages like the ORGANIZATION Game All-American Classic. While PERSON will never hit for power, he has added some strength in his lower half and should be able to continue to do so as he matures, allowing him to shoot the ball to the gaps. He's a plus runner with outstanding instincts, so he can stretch singles to doubles and doubles to triples. PERSON does play his home games on turf, so some of his times might be a bit inflated, but no one doubts his skills play on any surface.PERSON endears himself to scouts even more with his outstanding makeup and baseball IQ. His supporters see a Jose Altuve type profile, albeit one with less power, but who can stay at short and impact games in a variety of ways.

After dazzling at shortstop during his prep career, PERSON was widely revered by scouts as one of the 2017 PERSON's premier defensive players. But with his slight build and perceived signability concerns, PERSON remained somewhat of a wild card when the PERSON finally arrived. The A's, undeterred in spite of those concerns, selected the GPE prep in the third round and then lured him away from his ORGANIZATION commitment with a $2 million bonus, more than double slot value ($697,500) for the ORGANIZATION. 81 overall pick. Assigned to the Rookie-level PERSON for his pro debut, PERSON continued to draw raves for his defense but also raised questions about his offensive upside.There is no doubt among scouts that PERSON can stick at shortstop. He's already a plus defender there as a teenager, with outstanding range that leads to many highlight-reel plays, and plus arm strength that allows him to make throws from all over the diamond. On the other side of the ball, the jury is still out regarding PERSON's upside with the bat. While he shows good feel to hit and bat-to-ball skills, PERSON desperately needs to add strength to his undersized frame in order to consistently impact the baseball. He's a plus runner with outstanding instincts, knows how to play small ball and is aggressive on the basepaths. PERSON endears himself to scouts even more with his outstanding makeup and baseball IQ. His supporters see a Jose Altuve-type profile, albeit one with at least two full grades less power who relies more on his glove than bat to impact games.

Though GPE spun six shutout innings to win the LOCATION Group 3 state title for GPE (N.J.) High last June, teams definitely coveted PERSON's State Player of the Year for his bat rather than his arm. He has a quick left-handed swing and plenty of strength, so he could develop 20-25 homer pop as he learns to turn on pitches more often. He doesn't sell out for home runs, however, employing a patient approach and utilizing the whole field.While most of GPE's value will come from his offense, he's a decent athlete. Though he projects as a fringy runner once he's physically mature, his keen instincts give him an outside chance to stay in center field. More likely, he'll move to an outfield corner. He has enough arm strength for right field.

GPE had a memorable 2018 senior season at ORGANIZATION (N.J.) High, throwing six shutout innings to win the LOCATION Group 3 state title and capturing PERSON state player of the year honors. Despite his heroics on the mound, teams were more interested in his potential at the plate. The ORGANIZATION signed him away from a GPE commitment for $1.25 million as a second-rounder, though his pro debut subsequently was delayed because he sustained a small fracture in his left wrist while taking a swing.GPE has the potential to produce solid batting averages with similar power, though he'll need some time to develop. He has a quick left-handed swing, employs a patient approach and uses the entire field. He focuses on making hard contact rather than worrying about home runs and should show more pop as he learns to turn on pitches more frequently.While he's a decent athlete, most of GPE's value will come from his bat. A center fielder in high school, he'll slide to a corner in pro ball. He has close to average speed and flashes solid arm strength, so he could wind up in right field.

The ORGANIZATION knew that patience would be key in developing PERSON after drafting him in the third round of the 2016 Draft. He was, after all, a raw high school arm from a cold weather state in ORGANIZATION. The big right-hander taken in the third round and signed away from his GPE commitment was delayed even further when he needed PERSON surgery and missed the entire 2017 season.The good news is PERSON is back throwing and returned to pitch in the rookie level PERSON in 2018. He also used his time rehabbing to trim down his 6-foot-6 frame. There's a lot of fastball to come from PERSON, assuming he bounces back to pre-surgery levels, as he was up to 95-96 mph at times with his heater. He also featured a power curve that flashed plus and a changeup that was behind since he didn't need it much in the ORGANIZATION high school ranks. ORGANIZATION was an issue for PERSON, as he struggled to repeat his delivery consistently.The ORGANIZATION are pleased with where PERSON is and are happy he's back on a mound competitively. It'll be slow going, especially at the start, but the payoff, given his size and chance for two plus pitches, could be big.

PERSON was the highest unsigned pick from the 2016 Draft after turning down the ORGANIZATION as the GPE. 41 overall pick out of high school. The lefty received full pick value ($5,432,400) and made his pro debut in the rookie-level PERSON League.PERSON usually works at 90-94 mph and peaks at 96 with sink on his fastball, using his 6-foot-6 frame to deliver it on a steep downhill plane. He showed inconsistent feel for spinning a curveball in the past and is focusing instead on a tighter slider in the low 80s that has become a solid offering. He also sells his changeup well and it has good action at the plate, giving him three pitches that all can grade as plus at their best.PERSON has a long, lean body that could add more strength and an easy delivery. He did a better job of maintaining his three-quarters arm slot as a junior, resulting in improved control and command. He also was pitching with more confidence, attacking hitters and realizing the potential Pittsburgh saw in him three years ago.

The Pacific-12 Conference player of the year as a sophomore in 2017, PERSON saw his chances of repeating end when he broke his left wrist early in his junior season. PERSON has the hands and actions to play shortstop, though his average arm makes him a better fit at second base. PERSON planned on trying him at short but he has spent almost all of his pro career at second, where he could develop into a ORGANIZATION.

The FACILITY made PERSON the second-highest second baseman ever drafted when they selected him fourth overall in June, two spots lower than the ORGANIZATION took PERSON in 2003.
