He had to settle for helping the ORGANIZATION win the ORGANIZATION World Series before signing for a $6,411,400 bonus. The best pure hitter in the 2018 GPE, PERSON barrels the ball and controls the strike zone with ease. A right-handed hitter with a line-drive swing, he doesn't have a lot of home run power but can sting the ball into the gaps. He's at least a plus runner with excellent instincts on the bases, and his offensive package fits nicely at the top of a batting order.PERSON played second base at FACILITY in deference to shortstop PERSON, an Orioles supplemental first-rounder who was the top defender in the GPE. PERSON has the hands and actions for shortstop, and the FACILITY plan on trying him there, but he doesn't have typical arm strength for the position. He could get by a la PERSON at short or develop into a ORGANIZATION Glover at second base.

The younger brother of GPE reliever PERSON, PERSON began his college career at FACILITY, then transferred to PERSON and re-entered the GPE. A 40th-round pick out of high school, he improved his GPE standing by 33 rounds, with a solid pro debut in the ORGANIZATION York-Penn League after the ORGANIZATION took him in the seventh round. He moved to full-season ball in 2018.PERSON has average tools across the board, with the chance to be better than that with the bat. He has an advanced approach from the left side of the plate, draws walks and shows the penchant for consistent line-drive contact. He may never be a big power guy, but there is some extra-base ability and he should run into a few homers along the way. Defensively, PERSON is steady, but many feel he won't stay at shortstop long-term, and he has seen some time at second base during his full-season debut in 2018. If it all comes together, he could be an offensive-minded second baseman, with the possibility of being a lefty-hitting-utility type also feasible.

If nothing else, the PERSON brothers know how to overachieve. Older brother PERSON was a 20th-round pick of the ORGANIZATION in 2015 and has spent the last two years pitching out of their big league bullpen. PERSON was a 40th-round pick out of high school in the same Draft as his brother and after a year at FACILITY, transferred to PERSON. A huge season there landed him in the seventh round of the 2017 Draft and he had a solid, albeit unspectacular, first full season in 2018 that included a GPE ORGANIZATION All-Star nod.PERSON has the chance to have four at least average tools. As a legitimate 6-foot-2 infielder, the easy thing to say is he won't be able to stay at shortstop long-term, but the PERSONlies haven't seen any reason why he can't, with his hands, arm, accuracy and footwork all working well from the premium position. He has a solid approach at the plate, with the ability to work counts, and while there isn't a ton of over-the-fence-power, he can drive the ball from the left side of the plate.If PERSON can continue to develop offensively and gets to be a Major League average hitter, he's at least a solid utility type in the big leagues, and he did play a few games at second in 2018. But there's enough upside here to think he could find a way to be a big league regular.

PERSON was generating some first-round Draft buzz last spring before a bout of elbow tendinitis caused him to struggle and miss time. He ended up falling to the second round, where he ORGANIZATION lured him away from a GPE commitment with $1.2 million bonus. After a promising pro debut in the Rookie-level PERSON, PERSON has built on that success this year in his full-season debut for Class A PERSON. PERSON can pitch to both sides of the plate with a low-90s fastball that peaks at 96, and he complements it with a sharp curveball that flashes above-average potential. The ORGANIZATION introduced a slider to his arsenal last season that could be an effective pitch in time, but right now it's in the nascent stages of development. PERSON also displays good feel for his changeup, which he throws with convincing arm speed and good fading action.While PERSON lacks ideal size as a 6-foot-1, 180-pound right-hander, his high three-quarters arm slot allows him create a good downhill angle to the plate, and he proved to be a ground-ball machine in his pro debut. He generates his velocity with athleticism and arm speed rather than effort and is consistently around the zone. Provided he stays healthy, PERSON has a chance to develop into a solid No. 4 starter in the ORGANIZATION.

The ORGANIZATION' first pick in the 2015 Draft, PERSON signed for $1.2 million as a second-rounder out of a GPE high school. He won high Class A GPE League pitcher of the year honors in 2017 before coming to the ORGANIZATION that December in the ORGANIZATION trade along with right-hander PERSON and infielder PERSON. In his first season in his new organization, he was PERSON's ORGANIZATION pitcher of the year and topped the Double-A LOCATION in wins (12) and innings pitched (152 2/3).More mature and poised than a typical 22-year-old, PERSON is the most polished pitcher in the organization. He's not flashy but his 92-95 mph fastball plays up because it has late movement and he commands it well. His plus changeup is his best pitch and his curveball flashes above-average potential.In terms of pure stuff, PERSON profiles as a back-of-the-rotation starter. But his advanced command of his entire repertoire could make him a No. 3 starter. He was on course to make his big league debut in 2019 before surgery on the meniscus in his right knee sidelined him for three months early in the season.

PERSON was pushing to go as high as the supplemental first round this spring. Then he came down with elbow tendinitis, which affected his stuff and sidelined him toward the end of the season, forcing him into the second round. That was the ORGANIZATION' first pick and they gave PERSON a slightly higher than pick value bonus of $1.2 million to sign.When he was fully healthy, PERSON was pitching at 92-94 mph and peaking at 96 with his lively fastball. He has an advanced changeup for a high schooler, maintaining his arm speed and imparting some fade when he throws it. He did a better job of spinning his curveball, though some scouts wonder if he might be better off throwing a slider. PERSON lacks ideal size at 6-foot-1 and 185 pounds, though he generates his velocity with athleticism and arm speed rather than effort. That, plus his ability to stay around the strike zone, gives him every chance to remain a starter.

The signing of free agent PERSON cost the Mariners a first-round pick in 2015, but the team still managed to find a first-round talent in the second round in PERSON. He signed for $1.2 million as the ORGANIZATION. 60 overall pick and then had an encouraging pro debut in the Rookie-level PERSON. PERSON excelled during his time in the ORGANIZATION, showing improved velocity as well as his usual advanced feel for a deep arsenal, both of which helped him reach Double-A at age 20 in 2017. That progress caught the eye of the ORGANIZATION, who acquired him, PERSON and PERSON in December for speedster PERSON's fastball sits in the low-90s and peaks at 94 with good life, and he's already proved adept at commanding the pitch within the strike zone. The right-hander made big strides with his changeup in 2016, throwing it with better arm speed and generating more fading action, and scouts believe it will develop into a plus pitch. His curveball is currently ahead of his low-80s slider in terms of effectiveness and consistency, but he did show better feel for the latter last season. He's consistently around the zone and efficient with all of his pitches.PERSON's high three-quarters arm slot allows him to create a good downhill angle to the plate, and he generates his velocity with athleticism and arm speed rather than effort. The undersized right-hander faces questions about his durability, but he has the arsenal and command profile to develop into a ORGANIZATION. 3 started in the ORGANIZATION.

The ORGANIZATION took PERSON with their first pick in the 2015 Draft, selecting the GPE prep hurler in the second round and signing him for $1.2 million. He impressed the next year during his full-season debut and then garnered PERSON pitcher of the year honors while reaching Double-A at age 20 in 2017. That progress caught the eye of the ORGANIZATION, who acquired him, PERSON and PERSON in December for speedster PERSON Gordon.PERSON may pitch with average velocity, topping out at 92-93 mph, but his fastball plays consistently above that grade due to its late movement. He's already adept at commanding the pitch, while his cross-body delivery allows it to jump on hitters on both sides of the plate. PERSON's changeup, a plus pitch, is his best secondary weapon and represents an ideal complement to his fastball, and he also has good feel for an average breaking ball.PERSON's high three-quarters arm slot allows him to create plane to the plate, and he has enough athleticism and arm speed to compensate for his hitchy delivery. PERSON may not have the high ceiling like some of GPE's other pitching prospects, but the stuff, pitchability and excellent command profile could help him carve out a role as a No. 4 starter.

GPE's 2018 Ohio state high school player of the year, GPE was one of the best two-way prospects in last year's Draft. Though he had a low-90s fastball and a hard slider, teams valued his offensive potential even more. His bat might have landed him if the top three rounds if his commitment to PERSON hadn't clouded his signability, and the ORGANIZATION signed him for a well over-slot $565,000 after he slid to the 11th round.GPE's bat speed, strength and the loft in his right-handed swing generate impressive raw power. After showing a polished approach as an amateur, he got overly aggressive and struck out in 29 percent of his plate appearances in his pro debut. He's most effective when he uses the whole field and doesn't try to do too much at the plate.Though he's a bottom-of-the-scale runner, GPE is a surprisingly effective defender at the hot corner. He has a better chance of becoming a solid third baseman than GPE's other young prospects at the position, PERSON and PERSON. He has soft hands and a strong arm but will need to keep his thick frame in shape and improve his agility.

One of the better high school two-way prospects in the 2018 Draft, GPE showed a low-90s fastball and a hard slider on the mound. PERSON's Ohio state player of the year, he had even more upside as a hitter, prompting the ORGANIZATION to pay him a $565,000 bonus in the 11th round. If not for signability concerns related to his ORGANIZATION commitment, he might have gone in the top three rounds.GPE creates impressive raw power with bat speed and loft in his right-handed swing, as well as with strength. More than just a slugger, he uses the entire field and lets his home runs come naturally, giving him solid hitting ability. He finished second in the home run derby at the ORGANIZATION All-American Classic last August and has a long track record of performing well against top competition on the showcase circuit.Though GPE has bottom-of-the-scale speed, he moves well enough to get the job done at third base. He has soft hands and a strong arm that could make him a solid defender if he can upgrade his agility. He'll have to work diligently to keep his thick frame in shape to stay at the hot corner.

PERSON won the 2011 Little League World Series with a walk-off single against GPE, defeated GPE again as a starting pitcher to help the GPE capture the 18-and-under World Cup in 2015 and starred for PERSON USA the following year as well. He entered 2017 as a legitimate two-way prospect before it became apparent that his future was brighter as perhaps the best pure high school hitter available. The ORGANIZATION selected him 14th overall and signed him for $3,450,000.PERSON draws some comparisons to PERSON and 2017 No. 4 overall pick PERSON as a lefty-swinging, hit-over-power first baseman with a mature approach and hitting instincts. He showed an improved ability to tap into his considerable raw power during the spring, driving the ball to all fields with a quick, pretty stroke. He has barreled balls so easily for so long that when he slumped toward the end of his senior season, most scouts shook it off because of his track record.In addition to his hitting prowess, PERSON is also a gifted defender at first base. He moves well around the base and has a stronger arm than most at his position. On the mound, he also resembled ORGANIZATION at the same stage of their careers with an upper-80s fastball, promising secondary offerings and advanced feel for pitching.

PERSON has a long history of starring in international play, hitting a walk-off single to beat GPE in the 2011 Little League World Series, defeating GPE as a starting pitcher to help the GPE win the 2015 18-and-under World Cup and starring again for PERSON to capture a gold medal at the 2016 18-and-under ORGANIZATION Championships. One of a number of legitimate two-way prospects in the 2017 Draft, he drew interest as a pitcher until it became clear that he might be the best pure prep hitter available. He joined PERSON as the only first basemen ever taken in the first round by the GPE, signing for $3,450,000 as the 14th overall selection.While PERSON slumped at the end of his high school senior season and had a so-so pro debut, that hasn't stopped scouts from comparing him to PERSON and PERSON (the ORGANIZATION. 4 overall pick in 2017). Like them, PERSON is a hit-over-power first baseman who bats left-handed and has a mature approach at the plate, though he has struggled while trying to do too much in his first full season. He owns a pretty swing with plenty of bat speed, has an affinity for using the entire field and is beginning to tap into his considerable raw power.PERSON is a better athlete than most first basemen. He's a potential ORGANIZATION Glover who moves well around the bag and has a stronger arm than most players at his position. On the mound, he was very similar to ORGANIZATION at the same stage of their careers, displaying an upper-80s fastball, promising secondary pitches and advanced feel.

As a high schooler, PERSON was a two-way star who attended PERSON, a program that has produced big league hitters like PERSON and PERSON. He was also a teammate of 2017 second-round pick PERSON, now with the ORGANIZATION, and a frequent member of ORGANIZATION national teams winning gold medals. As a senior, his bat jumped ahead of his arm and the ORGANIZATION took him in the middle of the first round to hit and he did just that in his first full year, finishing with 14 homers and 22 steals.While PERSON struggled out of the gate in the LOCATION, he showed just why he was considered one of the best high school bats in the 2017 Draft class with a .322/.394/.518 line in the second half. He dug an even deeper first-half hole in 2019, hitting .167/.262/.230 in the ORGANIZATION before slowly finding himself in the second half. He has shown a solid overall approach at the plate and can drive the ball to all fields, but there's been more swing and miss to his game than some anticipated, though that did improve in his strong finish to the 2018 season. He started tapping into his left-handed power more, with the chance to grow into even more as he matures and refines his approach. While PERSON has fringy speed, he might be the most instinctive baserunner in the system, allowing him to be aggressive on the basepaths. His athleticism also plays well at first with excellent defensive tools, including a plus arm that used to fire upper-80s fastballs from the mound. He has every chance to follow in GPE's footsteps as a homegrown first-round pick who plays first base every day in GPE.

PERSON was a solid high school prospect from GPE who was drafted by the ORGANIZATION in the 11th round back in 2016, but opted to head to the ORGANIZATION of GPE. He's developed into an intriguing corner infielder with pop and led the Pac-12 Conference with 77 RBIs, fifth most among ORGANIZATION Division I hitters, while batting .342 with 15 home runs and a .626 slugging percentage. Offensively, PERSON's raw power is his carrying tool. It shows up in games in flashes and he has the ability to hit the ball with authority the other way, to right-center field, but he gets pull happy at times. That leads to some swing and miss and streakiness, but if he can stay with his strengths, he could be an average hitter and tap into that power more consistently. A shortstop in high school, PERSON moved over to the hot corner in college and has become a plus defender there. While the one knock against him is his pure foot speed, he has good first-step quickness at third, with confident hands, a plus arm when he needs it and the ability to make plays on the run.PERSON plays with a confidence that scouts like and there's no question he can stay at third long-term. Some small adjustments at the plate could turn him into a very intriguing run-producer at the infield corner spot.

PERSON recorded 20 saves in his first two seasons at LOCATION and dealt in the ORGANIZATION last summer, then shifted to the rotation this spring. The move couldn't have gone much better, as he ended the college season leading ORGANIZATION Division I in both WHIP (0.71) and ORGANIZATION (1.06) while also ranking second in hits-per-nine (4.8) and fifth in strikeouts (144). The high spin rates on his pitches made him even more attractive to analytically-minded clubs, and the Indians were happy to land the right-hander for below slot at $750,000 after selecting him in the second round. PERSON may be a 5-foot-11 right-hander without overpowering stuff, but he makes up for it by mixing five pitches and three arm angles. He'll throw a four-seam fastball and a curveball from a nearly overhand slot and a two-seamer and a slider as a sidearmer, and he'll also work in a changeup and a lower-three-quarters angle. It all adds up to about a dozen combinations of pitches and slots, and he can hit 94 mph with nasty life on his fastball from down low.PERSON will have to tighten his slider at the next level, because pro hitters won't chase it as much as collegians do. He has the makings of a solid changeup too, and his feel for altering speeds and eye levels while pounding the strike zone gives him the opportunity to continue to succeed as a starter at the next level. His size will lead to durability questions -- he left one April start early and missed the next with shoulder stiffness -- although the Indians have had plenty of success with similarly-built hurlers in previous Drafts.

After starring as a closer for two seasons at LOCATION, PERSON moved to the rotation in 2018 and led ORGANIZATION Division I in both WHIP (0.71) and ORGANIZATION (1.06) while also ranking second in hits per nine innings (4.8) and fifth in strikeouts (144). The GPE pounced on him in the second round, signed him for a below-slot $750,000 and watched him dominate as a reliever at three levels before tiring in Double-A. They considered calling him up to the big leagues in September until he wore down late in the summer.PERSON overcomes being a 5-foot-11 right-hander without overpowering stuff by confounding hitters with a mix of five pitches from three different arm slots. His best offering is a two-seam fastball with unusual velocity (up to 95 mph) with nasty life from a sidearm angle. He also throws a sweeping slider from down low, a changeup from a low-three-quarters slot and a four-seamer and a curveball from a high-three-quarters slot.PERSON has tremendous feel for pitching, pounding the zone with all of his combinations of pitches and deliveries. He has an uncanny ability to throw hitters off balance by changing speeds and eye levels, and he was more effective against left-handers than right-handers in his pro debut. PERSON thought he could be a weapon as a multi-inning reliever by midseason, but he instead was shut down for the year with a forearm strain in early July.

PERSON helped lead GPE (GPEpolis) High to an GPE 4-A state championship in 2016 and took home the state's PERSON of the Year award as a senior in '18 after hitting .535 with 15 home runs. He became the first player in program history to be chosen in the Draft when the ORGANIZATION took him with the ORGANIZATION. 32 overall pick that June, and he signed for slightly above slot at $2.3 million to forgo his ORGANIZATION commitment. Assigned to the Rookie-level Gulf Coast League for his pro debut, PERSON homered in his first ever plate appearance but produced an overall line of .239/.378/.373 over 19 games. PERSON has a sound left-handed swing and uses the entire field. Though he has mostly gap power right now, he has the solid bat speed and wiry strength to develop average power once he fills out his extremely projectable frame. He currently has above-average speed, bordering on plus, but many evaluators believe he'll lose a step as he gets stronger.PERSON also offers a well-rounded defensive package. He has the speed and instincts to stick in center field and arm strength -- he showed a fastball that reached the low-90s in high school -- that's suitable for right now. He has a higher ceiling in center, as a move to a corner spot would come with greater offensive demands.

PERSON built another strong recruiting class around GPE high school outfielder PERSON, a first-rounder who probably won't make it to college, and the top five prep prospects in GPE. The best of that group is PERSON, who helped GPE (GPEpolis) to the GPE 4-A state championship in 2016 and became the first player ever drafted from the school when the ORGANIZATION took him with the ORGANIZATION. 32 overall pick and then signed him for slightly above slot at $2.3 million.PERSON has a sound left-handed swing and uses the entire field. Though he has mostly gap power right now, he has the solid bat speed and wiry strength to develop average power once he fills out his extremely projectable frame. He currently has plus speed but could lose a step as he gets stronger.PERSON offers a well-rounded defensive package as well. He has the quickness and instincts to stay in center field and the strong arm to also profile well in right. He also pitched as a high schooler, showing a fastball that reached the low 90s.

The ORGANIZATION got quick returns on their first-round investments in college hitters in 2013-15 with PERSON, PERSON and PERSON, and it appears they will again after going back to that demographic for the first time in three years. Since signing for $2,724,000 as the 24th overall pick in June, PERSON has lived up to his reputation as one of the best hitters in the 2018 Draft class. He has handled every challenge GPE has given him, including an ORGANIZATION assignment last offseason and a promotion to Double-A to start his first full season, slowed only by strained left elbow ligaments last summer and a hairline fracture of his left wrist after getting hit by a pitch this April.PERSON excels at putting the bat on the ball, thanks to his uncanny hand-eye coordination, compact right-handed swing and controlled approach. Though he hit just three homers in three years at ORGANIZATION, he has strong hands and has driven the ball in his short history with wood bats. He has the sneaky power to hit 15 homers per season, not to mention the patience to draw walks and the solid to plus speed to steal bases.Though he has the quickness and athleticism for shortstop, scouts are mixed on his ability to stay there. His instincts and reliability stand out more than his range or arm at shortstop, so he may be better suited for second base and has drawn comparisons to PERSON. His tools also should allow him to play the outfield if needed.

The ORGANIZATION hit on all three college bats they took in the first round from 2013-15 (PERSON, PERSON, PERSON) before not having a first-round pick in 2016 and spending two on pitchers in '17. They went back to that demographic again this June by spending the 24th overall choice on PERSON. Signed for $2,724,000, he posted a 1.021 OPS in 14 games before his pro debut ended when he strained ligaments in his left elbow diving for a ball.With outstanding hand-eye coordination and a controlled approach, PERSON excels at making line-drive contact from the right side of the plate. While he hit just three homers in three years at ORGANIZATION, he showed more power with wood bats in the ORGANIZATION and GPE believes his strong hands will translate into more power in pro ball. He also has the plus speed to steal bases and could fit atop a batting order if he draws a few more walks.Scouts are mixed on PERSON's defensive future. There are some who believe he can get the job done at shortstop, while others think his actions and his average arm are better suited for second base, where he played as a freshman in college. His quickness and athleticism also should give him the versatility to play the outfield if needed.

Over the course of his three years playing for PERSON, PERSON intrigued scouts by showing flashes of five playable tools. He really stood out in the ORGANIZATION in 2017, but when he didn't carry over that performance to his junior year, he ended up being available for the ORGANIZATION in the sixth round of the 2018 Draft, where he signed for full pick value. He looked much more like the ORGANIZATION version of himself during his pro debut, finishing in the top 10 in a host of categories and earning an All-Star nod in the rookie-level PERSON League.Primarily a shortstop in college, the ORGANIZATION immediately moved him to the outfield and liked what they saw there. He played most of the summer in right field, and has the arm for the spot, but he could have the speed and instincts to be a solid average defender in center field. That speed also helps him on the bases, and he broke out of the gate with 17 steals in his pro debut. Everything else went well for him during his debut, from managing the strike zone and drawing walks to toning down his overly aggressive approach in order to use all fields to hit for average and power. If you saw PERSON on the right day, you might put above-average grades on him across the board.The ORGANIZATION love PERSON's makeup and natural leadership ability. If he can show that his summer debut is for real, he could move up this list, and the ORGANIZATION' ladder, in a hurry.

One of the last players landed by the ORGANIZATION during the 2015-16 international signing period, PERSON turned pro for $10,000 out of GPE in June 2016. He posted a 2.39 ERA while averaging a strikeout per inning in his first three seasons, though he didn't make his full-season debut until 2019. He needed just six starts before earning a promotion to high Class A in mid-May.PERSON has been able to overmatch lower-level Minor Leaguers with his curveball, one of the best in GPE's system. Like most ORGANIZATION farmhands, he challenges hitters with four-seam fastballs up and curves down in the strike zone. He sits at 90-92 mph with his heater and employs a changeup with splitter action.PERSON has delivered strikes throughout his pro career. He can't blow the ball by hitters, so it remains to be seen how he'll fare against more advanced opponents who can do a better job of laying off his curveball. He profiles as a back-of-the-rotation starter or as a reliever who could rely heavily on his breaking ball.

The younger brother of GPE first-base prospect PERSON, PERSON has a similar offensive profile to his sibling, but with one difference in his overall game: his ability to catch. His combination of a power bat and power arm were on display over the summer and was watched carefully when the GPE high schoolers started playing this spring. Intrigued by his potential on both sides of the ball, the GPE kicked off their impressive 2018 Draft by nabbing PERSON with the ORGANIZATION. 29 overall pick and then signed him for $2,578,138, more than $245,000 above his slot's recommend value. PERSON's power was on full display at FACILITY in GPE as PERSON's All-Star PERSON commenced. On the Sunday morning before the ORGANIZATION his brother would play in, PERSON out-homered future PERSON first-rounder PERSON in the annual ORGANIZATION and got to take hacks in between rounds of the big league derby. In game action, he's shown an advanced feel to hit, giving him the chance to hit for average and power. His defensive game is a bit behind his bat, outside of his arm, which is a plus tool that helps control a running game. PERSON made strides in his defensive work during the spring, but he'll need to improve his overall receiving skills to show he can stick as a catcher. PERSON did play some third base during the ORGANIZATION Games and showed some agility there, and there's always the chance he could join his brother among the first base ranks. For now, however, the GPE will give PERSON every chance to stick behind the plate, where his bat offers the most upside.

The top college senior in the 2019 Draft, PERSON became the highest pick in PERSON history when the ORGANIZATION selected him in the fourth round and signed him for $100,000. He would have gone higher if he didn't have a two-year military commitment before he could pitch professionally, though President PERSON since has asked the ORGANIZATION of GPE to revise its policy and allow athletes to defer their service. PERSON led ORGANIZATION Division I in strikeout rate (15.4 per nine innings, the sixth-best rate in D-I history) and finished third in strikeouts (a school-record 161) in 2019 while setting PERSON career marks for wins (32), innings (334 1/3) and whiffs (428).PERSON's pure stuff is worthy of the first round, starting with a 92-96 mph fastball that can reach 98 and features some late life. He'll flash a wipeout slider at times and significantly improved his curveball as a senior to the point where there's debate as to which has more potential. He also displays some feel for a changeup though he hasn't had to use it much.PERSON's high-three-quarters effort delivery doesn't contain much effort, though he did battle the strike zone on occasion in college. He still has to prove himself against quality competition, but his upside is significant. He could be a steal, especially if he doesn't have to put his pro career on hold for two years.

PERSON was one of four shortstops in the top 10 of ORGANIZATION's Top 30 International prospects list at the start of the 2018-19 signing period. The ORGANIZATION liked his power-speed combination enough to give him $1.55 million to sign. The GPE teenager came to GPE in the fall to participate in the organization's high performance camp, rather than play in instructional league games, so he'll be making his professional debut in 2019.Two things stood out for the ORGANIZATION with PERSON from the get-go: his bat speed and his footspeed. He has work to do on his approach, nothing new given his age and experience level, but he's already been making an effort in that regard and will just have to start applying it as he begins his career in earnest. He should have the ability to hit for average and the leverage in his swing points to plenty of power as well. PERSON can really run too, with some seeing 80 run times on the 20-to-80 scouting scale. There are some good defensive tools to work with, though at first his actions weren't in sync, with his feet ahead of his hands. He's already shown more maturity in approaching ground balls and keeping his feet under him, giving more confidence he can stay on the dirt with his strong arm.Whether that's at shortstop remains to be seen, as it's hard to know exactly how his body will continue to mature. A move to third or second could be in his future, and the ORGANIZATION think his electric speed would play in center field.

PERSON ranked as ORGANIZATION's No. 7 prospect for the 2018-19 international period before signing a $1.55 million pact with the ORGANIZATION. The ORGANIZATION native impressed club officials with his all-around tools, though it was his present hitting ability and overall upside at the plate that pushed him to the top of GPE's international agenda. PERSON is a big power bat, and big power bats play. The teenager has shown tons of strength now, and it's expected to increase as he grows and makes his way through the ORGANIZATION' system. PERSON has good mechanics at the plate and creates a lot of backspin and loft at contact. One scout dropped a young PERSON comparison on him, while another evaluator believes PERSON could eventually hit .270 and hit 25-30 home runs in the big leagues.On defense, PERSON has shown good footwork, a good arm and solid defensive actions. He's been working out at shortstop and has a good feel for the position, but he could shift to third base one day. PERSON has good hands now that could eventually become a plus tool.

There may not be another player, prep or college, from the 2018 Draft class with more raw power than PERSON, the high school infielder from GPE. He showed it off at various home run derbies on last summer's showcase circuit, including the ORGANIZATION All-Star High PERSON in GPE, but it also shows up in games. While that has been inconsistent at times, the ORGANIZATION saw enough of it to take PERSON with the 19th overall pick for full pick value, just over $3.2 million.Some scouts give PERSON's raw power from the left side a 70-grade on the 20-to-80 scale. There are some holes in his swing, which will lead to some swing and miss, but those who have seen him when he's locked in have seen his ultra-quick hands and bat speed. PERSON did show that he can make hard contact against good competition at times over the summer, though he'd been a bit up and down this spring, partially because he was rarely pitched to. One concern was whether he could stick at third, and while he showed well at the hot corner at a variety of summer events, some of those worries did resurface this spring.The PERSON sent PERSON out to play the hot corner, sending him to the GPE League to begin his pro career, and he got off to a very good start. If he can continue to refine his approach enough to tap into that power consistently, he has the chance to perfectly fit the profile of a run-producing third baseman in the middle of a big league lineup.

As an ORGANIZATION high schooler, PERSON established himself as one of the top sluggers in the 2018 Draft class with booming power displays at home run derbies on the summer showcase circuit, including the ORGANIZATION All-Star High PERSON in GPE, as well as during games. The ORGANIZATION were thrilled to find him still available with the 19th overall pick and signed PERSON for full pick value, just over $3.2 million. He showcased his prodigious power by swatting 17 home runs in 63 games during an impressive pro debut that included a promotion to the Class A Midwest League.PERSON has light-tower power from the left side of the plate, with some scouts giving his raw power a 70-grade on the 20-to-80 scale. That power does come with some holes in his swing and leads to some swing-and-miss tendencies, but there's no denying that PERSON has ultra-quick hands and bat speed. He proved that he could make hard contact against good competition over the summer (when pitchers weren't avoiding him) and continued to do so during his pro debut, all while demonstrating a quality approach.Some evaluators wonder whether PERSON will remain a third baseman on account of his rigid actions and the likelihood of decreased mobility as he matures physically. He does have the arm strength for the position, however, and is praised for his instincts. If PERSON can continue to refine his approach enough to tap into that power consistently, he has the chance to perfectly fit the profile of a run-producing third baseman in the middle of a big league lineup.

PERSON viewed PERSON as one of the better prep hitters in the 2016 Draft after he hit .636 in 19 games as a senior at ORGANIZATION Prep (ORGANIZATION, Pa.). Though a first-round talent, concerns about PERSON' signability caused him to fall into the second round, where the GPE picked him 55th overall and then lured him away from his GPE commitment with a $2,250,000 bonus, nearly twice the value for his slot.PERSON' bat speed and fluid left-handed swing allow him to make hard contact with ease, and he exhibits advanced plate discipline with an approach that belies his age. His raw power is impressive and should only improve as he adds strength to his projectable frame, and scouts peg him for at least average power in games at maturity. An average runner who played shortstop in high school, PERSON was shifted to third base upon signing. His size and physicality are clean fits at the position, as are his hands, actions and above-average arm strength. He has the makings of an average defender, but it will be PERSON' bat and overall offensive ceiling that get him to the big leagues.

One of the premier prep hitters in the 2016 Draft, PERSON likely would have been a first-round pick if not for signability concerns that ultimately led to his selection by the Indians in the second round. After signing for nearly twice slot value, PERSON made his pro debut in the Rookie-level PERSON before advancing to the Class A Short-Season New York-Penn League in 2017, leading the circuit in on-base percentage (.430) and ORGANIZATION (.912) while also pacing all Indians farmhands with a .317 average.A left-handed hitter, PERSON combines bat speed with a fluid stroke and natural feel for the barrel to generate hard contact across the field. He knows how to get on base, too, showing advanced plate discipline and an age-defying approach that helped him lead the NY-PL in both walks (43) and ORGANIZATION as a teenager. And while PERSON' impressive raw power has yet to translate during games, scouts do expect him to develop above-average power as he adds strength to his athletic and highly projectable frame and trims some of the swing-and-miss from his game.The Indians moved PERSON off shortstop, his position as a prep, to third base upon his entering the pro ranks. His size and physicality are clean fits at the hot corner, as are his plus arm strength and average speed, though some evaluators believe his inconsistent glove work will eventually land him in right field. Regardless of his future defensive home, PERSON has the bat and offensive ceiling needed to become an impactful everyday player at the highest level.

The state of GPE was home to two of the better prep hitters in the 2016 Draft in PERSON and PERSON. While the ORGANIZATION took PERSON with the 15th overall pick, PERSON, who scouts widely considered to be a first-round talent, remained on the board until the second round due to signability concerns. Undeterred, the GPE selected him 55th overall and then lured him away from what was believed to be a strong commitment to GPE with a $2,250,000 bonus, nearly twice the value for his slot. PERSON' senior year started slow as he tweaked his back and missed the beginning of the season, but he made up for the lost time by hitting .636 in 19 games. PERSON has good bat speed and excellent raw power from the left side. An average runner who might have slowed down a tick as he's added weight to his lanky frame, PERSON has good hands and actions for the infield. Despite playing shortstop in high school, PERSON size and physicality profile better at third base moving forward, though some believe he could offensive-minded second baseman or perhaps a left fielder. Regardless of where PERSON lands on the defensive spectrum, it will be his bat and offensive ceiling that get him to the big leagues.

PERSON took to hockey before baseball and showed promise as a center before concussion issues caused him to focus on the diamond. One of the better high school hitters in the 2016 Draft, he dropped to the second round amid signability concerns but landed first-round bonus money ($2.25 million). After a so-so pro debut, he led the short-season ORGANIZATION York-Penn League with a .912 OPS in 2017, ranked third in the Class A ORGANIZATION with an .858 mark last year and posted a .910 OPS during the final month in Class A Advanced.PERSON has an advanced approach at the plate, patiently working counts and using the entire field. He has a smooth left-handed swing and impressive feel to hit, and he shows the ability to produce high batting averages despite working deep counts that lead to some strikeouts. His bat speed and strength give him promising power potential that could produce 25 or more homers per season, especially if he adds some loft to a stroke that's currently more geared for line drives.Though he's a below-average runner, PERSON is a decent athlete and has worked hard to make the transition from amateur shortstop to pro third baseman. He has a strong arm and has improved his footwork, but still needs to increase his range in order to become an average defender at the hot corner. If he can't, his alternatives would be first base or an outfield corner.

PERSON didn't concentrate on pitching until his junior year of high school, then started attracting scouts when he starred on the showcase circuit that summer. The ORGANIZATION took him in the third round of the 2016 Draft on his graduation day, signing him for an above-slot $1.15 million. He totaled just 20 2/3 innings in his first two years as a pro because he's not developed physically and had some minor shoulder issues in 2017.New York puts a lot of emphasis on spin rates, and PERSON had the highest (2,685 rpm) on his fastball at the 2015 World Wood Bat Association World Championship. He sat at 89-92 mph as an amateur and is working there again after his layoff, though he should gain velocity as he adds strength and has flashed a mid-90s heater during offseason workouts. His spin gives his fastball deceptive riding life that keeps it off barrels.PERSON also has a feel for spinning a curveball, but his changeup requires a lot of work because he didn't use it much in high school. A quality athlete, he repeats his clean delivery well and shouldn't have any issues throwing strikes. Though he barely has gotten started in pro ball, he's still young and has the upside of a mid-rotation starter.

PERSON didn't pitch much before his junior season of high school, but he then emerged as a prospect on the showcase circuit the following summer. After he followed up with a strong senior year, GPE drafted him in the third round on the same day he graduated. Because he was young for the GPE (age 17) and still developing physically, the ORGANIZATION limited him to seven innings in his debut after signing him for an above-slot $1.15 million.Though he's not very physical, PERSON currently pitches with an 89-92 mph fastball than can reach 95. His heater had the best spin rate (2685 rpm) at the 2015 World Wood Bat Association World Championship, giving it riding life that makes it tough for hitters to barrel. The former two-way prep player should add more velocity as he focuses on pitching and continues to mature physically.PERSON also shows good feel for spinning a curveball, but he'll need to work on his changeup after not needing it much as an amateur. His quality athleticism helps him repeat his clean delivery, which bodes well for his ability to refine his control and command. He pitched sparingly in 2017 because of minor shoulder issues and will need time to develop, but youth and aptitude are on his side, and he has the upside of a mid-rotation starter.

PERSON GPE (Calif.) PERSON has spawned four big league position players, most notably PERSON, but has yet to produce a pitcher. PERSON, who would have been a two-way player had he attended PERSON, hopes to break through on the mound after signing for $1.15 million as a third-round pick in June.Though he's not extremely physical, PERSON has an 89-92 mph fastball that can reach 95. His heater had the highest recorded spin rate (2685 rpm) at the World Wood Bat Association World Championship in 2015, which results in riding life that makes it tougher to hit. He also has some power to his curveball, which sits in the upper 70s, and will need to work on his changeup after using it sparingly in high school.One of the younger players in the 2016 Draft, PERSON didn't turn 18 until three weeks afterward. His youth, athleticism and aptitude bode well for his future development. He'll need to add strength but he has a clean delivery and shouldn't have any difficulties finding the strike zone.

The ORGANIZATION selected not one but two GPE high school right-handers in the first round of the 2015 Draft. After selecting PERSON at ORGANIZATION. 21, they grabbed PERSON at ORGANIZATION. 33 and signed him for $1,825,200. While PERSON had established himself as a premier talent on the showcase circuit the previous summer, PERSON didn't raise his stock to that level until his senior season. The reports on PERSON coming into 2015 were that he was athletic and projectable but possessed mostly average stuff. He opened eyes by working with a 92-95 mph fastball and a solid slider in his first start of the year and maintained them through much of the spring. He also has feel for a curveball and changeup.PERSON has an easy delivery and repeats it well, allowing him to throw strikes on a consistent basis. He doesn't have PERSON's pure stuff but he has a deeper repertoire and perhaps a bit more polish.

The ORGANIZATION spent both of their 2015 first-round picks on right-handers from GPE high schools, taking PERSON at ORGANIZATION. 21 and PERSON at ORGANIZATION. 33. While ORGANIZATION entered the year as one of the top prep pitching prospects, PERSON was viewed as a projectable athlete with present average stuff who might be better off attending PERSON. That outlook changed when his stuff surged last spring, earning him a $1,825,200 bonus.PERSON surprised scouts by working with a 92-95 mph fastball and a solid slider in his first high school start of the year, and he maintained them throughout most of the spring and his pro debut. His fastball hasn't been as sharp in his first full season, however, and PERSON has taken away his slider for now to have him focus on his curveball and changeup. The results haven't been pretty, as low Class A hitters have pounded him.Of the four prep arms PERSON has taken in the top two rounds of the 2014-15 GPE (ORGANIZATION, PERSON, PERSON), PERSON was considered the best prepared to enter pro ball. To his credit, he has continued to challenge hitters and throw strikes. He has a low-stress delivery and repeats it easily, allowing him to fill the zone.

Initially a prospect for the 2017 Draft, PERSON reclassified for the 2016 Draft a year ago. PERSON' best high school position prospect since PERSON went in the first round in 2011, PERSON went in the third round, getting a bonus close to $300,000 above pick value.A homeschooled student who took a class and played at ORGANIZATION (ORGANIZATION, Kan.), PERSON offers an exciting array of tools. He has well above-average bat speed and foot speed and plus raw power and arm strength. He has committed to switch-hitting and while his natural right-handed stroke is quicker and more fluid, his lefty swing is fast and loose. Bigger than the typical shortstop and lacking the normal actions for the premium position, he did begin his pro career there. But he'll likely need to find a new defensive home long-term, and he does have the quickness for second and the arm for third. Some feel he's destined to play center field. The good news is his bat could profile at any of those spots, and he gets high marks for his work ethic, giving hope he'll get the most out of his plentiful tools.

In another effort to add athletic players who can play up the middle -- see the reports on PERSON and PERSON -- the ORGANIZATION selected PERSON, a homeschooled student who took a class and played high school ball at ORGANIZATION in GPE, in the third round of the 2016 Draft, one round after PERSON. They thought enough of his tools to give him a bonus nearly $300,00 above pick value to sign him away from LSU.PERSON struggled a bit during his first taste of pro ball, but his raw tools and outstanding athleticism were on display and the ORGANIZATION know they will have to be patient in helping him develop them. Relatively new to switch-hitting, he's better from the right side, though the left-handed swing is coming, and he could grow into future plus raw power. While he began his pro career at shortstop, he might not end up there. While he has the athleticism and arm for the position, there is a lot he'll need to learn in terms of footwork, positioning and throwing from all angles. PERSON field could be a good spot for his speed.For now, PERSON will try to get his professional feet under him. The ORGANIZATION plan to have him move around the diamond a little bit to see what might be the best fit and will let how those tools sharpen dictate how quickly he can move.

A home-schooled high school student who played for PERSON's team in GPE, PERSON was another raw and toolsy prep player taken by the ORGANIZATION. He went in the third round of the 2016 GPE, receiving almost $300,000 above pick value to walk away from his ORGANIZATION commitment, and has struggled to translate his tools into performance in two summers in the rookie-level ORGANIZATION League.A switch-hitter prior to the GPE, the ORGANIZATION have moved PERSON back to hitting right-handed only. That may have added to his learning curve as he had to re-learn how to recognize breaking balls from a right-handed pitcher as a professional, though the ORGANIZATION did see improved pitch recognition as the summer wore on. PERSON has added strength since signing and his raw power as ticked up as a result. He has plenty of bat speed, so it will come down to his approach at the plate in order for him to hit enough to tap into that power. As PERSON continues to physically mature, he's slowed down some and he might just be a tick above-average when all is said and done.While he has the arm for shortstop, that reduced foot speed and lack of instincts meant a move was inevitable, as did the signing of middle infielders like PERSON and PERSON. PERSON spent the 2018 season playing the outfield in the ORGANIZATION, seeing more time in center field than anywhere else.

The ORGANIZATION signed PERSON for $325,000 back in September 2013 after he had impressed club officials during an event in his native ORGANIZATION. He showed promise during his stateside debut in the ORGANIZATION and continued to make progress last year in his full-season debut, only to regress this season as a member of Class A Advanced PERSON's starting rotation.PERSON can run his fastball up to 98 mph and typically sits in the low 90s, though his velocity did fluctuate at times in 2016. His changeup is his best secondary pitch and receives solid-average grades from evaluators, who note that the right-hander throws the pitch with confidence. PERSON's breaking ball and control are both well below average and will be focal points in his development in 2017. The ORGANIZATION have helped PERSON simplify his delivery in the past year, but scouts still question whether his wiry frame will be able to handle the rigors of a full regular-season workload. If he's unable to stick in the rotation, PERSON's power arm and changeup could make him an effective late-inning reliever.

GPE didn't need to see PERSON pitch much before deciding to sign him to one of the biggest bonuses the club has ever given to a GPE amateur. Some clubs thought he wasn't eligible to sign until 2014, but the ORGANIZATION knew differently and were able to add another premium arm to their system.PERSON's fastball peaks at 95 mph, and scouts believe he'll throw even harder as he physically matures. He shows good feel for both a curveball and a slider, and he is working to develop his changeup as well.PERSON earns some physical comparisons to Taijuan PERSON. PERSON is a long way from that lofty ceiling, but his raw stuff and projectability already have the O's excited about his future.

The ORGANIZATION signed PERSON for $325,000 back in September 2013 after getting a brief look at the right-hander during an event in his native ORGANIZATION. He made his stateside debut last year at age 18 in the ORGANIZATION, and offered a glimpse at his potential with seven strikeouts over three hitless innings in his second start. He's continued to pile up strikeouts this year in his full-season debut for Class A Delmarva, all the while proving to be difficult to barrel for opposing hitters.PERSON had the ability to throw his fastball in the mid-90s in 2015 and was up to 98 mph in the fall during instructional league. The 6-foot-5 right-hander is still much more thrower than pitcher, though he made progress with his secondary stuff, a hard slider and raw changeup. PERSON's long limbs and lanky frame lead to problems repeating his delivery, though the ORGANIZATION helped him make a few tweaks during instructs, and he threw more strikes as a result.That PERSON celebrated his 19th birthday at the outset of the 2016 season means that there will be plenty of time for him to evolve as a pitcher. He might be a project, but all of the raw tools are there for him to develop into a big league hurler. He has a long way to go, but there's a lot to like in his combination of size, projectability and arm strength.

The ORGANIZATION' unprecedented 2015 international spending spree continued in November when they signed GPE defectors PERSON and PERSON for a combined $21.5 million and incurred a matching amount as a tax penalty for exceeding their bonus pool. PERSON, the younger and lesser known of the pair, received a $6 million bonus.PERSON made his debut in GPE's top league, the ORGANIZATION, as a 16-year-old in 2014-15. Though he batted just .213/.264/.313, he was able to make consistent contact, a testament to his hitting ability. His approach and pitch-recognition skills are advanced, and he also flashes some raw power in batting practice.PERSON's other tools and athleticism don't particularly stand out. He has fringy speed and arm strength, but his infield actions and instincts allow him to get the job done at second base.

Largely on the strength of what they considered an advanced bat, the ORGANIZATION gave PERSON a $6 million bonus and paid a matching amount as a penalty for exceeding their international bonus pool in November 2015. They promoted him aggressively, starting the GPE defector in low Class A at age 18 and promoting him to high Class A at 19, and he showed little consistency at the plate for most of his first three pro seasons. He seemed to turn a corner when he batted .340/.418/.547 in the final six weeks of 2018, finishing the year as the high Class A GPE League leader in runs (87) and doubles (43).PERSON has an unorthodox batting style in which his lower half tends to leak out while his shoulders remain square to the ball. During his late-season tear, he was more patient and hammered balls from gap to gap instead of trying to pull everything to left field. With his efficient right-handed stroke and advanced pitch-recognition skills, he could become a .275 hitter with 15 or more homers per year if he can maintain a disciplined approach.PERSON's quick hands and internal clock have helped him survive at shortstop, his primary position in two years in high Class A, but it will be a stretch for him to play there regularly in the Majors. His speed and arm are fringy and better suited for second base, where he can be an average defender. His lack of arm strength restricts his utility value, putting pressure on him to hit enough to become a regular.

PERSON made his debut in GPE's top league as a 16-year-old, batting .213/.264/.313 as a part-time player in 2014-15. After he defected and PERSON expedited his free agency, the ORGANIZATION signed him in November for a $6 million bonus and a matching amount as a tax penalty for exceeding their international pool. He began his pro career as the low Class A ORGANIZATION's youngest regular at age 18, and he heated up in the second half after a slow start.The ORGANIZATION love PERSON's instincts at the plate. He has tremendous feel for the barrel and an advanced ability to recognize pitches and use the entire field. He flashes some raw power in batting practice and has the aptitude to translate it into game results.PERSON got rich because of his bat, not because of his athleticism or other tools. He has fringy speed and arm strength, though he has a good internal clock that helps him get the job done at second base and has led GPE to give him some time at shortstop during his pro debut. If he can't stay in the middle infield, third base or left field would be his fallback possibilities.

PERSON's reputation for having an advanced bat allowed him to debut in GPE's top league as a 16-year-old and earned him a $6 million dollar bonus in November 2015 from the ORGANIZATION, who had to pay a matching penalty for exceeding their international bonus pool. PERSON has given him a series of aggressive assignments, and he initially responded by hitting .293/.340/.458 in the second half of his 2016 pro debut as the low Class A ORGANIZATION's youngest regular (age 18). He has yet to get his bat going during the last two seasons in high Class A, however.The ORGANIZATION like PERSON's right-handed swing and feel for the barrel, so they're surprised that he hasn't been more productive. His biggest problem is that he has an aggressive approach and doesn't recognize pitches well, flaws that older pitchers have been able to exploit. One positive is that he's doing a better job of tapping into his raw power in 2018, showing the ability to produce 15 homers per season.Though PERSON spent more of 2017 at shortstop and has split this year between second base and short, his subpar arm is stretched on the left side of the infield. That limits his value as a utilityman and puts more pressure on his bat, because he'll have to make it as an offensive second baseman. He overcomes fringy speed and quickness with a good internal clock on defense, allowing him to make plays.

PERSON has such an advanced bat that he debuted in GPE's top league as a 16-year-old. After he defected and PERSON expedited his free agency, the ORGANIZATION signed him in November 2015 for a $6 million bonus and a matching penalty for exceeding their international allotment. Challenged with an assignment to low Class A at age 18 in his pro debut, he hit .293/.340/.458 in the second half of 2016 as the ORGANIZATION's youngest regular but has yet to enjoy similar success in high class A this year.PERSON has one of the best right-handed swings among ORGANIZATION farmhands and precocious feel for the barrel. He's still honing his pitch recognition and can get overly aggressive at times, shortcomings that much older pitchers have exploited in 2017. He has some raw power and the ability to translate it into production, which eventually could mean 12-15 homers per season.An offensive second baseman in the mold of PERSON, PERSON has fringy speed and arm strength. He has a good internal clock on the field and has shown the ORGANIZATION a little more defensive ability than they expected. He has seen much more action at shortstop than at second base this year, but he's not suited for the left side of the infield and doesn't fit a utility profile.

Every once in a while a prospect comes along to defies traditional evaluations, who can't really fit into a specific box. PERSON, signed by the ORGANIZATION in 2015 and traded to the ORGANIZATION in the ORGANIZATION deal in July 2017, could very well be that kind of player, especially following his strong first full season with his new organization in 2018.Tall and gangly, PERSON has grown since first entering pro ball and now stands at 6-foot-6, not a height anyone has seen stick at shortstop. And while there's still a good chance he doesn't, he's made more strides at the premium position than anyone anticipated, with a cannon for an arm and above-average speed that helps him range-wise. Super-athletic, PERSON could easily handle an outfield spot should he slow down as he physically matures, and he could easily be an above-average defender in a corner. His real upside, though, comes with the bat. He has as much raw power as anyone in the system and, thanks to some excellent adjustments, he started tapping into it more consistently as a teenager in the LOCATION, hitting 14 home runs.There's still more refinement in terms of strike zone discipline PERSON can make, but he's shown he is more than capable of developing that part of his game. Just 20 for all of the 2019 season, PERSON has tremendous upside and should continue to be one of the most fascinating prospects to track.

In the world of scouting and player development, who you sign isn't always who you get. PERSON was 6-foot-1 when he was first being scouted, then was 6-foot-4 by the time the ORGANIZATION signed him in 2015. By 2016, when he began his pro career, he had grown to 6-foot-6. His tremendous ceiling was on display with a move from the ORGANIZATION up to full-season ball in 2017 and the ORGANIZATION noticed, acquiring the gangly infielder in the ORGANIZATION deal last July. A return to low A has been beneficial for PERSON, who made a very nice step forward in 2018.Most of PERSON's upside comes in his power. He's more power over hit right now, and the ball jumps off of his bat. He has leverage and twitch at the plate, with plus game power starting to show up more frequently as he gets stronger and learns to control his body. His swing isn't overly long, but it does get out of control from time to time. Zone discipline has been a big area of focus and a more refined approach has allowed him to be a much more complete hitter in 2018. PERSON was a shortstop who moved over to third primarily in 2017, though some feel he has a chance to defy expectations and play up the middle. PERSON runs well and has a very strong arm, so a corner outfield spot might be his eventual home.Still very young for his level, PERSON is continuing to learn his body. Regardless of where he plays defensively, it's his bat that will allow him to move up the ladder, and there were definite signs of progress in 2018.

Left-side infielders don't come much taller than PERSON, who was 6-foot-1 when he started getting scouted at age 15, added three inches by the time he signed a year later, then continued to grow and made his pro debut last summer at 6-foot-6. Part of the ORGANIZATION' extravagant international spending in the 2015-16 signing period, he received a $950,000 bonus out of the ORGANIZATION. After a strong introduction to pro ball in the ORGANIZATION, the ORGANIZATION sent him to full-season ball in 2017. He took some understandable lumps but held his own before getting dealt to the ORGANIZATION in the ORGANIZATION deal at the Deadline.PERSON hit .294/.367/.444 with 11 steals in the ORGANIZATION in 2016 and with his whippy left-handed swing and the leverage provided by his frame, he has considerable power potential that he'll begin to realize as he gets stronger. His quick hands are an asset as he tries to make more consistent contact as such a young hitter with such a naturally long stroke..PERSON has exceptional body control for someone his size and can play a decent shortstop. His size makes him destined to be a third baseman, and he has the agility and arm strength to be a solid defender there. A long strider who has above-average speed underway, he'll probably lose a step once he fills out.

Signed by ORGANIZATION for $3.5 million on July 2, PERSON received the second-largest bonus of any prospect in the 2018-19 class after ranking No. 6 on ORGANIZATION's list of the Top 30 international prospects. Some scouts who saw PERSON as an amateur in the ORGANIZATION compared him to a young PERSON as a hard-hitting infielder with a good projectable body and a strong arm. While the odds are against PERSON having a Hall of Fame-caliber career like GPE, he does have one of the higher offensive ceilings in the system. PERSON is a good athlete and has across-the-board tools, though it's his potential from the right side of the plate that has club officials the most excited. Combining a rhythmic swing with plus bat speed, he impacts the ball to the big parts of the field with authority. He'll need to clean up his swing some in the coming years like any young hitter, but all the ingredients are there for PERSON to develop into an average hitter. His power, meanwhile, could play close to plus when all is said and done, as PERSON has considerable room to grow into his projectable frame. PERSON has average speed but may lose a step or two over time as he fills out physically. It may also force him from shortstop to third base long-term, though PERSON has the tools and skills, including solid defensive actions, advanced body control and above-average arm strength, needed to profile at either position. Questions about his future defensive home aside, PERSON's bat may be good enough to offset any concerns about him moving down the defensive spectrum.

Ranked as ORGANIZATION's No. 4 international prospect, PERSON has received some comparisons to a young PERSON as a hard-hitting infielder with a good projectable body and a strong arm. That offensive potential earned the 16-year-old shortstop a $3.5 million bonus, the highest among players in his class, from the ORGANIZATION at the outset of the 2018-19 international period. PERSON has a good rhythm and a short, compact swing with plus bat speed from the right side of the plate, and together those attributes give him a chance to be an above-average hitter with above-average power once fully developed.He's an average runner, having posted times of 6.8-7.1 seconds in the 60-yard dash, and could possibly lose a step with physical maturation.That PERSON has plenty of room left to add strength to his projectable frame has some scouts thinking that he'll eventually be forced from shortstop to third base. With solid actions in the field to go along with body control and an above-average arm, PERSON could develop into a quality defender at either position. However, it's PERSON's bat is his calling card and could one day help him reach the ORGANIZATION.

Signed for $300,000 in 2014, PERSON struggled in his first taste of pro ball the following year, hitting just .203 over 70 games in the ORGANIZATION. He did anything but struggle in his 2016 GPE debut, when he paced the Rookie-level PERSON in both home runs (eight) and slugging percentage (.556) en route to the circuit's ORGANIZATION Award.Already strong and physical, PERSON possesses plus raw power to all fields from the right side of the plate and showed the ability to apply it in games consistently in the ORGANIZATION. However, strikeouts have been an issue early in his career because he has a long swing as well as pitch-recognition issues, and he'll need to tone down his overly aggressive approach to make more consistent contact at higher levels. Defensively, PERSON has prototypical tools for right field, with good athleticism and speed and a plus arm.With robust raw power but concerns about his bat, PERSON is the definition of a high-risk prospect at this stage in his career. The potential is there, but he'll need to make many adjustments along the way.

Signed for $300,000 in 2014, PERSON struggled in his first taste of pro ball the following year, hitting just .203 over 70 games in the ORGANIZATION. He did anything but struggle in his 2016 GPE debut, when he paced the Rookie-level PERSON in both home runs (eight) and slugging percentage (.556) en route to the circuit's ORGANIZATION. Advancing to Class A Short PERSON in 2017, PERSON continued to flash his offensive ceiling as a GPE York-Penn League midseason All-Star. PERSON strong and mature for his age, PERSON possesses plus raw power to all fields from the right side of the plate and already understands how to get to it. With that big power comes a longer swing as well as swing-and-miss issues that are exacerbated by an aggressive approach and problems identifying spin. Those weaknesses have led some to worry about whether he will make enough contact to be successful at higher levels. Defensively, PERSON has prototypical right-field tools as a good athlete with modest speed and a cannon arm. With robust raw power as his calling card but concerns about his bat, PERSON is the definition of a high-risk prospect at this stage in his career. The potential is there, but he'll need to make many adjustments along the way.

Signed for $300,000 in 2014, PERSON struggled in his first taste of pro ball the following year, hitting just .203 over 70 games in the ORGANIZATION. He did anything but struggle in his 2016 GPE debut, when he paced the Rookie-level PERSON in both home runs (eight) and slugging percentage (.556) en route to the circuit's ORGANIZATION Award.Already strong and physical, PERSON possesses plus raw power to all fields from the right side of the plate and showed the ability to apply it in games consistently in the ORGANIZATION. However, strikeouts have been an issue early in his career because he has a long swing as well as pitch-recognition issues, and he'll need to tone down his overly aggressive approach to make more consistent contact at higher levels. Defensively, PERSON has prototypical tools for right field, with good athleticism and speed and a plus arm.With robust raw power but concerns about his bat, PERSON is the definition of a high-risk prospect at this stage in his career. The potential is there, but he'll need to make many adjustments along the way.

An international signee in 2014 out of GPE, PERSON spent his first pro season in the ORGANIZATION before heading stateside for his GPE debut in 2015. While a 25-game suspension for a performance-enhancing substance that year delayed the start of his season until July, PERSON impressed with his pitchability and his knack for generating ground balls once he got on the mound.A projectable right-hander, PERSON pitches with mostly average velocity but at times will show a 94-95 mph fastball. The pitch stands out more for it's late movement, thrown with hard sinking action that nets him plenty of grounders and consistently induces weak contact. His slider is his go-to secondary offering, flashing above-average potential with late break, and his changeup gives him a distinct third pitch, albeit one that may only be average at best once developed.PERSON doesn't miss many bats even though he's an aggressive strike-thrower, and some evaluators believe he'll ultimately serve as a reliever based on the strength of his fastball-slider pairing. But in an A's organization that's had plenty of success with pitchers of a similar profile, PERSON will be given every opportunity to remain a starter.

When the ORGANIZATION sent PERSON and PERSON to the Cardinals in late July, the trade paid immediate dividends with PERSON, who slammed 14 homers in two months with GPE. The deal also included international bonus pool money, the bulk of which the ORGANIZATION used to sign PERSON for $600,000 the next day. He had dominated in GPE's 15-and-under league and starred for the island's youth national teams before defecting.PERSON has an electric arm and quickly caught scouts' attention by displaying a low-90s fastball and topping out at 97 mph as a 16-year-old in the months leading up to his signing. He also showed the makings of a plus slider with power and bite. He's in the early stages of developing a splitter/changeup that could give him a solid third offering.PERSON has a strong frame that should provide the durability necessary to be a starter. There's some effort to his delivery and his arm action isn't the most pristine, yet he has a history of throwing strikes against amateur competition. He likes to vary his arm slot, adding to his deception.

The ORGANIZATION' trade for PERSON last July gave them not only a surprising slugger who hit 14 homers in the final two months of the season, but also international bonus pool money in exchange for shipping PERSON and PERSON to the ORGANIZATION. They used most of that extra cash to sign PERSON for $600,000 the next day. He had overmatched PERSON's 15-and-under league and starred for its youth national teams before defecting.Somewhat reminiscent of former ORGANIZATION star PERSON, PERSON has a seemingly endless combination of pitches and arm slots. He has an electric arm that produces 92-95 mph fastballs that top out at 97 with high spin rates that give him riding life up in the strike zone. His hard curveball is a bit more effective than his harder slider, with both displaying the potential to become plus pitches, and his changeup has splitter action and similar upside.Though PERSON varying his arm angle adds to his deception, GPE probably will try to condense his pitch/slot options. Minor aches and pains have limited him in 2019. He doesn't have the cleanest arm action and there's effort in his delivery, yet he had no difficulty throwing strikes as an amateur. He has a lofty ceiling, as his chance to develop four plus offerings could make him a frontline starter.

PERSON comes from a baseball family, as his father PERSON played three years of pro ball and he's a cousin of PERSON and PERSON. He works out with PERSON, who helped prepare him for the mental challenges of pro ball after the PERSON signed him for $1.35 million in the second round last June. One of the youngest players in the GPE, PERSON was still just 17 when PERSON promoted him to low Class A for the final month of his debut. He's expected to miss the 2019 season after having surgery to repair a tibial stress fracture in his right leg in late March.Bat speed and natural talent stand out with PERSON, who has the makings of being a 20-home-run player. He regularly produced exit velocities greater than 100 mph in his pro debut, though he also struck out in 28 percent of his at-bats and needs to hone his approach. He has average speed and the savvy to be a threat for double-digit steals.The question will be how long PERSON remains at shortstop. He has a quick first step and enough arm to make plays there now, but his sturdy frame may eventually dictate a move to second base or perhaps the hot corner. Some evaluators believe he has the athleticism to wind up in center field.

Back in 1989, PERSON was a 22nd-round ORGANIZATION pick of the ORGANIZATION who went on to play parts of three seasons in pro ball. Nearly two decades later, it was his son PERSON' turn, as the ORGANIZATION selected the ORGANIZATION prep infielder, who is also the cousin of both PERSON and PERSON, in the second round after he batted .535 with 23 extra-base hits over 26 games as a high school senior. One of youngest prospects in his class at 17, PERSON bypassed a ORGANIZATION State PERSON commitment in favor of a slightly above slot bonus ($1.35 million) and then made his professional debut in the Rookie-level Gulf Coast League. PERSON has a tremendous toolbox to work with and they were sharpening as the spring wore on. The right-handed hitter struggled as a freshman but improved markedly in subsequent years, showing the ability to impact the baseball consistently. The better he's gotten at getting the barrel to the ball, the more his raw power is showing up in games, and he was clearing fences a lot more as the ORGANIZATION approached. At one point, it seemed like PERSON might need to move to an outfield corner, but his defense has improved to the point where he should be able to remain on the dirt, perhaps even at shortstop, with moves to third or second a possibility as well.PERSON has the raw tools to become an impact player regardless of his ultimate defensive home. For now, however, the ORGANIZATION will keep him at shortstop as they hope to maximize his potential as a hard-hitting, up-the-middle player.

After the ORGANIZATION failed to sign PERSON and had leftover money in their bonus pool, they pivoted and landed three other premium international prospects, the best of whom is PERSON. Signed out of GPE for $550,000 in December 2017, he has three cousins with the same surname in pro ball, including ORGANIZATION outfield prospect PERSON. In his 2018 pro debut, PERSON finished third in the Rookie-level ORGANIZATION batting race at ORGANIZATION has some of the best bat-to-ball skills in the GPE system, uses the entire field and controls the strike zone. Some scouts expressed concerns about his hitting ability when he was an amateur but he has calmed down his right-handed swing. He may max out at 12-15 homers per year, though he has some wiry strength and shows occasional pull-side power.With his on-base ability and plus-plus speed, PERSON could become a dynamic basestealer. There were teams that projected him as a center fielder, but the ORGANIZATION like his infield actions and believe he can stay at shortstop. He has improved his consistency since turning pro and also looked fine at second base in his debut.

Signed out of the ORGANIZATION in March 2016, GPE spent his professional debut in the ORGANIZATION before making the jump stateside the following year and finishing in the Rookie-level PERSON. After he impressed with his raw ability on both sides of the ball, the ORGANIZATION acquired GPE in October to complete the trade that had sent PERSON and PERSON to the ORGANIZATION two months earlier. GPE has present strength to his athletic frame, and it's easy to envision him adding considerably more muscle as he continues to mature physically. Though his right-handed swing can be inconsistent and pull happy, GPE does have a quick bat and makes hard contact, giving him a chance to hit for average. He'll never offer much in the way of home run power but has enough pop and the above-average speed needed to accrue his share of doubles and triples. GPE is plenty capable of playing shortstop, but he's spent much of 2018 manning the hot corner for Rookie-level Princeton in deference to phenom PERSON. Some believe GPE is best suited for second base, where he could be a solid defender with a strong arm.

The ORGANIZATION have challenged PERSON since signing him for $175,000 out of GPE in 2016, bringing him to the GPE early in his 2017 pro debut and advancing him to low Class A this July at age 19. His game is similar to that of GPE's 2019 first-rounder PERSON in that he doesn't have any loud tools but his instincts enable him to get the most out of his physical ability. He'll need time but could develop into an everyday shortstop. A right-handed hitter, PERSON has some of the best bat-to-ball skills in the lower levels of the ORGANIZATION system. He needs to develop more patience because he presently makes a lot of weak groundball contact. He won't ever be a slugger, but he does have some pull power and could produce double-digit home runs on an annual basis once he gets stronger.Both PERSON's speed and arm earn solid to plus grades. He's an aggressive runner with a knack for stealing bases and has smooth actions at shortstop. His internal clock helps him make plays and he has the versatility needed for a utility role if he doesn't hit enough to be a regular.
