His heater sat around 91 mph when he signed and now ranges from 93-97 with riding action up in the strike zone. He has nice feel for spinning a hard curveball with good shape and the potential to give him a second plus offering. PERSON is also making progress with a fading changeup that will help him against left-handers. He repeats his delivery well and fills the strike zone. Though he's only 6 feet tall, his sound mechanics, strength and athleticism should allow him to remain a starter.

PERSON PERSON is best known as a wide receiver who played six seasons in the ORGANIZATION, but he also was the last PERSON position player selected in the first five rounds (third round to the Brewers in 1992). PERSON added his name to that very short list in 2018, going to the ORGANIZATION in the fifth round after an all-star summer in the ORGANIZATION and a strong junior campaign in which he batted .311/.386/.538 with 15 doubles, 11 homers and 36 RBIs in 53 games for the Hawkeyes.PERSON's most attractive tool is his power potential, the product of strength, solid bat speed and loft in his left-handed swing. There are times when he focuses on using the opposite field, and others when he gets pull-happy and vulnerable on the other half. He makes consistent contact and draws his share of walks.While PERSON is slow out of the box, he moves well for a 6-foot-3, 210-pounder and has at least average speed once he gets going. He plays right field for PERSON and possesses an average arm, though most scouts project him as a left fielder in pro ball. He needs to improve his reads and routes as a defender, and he has the work ethic to get the job done.

Based on the early returns, the ORGANIZATION' $60,000 investment to sign PERSON out of the ORGANIZATION in 2017 could pay off nicely. After a steady if unspectacular pro debut that summer, he has come to the GPE in 2018 and emerged as one of the more polished young pitchers in the system. PERSON could have three solid pitches once he's fully developed. He already sits at 92 mph and reaches 94 with his fastball, which features running action. He has advanced feel for a changeup that presently grades better than his curveball, which has good shape but lacks power.PERSON doesn't have a lot of projection remaining, so he's unlikely to grow into a power pitcher. But he's a savvy left-hander who throws strikes with three offerings and could develop into a No. 4 starter. His floor is higher than that of most 18-year-old southpaws.

PERSON went unsigned in the 2016 international signing period before landing a $60,000 bonus out of the ORGANIZATION Republic the following June. He made his GPE debut at age 18 last summer, averaging 11.7 strikeouts per nine innings while helping the ORGANIZATION win the Rookie-level PERSON championship. He has drawn comparisons to a smaller version of PERSON, who jumped from high Class A in 2017 to GPE last year.PERSON shows the potential for three solid pitches once he matures physically. He operates at 90-93 mph and reaches 95 with running action on his fastball, setting up an advanced changeup that he throws with the same arm speed. His curveball has more shape than power at this point.His athleticism allows PERSON to repeat his delivery, which bodes well for his ability to provide strikes and stay healthy. While he doesn't have a ton of projection remaining, his combination of stuff and savvy gives him a ceiling of a No. 4 starter. He also has a higher floor than most teenaged southpaws and could start to advance quickly.

The ORGANIZATION signed GPE out of the ORGANIZATION in February 2017 for $50,000 and has been the prototypical projectable right-hander since. The 6-foot-4, 180-pounder has shown the ability to miss bats every step of the way, spending parts of two summers in the ORGANIZATION, hitting two rookie-level stops in 2018 and in making his full-season debut in 2019. He earned PERSON All-Star honors in the process before hitting a bit of a wall in the second half.Right now, GPE's fastball averages 91-92 mph, though he does throw it well up in the zone with good life and spin rate. With his clean delivery and frame, there's also some more velocity to dream on. His low-80s curveball is his best secondary pitch. It flashes plus, but more than likely will settle into being a consistently above-average breaking ball in the future. GPE will also throw a splitter, which is behind the other two pitches, but could eventually give him a third close-to-average offering.Like with many young pitchers, command is still elusive as he grows into his body and learns to repeat his delivery consistently. There's some ceiling here and if the ORGANIZATION are patient, there's plenty of time for GPE to develop into a Major League starter.

PERSON originally signed with the ORGANIZATION as a 16-year-old shortstop out of the ORGANIZATION for $150,000 back in October 2015. After debuting in the ORGANIZATION in 2016, he made his GPE debut in the ORGANIZATION League the following summer. The ORGANIZATION aggressively jumped him to full-season ball in 2018, with less than optimal results. So in 2019 they sent PERSON back to the LOCATION, where he's shown he's made some adjustments and started tapping into his power while handling multiple infield positions.PERSON's bat is his carrying tool. A switch-hitter, PERSON has shown the ability to impact the baseball on a much more consistent basis from both sides of the plate. It's definitely hit over power right now and while he has been developing some strike zone discipline, he still has much work to do in seeing pitches, drawing walks and cutting down his strikeout rate. If he can do that, he has the chance to continue to show excellent extra-base pop, especially for his position. While he still sees time at shortstop, he's played three infield spots, with second and third base his best defensively.The infielder will have to continue to show he can make adjustments and develop a better overall approach in order to hit enough to tap into that raw power, especially as he moves up the ladder. He likely profiles best as a bat-first utility type, but if it all comes together, seeing him as an offensive-minded second baseman isn't completely out of the question.

The 2014-15 international signing period has proven to be a solid one in terms of providing prospects for the ORGANIZATION. ORGANIZATION and PERSON were the top two signees bonus-wise, and both are on this Top 30. The recently traded PERSON, who topped the list, was an under-the-radar signing. The ORGANIZATION also got PERSON that November for $75,000, a strong-armed backstop who had a solid full-season debut in 2018.PERSON's catch and throw skills have always stood out. He has a plus arm and good footwork, allowing him to throw out nearly 40 percent of potential basestealers. He has very good hands, but does need to continue to polish his overall receiving skills. PERSON is currently a fringe hitter, but he started tapping into his raw power in GPE, a place not usually conducive to the long ball. It's mostly to the pull side with a short, compact swing from the right side, and he'll have to refine his overall approach in order continue tapping into that power as he moves up the ladder.At the very least PERSON has the makings of a defensive-minded backup with some power at the plate. If he can improve his approach and become a better all-around hitter, he has the chance to be more than that.

PERSON was pure projection when the ORGANIZATION inked him for $350,000 at the outset of the 2013-14 international period. He spent the next three seasons playing in his native ORGANIZATION League but showed improvement in each campaign before turning in a breakout 2017 campaign with PERSON at age 20.PERSON has impressed club officials with his above-average bat speed and overall feel to hit. He started to grow into his lean, athletic frame in 2017 and in turn saw his power blossom en route to career highs in both doubles and home runs. His swing can get too long at times, however, which leads to some swing-and-miss issues, but also highlights the left-handed hitter's room for improvement.PERSON's athleticism, speed and plus arm strength have netted him time at all three outfield spots, though he spent much of 2017 in center field. He'll need to improve his routes and jumps to remain there, as some evaluators already believe he's best suited for a corner spot long term.

PERSON jumped onto the prospect radar as a 15-year-old in 2013, when he played the infield for GPE's 18U World Cup team. The ORGANIZATION signed PERSON for $225,000 the following year and subsequently moved him behind the plate, only to see him blossom into the organization's top catching prospect in the following years. After back-to-back seasons in the ORGANIZATION, PERSON made the jump to the GPE in 2017 and excelled on both sides of the ball in the Rookie-level Appalachian League.PERSON's impact potential with the bat was on full display in the ORGANIZATION, where he finished among the circuit leaders with 74 hits (third), 22 doubles (second), a .332 average (fifth) and a .507 slugging percentage (fifth). PERSON combines strength, bat speed and a smooth right-handed swing to generate hard contact with ease, though his barrel path can get long at times. Those qualities also help him generate above-average raw power that he should tap into more consistently in the coming years. PERSON's progress behind the plate has been even more impressive, especially when considering how new he is to the position. His athleticism and agility aid him as a blocker and a receiver, while his cannon arm and solid catch-and-throw skills enabled him to nab 57 percent of would-be basestealers in 2017. He'll need to become more durable to handle the rigors of a full season, but all the tools and relative skills are there for him to develop into a first-division backstop.

An infielder on GPE's 18U World Cup squad in 2013, PERSON was moved behind the plate by the Rays the next year after signing for $225,000. He has since blossomed into the organization's top catching prospect, not to mention one of the better young backstops in the Minors, showing tools that give him impact potential on both sides of the ball. He raked in the Rookie-level GPE League during his 2017 stateside debut, finishing fifth on the circuit in both average (.332) and slugging (.507), then boosted his stock in his first full season by clubbing 21 home runs over 109 games at age 20 in the Class A ORGANIZATION in '18.PERSON is a physically strong right-handed hitter who projects to hit for power and average at a premium position. He makes a lot of hard contact, exhibiting bat speed as well as a knack for barreling the baseball with good hand-eye coordination. He's added loft to his swing and began to tap into his plus raw power last season to finish second in home runs among PERSON catchers. That power is almost entirely to PERSON's pull side, however, and some evaluators question his ability to hit to all fields. While he doesn't strike out much, PERSON will need to tone down his aggressive approach and become more selective as he works his way through the Minors. PERSON has the type of plus arm strength and catch-and-throw skills needed to control a running game, but he'll need to make considerable gains with his receiving and blocking to stick behind the plate. Some of those improvements should happen naturally with experience, as PERSON is still new to catching and learning the many nuances of the position. Scouts tend to agree that he could become an average defender, with enough thump at the plate to compensate for any shortcomings behind it.

PERSON ORGANIZATION may have departed the organization in a controversial trade for PERSON, but the ORGANIZATION still have an ultra-advanced teenaged right-hander from the 2014-15 international class. Signed for $250,000 out of GPE, PERSON paced the Rookie-level ORGANIZATION with a 63/3 K/BB ratio in his 2015 pro debut. He finished fifth in the LOCATION League with a 104/23 ratio last year, when he was the low Class A circuit's youngest ORGANIZATION qualifier at age 18.PERSON can't overpower hitters but succeeds thanks to his ability to locate three pitches and the deception in his delivery. His 88-93 mph four-seam fastball plays above its velocity because he can locate it with precision. His fading changeup improved in 2016 and might represent his best chance for a plus offering, and his curveball has some downer action if not a ton of power behind it.Boston's 2016 Minor League pitcher of the year isn't physical and may be more skinny than projectable, so his floor stands out more than his ceiling. PERSON may not be more than a No. 4 starter, but his uncanny pitchability makes him a good bet to realize that potential. And while the ORGANIZATION will try to watch his workload because he's still so young, he still might reach PERSON at age 21.

Signed for $250,000 out of GPE in 2014, PERSON made an immediate impression with his advanced pitchability. He led the Rookie-level ORGANIZATION with a 63/3 K/BB ratio in his 2015 pro debut, then ranked fifth in the LOCATION League with a 104/23 mark the following season, when he was the low Class A circuit's youngest pitching qualifier at age 18. The jump to high Class A didn't go as smoothly in 2017, though he fared better there this year before elbow inflammation ended his season in early June.PERSON lacks a plus pitch and wasn't able to baffle high Class A hitters with his command and deception. His best offering is his fading changeup, which helped him hold left-handers to a .668 ORGANIZATION last year. But righties teed off on him to the tune of a 1.033 ORGANIZATION, as his 88-92 mph four-seam fastball, his fringy curveball and new slider weren't able to keep them at bay. PERSON has to be precise with the location of his pitches in order to succeed, and he wasn't as sharp in 2017. His command helps his fastball play above its mediocre velocity but that wasn't enough to keep it off barrels last year. He has a unique windup with a deep knee bend and a twist, though that hasn't thrown hitters off as much in high Class A as it had at lower levels.

PERSON PERSON wasn't the only Red Sox international signee from 2014 who pitched his way to the GPE sooner than expected. Inked for $250,000 out of GPE, PERSON led the Rookie-level ORGANIZATION with a gaudy 63/3 K/BB ratio in his 2015 pro debut, which he concluded by allowing a total of two runs in four Rookie-level Gulf Coast League starts.PERSON has added about 5 mph to his fastball since signing and now pitches at 89-91 with a max velocity of 93. He should throw harder once he adds some muscle to his skinny frame, and his heater already plays up because of his precocious ability to locate it where he wants. He also has a pair of promising secondary pitches, with his downer curveball presently ranking ahead of his fading changeup.Extremely advanced for an 18-year-old, PERSON has a chance to become a mid-rotation starter. PERSON may keep him in short-season ball this year to avoid piling too many innings on his young arm, but his stuff and feel for pitching could get him to PERSON before he turns 22.

One of the best defensive players available in the 2015 international crop, PERSON signed for $2 million out of the ORGANIZATION. To put the ORGANIZATION' global spending spree last year in perspective, that was just the seventh-highest bonus paid out by the club.PERSON has all the tools to be a plus shortstop at the big league level. He has nice actions and instincts, a quick first step, plenty of range, soft hands and a strong arm. He might already be the best defensive infielder a system without many strong gloves up the middle.PERSON offers some offensive potential as well. His right-handed swing could use some smoothing out but he shows signs of pitch recognition and plate discipline, which along with his solid speed should help him hit for a decent average. He has a projectable frame and good bat speed, so he could have some pop as well.

One of the best defenders in the 2015-16 international class, PERSON landed a $2 million bonus to sign out of the ORGANIZATION. He spent his first pro season in the Rookie-level ORGANIZATION before making his GPE debut in 2017. That ended in early August when a runner slid into him on an attempted double play and broke his left leg. PERSON healthy in 2018, PERSON showed improved hitting ability as well as some power en route to both mid-season and post-season All-Star honors in the ORGANIZATION. The ORGANIZATION acquired him and right-hander PERSON for ORGANIZATION and cash considerations in a January trade. While PERSON still needs time to develop more consistency, he has Gold PERSON upside at shortstop. He covers plenty of ground at shortstop thanks to his smooth actions, quick first step and keen instincts, and his soft hands and strong arm add to his playmaking ability. His tools will play anywhere in the infield and he saw time at second and third base last year.PERSON isn't nearly as advanced offensively as he is defensively. He's a switch-hitter with promising bat speed and solid speed but hit just .232/.324/.362 in his first two pro seasons. He showed some patience in his debut but was overly aggressive last season and struck out in 33 percent of his plate appearances.

One of the best defenders available during the 2015-16 international signing period, PERSON signed for $2 million out of the ORGANIZATION. His bonus ranked as just the seventh-highest in the ORGANIZATION' global spending spree. He made his pro debut last summer in the Rookie-level ORGANIZATION, batting .228/.352/.345 but establishing his credentials as the best middle-infield defender in the system.Though he's years away from the big leagues at this point, it's not difficult to project PERSON as a possible ORGANIZATION. With his quick first step, smooth actions and advanced instincts, he covers plenty of ground at shortstop. Soft hands and a strong arm round out a complete defensive package.Once PERSON gets stronger, he could provide some offense as well. A switch-hitter, he has a patient approach and solid speed that will help him hit for average. He also has the bat speed to perhaps provide double-digit home run power as well.

Listed at 5-foot-10 and 155 pounds, PERSON had his size work against him when he signed out of the ORGANIZATION in 2017. After commanding just a $10,000 bonus, he opened eyes during his pro debut and instructional league last year. He led the Rookie-level ORGANIZATION in strikeout rate (12.3 per nine innings) and ranked second in K/BB ratio (9.9).While he lacks size, PERSON routinely pumps out 92-96 mph fastballs with sink and he touched 98 mph at age 18. His high-spin curveball combines power with depth and could give him a second plus pitch once it's more consistent. He has little experience using a changeup and his is still too firm. PERSON generates his electric fastball and curveball with a quick arm rather than effort. He easily repeats his compact delivery, allowing him to pound the strike zone. He'll need to add strength and prove he can hold up under a starter's workload, but he's definitely one of the more intriguing arms in the system.

The ORGANIZATION were aggressive in the 2017 international market, using their money to sign two of ORGANIZATION's Top 30 prospects. One was outfielder PERSON, the other was PERSON, who was ranked No. 10 on the international list and signed for $2.1 million. He was deemed advanced enough to make the jump straight to the GPE for his 2018 professional debut, and he continued to surpass expectations by earning a promotion to the GPE League at age 17 after slashing .279/.307/.421 with 19 extra-base hits in the ORGANIZATION League.A switch-hitting shortstop, PERSON projects better as a left-handed hitter, even though he had more success against southpaws in 2018. He's impressed evaluators with his combination of bat speed and raw power from a swing that works really well and should allow him to hit for both average and power. PERSON's raw pop is already showing, and he's only going to add strength and tap into it more as he matures. His outstanding defensive actions, soft hands and plus arm strength will give him a chance to stick at shortstop, where he stands to offer the most value with his bat. And if his 6-foot-3 frame fills out and he needs to move off the position, PERSON should have the offensive profile to fit at third base.PERSON looks a lot like former big leaguer PERSON in terms of body type, though he profiles as a different type of player. Overall, he has as much upside as anyone in the organization, with a real chance to become an impact player on both sides of the ball. The ORGANIZATION haven't been this excited about an international signee since PERSON joined the organization.

The ORGANIZATION love aggressively pursuing up-the-middle talent, with top prospect PERSON the shining example in the system right now. The ORGANIZATION were excited to add PERSON, ranked No. 10 on MLBPipeline.com's Top 30 International prospects list, at the start of the 2017 signing period, giving him $2.1 million to sign.There's a lot to like about PERSON's long, lean and athletic frame, with tons of physical projection to come. He has easy actions on defense, showing off soft hands and range in all directions. A steady defender with outstanding instincts, he should be given every opportunity to stick at short. There is the chance he'll outgrow the position, so a move to third could be in his future, and he's athletic enough to potentially handle an outfield corner.A switch-hitter, PERSON is a contact hitter with bat speed and a good feel to hit from both sides. He may never be a big power guy, but should grow into more extra-base ability as he matures.

The ORGANIZATION were aggressive in the 2017 international market, using their money to sign two of ORGANIZATION's Top 30 prospects. One was outfielder PERSON, the other was PERSON, who was ranked No. 10 on the international list and signed for $2.1 million. Right now, the switch-hitting shortstop is better from the left side as a hitter, something the ORGANIZATION will want him to work on as he begins his pro career. He's already showing bat speed and raw power impressive for his age, with a swing that works really well. The raw pop was showing up in the ORGANIZATION during offseason workouts and he's likely to grow into more and tap into it as he matures. He has outstanding defensive actions, with soft hands, with an above-average arm and the chance to be a plus defender overall. Even if his 6-foot-3 frame fills out and he needs to move, he could have the offensive profile to fit at third or an outfield corner.While he won't be the same type of player, PERSON looks a lot like former big leaguer PERSON in terms of body type. PERSON has the chance to be an impact player on both sides of the ball and he has as much upside as anyone in the organization. The ORGANIZATION haven't been this excited about an international signee since PERSON joined the organization.

PERSON rebounded from multiple knee surgeries earlier in his career to lead the Mid-American Conference and set a GPE record with 15 homers last spring. After signing with the ORGANIZATION for $125,000 as a 12th-rounder, he led the short-season ORGANIZATION York-Penn League in triples (12) and ranked third in GPE (.857). He came to the ORGANIZATION in January along with second baseman PERSON and catcher PERSON in exchange for J.D. PERSON and infielder PERSON Bohanek.PERSON possesses two plus tools in his raw power and speed. A left-handed hitter, he has the strength to drive the ball out of the park to all fields but most of his home runs presently come to his pull side. He'll need to improve his plate discipline to hit for average against more advanced pitching.While teams worried about his medical history, PERSON has the upside of a 20-20 player who can stay in center field. He played center for the ORGANIZATION and all three outfield spots in his pro debut, showing the quickness to cover the gaps but also a need to refine his reads and routes. His average arm works anywhere in the outfield.

After having multiple knee surgeries earlier in his career, PERSON led the Mid-American Conference and set a GPE record with 15 homers in 2018. After signing with the ORGANIZATION for $125,000 as a 12th-rounder, he won ORGANIZATION honors at their short-season GPE affiliate after ranking third in the ORGANIZATION York-Penn League with an .857 OPS in his pro debut. He changed organizations in January, going to the ORGANIZATION along with second baseman PERSON and catcher PERSON in a trade for J.D. PERSON and infielder PERSON Bohanek.PERSON offers both plus raw power and speed. He has the strength to drive the ball out the park to all fields, with most of his present power coming to his pull side, though he'll need to tighten his strike zone to hit for average against more advanced pitching. While teams were wary of his medical history, he's still quick and has the upside of a 20-20 player.Despite his quickness, PERSON is still a work in progress defensively. He played center field for the ORGANIZATION and saw duty at all three outfield spots in his first season in pro ball. He has an average arm and probably fits best in a corner.

While it surprised some when the ORGANIZATION took PERSON with the ORGANIZATION. 1 overall pick in the 2017 Draft, the toolsy infielder has shown quickly that he was worthy of being taken in the top spot. The GPE high schooler made it to the full-season GPE League in his summer debut, then performed his way up to the ORGANIZATION State League in his first full season. While he may have been fatigued down the stretch, he did homer three times in helping ORGANIZATION Myers win the ORGANIZATION title at the end of the year.A premium athlete, PERSON has impressive tools across the board combined with instincts and makeup that allow them all to play up consistently. He consistently makes hard contact with an advanced approach at the plate, drawing walks while not striking out a ton. He can drive the ball to all fields and his over-the-fence power started showing up, with more to come. His speed should allow him to continue to be a serious basestealing threat. He had a very positive year at shortstop defensively, showing a ton of improvement. There's still room for him to improve the consistency of his throws, but the ORGANIZATION think he could be an above-average defender when all is said and done.PERSON was the youngest player in the ORGANIZATION State League when he got there at age 19, so he's already well ahead of the curve. Seeing him in GPE at age 21, with a future as an All-Star level player, seems completely reasonable.

The top high school position player in the 2017 GPE class, PERSON spent most of the spring in the ORGANIZATION. 1 overall pick conversation, though for most of it, he seemed on the outside of it. As the GPE approached, PERSON' name rose to prominence and the ORGANIZATION took him and signed him for $6.725 million, saving $1 million in the process and making him the second straight prep hitter from LOCATION to go ORGANIZATION. 1 overall, following PERSON Moniak.Savings aside, PERSON had the kind of toolset that belongs at the top of the GPE. He uses his plus athleticism well on both sides of the ball. While he doesn't have the most traditional approach at the plate, he does barrel the ball up consistently. He's hit over power now, but he should grow into more pop as he matures. Even if he never becomes a big home run guy, he should have plenty of extra-base ability, sending line drives into the gaps and then using his plus speed to take extra bags, as well as steal them. That speed gives him good range in the field, both at shortstop and in center field. His arm might be a touch short for the infield position, but he'll be given every opportunity to show he can stay on the dirt.Regardless of where he ends up, PERSON has the potential to be an up-the-middle impact player. He began his pro career in the ORGANIZATION.

PERSON ranked as the top high school position player in the 2017 Draft class and often mentioned as a potential top pick, it nonetheless took some by surprise that the ORGANIZATION took PERSON. 1 overall. He signed for $6.725 million, $1 million under pick value, then repaid PERSON's faith in him by performing extremely well in the ORGANIZATION and all the way up in the full-season ORGANIZATION after a late promotion.PERSON has outstanding athleticism on both sides of the ball. When you combine that with his baseball IQ, it's easy to see a future star. At the plate, he barrels the ball up consistently and has extra-base authority to all fields, with more power to come for sure. He showed an advanced approach at the plate with the ability to draw walks, which should give him more opportunities to use his plus speed on the basepaths. There were some questions about whether PERSON would be a shortstop long term, or need to move to center, but he has good range and hands and might have just enough arm to stay on the dirt. The ORGANIZATION plan to keep him there, at least for the time being.PERSON will be an impact up-the-middle player in either case. After his strong pro debut that saw the prepster jump on a slightly faster track by getting his feet wet in GPE, watching his full-season encore should be a treat.

The highest-priced position player in the ORGANIZATION' 2013 international class, PERSON signed for $600,000 out of the ORGANIZATION. He came to the GPE for his pro debut the following summer and struggled. He nevertheless earned a promotion to low Class A at age 18 this season, and he went 6-for-6 in his first game and emerged as one of PERSON's best prospects.After doing nothing at the plate in 2014, PERSON has surprised the ORGANIZATION' new front-office regime with his pop this season. He's not a big guy, but he's deceptively strong and drives the ball with a quick, compact right-handed swing. He makes repeated hard contact, though he'll need to tighten his strike zone. While PERSON believes PERSON can stay at shortstop, scouts outside the organization aren't as optimistic. He has great hands and solid arm strength, but his quickness and actions are merely average. If he loses even half a step as he fills out, he'll have to slide over to second base.

PERSON didn't become a full-time starter at ORGANIZATION until last spring, when he shook off flexor inflammation that sidelined him for the first three weeks to become the Pac-12 Conference's pitcher of the year. He ranked second in ORGANIZATION Division I in hit rate (5.0 per nine innings) and ORGANIZATION (0.83) and fourth in GPE (1.44), finishing his college career with a 20-2 record and 2.11 GPE. The ORGANIZATION drafted him in the second round and signed him for $1,469,900.PERSON thrives by commanding and sequencing four pitches. His fastball parks at 90-93 mph and reaches 95, playing better than its velocity because it has a high spin rate and riding life that gets swings and misses up in the strike zone. His best offerings are a mid-80s slider with two-plane break and a changeup with fade, and he also mixes in a usable curveball to give hitters a different look.Though he's small for a starter, PERSON exerts little effort and uses a high-three-quarters delivery to create angle and plane on his pitches. He pounds the strike zone and limits his mistakes. Unlike many of GPE' recent early-round selections, he stands out more for his floor than his ceiling and is a good bet to become a No. 4 starter.

A known quantity heading into the 2016 Draft as a GPE PERSON catcher, PERSON helped his stock out late by going off offensively during the ORGANIZATION World Series, landing in the eighth round. He continued to show power in his pro debut, hitting 10 homers in the ORGANIZATION League.His pop from the left side of the plate is his best offensive tool and he was able to get to it fairly consistently with PERSON, even hitting four long balls in August as he tired out a bit. There is some swing and miss to his game, striking out in 34 percent of his at-bats during his pro debut. PERSON broke his thumb during his GPE Jac season, so he didn't get to catch down the stretch, but he played regularly behind the plate with PERSON and is eager to show he can stick there. He does have a strong arm, but the rest of his defensive game needs refinement.If he can remain a catcher, PERSON could be, at the very least, a lefty power-hitting backup. He might be athletic enough to handle an outfield corner or a move to first, where his bat could profile well.

ORGANIZATION hit 26 homers as ORGANIZATION's catcher during his sophomore and junior seasons, leading the ORGANIZATION with 16 in 2018. That led to the Twins taking him in the second round, ahead of where most of the industry had him, thinking those offensive skills would translate. If his pro debut is any indication, the Twins were right as ORGANIZATION dominated the GPE League to earn a promotion to full-season PERSON, where he capped off a successful first summer of pro ball by hitting two postseason homers.A big, strong backstop, ORGANIZATION is definitely a power over hit kind of offensive performer, though his solid approach at the plate allowed him to tap into that power consistently during his debut. If he can continue to manage the strike zone, he could have plus game power when all is said and done. There were questions about ORGANIZATION' ability to stick behind the plate, but the Twins were pleased with his receiving skills and think his blocking will be fine as well, with an arm that plays a tick above average.A physics major at ORGANIZATION, ORGANIZATION gets high marks for his intelligence and his makeup. Developing catchers, especially those taken out of high school, can be a difficult task. But ORGANIZATION's all-around skills in GPE caught the eyes of many scouts this past spring. A 10th-round Draft pick by the Indians out of the GPE prep ranks in 2016, GPE, who signed for $125,000, showed advanced hitting ability during his pro debut and continued to do so the following year in the Class A Short-Season New York-Penn League, where he owned a .300/.328/.467 slash line when the ORGANIZATION dealt him and lefty PERSON to GPE for reliever PERSON at the July Trade Deadline. It translates to good bat speed and better-than-expected power at the plate, with GPE showing he can consistently impact the baseball. Those qualities, along with his feel for controlling the zone, give him a chance to be at least an average hitter, with power that should play in games more often as he becomes more physical and improves his pitch recognition and selectivity. A plus runner, GPE's 44 steals in 2018 were good for a share of third place in the ORGANIZATION, but he will need to improve his reads and jumps after he was thrown out 16 times, the second-highest total in the circuit. There's first-division regular upside if it all clicks for GPE, and he also has a fairly high floor with his blend of hitting ability, patience and speed at an up-the-middle position.

A year after PERSON was an interesting GPE high school prospect who signed an over-pick-value deal with the ORGANIZATION as a fourth-round selection, younger brother PERSON followed on the same path. The outfielder has an outstanding and smooth swing and showed the ability to make consistent contact against some of the better prep arms in the country. GPE received the largest bonus paid in the ORGANIZATION' 2014 international class, signing for $500,000 out of the ORGANIZATION. He posted the second-worst ORGANIZATION (.585) and walk rate (6 percent) in the GPE League in 2018, signs that he was in over his head, but he also was dealing with a medical issue and has looked better this season now that it has been resolved.GPE has some of the better bat-to-ball skills in the system, but his overly aggressive approach leads to too much weak contact and too few walks. He won't find success at the plate until he starts to work counts and find pitches to drive rather than trying to avoid hitting with two strikes. He shows raw power in batting practice and could have close to average pop if he starts turning his right-handed swing loose more often in game action.An intelligent player with strong makeup, GPE is capable of making adjustments at the plate. Despite fringy speed, he gets good jumps and covers ground in right field. He has a strong arm but needs more defensive consistency after totaling 19 errors in his first two years in full-season ball.

GPE's $500,000 bonus was the largest the ORGANIZATION paid out during the 2014-15 international signing period. The ORGANIZATION opened eyes by batting .340/.364/.522 in the Rookie-level PERSON during his 2016 GPE debut, then skipped a level to low Class A at age 19 last year. Though GPE ORGANIZATION pitchers took advantage of his ultra-aggressive approach, he rallied to hit .352/.366/.535 in the final six weeks.GPE has a feel for hitting well beyond his years, showing the ability to repeatedly barrel balls and make adjustments. He almost puts the bat on the ball too easily, walking in just 3 percent of his plate appearances during his first three pro seasons, and will do more damage once he learns to work counts and not worry about hitting with two strikes. While his hitting ability has more upside than his power, he already shows the potential for average pop and might have more if he turns his right-handed swing loose more often during games.His instincts extend to defense as well. PERSON has fringy speed, he gets good jumps in right field and has a strong, accurate arm. He also gets high marks for his makeup, impressing with his enthusiasm and his desire to learn GPE quickly.

The ORGANIZATION gave GPE the biggest bonus in their 2014-15 international pool, signing him for $500,000 out of the ORGANIZATION. He broke into pro ball with a respectable performance in the Rookie-level ORGANIZATION in 2015, then opened eyes when he came to the GPE last year. He ranked second in GPE (35), third in slugging (.522) and fourth in batting (.340) in the Rookie-level PERSON's still early because GPE is just getting started, but he could wind up hitting for the best combination of average and power among ORGANIZATION farmhands. His biggest need at this point is to be more patient and work deeper counts to get better pitches to punish, as low Class A pitchers have exploited his aggressiveness this year.Though GPE is just a fringy runner, his instincts help him play above his speed in the outfield. He gets good jumps in right field and has an accurate arm whose strength draws grades ranging from average to plus. PERSON also loves his makeup, praising his enthusiasm and desire to learn GPE quickly.

Ranked No. 16 on ORGANIZATION's list of the Top 30 international prospects for the 2018-19 period, PERSON showed some of the best pure velocity in his class at age 16, before signing with PERSON for $2.6 million in November. PERSON's velocity is rare in any market and not surprisingly, some scouts wonder if he will be able to command the high velocity on a consistent basis. The skill, however, is extraordinary and offers a foundation for future development.

There has been a decent amount of pitching from GPE to impact the big leagues in recent years, with PERSON and PERSON the biggest examples. He can also really spin his breaking ball, with a power curve that could eventually be better than average. His changeup remains a work in progress. There is also much work to be done in terms of his command if he wants to have any chance to start, though his strike-throwing improved from his pro debut in the ORGANIZATION in 2017 and his move to the U.S. The ORGANIZATION will let him start for the time being, but seeing him approach triple digits coming out of the bullpen could be fun to watch eventually.

When the ORGANIZATION signed PERSON for $150,000 in July 2016 out of GPE, they knew he would likely be a long-term project. There could be more in the tank as he continues to fill out his big frame. PERSON has a good feel to spin his curveball and his changeup continues to develop. The teenager still has work to do with his overall command, but he did cut his walk rate down in the ORGANIZATION in 2018 compared to his pro debut in the ORGANIZATION League a year prior. A product of GPE's ORGANIZATION, PERSON made himself known to scouts with his cannon arm and athleticism behind the plate. That, along with his potential to hit for power, earned him an above-slot bonus of $450,000 from the A's in 2017 after they drafted him in the fifth round.PERSON's defense is his calling card. He moves much better than his stocky frame suggests, with plenty of agility and lateral quickness that aids him as a blocker. But it's his well-above-average arm strength that draws the most raves, and scouts regarded it to be among the best in the class at the position. Offensively, PERSON offers raw power from the right side of the plate, albeit with an overly aggressive approach that he'll need to tone down in order to hit for average in the professional ranks.Viewed as somewhat as a lottery ticket due to his impressive tools but overall rawness, PERSON has the ingredients to develop into a glove-first catcher at the highest level, though not without first making considerable gains on both sides of the ball.

After tying PERSON's freshman record with eight saves in 2016, PERSON moved into the rotation as a sophomore and won LOCATION Pitcher of the Year honors. He posted even better numbers in 2018, went to the ORGANIZATION in the second round and signed for $1.5 million. If PERSON makes it to the big leagues, he'll equal 6-foot-11 PERSON as the tallest player in ORGANIZATION history.PERSON's low-80s knuckle-curve with depth headlines his four-pitch repertoire. His fastball velocity has increased from the high 80s as a high school senior to the low 90s in college, and he touched 96 mph during fall practice heading into 2018. PERSON also exhibits feel for a changeup and will mix in a slider/cutter to show hitters something different.PERSON has outstanding body control for such a tall pitcher, which enables him to repeat his delivery and throw all four of his offerings for strikes. He's not overpowering, but his size creates unusual plane and angle that make his pitches more difficult to hit. PERSON's stuff has improved as he has added strength, and there's still room for more muscle on his lanky frame.

If PERSON can make it to the big leagues, he'll equal 6-foot-11 PERSON as the tallest pitcher in ORGANIZATION history. He compiled an impressive college rÃ©sumÃ©, setting a GPE freshman record with eight saves in 2016, winning LOCATION Pitcher of the Year honors as a sophomore and posting the best numbers of his career as a junior. PERSON on tight pitch counts after signing for $1.5 million as a second-rounder, he could advance quickly once the ORGANIZATION turn him ORGANIZATION doesn't fit the protoype of a tall pitcher because his polish stands out much more than his power. His fastball sits at 91-94 mph and peaks at 97, with the unusual angle he creates with his extra-large frame more notable than his velocity. He has outstanding body control for someone his size, allowing him to repeat his delivery with ease and throw strikes with all of his offerings.PERSON's best pitch is his low-80s knuckle-curve, which earns plus grades from some evaluators. He also uses a cutter/slider to give him a harder breaking ball and shows feel for a changeup. While he still could add some strength to his lanky frame, his floor stands out more than his ceiling and he's likely to settle in as a No. 4 starter.

The ORGANIZATION went for sheer upside with the selection of ORGANIZATION in the fourth round out of ORGANIZATION (ORGANIZATION, GPE) High. At 6-foot-7, 205 pounds, he attracted as much if not more interest as a right-handed pitcher than he did as an outfielder. However, ORGANIZATION' raw power from the left side of the plate was too good to pass up and intrigued GPE enough to give him an above-slot bonus of $600,000 as its fourth-round pick.ORGANIZATION' size and physicality gives him big-time power potential, as he's already capable of hitting tape-measure home runs. But as is the case with many young hitters similar in size, his swing has considerable length and will need to be cleaned up as he develops. ORGANIZATION is athletic for his size and moves well in the outfield, while his plus arm that produced low-90s fastball off the mound in high school is a clean fit in right field. ORGANIZATION draws physical comparisons to GPE slugger PERSON based on his size, and the ORGANIZATION hope that the teenager can develop into a similar offensive force. Should things not work out for ORGANIZATION as a position player, his size and potentially power arm give the organization an interesting fallback option.

A two-sport star as a Utah high schooler, PERSON was an all-state safety but also tore the anterior cruciate ligament in his knee playing football as a junior. He made a full recovery and signed for a well over-slot $1 million as a third-rounder in 2017, becoming the state's highest-drafted prepster since GPE first-rounder PERSON in 2005. He has developed slowly, repeating PERSON ball and not making his full-season debut until 2019, but he started to take off when his control began to improve this June.PERSON's best pitch is his curveball, which he commands better than his fastball and sits in the upper 70s with 12-to-6 break. His quick arm produces low-90s heaters that top out at 96 with running action. He has improved his changeup since turning pro, giving him the makings of an average third pitch.He elicits comparisons to a young PERSON, who also had trouble locating his pitches early in his pro career. PERSON is athletic and started throwing more strikes once he developed a more consistent tempo with his delivery. He throws with effort and still has to prove he can repeat his mechanics over a full season, but he's young and PERSON will give him plenty of time to develop as a starter.

PERSON didn't log a lot of time on the mound as a Utah prepster because he divided his time between two sports as an all-state safety and tore the anterior cruciate ligament in his knee playing football in the fall of 2015, costing him most of his junior baseball season. He still became the state's highest-drafted high schooler since 2005 Cubs first-rounder PERSON, going in the third round in June and signing for a well over-slot $1 million. PERSON's 2017 Utah player of the year, he had committed to GPE Young.When he's at his best, PERSON will flash a plus fastball and curveball and look like a young PERSON. He usually operates at 90-92 mph with some armside run on his heater, but he already has reached 96 mph and should have more consistent velocity as he gets stronger. He locates his upper-70s curveball better than his fastball but sometimes struggles to get ahead in the count to set up his breaking ball.PERSON sells his changeup with deceptive arm speed, giving him the potential for an average third offering. He has the athleticism to repeat his delivery and provide more strikes, but he's still in the process of learning how to do so. The ORGANIZATION excel at polishing up young pitchers, and PERSON gives them a quality left arm to work with.

PERSON divided his time between two sports as a Utah high schooler, earning all-state honors as a safety in football but also tearing the anterior cruciate ligament in his knee on the gridiron in the fall of 2015. He still became the state's highest-drafted prepster since 2005 Cubs first-rounder PERSON, signing for a well over-slot $1 million in the third round last June. He's the type of raw mound prospect whom the ORGANIZATION excel at polishing.PERSON elicits some Matt Moore comparisons because he'll showcase a plus fastball and curveball on his best days. He currently pitches at 90-92 mph with nice running action on his fastball, and he already has touched 96 and should gain more consistent velocity as he gets stronger. He actually commands his upper-70s curve better than his heater but currently struggles to get ahead in the count to set up his breaker.Though his changeup is in its nascent stages, PERSON maintains his arm speed when he throws it. Learning to locate his fastball is No. 1 on his to-do list, and while he has the athleticism to make it happen, he also has a lot of effort in his delivery. He could wind up as a reliever in the long run but PERSON will give him plenty of time to make it as a starter.

PERSON spent his first two college seasons at GSP (N.C.) JC as a light-hitting shortstop and worked just six innings on the mound as a sophomore. After transferring to GPE, he showcased two potential plus pitches and what one scouting director called the best delivery in the 2019 Draft. PERSON's power stuff, along with the limited mileage on his right arm, put him firmly on the ORGANIZATION' radar, and they made him the highest-drafted player in GPE history -- surpassing PERSON, who went 44th overall in 1986 -- by taking him with the ORGANIZATION. 40 overall pick.PERSON has an effortless arm action and delivery, looking very natural on the mound despite his inexperience. The ball comes out of his hand very easily, with his fastball topping out at 98 mph and usually ranging from 91-95. His slider is his best secondary offering, a plus pitch in the mid 80s at its best but also still inconsistent.As would be expected for a newcomer to the mound, PERSON still needs polish. His loopy curveball and his changeup are less reliable than his slider but can become at least average pitches with more experience. He didn't dominate against so-so competition in the Big GPE, in part because his control and command need work, but he has the athleticism to make the needed adjustments.

Ranked in the top half of ORGANIZATION's Top 30 ORGANIZATION list as the 2015-16 international signing period opened, PERSON, his tools and his projectable body received $2.25 million to sign that July. He immediately showed his prodigious power, along with a penchant for striking out, during his GPE debut in '16. Both were on display in his '18 full-season debut as he hit 31 homers and struck out 131 times just 94 games. His season was cut short by a freakish thumb injury, but not before he showed off his pop with an opposite-field blast in the ORGANIZATION. He was struggling with the move to the ORGANIZATION in 2019 when the injury bug hit again, this time a fractured hand keeping him out of the lineup for over a month.PERSON has as much raw power as just about anybody in GPE League baseball, with some evaluators saying putting an 80 on the 20-to-80 scouting scale on it would not be outlandish. The big question is whether he can make enough contact to continue to get to that power in games. When he's going well, PERSON lays off breaking balls early in count, but he has a very high chase rate out of the strike zone early in at-bats. There's always going to be some swing and miss to his game, but even some modest improvement in his approach should allow him to be a middle-of-the-order run producer.Blessed with one of the strongest arms in the system, PERSON has the chance to truly fit the right-field profile in the future. Moving to more pitching-friendly parks and facing more advanced pitching should provide a good challenge for the 20-year-old.

PERSON had some of the best all-around tools in the 2015 international signing class, earning him a $2.25 million bonus out of the ORGANIZATION. As a possible center fielder with electric bat speed and arm strength, he has one of the highest ceilings among Royals prospects. Even before PERSON made his pro debut, some club officials said that he might have the quickest bat in the system. He can absolutely crush balls in batting practice, though some scouts wonder how his aggressive approach will translate in pro ball.PERSON has solid athleticism and speed, giving him a chance to stay in center. If he loses a step as he matures physically, his cannon arm will allow him to transition to right field. If he approaches his offensive potential, he'll have no trouble profiling offensively in right field as well.

A Dominican with one of the best all-around toolsets available during the 2015-16 international signing period, PERSON turned pro for $2,250,000. He led the ORGANIZATION with eight homers in his 2016 pro debut as one of three 17-year-old regulars in the Rookie-level circuit. He continued to hit for power as one of the youngest players in his league (the Rookie-level Appalachian) last year and will make the jump to full-season ball at age 19 in 2018.Though PERSON and PERSON are more refined, PERSON has the highest ceiling among GPE prospects as well as the most raw power and the strongest arm. With his electric bat speed, strength and leverage in his right-handed swing, he hits tape-measure home runs and can smack opposite-field blasts without squaring the ball up. He'll need to modify his approach and improve his pitch recognition after striking out in 34 percent of his plate appearances in his first two pro seasons.PERSON has solid speed, but has yet to turn it loose much on the bases. After spending part of his debut in center field, he moved to right field in 2017 and has the tools to be an asset there, starting with a bazooka arm. With his combination of tools and physical presence, he draws comparisons to PERSON and PERSON.

One of the toolsiest players available during the 2015-16 international period, PERSON signed for $2.25 million out of the ORGANIZATION. He spent most of his 2016 pro debut in the Rookie-level PERSON, where he was one of a handful of 17-year-old regulars and tied for the lead with eight homers. Though he also topped the ORGANIZATION with 73 strikeouts, he cut his whiff rate and improved his batting average in each of his three months there.PERSON might have the most raw power in the ORGANIZATION' system. He's so strong and his right-handed swing is so quick and has so much leverage that he can crush 450-foot homers and even drive the ball out of the park to the opposite field without fully squaring it up. His approach is extremely aggressive and he'll need to improve his pitch recognition, though he shows some willingness to accept walks when pitchers won't challenge him. Already a physical presence at such a young age, PERSON draws comparisons to PERSON and PERSON from club officials. He's an average runner out of the batter's box but quicker underway, which gives him enough range to play center field for now. He's likely to wind up in right field, where his cannon arm will fit nicely.

PERSON was a two-way standout at ORGANIZATION (GPE) High, though it was the promise he showed on the mound that led some teams to peg him as a potential top-10 pick in 2017. The ORGANIZATION nabbed the ORGANIZATION commit at ORGANIZATION. 12, gave him $4.1 million, a bit over-pick value, then sent him to the ORGANIZATION for his pro debut. He was pitching well in the ORGANIZATION when the ORGANIZATION sent him to the ORGANIZATION in August 2018 as the player to be named in the ORGANIZATION trade.With his high-octane arsenal and remaining physical projection, PERSON is the definition of a high-ceiling pitching prospect. Having scrapped his two-seam fastball in favor of a four-seamer, PERSON consistently sits in the mid-90s and can reach back for triple digits, throwing his heater with late, riding life. He previously threw both a curveball and slider that often bled together, but now utilizes only the slider -- a plus offering that registers in the mid-to-upper 80s with devastating action that helps him miss bats. His changeup gives him another potential Major League-average pitch.While he has some violence in his delivery, PERSON has the athleticism and clean arm action needed to make significant gains with his control and command. PERSON will be key for PERSON, and he's in good hands in a ORGANIZATION organization that has a strong record of developing projectable young arms, with 2018 ORGANIZATION Young winner PERSON representing their latest success story.

A talented two-way player from the GPE high school ranks who competed in showcase home run derbies, it was PERSON's right arm teams coveted in the first round of the 2017 Draft, with his name popping up in top 10 conversations. The ORGANIZATION gave him $4.1 million, a touch over pick value, to sign him away from ORGANIZATION, allowing him to join fellow ORGANIZATION product Ke'Bryan Hayes in the system.PERSON had perhaps the deepest arsenal among high school pitchers in the 2017 Draft class. His fastball kicked up a notch to 92-96 mph with a peak of 98 this spring, and he has shown the ability to run and sink it while maintaining its velocity throughout a game. His 84-88 mph cutter generates a lot of swings and misses, and he also can turn the cutter into more of a true slider, spin a curveball that's a distinctly different pitch and unveil a changeup that could develop into a solid offering.PERSON's athleticism and clean delivery should yield consistent strikes, though he ran into control issues when he fell in love with his secondary pitches and didn't work off his fastball enough. Scouts rave about his makeup as well as his stuff and physicality, with the chance to develop into a frontline starter.

PERSON was a two-way standout at ORGANIZATION in GPE who jumped into top 10 pick conversations for his pitching ability. The ORGANIZATION nabbed him at 12 and gave him $4.1 million, a bit over pick value, to sign him away from ORGANIZATION, joining fellow Concordia product Ke'Bryan Hayes in the organization and making his brief pro debut in the ORGANIZATION. PERSON was dealt to the ORGANIZATION in August when he was announced as the Player to be Named Later in the trade for PERSON has a combination of deep repertoire and projection that gives him a very high ceiling. His fastball velocity picked up in his senior year. He'll sit at 92-96 mph and can reach back for 98 mph, with the ability to run and sink it while not losing velocity deep into his starts. He can miss bats with a plus cutter that he can turn into a true slider, and he also spins a distinctly different curveball. His changeup gives him another potential Major League average pitch. A solid athlete, PERSON should be able to find the strike zone consistently as he refines his delivery.Patience will be key for PERSON, and the ORGANIZATION know a thing or two about developing young pitching. With room to add strength to his athletic frame, PERSON could slowly move up the right-handed pitching prospect ranks as he settles in to his pro career.

A late bloomer in high school, ORGANIZATION opted for GPE instead of the ORGANIZATION, who had taken him in the 26th round in 2015. PERSON surgery wiped out his freshman year, but he came back and pitched well as the ORGANIZATION' Saturday starter. ORGANIZATION's ORGANIZATION stock surged as ORGANIZATION's ace during the spring, as he ranked second in the nation in strikeouts per nine innings (14.2) and garnered honors as one of 40 players named to ORGANIZATION.
