Perhaps the hardest thrower among college hurlers in his class, ORGANIZATION consistently touched triple digits with his fastball during the spring while sitting at 97-100 on a regular basis. The left-hander complements his dynamic heater with a plus changeup, a pitch he throws with good arm speed that features a ton of late drop to it. ORGANIZATION's slider gives him a third at least average pitch.While ORGANIZATION's strikeout rate has been really high, his walk rate has been as well. That, plus a delivery that features a fairly big recoil, has led some evaluators to project him as a future reliever -- albeit one who could get to the big leagues in a hurry. But with a loose and very athletic frame, ORGANIZATION might be able to get away with those mechanics. He's elicited some PERSON comps, with some scouts thinking he has better stuff now, at least with the fastball, than PERSON did in his ORGANIZATION year.

ORGANIZATION spurned the ORGANIZATION as a 26th-rounder in 2015 and honored his commitment to GPE, only to have his freshman year wiped out by PERSON surgery. He emerged as one of more interesting pitching prospects in the 2018 ORGANIZATION as a junior by ranking second in the nation in strikeouts per nine innings (14.2), though a regression in command cost him some traction late in the spring. He still became a first-round pick in June, going to the ORGANIZATION with the ORGANIZATION. 31 overall pick, and received a slightly above-slot bonus of $2,230,100. ORGANIZATION impressed during his brief pro debut, making four scoreless starts during which he fanned 13 and allowed three hits across seven innings. ORGANIZATION's ORGANIZATION stock took off early last spring with reports of the left-hander's fastball reaching 100 mph. It set an unfair standard for his future outings, and some teams were turned off when he failed to achieve the same elite velocity in subsequent starts. That being said, ORGANIZATION does throw exceptionally hard, as he'll sit 92-95 mph and reach back for a few extra ticks. ORGANIZATION's slider, though inconsistent, is an above-average pitch and complements his heater nicely, and scouts believe that his upper-80s changeup will be at least average once he develops better feel. ORGANIZATION's high strikeout rate in college came with a high walk rate. That, plus a delivery that features a fairly big recoil, has led some evaluators to project him as a future reliever -- albeit one who could get to the big leagues in a hurry. But with a loose and very athletic frame, ORGANIZATION might be able to get away with those mechanics, and the ORGANIZATION are committed to developing him as a starter.

GPE's PERSON was the top catcher, and overall player, in the 2019 GPE, and went No. 1 overall as expected. PERSON, who shared catching duties with him on the GPE collegiate national team last summer, also landed in the top 10. He recovered from a rough sophomore season at the plate by performing better as a junior despite breaking the hamate in his left hand and rushing back after just three weeks. He homered three times and set an ORGANIZATION Division I tournament record with 11 RBIs in one game two days before the GPE, then was taken ninth overall by the ORGANIZATION, signing for a below pick value bonus of $3,997,500.PERSON would have been a first-round pick on his defense alone. He has a cannon arm that can produce 1.7-second pop times in workouts and 1.8-second clockings during games, and he used it to erase 70 percent of basestealers as sophomore. The 2018 Rawlings/ABCA Gold Glove recipient as the best defensive catcher in college baseball, he's a quality receiver who's more agile and athletic than most at his position. He also has the strong leadership skills teams desire in a backstop.Even when PERSON slumped last year, he still made consistent contact and doesn't have any glaring flaws in his right-handed stroke. It was more a matter of trying to do too much at the plate rather than letting his solid to plus raw power play without selling out for home runs. He's a below-average runner but quicker than a typical catcher.

PERSON drew interest as a right-hander with a low-90s fastball as an amateur in GPE, but he preferred to hit and signed with the ORGANIZATION as a third baseman for $200,000 in 2015. They also signed his brother Shendrik two years later but broke up the siblings when they included PERSON as the player to be named in the ORGANIZATION trade with the ORGANIZATION last summer.PERSON is still a work in progress offensively but has the upside of at least an average hitter with plus power. He has a strong and still-projectable 6-foot-4 build and shows pop to all fields, though he needs to adjust his right-handed stroke to get more balls in the air after posting an extreme 1.5 groundout/airout ratio in his first three seasons. He controls the strike zone well and makes repeated contact.Though he's athletic for his size, PERSON could wind up as a below-average runner once he fills out his big frame. He moves well and has a big arm at third base, though he has been an erratic defender early in his career. If he can't become more consistent or he slows down too much, he could wind up at first base.

Signed out of the GPE for $50,000 back in July 2015, GPE spent his first two pro seasons in the ORGANIZATION, faring much better in his return to the level in '17. That success prompted the ORGANIZATION to challenge GPE with an assignment to the Rookie-level Appalachian League for his GPE debut, and he responded by hitting for both average and power against advanced pitching, all while reaching base more than 40 percent of the time. An athletic, 6-foot-4 switch-hitter, GPE has shown a very advanced approach at the plate for a prospect his age, drawing a ton of walks and keeping his strikeout rate relatively low. With his mix of bat speed and strength, GPE has the physical tools needed to develop an above-average bat, though some evaluators do question his overall feel to hit, because his swing mechanics are inconsistent. He has plus raw power that he's already starting to get to, and given GPE's size, it's easy to dream on more as he matures.Defensively, GPE has shown the hands, footwork and instincts -- not to mention the plus arm strength -- to potentially stay at shortstop, though the ORGANIZATION played him more at second base in 2019, while also giving him reps at the hot corner. Regardless of where he ends up on the defensive spectrum, GPE should have the power-over-hit offensive profile and necessary defensive skills to be an impactful regular.

Signed out of the GPE for $50,000 back in July 2015, PERSON has taken a little while to get going. He spent two summers in the ORGANIZATION, and a huge step forward in his second season prepared him to make the leap to the GPE League for his GPE debut in '18.An athletic, switch-hitting, 6-foot-4 shortstop, PERSON has shown a very advanced approach at the plate for a prospect his age, drawing a ton of walks and keeping his strikeout rate relatively low. He has excellent bat speed and strength, and could be an above-average hitter in the future. PERSON has hit from both sides of the plate, though his left-handed swing might be a touch better. He is starting to tap into his raw power, and given his size, it's easy to dream on more as he matures. While he's big for a shortstop with average speed, he has shown the hands, footwork and instincts -- not to mention enough arm -- to potentially stay at the position.PERSON has a while before he reaches his ceiling, and the ORGANIZATION will have to continue to be patient, but his tools are exciting and it looks like he's starting to tap into his considerable upside.

A strong showing on the summer showcase circuit put PERSON firmly on the GPE prospect map, looking for sure like a top-three-rounds pick. He didn't back that up during his senior year, causing some teams to back off. The ORGANIZATION weren't one of them, remembering his summer dominance when they took him in the second round. They gave PERSON an above-pick-value bonus of $1.85 million to sign him away from his GPE commitment, then watched him dominate over five scoreless outings in the ORGANIZATION and finish his pro debut as a 17 year old in the GPE. After a strong start to his full-season debut in 2019, PERSON was packaged with PERSON to the ORGANIZATION in July in the ORGANIZATION Stroman trade. After running his fastball up to 95 mph during the summer, PERSON sat more around 89-92 as a senior. But with his size, arm speed and athleticism, it was seemingly only a matter of time until velocity returned, and he spent his pro debut sitting around 93, while touching 97 with a riding fastball. PERSON's quick arm from a high-three-quarters slot helps him snap off a sharp, top-to-bottom curveball that shows plus potential, and he already demonstrates some feel for turning over an effective changeup.PERSON has a good delivery and repeats it well, but he'll need to show he can maintain his stuff deep into his outings and handle the rigors of a full season to remain a starter long term. There's certainly less concern about that after his impressive pro debut, and it'll now be up to the ORGANIZATION to further the young right-hander's development as he works to become a big league starter.

A strong showing on last summer's showcase circuit put PERSON firmly on the GPE prospect map, looking for sure like a top-three-rounds pick. He didn't back that up during his senior year, causing some teams to back off. The ORGANIZATION weren't one of them, remembering his summer dominance when they took him in the second round and giving him an above-pick-value bonus of $1.85 million to sign him away from his GPE commitment.Over the summer, PERSON ran his fastball up to 95 mph and showed three-pitch potential. During his senior year, he sat more around 89-92 mph with his fastball, though scouts still loved his arm speed and athleticism. His curve wasn't quite as sharp as it was over the summer and he didn't used his changeup as much during his high school season.With a good delivery featuring a high-three-quarters arm slot, PERSON repeats his delivery well. He'll need to show he can maintain his stuff deep into his outings to show he can remain a starter long-term. A talented two-way player in high school, the ORGANIZATION hope a focus on the mound will help him to put it all together in the future.

PERSON had signed with the ORGANIZATION in 2015 for $300,000 and made his official pro debut the next summer in the ORGANIZATION. But he was declared a free agent after just 17 games as PERSON voided the contracts of his and four others because of signing infractions. The ORGANIZATION signed him quickly for $750,000, and he finished off the summer in the ORGANIZATION. He had a solid GPE debut in the ORGANIZATION in 2017 and made the jump to full season ball in 2018.PERSON has a long way to go, but the tools are there for him to potentially be an impact player. He has outstanding bat-to-ball skills and makes a ton of contact. He doesn't strike out much, but he also doesn't draw many walks. Refinement of his approach will help his overall game, with the chance to be an above-average or better hitter. He can spray line drives all over the field and there could be more power to come as he adds strength. His speed should play on both sides of the ball, and he could play center field for a long time with at least an average arm.There is considerable upside for PERSON, though the ORGANIZATION will have to be patient in helping him get there. If it all clicks, he could be a dynamic everyday center fielder. At worst, he could be a valuable fourth outfielder in the big leagues.

Back in July 2015, PERSON was an intriguing prospect coming out of Venezuela who signed with the ORGANIZATION for $300,000. After beginning his career in that organization in the ORGANIZATION, he was declared a free agent by PERSON because of signing infractions involving him and four other prospects. The ORGANIZATION signed him quickly and he's been progressing methodically, making his GPE debut in '17 and getting his first taste of full-season ball in '18.As with most young hitters, PERSON still needs to work on refining his overall approach, but he already brings to the table the ability to make consistent contact, a knack for line drives and rarely striking out. He is starting to get more physical and is adding strength, so there is some hope there will be more power to come, though it's unlikely he'll ever be a huge home run threat. A solid athlete, PERSON runs well and has the instincts to steal some bases. He also has shown the ability to handle center field capably, sometimes showing plus defense out there, with a strong arm.If his bat can continue to develop and he can stay in center field, PERSON has the chance to be a solid big league regular. If not, his floor might be as an excellent contributor as a fourth outfielder.

PERSON may have been an under-the-radar signing back in 2015 when the ORGANIZATION nabbed him for just $35,000. But starting with his GPE debut in '16, when he won the ORGANIZATION ERA crown, he's been raising his prospect value exponentially. The only thing that's slowed him down has been the injury bug, with elbow inflammation shutting him down in early June in 2018, though that didn't stop the Marlins from insisting PERSON be included in the package they received for trading J.T. PERSON to GSP in February.When healthy, PERSON has perhaps the best combination of electric stuff and command of any pitcher in the ORGANIZATION. He might appear undersized at six-feet tall, but he's deceptively strong, with an athletic and repeatable delivery. PERSON throws both a two- and four-seam fastball, the former thrown with a lot of sink to get ground-ball outs and the latter cranked up to triple digits at times. Not only can PERSON maintain velocity deep into starts, the fastball plays up because of movement and his plus command of the pitch. He can add and subtract from his breaking ball, and seeing it as a future plus strikeout pitch isn't out of the question. He shows good feel for his changeup as well, giving him the chance to have at least three above-average offerings.PERSON's workload has been limited, partially because of understandable caution and partially because of injury. A healthy and complete 2019 should help get him ready for an eventual career at or near the top of a big league rotation.

Some international signees are seven-figure bonus babies. Others are diamonds in the rough given a much lower dollar figure to start their pro careers. PERSON fits into the latter category, signing for just $35,000. After beginning his career in 2015 in the ORGANIZATION, he jumped on everyone's radars when he led the ORGANIZATION with a 0.50 ERA during his GPE debut in 2016.A one-time infielder, the right-hander has truly taken to the mound. He repeats his delivery well and throws a lot of strikes, especially for a teenager. He'll throw his fastball consistently into the mid 90s and can reach back for more, throwing the heater with excellent movement to miss bats and generate groundball outs. His secondary stuff -- a curve and changeup -- has the chance to be at least PERSON average. He fields his position well, and while he is just 6-foot, his strength and athleticism point to a future as a starter.Considering he's only been pitching for about two years, and that his GPE debut went better than anyone could have expected, he raised expectations quite a bit for 2017.

PERSON signed for just $35,000 and immediately looked like a steal as he won the ORGANIZATION crown in the ORGANIZATION for his GPE debut in 2016, then dominated in his first taste of full-season ball and earned a promotion up to the ORGANIZATION State League just after his 19th birthday for an encore. His race to GSP was slowed somewhat by elbow inflammation in 2018, and a sore collarbone cost him a chance to make up innings in the ORGANIZATION. In February 2019, the ORGANIZATION sent him, PERSON, PERSON and international pool money to the ORGANIZATION in exchange for J.T. Realmuto.It's hard not to get excited about PERSON's combination of pure stuff and feel for pitching. While he is just six feet tall, he's strong and athletic with a repeatable delivery that points to a future in a rotation. He can hit triple digits with his four-seam fastball and also features a two-seamer with a ton of sinking action. His fastball is better than its pure velocity because of its movement as well as his ability to command it extremely well. His secondary stuff continues to improve, with a breaking ball he adds and subtracts from and a changeup he shows a good feel for at times. Both will flash above-average to plus, and given his overall feel for pitching, there is confidence both will get there consistently in time.PERSON has one of the highest ceilings among PERSON pitchers and possesses all the ingredients needed to headline a big league rotation. A healthy and uninterrupted campaign in 2019 will be crucial in helping him to reach that potential, though the ORGANIZATION may very well exercise caution with PERSON's workload after he logged just 46 2/3 frames in '18.

First impressions aren't the be-all and end-all in the often long development path for prospects, but they certainly don't hurt. After signing for just $35,000 in 2015, PERSON had a fairly ordinary debut in the ORGANIZATION. But when he showed up to pitch in the GPE for the first time in 2016, he was lights out and led the ORGANIZATION in ERA.A very efficient strike-thrower, PERSON isn't the tallest right-hander in the world, but he has plenty of arm. He'll throw his fastball consistently in the 93-96 mph range and was up to 97-98 mph at times last summer. He separates himself from others at his level because of his outstanding fastball command, throwing his heater with movement in the zone that gets ground-ball outs and swings and misses. His curve is developing and could be a plus pitch in the future, and he has a good feel for his changeup. He's strong and athletic, repeating his delivery well.Between extended spring training and the ORGANIZATION in 2016, PERSON threw about 90 innings. That set him up well for his first full season in the ORGANIZATION, where he added to that first impression as a potential impact starter in the big leagues.

PERSON threw a perfect game as sophomore at FACILITY (ORGANIZATION, GPE.) and then won five playoff games to lead the Kingsmen to the state 4-A title as a junior in 2015. He boosted his stock with a succession of strong performances on the showcase circuit during the summer and fall, and he continued to impress scouts throughout his senior season. After selecting college players with its first four picks, the A's went well over slot to land PERSON in the fourth round, giving him $1 million to forego his commitment to GPE.PERSON uses a quick arm and strong frame to generate consistent 90-92 mph fastballs and can reach 95. His high-three-quarters delivery enables him to stay on top of his hard curveball, a solid second offering. He also shows some aptitude for throwing a changeup, though it can get too firm at times.PERSON has a little less arm strength but better secondary pitches than GPE high school righties PERSON and PERSON, both of whom the ORGANIZATION selected in the first round a year ago. His control and command are improving, so there's little doubt that he can make it as a starter in pro ball.

The ORGANIZATION were very aggressive on the international market in July 2017, signing a pair of players for seven figures in shortstop PERSON and outfielder PERSON. They also signed ORGANIZATION for $500,000 that July and while the teenager wasn't as high profile a signing as the other two, he nonetheless made it to the GPE during his debut summer, playing in the ORGANIZATION in 2018.A one-time shortstop, ORGANIZATION is now a full-time outfielder, where his tools and athleticism have the chance to play well. He's seen time in both center and right field, with an easily plus arm that could help him profile in the corner spot down the road. He's very projectable offensively, with the potential to have future plus power thanks to his physicality and bat speed, to go along with good hand-eye coordination. There is some length to his swing, but the ORGANIZATION think that might have to do more with inexperience and lack of present strength than anything mechanical.There's a long development path ahead for ORGANIZATION to get to what he eventually might become. The ORGANIZATION have never shied away from working with young international signees and will let ORGANIZATION dictate how quickly he moves through the system.

A standout on the international showcase circuit, PERSON routinely dazzled scouts with his power/speed combination and finished second in the home run derby at the 2014 Under PERSON All-America Game. He signed out of the ORGANIZATION in 2015 for $2.6 million, the largest bonus GPE paid to a non-Cuban during its record international spending binge in 2015-16. He offers tantalizing upside but also the widest gap between his ceiling and floor of any Dodgers farmhand.PERSON has tape-measure power thanks to lightning bat speed, prodigious strength (he weighs much more than his listed 200 pounds) and the leverage in his right-handed swing. There are times when he keeps his stroke compact and shows the ability to make adjustments, and others when his swing gets much too long and he looks lost at the plate. He looked overmatched when he reached low Class A last August and again this spring before an eye injury sidelined him in June.PERSON moves well for his size, showing average speed out of the batter's box and a step more quickness once he gets going, though he'll slow down as he continues to get bigger. He has played all three outfield positions as a pro, getting most of his action in left field. It's hard to know what to make of him as a defender because reports on him are all over the place, with grades ranging from 30-55 on his fielding and 40-60 on his arm.

PERSON performed very well on the international showcase circuit, showing huge power in batting practice and posting plus running times, and he finished second in the home run derby at the 2014 Under PERSON All-America Game. The ORGANIZATION signed the ORGANIZATION for $2.6 million in July 2015, giving him the largest bonus they paid a non-Cuban as part of their record international spending spree that year. He continued to show power and speed during his 2016 debut in the Rookie-level ORGANIZATION and will come to the GPE this year.Already physically imposing at age 18, PERSON carries more than the listed 200 pounds on his 6-foot-2 frame. He combines bat speed, strength and leverage from the right side of the plate and can drive the ball great distances. There are no red flags with his swing or approach, though he'll have to make the necessary adjustments as he faces better quality pitching.Though PERSON spent most of his debut in left field and GPE plans to give him more time in center in 2017, he projects more as a right fielder. He has the strong arm for the position and figures to lose some speed as he continues to mature physically. If he hones his instincts and stays on top of his conditioning, he can become an average defender in right.

The ORGANIZATION spent more money than any team on the international market this summer. They gave GPE right-hander PERSON a $16 million bonus, and PERSON was their second-biggest expenditure at $2.6 million. One of the strongest and most physical players in the 2015 international class, PERSON has a big swing that can launch baseballs great distances when he makes contact. He may have to tone down his approach to succeed against professional pitching, though he did perform well in game action in the ORGANIZATION League.Presently a solid runner, PERSON figures to lose a step as he adds more strength. That would necessitate a move from center to right field, and his strong arm would play well at the latter position.

GPE of the ORGANIZATION' massive international spending spree in 2015, PERSON signed for $2.6 million, the largest bonus the club gave to a non-Cuban. He impressed on the tryout circuit, regularly showing big power in batting practice and plus 60-yard-dash times, and finished second in the home run derby at the 2014 Under PERSON All-America Game. One of the strongest and most physically mature players in the 2015 international class, PERSON already carries 200 pounds on his 6-foot-2 frame at age 17. PERSON generates impressive bat speed and leverage from the right side of the plate. His swing can get long and he may need to tone down his approach against pro pitching, though he did perform well in GPE Prospect League games.Though he signed as a center fielder, PERSON figures to lose a step off his solid speed and eventually move to right field. Both his power potential and his arm strength would fit nicely at that position.

Signed by the ORGANIZATION for $35,000 out of GPE in 2013, PERSON has slowly but surely pitched himself into prospect status. After some inconsistent seasons early in his career, he showed signs of turning the corner in his second-full season campaign before breaking out in earnest in 2019 at age 22. He dominated out of the bullpen at ORGANIZATION A Advanced Potomac, posting a 0.53 ERA with 26 strikeouts in 17 innings, and continued to pitch well following a May promotion to Double-A Harrisburg, excelling in his first true audition as a starter. PERSON stands out for his pitchability, but he also has some sneaky good stuff. He'll touch 93-94 mph and sits in the low 90s with his fastball, throwing it with natural sinking action that nets him a bunch of ground balls. His changeup is a plus offering, one that generates whiffs for him against hitters on both sides of the plate with its diving action, and he adeptly mixes in an average slider that has two-plane break. He can throw all three pitches for strikes and doesn't hurt himself by issuing many free passes. PERSON' ability to work effectively in various roles is an asset, and club officials view him as a potential multi-inning reliever much like former ORGANIZATION hurler PERSON. At the same time, it wouldn't surprise anyone in the organization if PERSON were to continue to excel as a starter en route to a spot in the back of a big league rotation.

Despite his lack of size and premium stuff, PERSON was having an outstanding collegiate career at ORGANIZATION, serving as the team's No. 2 starter during its College World Series run in 2016 and earning Big 12 Conference Pitcher of the ORGANIZATION honors the following season. After a strong turn with the GPE national collegiate team last summer, there was excitement about his junior season, but it ended early when he blew out his elbow in February and needed PERSON surgery. The ORGANIZATION decided it was worth the risk to take PERSON and let him rehab with their staff, signing him in the fourth round for an above-pick-value bonus of $825,000. He suffered a setback while rehabbing during Spring Training that further delayed the start to his pro career. PERSON's velocity on his fastball is fringy, sitting at 88-92 mph and occasionally touching 94, but it plays up because it has good sink and he can command it to both sides of the plate. It's also helped by his best pitch, a plus fading changeup that was among the best in the 2018 Draft class. PERSON has an average curveball as well, one that he throws for strikes consistently.PERSON's ceiling is somewhat limited to that of a back-end starter. At the same time, he does have a fairly high floor as a pitchability lefty who can eat a lot of innings and is a plus competitor. Once healthy, PERSON will try to exceed the comps to PERSON he elicited before getting hurt.

Despite his lack of size and premium stuff, PERSON was having an outstanding collegiate career at ORGANIZATION, serving as the team's No. 2 starter during its College World Series run in 2016 and earning Big 12 Conference Pitcher of the ORGANIZATION honors the following season. After a strong turn with the GPE national collegiate team last summer, there was excitement about his junior season, but it ended early when he blew out his elbow in February and needed PERSON surgery. The ORGANIZATION decided it was worth the risk to take PERSON and let him rehab with their staff, signing him in the fourth round for an above-pick-value bonus of $825,000.PERSON's velocity on his fastball is fringy, sitting 88-92 mph and occasionally touching 94, but it plays up because it has good sink and he can command it to both sides of the plate. It's also helped by his best pitch, a plus fading changeup that was among the best in the 2018 Draft class. PERSON has an average curveball as well, one that he throws for strikes consistently. PERSON's ceiling is somewhat limited to that of a back-end starter. At the same time, he does have a fairly high floor as a pitchability lefty who can eat a lot of innings and is a plus competitor. Once healthy, PERSON will try to exceed the comps to PERSON he elicited before getting hurt.

PERSON didn't think they were going to get to see Jennings much this past spring because the star quarterback at ORGANIZATION in GPE tore his anterior cruciate ligament in his knee in September. But not only did he get back in time for baseball season, he turned out to be the top prep prospect in the state, landing in the second round and getting an above-pick value bonus to sign him away from his GPE commitment.Jennings has a loose, quick arm that delivers fastballs regularly in the 89-92 mph range. He can touch 95 mph and should add velocity in the future as he fills out his 6-foot-2 frame. He'll touch the mid-80s with his hard slider, which could be plus in time, and his curve gives him another solid option as well. While he didn't use his changeup much, he has shown a feel for it, giving him the chance to have four at-least-average offerings.Jennings' athleticism plays well on the mound, helping him to repeat his delivery and throw strikes. Now no longer splitting focus among two sports, there could be quite a bit of upside to unlock here.

Jennings was a two-sport star at ORGANIZATION in GPE, serving as ace pitcher as well as quarterback for the football team. A torn ORGANIZATION during the fall of his senior year left many wondering how much mound time he'd get, but he turned out to be the best prep prospect in the state. The ORGANIZATION went above pick value to sign him for $1.9 million in the second round and he made his pro debut in the ORGANIZATION League.Jennings provides an intriguing combination of feel for pitching, projectability and athleticism to the system. He's more of a pitchability right-hander right now, with a fastball he throws 89-92 mph. But he can reach back for more and there might be more velocity to come as he physically matures. He commands the fastball well, moves it in and out and throws it with movement. He'll throw two breaking balls, the slider is liked more by evaluators, and he might focus on just one in the future, and he has good feel for his changeup.The athleticism comes in handy in terms of repeating his delivery and filling the strike zone with all of his pitches. How much his stuff ticks up as he matures and as he focuses on baseball only will determine what kind of starting pitcher he eventually becomes.

The best high school prospect out of GPE in the 2017 GPE class, GPE was a two-sport athlete who got past a torn ORGANIZATION suffered during his senior football season to pitch his way into the second round of the GPE. The ORGANIZATION went over slot to give him $1.9 million to sign rather than head to GPE. While the results on paper don't look great, the ORGANIZATION are still very bullish on his combination of athleticism and feel for pitching.GPE will rely on his ability to command his four-pitch mix, rather than be that prototypical projectable power pitcher. Very athletic on the mound, he has the chance to have above-average control of all four offerings. His fastball typically sits around average, though he can reach back for 94 mph on occasion. Without a big frame, there might not be a ton of strength to add, so this might be more or less where he stands velocity-wise. The good news is that he does a nice job using his fastball, two distinct breaking balls -- the ORGANIZATION like the slider a little bit more than the curve but they do complement each other -- and his changeup to keep hitters from barreling up the baseball.Some evaluators see some PERSON in GPE as an athletic right-hander with a repeatable delivery who will use command and savvy to get big league hitters out. If he can do that and sharpen a breaking ball to become more of an out pitch, he could profile closer to the middle of a rotation.

PERSON PERSON surgery is never thought of as a positive achievement, despite it becoming almost commonplace among young pitchers these days. But there might be a silver lining in having needed the surgery in 2018 for PERSON, the 6-foot-6 right-hander who got $100,000 to sign in Dec. 2016. Yes, he missed development time on the mound by being out for all of 2018, but the strength and conditioning that went along with rehabbing the injury could help him take a big step when he returns to the mound.Before PERSON went down with injury, he had already improved strength-wise enough to add velocity to his fastball. What was a 90-91 mph heater when he first signed was touching 96 mph at instructs in the fall of 2017 with excellent spin and riding life. He's filled out even more now, so dreaming about more velocity once he gets his feet under him isn't unrealistic. He can really spin his breaking ball, giving him the chance for a second plus pitch, and he'll continue to work on what could be a decent changeup. With his size, PERSON will have to work at repeating his delivery. He'll get a chance to do that as he puts his rehab in the rearview mirror and hopefully gets a full season of work in 2019.

If it seems like the GPE are collecting intriguing, young pitching prospects courtesy of their efforts on the international amateur market, looks are not deceiving. PERSON, a 6-foot-6 right-hander signed in December 2016, might have as much ceiling as any of them, though he also might have the furthest to go to get there, especially since offseason PERSON surgery kept him from pitching during the 2018 season.The GPE compare PERSON's fastball-curve combination with that of PERSON in terms of future impact and he used it to pitch his way from the ORGANIZATION to a brief taste of pro ball in the GPE in the rookie-level ORGANIZATION. When PERSON signed, he was 90-91 mph with his fastball, but thanks to some big strength gains, he was touching 96 mph and sitting 93-94 mph last fall at instructs, thrown with plus spin and riding life up in the zone. His curve already flashes plus with a very high spin rate, while his changeup will flash average, though it needs work.PERSON doesn't have as athletic a delivery as GPE, and will need to continue to work to repeat it effectively. If he can get more consistent with his direction to the plate, his command should get better, as should his already impressive raw stuff.

Since 2003, PERSON has produced 10 big league pitchers (most notably PERSON) and six arms selected in the top two rounds. PERSON was a surprise addition to that latter group after entering 2019 with little Draft buzz but creating plenty of it by leading the LOCATION with a 1.32 ERA that ranked third in ORGANIZATION Division I. The ORGANIZATION selected him in the supplemental first round with a pick acquired in the ORGANIZATION trade with the ORGANIZATION and signed him for $1,949,800.PERSON usually pitches at 89-91 mph with run and sink on his fastball from a lower three-quarters slot, and he also can raise his arm angle and reach back for 93-95 mph when needed. He excels at manipulating the shape of his 78-83 mph slider, which features high spin rates and can be a plus offering at its best. He also has nice feel for his sinking changeup and the trust to use it in any count.PERSON's stocky frame and crossfire delivery aren't the prettiest, but his stuff plays up because of the angle and extension he creates and because he's supremely confident. He throws strikes, will go inside against left-handers and right-handers and sequences his pitches well. He had one of the highest floors among college pitchers in the 2019 Draft, projecting as at least a lefty reliever in the Majors with a good chance of becoming a No. 4 starter.

Primarily an infielder as an amateur in the GPE, PERSON signed with the GPE for $200,000 and focused on pitching for the first time. ORGANIZATION was dominant as a senior at ORGANIZATION (Fla.) After a dominant senior season at ORGANIZATION (Fla.) ORGANIZATION got the highest bonus among high school pitchers in the 2015 GPE, signing for $2,302,500 as a supplemental first-rounder selected 42nd overall. The GPE' 2016-17 international spree garnered notoriety for the money spent. But some of the best pieces from that class weren't high-bonus signings at all. PERSON is a perfect example. PERSON was a top-flight high school prospect in GPE in 2016, but removed his name from the ORGANIZATION because he wanted to pitch for the ORGANIZATION of GPE. He has reached 97 mph with his fastball coming out of the bullpen and could have a more consistent plus curveball in shorter stints.

They say guys who hit always find a place to play. PERSON, who swung the bat consistently well all summer, is now putting that to the test. For the last three years, a pitcher from the ORGANIZATION of GPE has been selected in the first round. PERSON A.J. PERSON spent his first two high school seasons at FACILITY (Ill.) PERSON before transferring to the ORGANIZATION (PERSON, Fla.) to focus on baseball. The ORGANIZATION took two Louisville position players in the first four rounds of the 2019 Draft, first baseman PERSON in the second and ORGANIZATION in the fourth. A teammate of PERSON at ORGANIZATION Heritage-Delray Beach High School in GPE, PERSON went on to become a three-year starter at ORGANIZATION and a member of ORGANIZATION's ORGANIZATION. PERSON PERSON had seven players drafted in its history, none earlier than the sixth round and none since 2008. While he's not a burner, he is an above-average runner, especially once underway.If PERSON can continue to swing the bat like he's capable, he could develop into a PERSON type. At worst, he becomes a PERSON type of utility man. At worst, he becomes a PERSON type of utility man.

The son of former No. 1 overall pick and current ORGANIZATION third-base coach PERSON, PERSON missed his high school junior season while recovering from PERSON surgery but recovered to land an over-slot $2 million bonus as a supplemental first-rounder in 2015. The son of former No. 1 overall pick and All-Star PERSON, PERSON bounced back from PERSON surgery that cost him his junior season of high school to become a supplemental first-rounder in 2015. Ever since signing with the ORGANIZATION as a supplemental first-round pick in 2015, PERSON has had bad luck with injuries. The son of former big leaguer, and ORGANIZATION. 1 overall pick, PERSON, PERSON was taken ORGANIZATION. 38 overall by the Rockies in the 2015 GPE and was given an above-pick value bonus of $2 million.Fully recovered from 2013 PERSON surgery, PERSON's arm is a solid average tool from third. GPE school pitchers with premium arm strength always generate interest among scouts, especially in typical baseball hotbeds like GPE. Like with many prep pitchers, he's more control over command, though he tends to find the strike zone fairly consistently.Because of his size, some wondered if PERSON will be durable enough to be a starter at the next level. His fastball-breaking ball combination likely would play up in a bullpen role, but the ORGANIZATION are a long way away from making that kind of decision. He'll develop as a starter and had pitched across two levels of rookie ball during his summer debut.

There's still some projection remaining in his big, athletic frame, so it's possible he could add more velocity.

Heading into his 2015 senior season at ORGANIZATION Prep (ORGANIZATION, GPE), scouts viewed PERSON as a classic projection arm who would be best off with some development time in college. While he's a project who will need time to develop, his ceiling is higher than most of the starters in the GPE system.

ORGANIZATION' fastball jumped from the high 80s to the low 90s during his senior season as a GPE high schooler in 2015, spurring the ORGANIZATION to lure him away from a commitment to ORGANIZATION JC of GPE Manatee-Sarasota with a $160,000 bonus in the 16th round. His curveball and changeup are becoming solid pitches but lack consistency at times.While ORGANIZATION has had no problem throwing strikes, his command isn't nearly as advanced as his control, making him fairly hittable in the early stages of his career. PERSON was set to attend PERSON before the ORGANIZATION took a flier on him in the 34th round of the 2015 Draft and then lured him away from his college commitment with a $400,000 bonus. He made a strong impression last summer during his brief pro debut by not allowing an earned run over 13 1/3 innings in the ORGANIZATION, and that success continued in 2016 at ORGANIZATION A Short PERSON, where he was the team's Opening Day starter as well as a GPE York-Penn League All-Star.PERSON's fastball operates in the low 90s and bumps 93 mph, and scouts expect him to continue to add velocity as he grows into his tall, lanky frame. He has present feel for locating his heater to all quadrants of the strike zone, while his downhill plane helps him to generate plenty of weak contact and ground balls. PERSON's curveball is his best secondary offering, thrown with tight spin and good downer action, and he made strides in developing his changeup in 2016.At 6-foot-5, 200 pounds, PERSON already possesses outstanding size for a player his age, with considerable physical projection remaining. Though his stuff isn't overpowering, the left-hander's size and feel for pitching has the ORGANIZATION excited about his future. With an improved third pitch, PERSON could develop into a mid-rotation starter.

PERSON was set to attend PERSON before the ORGANIZATION took a flier on him in the 34th round of the 2015 Draft and gave him a $400,000 bonus. He earned All-Star honors once again this season with PERSON before being sent to the Twins at the ORGANIZATION for reliever PERSON. PERSON's fastball seldom exceeds 90 mph but consistently plays above its velocity because he locates it to all quadrants of the zone while working on a steep downhill angle to the plate. What's more, the left-hander is sure to add more velocity as he grows into his 6-foot-5, 200-pound frame. PERSON's curveball is his best secondary offering, thrown with tight spin and good downer action, and he continues to make strides with a changeup that has average potential. Though his stuff isn't overpowering at the moment, PERSON's size and feel for pitching gives him the chance to develop into a mid-rotation starter, especially with an improved third pitch.

PERSON consistently smoked the ball at the ORGANIZATION Games last August and at the World Wood Bat Association World Championship two months later, establishing himself as one of the best high school hitters in the 2016 Draft. He was bothered by a shoulder injury in the spring, which made him tricky for scouts to evaluate and ultimately caused him to the sixth round, where the Indians were able to land him at pick value for $270,300.When healthy, PERSON has a quick, compact right-handed swing and barrels balls with ease. He has good balance at the plate and recognizes pitches and manages the strike zone better than most prep hitters. He has some strength too and could have average or better power.PERSON has a strong arm, but his hands, quickness and athleticism leave something to be desired. He does work hard and perhaps could become an adequate third baseman, but a move down the defensive spectrum to first base would make for a less attractive overall profile, not to mention one that will be harder to achieve as he ascends the ORGANIZATION ladder.

Ranked No. 15 on MLBPipeline.com's Top 30 international prospects class in 2016, PERSON was part of the ORGANIZATION' aggressive spending in that market when the July 2 signing period began. Signed at age 16 out of GPE, PERSON received $1.5 million as GPE PERSON blew past its international spending pool.The investment in PERSON is all about his power potential. The right-handed hitter might have had the most raw power of any member of the international prospect class in 2016. He can put on a show during batting practice and hit balls out of the park to all fields. He'll need to refine his approach and improve his pitch recognition in order to tap into that power consistently in games, but evaluators think he'll eventually be a solid all-around hitter. PERSON has an average arm and enough range to man an outfield corner.Regardless of where he plays, the hope is PERSON will eventually develop into a run-producing, middle-of-the-lineup type of player.

The sons of legendary GPE outfielder PERSON both defected from the island in May 2018 and signed with the ORGANIZATION five months later, with PERSON receiving a $5.25 million bonus and PERSON Jr. landing $1 million. Five years younger and less athletic than his brother, a member of ORGANIZATION's Top 100 Prospects list, PERSON Jr. may have a higher offensive ceiling. He led PERSON's 18-and-under league in hitting (.440), on-base percentage (.560) and slugging (.667) in his final season before defecting.A switch-hitter growing up, PERSON will bat solely left-handed in his first season in the GPE. He has a fluid swing and advanced bat-to-ball skills, leading to optimism that he'll be a quality hitter. He shows the ability to backspin the ball and while most of his present power comes to his pull side, he has the potential to drive the ball to all fields.PERSON has average speed and outfield range, so he fits best on a corner. He has solid arm strength and likely will end up in right field. More outgoing than his brother, he's a brash player who displays plenty of confidence, though his youth means PERSON won't rush him.

The 2016-17 international signing period has been a solid one for the ORGANIZATION thus far, highlighted by the emergence of top 10 prospect PERSON. PERSON top 30 prospect PERSON also came in that haul and now they are joined by PERSON, who signed for $150,000 in November 2016 and has used his command and feel for pitching to join PERSON as teenaged rotation-mates in full-season Lakewood in 2019.None of PERSON' individual pitches jump off the page, but his ability to use any of his three pitches when he wants allows them all to play up. Velocity-wise, his fastball is below average, but his plus command of it to go along with solid life allow it to play close to average. His changeup is his best secondary offering, an offspeed pitch with splitter-like action to it and he throws his average slider for strikes consistently.Because of the lack of premium stuff, PERSON' ceiling might be limited. But his advanced pitchability -- he's walked roughly one batter per nine innings in his career to date -- gives him the chance to stick in the back end of a big league rotation.

Sub-six foot high school right-handers are a little tough to evaluate, especially when they have a reliever profile. But the 5-foot-11 PERSON had opened eyes with his arm strength as the 2018 PERSON approached. The ORGANIZATION took the GPE, GPE, native in the 14th round and gave him $200,000 to sign him away from his commitment to PERSON. After a brief pro debut in the ORGANIZATION last year, he made a successful leap to full-season ball in 2019, almost exclusively as a reliever.Now listed at 6-foot, PERSON might be undersized, but he certainly doesn't lack arm strength. He has a live fastball that sits in the low-90s, but often touches 95-96 mph. He complements that with a slider that flashes above-average and he gets swings-and-misses along with ground-ball outs with his two-pitch repertoire. While he isn't tall, he does have a strong build, reminding some in the organization of PERSON in terms of body type. While he doesn't have pinpoint command, he's around the plate enough to be successful.PERSON entered pro ball a bit raw, but has already taken solid steps forward in terms of his development. He's shown the ability to pitch multiple innings and could be a solid middle reliever or even a setup type if he continues to progress.

PERSON quickly has blossomed into one of PERSON's more promising middle-infield prospects since signing for $15,000 out of the ORGANIZATION in 2014. He spent parts of the next two seasons in the ORGANIZATION before finally making his GPE debut with PERSON in late 2016. Returning to the ORGANIZATION York-Penn League last season, PERSON broke out in earnest, hitting .285 with 23 extra-base hits while ranking among the circuit leaders with 74 hits (first), 51 runs scored (first), 108 total bases (first), 16 steals (fifth) and a .378 on-base percentage (fifth). The switch-hitting PERSON is advanced from both sides of the plate. He already knows how to control the strike zone at a young age and recognizes pitches well, with bat-to-ball skills and a knack for making hard contact that led scouts to project him as an above-average hitter in the future. That PERSON rarely strikes out and has strong on-base skills to go along with natural hitting ability underscores his potential as a top-of-the-order presence, a profile that's only enhanced by his well-above-average speed and impact potential on the basepaths.PERSON's wheels translate to exceptional range at second base, where he profiles as a slightly above-average defender with average arm strength. PERSON's glut of middle-infield depth could complicate his rise through the ORGANIZATION, though there are many evaluators who believe PERSON could make a smooth transition to center field should the need arise.

Signed for $15,000 out of the ORGANIZATION in 2014, PERSON made his stateside debut two years later and then flashed his top-of-the-lineup potential in '17 by ranking among the Class A Short-Season New York-Penn League leaders in a host of offensive categories. He was even more impressive last year with the move up to full-season ball, as PERSON led the Minors in runs scored (112) and finished second in steals (55) while hitting .320/.403/.459 with 41 extra-base hits in 122 games between the GPE and PERSON. The switch-hitting PERSON is advanced from both sides of the plate. He already knows how to control the strike zone at a young age and recognizes pitches well, with bat-to-ball skills and a knack for making hard contact that lead scouts to project him as a plus hitter in the future. He has sneaky raw power in his left-handed swing, and it was from that side that he hit all nine of his home runs in 2018. His right-handed swing is more contact-oriented. That PERSON rarely strikes out and takes his walks to go along with natural hitting ability underscores his potential as a top-of-the-order presence, a profile that's only enhanced by his plus-plus speed and aggressiveness on the basepaths.PERSON's wheels translate to good range at second base, where he profiles as a slightly above-average defender with average arm strength. The ORGANIZATION have no shortage of promising middle infielders in their system, though none can rival PERSON's upside as a true leadoff man.

PERSON signed with the ORGANIZATION back in February 2014 as an infielder, but was quickly moved to the outfield. That's the only fast transition PERSON has made so far as his tools have taken a while to percolate, spending three summers in the ORGANIZATION before getting to the GPE briefly in 2016 and making his full GPE debut in the Rookie-level GPE League in 2017. He struggled in a move to the short-season ORGANIZATION York-Penn League in 2018.When he first arrived in the ORGANIZATION, PERSON did show off some considerable tools, finishing in the top 10 in the ORGANIZATION in slugging percentage and ORGANIZATION while also swiping 11 bases. Still maturing physically, PERSON has shown that he is already capable of impacting the baseball, with most of his power coming to his pull side thus far. There is concern that PERSON will hit enough to tap into that power as he moves up given a very high strikeout rate a summer ago, but the ORGANIZATION feel he'll make the adjustments with his setup at the plate to improve his hit tool.PERSON's plus speed will continue to make him a basestealing threat and give him enough range to play center field. The ORGANIZATION have a number of athletic outfielders who can play center, so PERSON will get exposed to all three outfield spots.

PERSON is the latest prospect hailing from PERSON in GPE, the most recent ones before him being Cubs 2014 fifth-rounder PERSON and PERSON's older brother PERSON, who went on to LOCATION. This younger PERSON was nabbed in the fifth round and given an above-pick value bonus of $450,000 to not head to PERSON advanced high school hitter with a compact left-handed swing and all-fields approach, PERSON employs more of a line-drive stroke at present, which has not led to much power to date. He does have the bat speed and strength to get to at least average power once he learns to lift and turn on pitches more frequently. PERSON moves well and was an excellent defender at first base. As a pitcher, he touched the low 90s with his fastball, giving him a stronger arm than your typical first baseman, perhaps a reason why the PERSON sent him out to play left field during his pro debut.Whether PERSON can stick in an outfield corner remains to be seen, but the Cardinals know he can easily slide back to first if needed. He should eventually develop into the offensive profile desired at either corner spot.

A switch-hitting shortstop with deep baseball ties in his family, GPE ranked as ORGANIZATION's No. 2 international prospect before signing with PERSON for $3,825,000 at the outset of the 2017-18 period. The ORGANIZATION native made the jump stateside for his pro debut last season and promptly established himself as one of baseball's better prospects by winning the Rookie-level GPE's ORGANIZATION at age 17. Playing against considerably older competition, he produced a .351/.418/.587 line with 11 home runs in 61 games and led the circuit with 85 hits and 57 RBIs.GPE's robust production during his pro debut reflects his high offensive ceiling. He consistently impacts the baseball from both sides of the plate, showing a combination of bat speed, strong wrists/hands and elite bat-to-ball skills that leads some scouts to project him as a plus-plus hitter. He should offer above-average over-the-fence power, too, especially from the left side of the plate, from where he hit all but one of his home runs in 2018. GPE's approach, much like his physical tools, is advanced beyond his years, and he receives raves for his ability to recognize spin and control the zone. In the field, GPE has impressed evaluators with his hands, range and actions at shortstop, not to mention the high level of confidence he exudes. He could outgrow the position and shift over to second or possibly third base, though such a move would do little to detract from his All-Star-caliber ceiling. While the Rays have historically employed a patient approach in developing young talent, GPE could be the rare exception, as many have already identified him as the next teenage wunderkind to reach the ORGANIZATION.

Ranked as ORGANIZATION's No. 2 prospect for the 2017-18 international signing period, PERSON has deep family ties to baseball. His father, PERSON, played professionally, and he has a pair of older brothers currently in the ORGANIZATION' and PERSON' systems. He's also the nephew of GPE shortstop PERSON. However, it was the teenager's high ceiling as a switch-hitting shortstop that netted him a $3,825,000 signing bonus from PERSON when the international signing period opened on July 2. The deal is already looking like a steal for the ORGANIZATION after PERSON dazzled with his hitting ability during his pro debut as a 17-year-old in the Rookie-level Appalachian League.The Dominican Republic native has impact potential offensively. With his combination of bat speed, strong wrists and feel for manipulating the barrel, PERSON knows how to generate hard contact from both sides of the plate, with enough speed to hit atop a lineup and enough power to serve as a middle-of-the-order force. Those qualities should enable PERSON to hit for a high average, and with considerable physical development ahead of him, he's merely scraping the surface of his power potential. PERSON also impresses in the field, earning plaudits from evaluators for his hands, range and actions at shortstop, not to mention a high level of confidence that belies his age. Some evaluators do believe he'll ultimately outgrow the position and shift over to second base, though such a move would do little to detract from his overall upside.

Ranked as ORGANIZATION's No. 2 prospect for the 2017-18 international signing period, PERSON has deep family ties to baseball. His father, PERSON, played professionally, and he has a pair of older brothers currently in the ORGANIZATION' and PERSON' systems. He's also the nephew of GPE shortstop PERSON. However, it was the teenager's high ceiling as a switch-hitting shortstop that netted him a $3,825,000 signing bonus from PERSON when the international signing period opened on July 2.The GPE native has impact potential offensively. With his combination of bat speed and feel for manipulating the barrel, PERSON knows how to generate hard contact from both sides of the plate, with plus speed that could land him at the top of the batting order. And while he may never offer more than average power, PERSON, at age 16, still has considering physical development ahead of him. PERSON also impresses in the field, earning plaudits from evaluators for his hands, range and actions at shortstop, not to mention a high level of confidence that belies his age. Some evaluators do believe he'll ultimately outgrow the position and shift over to second base, though such a move would do little to detract from his overall upside.

Being ranked as one of the top international amateur prospects comes with certain expectations, and PERSON was ranked No. 12 on ORGANIZATION's Top 30 international list in 2015. Signing for a franchise-record $4 million dollars also raises the bar some. PERSON's pro career started with a small roadblock, as a hamstring injury limited him to just nine games in the ORGANIZATION in 2016. He was one of the best prospects in the Rookie-level GPE League during his GPE debut in 2017, starting to show what all the fuss was about. He wasn't able to repeat that performance in 2018 as a torn labrum in his non-throwing shoulder forced him to miss the 2018 season.When healthy, PERSON has shown an outstanding feel to hit and an ability to make consistent hard contact to all fields. He is continuing to refine his approach at the plate, but he has drawn walks and there is confidence he'll cut his strikeout rate as he figures things out, to the point where some feel he could be a plus hitter in time. As he physically matures, he should be able to use his bat speed to tap into considerable raw power as well. While he still has some growing to do, he has all the skills needed to be a long-term shortstop. How that will work with PERSON and PERSON in front him remains to be seen, but for now, his focus will be on getting reps and staying healthy in the lower levels of the ORGANIZATION' system.

After giving PERSON, GPE. 12 on MLBPipeline.com's Top 30 ORGANIZATION list in 2015, a franchise record $4 million bonus, the Twins were excited to see this talented infielder get his career started in the ORGANIZATION last year. A hamstring injury kept that from happening for the most part, as PERSON appeared in just nine games, but he was able to make his GPE debut in the GPE League in 2017. GPEw back to full speed, PERSON can start showing off all of his considerable tools. He has shown the ability to make consistent hard contact with plus bat speed, and many think he could be an above-average hitter with more reps and perhaps even above-average power as he continues to add strength. He is more than athletic enough to stay at shortstop, perhaps even if he grows some more, and could follow in the footsteps of other big shortstops who stuck there. There's still a very long way for PERSON to go before he lives up to his ceiling or the expectations that can come with a $4 million price tag. The first order of business is staying on the field. If that happens, the tools should take care of the rest.

There was obvious excitement when the ORGANIZATION aggressively pursued PERSON, one of the top prospects in the 2015-16 international class, and signed him for $4 million in July 2015. Since then, however, there have only been glimpses of what he can do. The talented infielder missed most of his first summer, in 2016, because of a hamstring injury, then re-set a high bar by being one of the best prospects in the GPE League in his GPE debut in 2017. PERSON was halted when a torn labrum in his non-throwing shoulder kept him off the field for all of 2018.Because the injuries have limited his time on the field, PERSON is a bit of a wild card. Once he can shake the rust off, there is confidence he'll once again show his considerable offensive upside. He makes consistent hard contact with a natural feel to hit and while as a young player without that many reps, he'll need to refine his approach. He does work counts and draw walks. As he fills out, his bat speed and potential plus hitting tool could lead to at least average power. Fortunately, PERSON's injury wasn't to his throwing shoulder, so his plus arm should be just fine. Whether he outgrows the position remains to be seen.With a clean bill of health and no setbacks from his injury, PERSON should be ready to show what he can do over the course of a long season. Getting at-bats and reps in the field is priority number one for now.

The PERSON thought highly enough of PERSON, who was ranked No. 12 on MLB.com's Top 30 international prospects list heading into the July 2 signing period, and his five-tool potential that they went over their international pool amount by giving him a $4 million bonus to sign, more than PERSON paid to bring PERSON into the fold.He may be far away, but PERSON has a ton of potential and ceiling. With plus bat speed and strength, he has considerable raw power. He's shown ability to hit in games, with very good bat-to-ball skills, something that will only improve with pro instruction and consistent reps. There's the chance for him to have above-average hit-and-power tools when all is said and done. A very good athlete, he's already added good strength since signing. Some feel he'll eventually outgrow shortstop, but the PERSON feel he'll be able to stay there, in the body mold of bigger shortstops like PERSON, PERSON or, more recently, PERSON. He has good defensive actions and a strong throwing arm.The PERSON won't rush their investment, with a plan to let him get started in the ORGANIZATION and come to the GPE for instructional league play in the fall.

Not every successful international signing has to be a seven-figure expenditure. If the early returns are any indication, PERSON, who signed for $550,000 in July 2016 out of the ORGANIZATION, will be one of those bargain finds. He showcased natural hitting ability during his pro debut in the ORGANIZATION and firmly put himself on the prospect radar in 2018, ascending three levels to finish the season as an 18-year-old in the Class A ORGANIZATION. With his plus bat speed, barrel control and a clean swing from both sides of the plate, PERSON shows many of the attributes needed to hit for a high average. He covers the plate well, too, trusting his approach to let pitches travel deep and open up his use of the entire field. He projects for more gap power than true over-the-fence pop, but there's enough raw power and physical projection remaining to think he could produce double-digit homers in his prime. PERSON's loudest tool is plus speed that shows up in all facets of the game. He gets out of the box and down the line well and is aggressive on the basepaths, at times to a fault. Those wheels, along with his overall athleticism, translate well at shortstop, where he profiles as an above-average defender with the necessary hands, actions and arm strength to stick at the position long term. PERSON's lack of power limits his ceiling, but the pieces are there for him to develop into a glove-first regular up the middle.

PERSON was the ORGANIZATION. 26 prospect on ORGANIZATION's list of the Top 30 international prospects and had reportedly agreed to sign with the ORGANIZATION for $1.3 million before an arm injury led to a voided deal. The D-backs went on to sign him in October, 2017, and he impressed the organization with his development and overall performance the following summer at age 17 in the ORGANIZATION. The ORGANIZATION native is extremely athletic with a projectable body and the potential to have plus tools across the board. He showed an advanced approach during his pro debut, and he's poised to start impacting the ball more consistently as he adds strength and gains experience. A decent runner, PERSON has the potential to be a base-stealer and profiles well in center field, where he has impressed scouts with his defensive actions and range. He has plenty of arm strength for the position and could probably play all three outfield positions if needed.The D-backs have been very impressed with PERSON's athleticism and by how quickly he's added size and strength since entering their system. He'll need a lot of time to develop, but the final product could be a tooled-up center fielder who hits for power as well as average.

The ORGANIZATION spent more than $17 million during the 2014-15 international signing period, handing out seven-figure bonuses to seven different position players. PERSON, who signed for $1.35 million out of GPE, has been the most impressive among that group to date. He had no problems transitioning to the GPE at age 17 during his 2015 pro debut.While he was having a rough encore in the GPE, he still was showing some ability to control the strike zone and use the entire field from both sides of the plate. PERSON strong for his age, he has the bat speed and projectable frame to perhaps grow into average power once he matures physically.Though some scouts questioned PERSON's long-term ability to remain at shortstop when he signed, GPE has no such concerns. He has plus speed and arm strength, and his hands and feet work well on defense.

It looked as though GPE might become the third PERSON (ORGANIZATION, Ga.) product Drafted in the first round, following PERSON (2001) and PERSON (2012). Though he didn't end up going quite that high, GPE, the best defensive catcher in the 2018 Draft, still earned a selection in the ORGANIZATION B Round (ORGANIZATION. 69 overall) and signed for $1.8 million, nearly twice the recommended value for his slot, to forego his commitment to Vanderbilt.GPE's signature tool is his well-above-average arm strength, and he gets the most out of it with a quick transfer and fine accuracy on his throws. His receiving and framing skills are solid, and he's agile behind the plate. He also exhibits the desired leadership skills for his position.While his defense overshadows his offense and he struggled at times on the showcase circuit last summer when he tried to do too much, GPE offers some upside with the bat as well. With his strong build, solid bat speed and loft in his right-handed swing, he has at least above-average raw power. He didn't shown as much feel for the barrel during the spring as he has in the past, so it's unclear how much he'll be able to tap into his average raw power.

The most polished high school defensive catcher in the 2018 Draft, GPE made a case to become the third PERSON (ORGANIZATION, Ga.) product selected in the first round, following PERSON (2001) and PERSON (2012). PERSON grabbed him with a supplemental second-round choice and paid him a $1.8 million bonus (nearly twice his slot value at ORGANIZATION. 69) to sway him away from GPE's signature tool is his well-above-average arm strength, which he enhances with a quick release and accuracy on his throws. His receiving skills are advanced and smooth. A natural leader, he impressed teammates in his pro debut and has taken to learning GPE so he can better communicate with all of his teammates, especially the pitchers. Though he's considered a defense-first catcher and struck out in 29 percent of his plate appearances during his first taste of pro ball, GPE offers some upside at the plate. He has good bat speed and impacts the baseball, but he tends to get overly aggressive and his right-handed swing gets long. The question is how patient the ORGANIZATION will be with his hitting before advancing him to the upper levels after they sent him to low Class A at age 18 last summer.

PERSON endeared himself to scouts with his loud tools while playing for ORGANIZATION's gold medal-winning squad in the 18U World Cup in GPE. As a senior, he batted .454 with eight home runs and 41 ORGANIZATION and led The ORGANIZATION to a GPE 3-A championship, the ORGANIZATION' first title since 1975. Targeting offensive upside, the GPE selected PERSON, a Duke commit, with the ORGANIZATION. 14 overall pick in June, and then saved nearly $500,000 by signing him for $2.5 million. He struggled at times in the ORGANIZATION during his pro debut but still showed the ability to impact games in a variety of ways, finishing second on the team in doubles (10), home runs (6), walks (22) and stolen bases (10).PERSON's bat speed and strength give him well-above-average raw power from the left side of the plate, and he already shows the ability to get to it during games. He's at his best when he stays short to the ball and uses the whole field, and the GPE have worked to get him into a better position to hit. And while strikeouts may always be a part of his game, PERSON impressed club officials during his pro debut with his ability and willingness to coax walks.PERSON is a standout athlete with slightly above-average speed, although he's likely to lose a step or two as he fills out physically. It's also why PERSON, a center fielder in high school, is best suited to play right field in pro ball, where he profiles as an average defender with a plus arm. PERSON has the tools to develop into a middle-of-the-order hitter, but he may require extra time to refine his skills in the ORGANIZATION.

It's almost impossible to discuss PERSON with a scout and not have PERSON's name come up as a comparison. They're both Atlanta-area high school prospects, left-handed hitters with similar builds at the same stage of their careers and outstanding athletes for their size. As a senior, PERSON batted .454 with eight home runs and 41 ORGANIZATION and led The ORGANIZATION to a GPE 3-A championship, the ORGANIZATION' first title since 1975. Targeting offensive upside, the GPE selected PERSON, a Duke commit, with the ORGANIZATION. 14 overall pick in June, and then saved nearly $500,000 by signing him for $2.5 million.PERSON's bat speed and strength give him well-above-average raw power, and the fact that he's more aggressive than PERSON bodes well for PERSON's chances of tapping into it. He's at his best when he uses a short stroke, though he falls into the trap of trying to do too much at times. He hasn't had a great spring with the bat but still has enough offensive upside and all-around potential to go in the first round.A solid runner, PERSON led the GPE 18-and-under team with four steals in 14 games during the summer, and he swiped 11 more bags during the spring. Though he played center field in high school, PERSON is best suited to play right field in pro ball, and has the required arm strength for the position. He also has experience at first base.

PERSON excited scouts with his size and power/speed combination leading up to the 2016 Draft, earning comparisons to PERSON as an Atlanta-area high schooler with a similar build and athleticism. After signing for an under-slot $2.5 million as the 14th overall pick that June, he hit just .201/.329/.409 in his first three pro seasons. He led the Class A ORGANIZATION with 22 homers and ranked third with 82 walks in 2018, but his .180 batting average was the second-lowest among full-season batting qualifiers in the Minors.PERSON offers massive raw power, the product of a quick bat, prodigious strength and the leverage in his 6-foot-5 frame. He's also extremely selective at the plate, able to recognize offspeed pitches and refrain from chasing them out of the strike zone. But there are mechanical and timing issues with his left-handed swing, resulting in way too many swings and misses at hittable strikes.If PERSON can solve his hitting issues, he would have some of the highest upside in the system. He's very athletic for his size, displaying solid speed and a plus arm. He has the tools to be an asset in right field, though he needs to smooth out some rough edges first.

PERSON starred at ORGANIZATION (ORGANIZATION, Ga.), going 13-0 as a junior in 2015 and winning the clincher in the GPE state 6-A championship series that also wrapped up the ORGANIZATION. 1 national ranking. His talent dictated that he would have gone in the top five rounds of the 2016 Draft, but he fell to the ORGANIZATION in the 35th because he was set on attending PERSON and becoming part of college baseball's top recruiting class. After two years as a reliever, he fared well as the ORGANIZATION' ORGANIZATION. 1 starter and landed in the fifth round to the ORGANIZATION, who signed him for full pick value.PERSON excels at pitching to contact with a 91-93 mph fastball that tops out at 95, creating ground balls and awkward swings with sink and the extension in his low-three-quarters delivery. His low-80s slider can be a solid offering when he stays on top of it, though it also can get sweepy and slurvy at times. His fading changeup similarly varies between effectiveness and inconsistency.Strong and durable, PERSON does a nice job of repeating his simple mechanics. Scouting grades: Hit: 45 | Power: 45 | Run: 60 | Arm: 60 | Field: 50 | Overall: 45The ORGANIZATION made a huge splash when they signed PERSON prior to the 2018 season and allowed him to both pitch and hit at the big league level. GPE was nearly 18 when he signed for $60,000 out of the ORGANIZATION in 2015 and he lost most of the 2017 season to a 75-game suspension after testing positive for a banned diuretic.
