If he outgrows the middle infield, he has the bat and arm to profile at third base.

GPE of the ORGANIZATION' $8.4 million international spending spree in 2013, PERSON is the most promising prospect from that crop. Signed for $1.35 million out of the ORGANIZATION, he was advanced enough to come to the GPE during his 2014 pro debut and to hold his own during an emergency callup to Double-A last year at age 18.The nephew of former big leaguer PERSON, PERSON has more offensive upside than a typical shortstop. He has a sound right-handed swing with bat speed that gives him potential to hit for power and average once he matures physically and at the plate. He's an extremely aggressive hitter who needs to improve his plate discipline, though he does have a knack for making hard contact.PERSON has solid speed but is still learning how to use it on the bases. He has enough range to stay at shortstop and a cannon arm capable of making any throw necessary. He also has seen action at second and third base as a pro, mainly because GPE has shortstop depth at the lower levels.

Signed for $450,000 out of the ORGANIZATION in 2013, PERSON has some of the best all-around tools in the ORGANIZATION system. He also has one of the biggest gaps between his present ability and future potential, as he could take a career path anywhere from becoming a four-tool center fielder to winding up on the mound.At the plate, PERSON shows promising bat speed and some feel for the barrel, but he can look lost at times because he still has difficulty recognizing pitches and managing the strike zone. He should have at least gap power and perhaps more once he adds some strength to his skinny 6-foot-2 frame. He has plus speed but is still figuring out how to use it on the bases and could lose a step if he adds weight.PERSON currently has the quickness to track down balls in center field and could slide over to right if he slows down as he matures physically. He has plus-plus arm strength and drew some interest as a left-handed pitcher as an amateur. He could have a mid-90s fastball if he follows in the footsteps of ORGANIZATION outfielder-turned-lefty-reliever PERSON.

Signed for $450,000 out of the ORGANIZATION in 2013, PERSON is somewhat similar to PERSON, the center-field prospect who headlined the four-prospect package the ORGANIZATION sent to the ORGANIZATION in November. PERSON hits left-handed and isn't as advanced at the same stage of his career, but he has the same type of tools (albeit with a better arm).PERSON needs to add a lot of strength to his skinny 6-foot-2 frame. That would enable him to translate his bat speed and hand-eye coordination into producing for both average and power. He currently has plus speed, though he could slow down some as he fills out.If PERSON loses a step and has to move from center to right field, his arm will be up to the task. Before he signed with GPE, he drew interest as a pitcher from some clubs.

The ORGANIZATION envisioned PERSON as a potential five-tool center fielder when they signed him for $450,000 out of the ORGANIZATION in 2013, but he batted just .241/.279/.345 in his first four pro seasons and his strikeout rate ballooned to 35 percent when he finally reached full-season ball. He always exhibited one of the strongest arms among the system's position players, so GPE decided to try the outfielder-to-lefty reliever conversion that worked well with PERSON, who made his big league debut after going to the ORGANIZATION in the PERSON trade last July. PERSON was understandably raw in his first year on the mound but improved during the course of 2018.PERSON threw 90-93 mph fastballs when he first took the mound but was sitting at 94-97 and hitting 99 at the end of the season and in instructional league. Though he's still gaining feel for his secondary pitches, he'll flash some sharp sliders in the mid-80s when he's on. His changeup is rudimentary but can leave right-handers off balance on occasion.PERSON's athleticism has helped him in his career change, as he throws a decent amount of strikes while he's still learning to keep his delivery in sync. It's still too early to know what he'll become, but his pure stuff could make him a late-inning weapon if he can develop consistency. One club official watched him work out and said it was the best bullpen session the system had seen since PERSON, who was part of the ORGANIZATION trade with the FACILITY and might have the most devastating fastball/slider combo of any current prospect.

Though PERSON oozed projection with a skinny 6-foot-3 frame and already ran his fastball into the low 90s as a 16-year-old, GPE was able to sign him for just $50,000 out of GPE in 2016. He's a long-term project who probably won't be ready for full-season ball until 2020, but he added about 5 mph to his heater in his first two years of pro ball. PERSON now operates at 92-97 mph with his fastball, which plays up because of its high spin rate and the downhill plane he creates with his size and high-three-quarters delivery. He also shows feel for spinning a curveball with some power and depth that shows flashes of becoming a plus pitch. He has some fade on his changeup and grasps the importance of using it.While PERSON has a quick arm and a clean delivery, he's still young and figuring out how to keep his mechanics in sync. He has yet to provide consistent strikes but has the ingredients for average control. Given his upside, the ORGANIZATION are willing to be patient with his development.

It can take years to evaluate who won a trade and sometimes it's the player who is the farthest away from the big leagues who creates the biggest tip in the scales. The ORGANIZATION hope that's the case with PERSON, one of the three prospects they got from the Nationals in the ORGANIZATION trade. Signed in July 2017 for $100,000, the teenager had pitched just once in the ORGANIZATION before he was traded, then came to the GPE and fared well in the rookie-level ORGANIZATION while making his ORGANIZATION organization debut.Strong and stocky, PERSON stands out for his quick arm and what could eventually be consistent premium velocity. He dominated at times in the ORGANIZATION with a fastball that was up to 94-96 mph at times and a slider, thrown 83-84 mph, that flashes plus at times. He shows a very advanced feel for his changeup, especially given his age. PERSON's delivery can be a bit too upright and he's worked with the ORGANIZATION to change that for long-term health. With a little recoil at times, he doesn't always allow himself to finish the way he should, another area of focus.PERSON doesn't have much track record as of yet, but could start being recognized as the prize of this trade this season as he truly begins his pro career in earnest, spending nearly all of the 2019 season at age 18. It should shock no one if he makes a large leap up this list sooner rather than later.

PERSON broke into GPE's top league as an 18-year-old and played three seasons before defecting in 2018. ORGANIZATION cleared him as a free agent this February, but he decided to wait until the 2019-20 signing period before joining the FACILITY for a $2.5 million bonus. He immediately became the best shortstop prospect in GPE's system.A former teammate of top FACILITY prospect PERSON on GPE's 18-and-under team, PERSON stands out most with his defense. He has smooth actions, quick feet and hands and solid arm strength. Some scouts believe he's ready to play shortstop in the big leagues immediately. There's less conviction about PERSON's bat. A right-handed hitter with a contact-oriented approach, he showed promising bat-to-ball skills but made little offensive impact during his time in GPE. The hope is that he'll get on base enough to take advantage of his solid to plus speed while developing enough pop to make pitchers respect him.

The son of former GPE national team outfielder PERSON, PERSON was born in GPE and moved to GPE as a 5-year-old. He improved his 2019 Draft stock by playing well at the World Wood Bat Association World Championship in October of his senior year, then showing improved strength during the spring. The GPE selected him in the second round and signed him for $1,000,001 as the 63rd overall pick.One of the best defensive shortstops in the 2019 crop, PERSON has the tools to make all the plays and win ORGANIZATION. He has a quick first step, reliable hands and an arm that earns well above-average grades from some scouts. He also has good instincts in the field and has drawn comparisons to PERSON PERSON.As with PERSON, PERSON is much more advanced with the glove than the bat. A switch-hitter, he makes consistent contact but will have to continue to add muscle and prove he can drive the ball. Though he clocks fringy to average running times out of the batter's box, he's quicker than that once he gets going and shows some aptitude for stealing bases.

The ORGANIZATION spent more than five times their international bonus allotment for 2015, landing players such as catcher PERSON and shortstop PERSON, but also leaving them restricted to handing out bonuses no greater than $300,000 in the next two signing periods. Based on early returns, the best from their 2016 crop is PERSON, who signed for $60,000 out of the ORGANIZATION. He easily handled the Rookie-level PERSON in his 2018 GPE debut and finished the summer with five scoreless innings at short-season GPE, though he missed the start of 2019 short-season play with a mild case of tendinitis.PERSON has the makings of a legitimate three-pitch repertoire, beginning with a sinker that sits at 90-93 mph, touches 95 and helped him produce a 1.3 groundout/airout ratio last season. He has feel for spinning that ball and already shows flashes of a plus slider. His changeup is advanced as well and helps him shut down left-handers.PERSON has an easy delivery and repeats it well. That gives him better control and command than most teenagers, adding to a possible mid-rotation starter profile. He has one of the highest ceilings among GPE's starting pitcher prospects and one of the higher floors as well despite his youth.

PERSON began his career with the ORGANIZATION after signing for $1.9 million in July 2016. After one year in the organization, he was declared a free agent in the wake of the ORGANIZATION' international signing violations and the ORGANIZATION signed him just a few weeks later for $2.5 million. He had a solid organizational debut in 2018 in the rookie-level GPE, getting a chance to join full-season PERSON during their ORGANIZATION playoff run to close out his season.While PERSON's numbers look better facing right-handed pitching thus far, the ORGANIZATION think the switch-hitter's right-handed swing is underrated and should catch up in time. He's still figuring things out at the plate and needs to refine his approach and pitch recognition, which should allow him to tap into surprising raw power. Right now, PERSON is an average runner, but speed isn't a part of his game.One thing that's unclear is where PERSON will play defensively long-term. He patterns his game after PERSON, including wanting to play second base. The ORGANIZATION think he has the hands and arm to handle shortstop, and he did see some time on the left side of the infield in 2018. That should continue for the time being, with the ORGANIZATION knowing that if he slows down more as he matures, he profiles well at GPE's spot.

PERSON signed with the ORGANIZATION in 2016, when he was ORGANIZATION's No. 26 prospect on the Ttop 30 ORGANIZATION list, for $1.9 million. He had a solid pro debut, which saw him get pushed stateside to the ORGANIZATION, but then was made a free agent as part of the penalty levied against the ORGANIZATION for violation of baseball's rules on signing international amateur free agents. The ORGANIZATION swooped in and signed PERSON for $2.5 million.The ORGANIZATION moved PERSON to second base immediately upon the start of his career, and the ORGANIZATION have largely left him there, even though they feel his above-average arm and good hands could play at short.There is a long way to go before the ORGANIZATION know exactly which kind of player PERSON ends up being. Either way, the organization feels it's added a dynamic offensive performer who will play up the middle defensively.

Because of the hacking scandal, the ORGANIZATION didn't pick in the 2017 GPE until the third round. As a result, they had a very small bonus pool to deal with. They did go over pick value to get PERSON, a talented high school catcher from GPE, who was signed away from the ORGANIZATION World Series champion PERSON, is the hottest of commodities: a left-handed-hitting catcher. PERSON really liked his bat heading into the GPE, as he is capable of making loud contact from the left side, albeit with some swing and miss. There is confidence he'll hit enough to tap into his raw power, his best tool. There are more questions about his work behind the plate. He does show off a strong arm, flashing plus at times, but he's not overly agile and he'll need work to bring his other defensive skills up to speed.Developing high school catching is always tough, with patience needed to allow the player to learn on both sides of the ball. PERSON does have the ability to eventually become an offensive-minded backstop with a power bat and arm.

As a freshman, PERSON was PERSON's most dangerous hitter in the postseason, homering five times in 12 games as the ORGANIZATION made it to the 2017 College World Series finals. He hasn't shown quite the same power since but has posted identical stat lines in each of his three years of college while impressing with his speed and defense. After dropping to the ORGANIZATION in the 40th round amid signability concerns as a sophomore-eligible, he signed with the ORGANIZATION for slot value after they took him in the third round of the 2019 Draft. PERSON's best pure tool is his well above-average speed. His quickness and instincts allow him to steal bases and chase down balls all over center field, where he has a playable if fringy arm. His defensive ability is reminiscent of that of former ORGANIZATION star PERSON, who has seen big league time with the Nationals.PERSON's offensive game draws more mixed reviews from scouts. He has surprising bat speed and sneaky power for a speedster who's not physically imposing, though he gets caught up swinging for the fences too often. He'll need to make some adjustments to his right-handed stroke and improve his pitch recognition and plate discipline to handle more advanced pitching.

PERSON was as talented as any high school left-hander in the GPE in 2016, which could have landed him in the top five rounds, but concerns about his shoulder and his commitment to PERSON caused the GPE prepster to slide to the ORGANIZATION in the 11th. He still would have landed a well over-slot bonus from PERSON if he hadn't failed a post-GPE physical, and more medical questions arose when he missed two months as a sophomore with an elbow injury that didn't require surgery. He stayed healthy and did a much better job of throwing strikes in 2019, racking up 130 strikeouts against 34 walks while posting a 2.40 ERA. The ORGANIZATION took him with their first-round pick (ORGANIZATION. 19 overall) in June, making PERSON the highest-drafted pitcher ever from the ORGANIZATION program. As a southpaw with a strong frame and four pitches, PERSON has the ingredients to become a mid-rotation starter. Both his fastball, which sits in the low 90s and tops out at 96 mph with some run and angle, and his low-80s slider are plus pitches at their best. He generates good spin rates on both his slider and curveball, which has more depth than power, and also mixes in a decent changeup.Some clubs still had concerns about PERSON's health history leading up to the GPE. The ORGANIZATION weren't one of them, with the club pointing to his modest college workload as the primary reason, and noting that PERSON did his part to assuage any concerns by not missing a start while working deeper into games as a junior.
